title: 0-2-Introduction
summary: Prefatory note to Operations Handbook explaining its purpose as reference guide for directors, officers, committee members, staff, and volunteers. COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND


Operations Handbook




















INTRODUCTION







The
Operations Handbook brings together a number of key documents that
determine the nature and operation of the Community Foundation of
Prince Edward Island.  Documents include key decisions made and by
the Board from time to time.






This
volume is very much a work in progress.  Although all documents have
had board approval, some may have been amended over the years.  The
plan is update all and seek new approvals.  In the meantime, changes
to documents in this book will be made by the Secretary.






In
determining what the Foundation can and cannot do, the following

title: 0 Contents
summary:
(100-200 words):**
Primary table of contents for About Education binder, structured thematically rather than alphabetically. Organized into seven major sections: (1) Introduction and Background; (2) Community (comprising make-up, life roles, education interests, numbers, clarity, definitions, meaning, learners and learning, learning paths, functions, and education services); (3) Government (role of Department, organization); (4) Purpose/mission and key operating beliefs; (5) Structure and accountabilities; (6) Key Issues (access, education vs schooling, teaching model, instruction, collaboration/silos, content/curriculum, school); (7) Appendices (definitions, reading lists). Structure reveals Don's systems thinking approach: analyzing education within nested contexts (community, government, organizational structure) with emphasis on purpose-driven reform and addressing critical systemic issues.

title: 00 A Personal Framework-1@2015-03-13T18;20;20
summary: Don's foundational framework document for his "About Education" project, an evolving draft presenting his personal philosophy on education in an era of change. The document references 140,000 Islanders and establishes the context for his comprehensive educational thinking developed over decades of institutional leadership and consulting work.
content_preview:
About,
00

March
10, 2015

About
Education

A
Personal Framework for change

(An
evolving draft)






Background:

Some
140,000 Islanders  are  currently travelling life’s road, a road of
varying lengths and for most, a road with many twists and turns.
While on that road, each engages in a number of life roles including
that of an individual, family member, learner, citizen, consumer and
producer.  The preparation for life’s roles is called education and
the better prepared we are, the better we are able to cope with all
that we encounter or create.  That learning is complicated by the
fact that each
person is unique; unique in our basic physical, mental, emotional and
social make up, unique in our combination of previous experiences,
unique in our perceived futures for ourselves, but unique also in
terms of our pace and style of learning. Our education consists of
what we have learned or perhaps, what we have retained from our
learning experiences, or even what we are able to do as a result of
what we have learned






It is widely recognized that education
is a key factor in determining each citizen’s quality of life; in
the same way, the collective education of our citizens will determine
to a significant degree the quality of the community in which we
live.  Recognizing all of the above, our communities invest heavily
in programs and facilities; the state has two interests.  One is to
encourage and support a high level of personal growth and development
for every citizen; the other is to ensure that our communities have
the skills needed to provide a quality of life that our citizens need
and expect. 







There is a gap between what Islanders
have and what they want in the way of education.  This gap, the
writer believes, arises primarily from our sloppiness with the
language.  Let me explain.  Educators and the public at large tend to
use schooling and educationa interchangeablyThey do not do so with
agriculture and farming, health and hospitals, justice a...

content_preview:
_____________________________________________________________________________








For immediate release














Literacy
for the 21st
century


Islanders
will have a chance to learn about literacy training for adults at a
presentation and discussion Stratford Town Hall on Wednesday,
September 14, 2016 at 9:00 am.  
 The session will deal with services available, what more needs to be
done, and, generally, why literacy is important to the future success
of PEI.  The presentation will provide information on where PEI
students stand compared to the rest of Canada, and, in particular, to
the other Atlantic Provinces.  



It
is widely recognized that boosting our education levels would boost
the Island economy.  The
matter of preparedness for the workplace
was identified as an issue by The Community Foundation of Prince
Edward Island (CFPEI) in its survey of Island youth in late 2013. 
According
to the Conference Board of Canada, education drives success yet some
40 percent of our adult workforce lacks education skills needed for a
modern economy.  Responsibility
for literacy training in PEI is shared; the Department of Education,
Early Learning and Culture serves young people still in school and
the
Department
of Workforce and Advanced Learning.
serves out of school youth and adults.  



The
workshop
is being is being organized by Education 20/20 and

Education: Let’s make it personal 




We are all educated

Educated is  the result of experiences 

The experiences that shape us

Its partly the result of what we did to ourselves and what others did to and for us

it’s personal

No one can learn for us




Education is something that happens




Three domains

Attitudes

Skills

Knowledge




The uniqueness of  each person

Education is most important issue of the day

Learners centered delivery

Education – intended to help us on the road of life

title: 01  Standards - the current challenge
summary: Don reflects on his leadership journey at Holland College with forty-year perspective. Upon founding Holland College in 1969, he identified institutional flexibility as education's most pressing issue, addressing how educational systems had locked themselves into teaching models failing to reflect learning science. He describes Holland College's adoption and development of the DACUM model from Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation, valuing its learner-centered approach, relevant competencies, community interaction, cost-effectiveness, performance-based rating, continuing education tools, learner-teacher communication, and flexibility. Writing forty years later, Don identifies exit standards as the urgent contemporary challenge—a gap between public expectations and system delivery. He cites Martin Haberman's research on the non-academic gap between school and employment. Don emphasizes the need for performance-based standards with clear exit outcomes, well-defined performance level descriptions, and recognized benchmarks, noting progress but indicating work remains.
content_preview:
SCHOOL STANDARDS – 101




Today’s challenge 




In 1969, when I became President of the newly-established Holland College, I believed that the most pressing issue in education was that of institutional flexibility.  It was my view that educational institutions at all levels had locked themselves into a system of teaching that failed to reflect what we know about learners and learning.  Education systems were bureaucratic, rigid, delivery-centered and time based.  




Given a new institution, a young Board of Governors and freedom to act, the College sought out, adopted and further developed a delivery model incorporating a set of beliefs about learning and teaching, program development, evaluation and the role of the learner in the process.




Our search for a model took us to a number of colleges in Canada and the USA, to Project Poet then operating at a military base in Kingston, Ontario, the TERC model being developed  at the Technical Education Research Centre in Cambridge Massachusetts; a competency based project in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area outside New York City, and finally to the Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation in Yarmouth Nova Scotia where we saw the DACUM model under development.  What we saw in Yarmouth came closest to what we were looking for. We adopted that model because it was learner centered,  ensured that competencies were relevant, maximized interaction with the employing community, was cost effective, included a performance based rating scale, provided learners with a tool to aid in planning and recording continuing education, strengthened learner-teacher communication and met our need for flexibility.  




Forty years later, I am of the view that the most pressing issue in education today is that of exit standards.  A gap exists between what the public expects and what system delivers.  The promise of Outcomes Based Education has been replaced with the reality of curriculum objectives. 




The non-academic gap between school and employm...

title: 02 Abstract
summary: Abstract of Don's manuscript on DACUM methodology, tracing its Canadian origins in the 1960s NewStart Corporations and its evolution into an internationally recognized competency-based education framework. Positions DACUM as significant Canadian contribution to education philosophy.
content_preview:
ABSTRACT




DACUM is an acronym for either Developing A CUrriculuM or Designing A CUrriculuM.  It is a Canadian term and a Canadian development.  The acronym is well-known in competency based education and curriculum development.  Its impact is international.  DACUM is widely practised, highly respected and easily identified.  Surprisingly, however, we know little of its origin.  Although coined only 25 years ago, the origin and development trail in Canada are somewhat obscure.   




During the 1960's, federal and provincial governments provided massive funding to establish and expand vocational training facilities and programs.  During this period a number of centres, NewStart Corporations, were established to demonstrate new and innovative ways of assisting communities with their social and economic development.




Within the framework of the NewStart Corporations considerable attention was focused on innovative approaches to training as a component of individual and community development.  Out of the NewStart activity came the concept of DACUM.




There are three common views of what constitutes DACUM, namely (1) a way of presenting curriculum, (2) a performance based analysis of a field or occupation, and (3) a model for developing and delivering competency based education.  The first and second views have been implemented widely.  The latter, full implementation, is not widely practised.  Most users of DACUM share one major characteristic - the entire analysis is presented in a single sheet visual format.




As a result of the review involved in preparing this document, the writer is satisfied that DACUM can easily be recognized as a significant Canadian contribution to education, especially the philosophy of education that builds a system on a foundation of competencies, outcomes or results.

title: 02 CONTENTS
summary: The table of contents for the Literacy 20/20 project, revealing the comprehensive scope of Don's literacy initiative. The project includes major sections on reading (discussion paper, proposals, modest proposal, intervention points, assessment criteria, skills/competencies, PEI Grade 4 reading standard, benchmarks, rating scale, and statistics), literacy (discussion paper, proposals, roundtable, statistics, and providers), essential skills, and general information (glossary, funding sources, contacts, project guidelines). This structure demonstrates Don's systematic approach to educational development, applying his expertise in standards, assessment, and competency-based frameworks to the literacy domain. The presence of provincial standards references (PEI Grade 4) suggests institutional collaboration and intended application to public education systems.

title: 02 Elections
summary: The May 10, 2013 second issue of Open Education addresses school board elections as an educational issue central to student learning. Don argues that student achievement improves when families, schools, and communities collaborate, citing National Parent Teacher Association research. He advocates for local decision-making authority for trustees, contending that low voter turnout reflects perceived lack of trustee power rather than community disinterest. The newsletter thanks Gaylene Smith for her account of teaching at College of the North Atlantic in Qatar and discusses debates over voting age and student board representation in British Columbia and PEI. This issue exemplifies Don's civic engagement advocacy and belief in democratic participation's role in educational improvement.

Board

The

	learning;  in fact, the impact on student learning should be the

People
	are concerned about the quality of education and want a greater

Some

title: 02 Personal framework
summary: Extensive 2016 document presenting Don's comprehensive personal educational philosophy evolved over years of professional experience. Addresses education as most important societal issue and spans multiple sections: quality education characteristics (accessible, affordable, flexible, relevant, accountable, transparent), systemic gaps (lacks philosophy, suffers from politicization/bureaucracy), barriers to change, organizational problems (top-down, formula-driven, out of touch with clients), and proposed solutions. Includes Don's core beliefs about learner-centered delivery, distinguishing education from schooling, mathematics as prerequisite for opportunity, and need for external qualification authorities. Proposes priority changes from simple (exemptions/challenge for credit) to structural (depoliticizing education, establishing independent assessment bodies). Major theme: education system is production-oriented rather than development-oriented and requires fundamental restructuring.

title: 02 The Incubator
summary: Don conceptualizes schools as incubators preparing young people for adult life roles. Drawing from the Oregon Education Act's six life roles (individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member, citizen), he argues all people benefit at some point from instructional support. He identifies the fundamental challenge: while schools fill important roles, society hasn't clearly expressed expectations about their function. Don contrasts business models (investment/consumer purchase) with education, which involves overlapping stakeholder interests (learners, service providers, investors, employers). He identifies a critical gap: educators measure quality by inputs (subjects, schooling years, institutions, instructor qualifications, technology, test scores) while taxpayers and employers judge by outputs—what graduates can do. Schools measure input and infer performance; the public rates performance directly. Don argues little progress in raising standards will occur until these conflicting measurement frameworks are reconciled, requiring dialogue that aligns training program content with community standards.
content_preview:
SCHOOLS AS INCUBATORS 







In my earlier item, I identified exit standards as the urgent issue of the day.  I say this because of the frequency with which the subject arises in the media and in private discussions; the school system is usually blamed.  Schools, colleges, universities and professional and certification bodies “raise” their standards but complaints continue.  A gap exists between public expectations and what the system delivers; perhaps it always will.    




We fill many life roles in the course of a life time.  The Oregon Education Act of 1991 identified the following six: individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member and citizen.  The relative importance of each role varies from individual to individual and will change over time.    People will move into some roles without formal schooling but it is generally recognized that, at some point in our lives and for a varying length of time, all can benefit from help in the form of instruction, advice, coaching, information, counseling and practice.  The amount of help needed varies from individual to individual; that is one of the complications of teaching.  But the ability of each learner to function in society is the final test of the school system




Schools are incubators in that they prepare young people for life in the adult world; they help people in their most formative years to develop skills needed in their adult lives.  Schools offer a safe and controlled environment to experiment, to try new things, even to fail.  Society has placed few restrictions on what schools can or should do but neither has it described well its expectations.




Schools do not operate on the normal business model in which a person or a company invests in a product or service and a consumer or client purchases the product or service.  In the case of education, there are at least three sets of stakeholders and their interests overlap.  It is not always clear just who is the customer?  the learner?  the se...

Develop a

Although much has been written about education, Prince Edward Island

Reinstate
	exemptions 
	









Organized education lacks incentives to improve educational products
and services.  Where awards exist, they focus on individual student
achievement rather than improving the education process, and it is
the latter issue that is most pressing at this time. At a minimum we
need a better balance, a focus on improving the system for all versus
rewarding the few.  Exemptions, one low-cost
incentive available at Colonel Grey High School, was cancelled
in 2012 with a vague reference, at least in the press, to some new
scheme under development; Islanders are still waiting.  As a minimum,
exemptions should be reinstated then expanded at least to the extent
available in other Provinces.

	self-study and tutoring



Most public education is focused on instruction;
virtually absent is support for self-study, practice, self-

If we want life long learners, we need to encourage it

title: 03 Teachers as Change Agents
summary: Don defines teaching fundamentally as helping others change across cognitive, affective, and psychomotor domains. Teachers shape lives and help learners develop new attitudes, skills, and knowledge. Don emphasizes learning is individual—only the learner can learn—and teaching creates change conditions. He reiterates his core principle: "A teacher hasn't taught if a learner hasn't learned," applied to each learner. Teachers stimulate learning through varied techniques: modeling, information provision, questioning, timelines, projects, field trips, and performance assessment. The crux of good teaching is creating favorable learning environments for each individual within group settings. Don notes schools organize around academic disciplines with assigned hours and teachers hired accordingly, resulting in report cards with subject ratings disconnected from life roles except future academic study. The essay implies this structure inadequately prepares learners for their actual future roles as individuals, learners, producers, consumers, family members, and citizens. The essay suggests a fundamental need to align schooling structures with adult life role preparation.
content_preview:
Teachers as Change Agents







To learn is to change; to teach is to help others change.  In educational jargon, changes may be in the cognitive, affective or psychomotor domains.  More simply put, a person who has learned has new attitudes, skills or information or some combination thereof.  




Schools, or at least teachers in schools, help shape lives; they cause and help learners to change behaviour ; under their tutelage, learners gain new and expanded attitudes, skills and knowledge.  The output of schools for each learner is the growth that occurs between entering and leaving the school system – growth attributable to the efforts of teachers.  The clearer we specify the desired exit performance, the more likely learners are to achieve it.  The better we describe the difference schools make, the more likely we are to meet our community’s faith in us and their expectation of returns on their investment.  







Learning is an individual matter.  Only the learner can learn.  To help a learner to learn is to help bring about changes in the learner.  The stimulus for learning may be internal or external and the actual learning may take place in a group setting or when the individual is alone.  A teacher does not teach a class; a teacher teaches a number of individuals at the same time in a group setting.  




Readers have likely heard the statement “A teacher hasn’t taught if a learner hasn’t learned”.  That statement always brought vigorous discussion in my classes.  I believe that to be true but it must be applied to each learner.  A learner has learned only if there is a change of behaviour.  




The role of a teacher is to stimulate learning – to create a set of circumstances so that a learner learns the desired behaviour.  Teachers need a variety of techniques in their tool chest – and they will likely require all of them.  Tools include setting an example, providing information, asking questions, setting time lines, assigning projects or home work, org...

title: 04 Barriers to educational reform
summary: Don identifies three overlooked barriers to educational reform: employer recruitment practices that contradict their stated need for employability skills, professional certification requirements locked into traditional course offerings, and rigid college/university entrance requirements. He argues employers should lead by basing hiring on competencies rather than credentials; professionals should base designations on performance not time served; and post-secondary institutions should relax course rigidity. He ends optimistically: with ministerial directives, reform could advance through hiring and promotion based on competencies rather than credentials.
content_preview:
Barriers to educational reform




The clamor for educational reform, like the sounds of the holiday season, is all around us.  It’s exciting and full of promise.  Through educational reform we can right all wrongs, develop a highly skilled labor force, compete internationally, rescue drop-outs, improve the standards of education, reduce numbers on UI and welfare, reduce annual deficit and many other good things.

Now don’t get me wrong; I’m all for educational reform.  Every endeavor requires periodic assessment to review and restate goals and objectives, to realign organizational structures, to provide a new sense of coherence to its activities.  Education is no exception.

Current educational reforms include reducing the number of school boards, centralizing hiring and purchasing practices, cutting down on the number of non-school based administrators, introducing outcomes-based education, contracting some services now provided by people on the educational payroll, hiring new (and less expensive) staff, and delivering instruction using the latest technology.  And the list goes on, and on, and on.

But change doesn’t come easy.  There are all kinds of reasons why changes are delayed, not implemented, or get sidetracked.  Each of us could prepare our own list of reasons and there would be considerable overlay.  Most lists would include such things as inertia in the system, tradition, the system does not require changing, lack of political will, too many aging administrators, lack of leadership, outmoded teacher education programs, insufficient funding, poor motivation by students, lack of parental support, teacher unions and loss of control to the professionals.  And this list could also go on.

But there are other barriers which are seldom, if ever, mentioned.  These include recruitment practices of employers, certification and licensing regulations and entrance requirements to universities and colleges.  The remainder of my column will be devoted to these three a...

title: 04 Introduction
summary: Don's introduction to DACUM Achievement manuscript, establishing DACUM as Canadian development with international impact. Argues the methodology deserves telling as historical record and practical tool for improving accountability, relevance, and outcomes-based education.
content_preview:
INTRODUCTION




DACUM is Canadian; the termed was coined in Toronto?, the model was developed in Nova Scotia and applied in Prince Edward Island from where it has spread around the world.  DACUM is a major Canadian success story but, like so many other Canadian developments, it gets little recognition, support of application in Canada.







The fact that DACUM is a Canadian development that has found international acceptance and acclaim is a sufficient reason itself for its telling.  In addition, however, the arrival of DACUM on the scene provided a highly credible yet inexpensive tool to identify desirable learning outcomes.  Nothing has emerged to equal or replace it.  But the story deserves telling for another reason in that, if adopted or even allowed in the school system at large, it could improve accountability, relevance, flexibility, and support outcomes based and learner centred education that the system espouses.




Full credit for the DACUM model described in this book goes to Robert Adams and the Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation, Yarmouth, Nova Scotia.  The writer has tried to be faithful to the model in the pages which follow.  Readers are encouraged, however, to read the original report if a copy can be found. Nevertheless, the writer is aware of modifications which have been made, but a description of any modifications is not part of this book.













This document is neither a description of how to develop and use a DACUM chart nor the full DACUM methodology.  Neither does it describe in any detail the DACUM model of program development and student management.  It is an historical document intended primarily to trace the evolutionary thread of DACUM during its early and formative years.  The heart of the document is a Chart (Figure 1) which attempts to show the sequence in which the early players became involved.  It also should deals with the two branches of DACUM in Canada during its first decade.




The paper limits itself to a period o...

title: 04 Learning path
summary: Interim report describing development of a learning path model based on consultation with young people about helpful learning supports. Identifies five learning path components: entry point, exploration (information gathering, observation, assessment, counselling), engagement in teaching-learning process (instruction, self-study, practice, feedback), documentation (credentials/qualifications), and exit point. Demonstrates that learners cycle through process differently based on individual style and pace, supporting spiral or learner-centered curriculum approach. Emphasizes that learning is broad concept encompassing all experience, not just schooling. Notes learning path remains work in progress open to continued development and input.

About

Learning
Path


An
interim report


Occasional Paper No.4

The development of a learning path grew out of the belief that
learning is a process, that the steps that learners take can be
identified and charted, and that a clear understanding of the
learning process and path is important for teachers and parents
alike.








The process started when Education 20/20 invited a panel of young
people to identify the kinds of support they found most helpful when
learning.  Not surprising, a long list of ideas emerged with the
following being chief among them: gather
information, analyze experiences, obtain feedback, take instruction,
evaluate selves, coach others, practice, observe others, attend
lectures, seek counselling and observe demonstrations. When asked
about the order in which help was needed, not surprisingly,
students followed quite different paths.  As an example, one student
said his first step would be to Google the topic; another said if it
involved a new skill, he would probably attempt it first, while
others liked the traditional lecture as a place to start.  Since
panel members were in school or recent graduates, much of the
discussion revolved around gaining new knowledge rather than skills
or attitudes.  Different purposes for learning did not substantially
change the range of help needed, although it may change the order and
the amount of time on the path. Since then, the Learning Path has
been the subject of a number of both formal and informal
consultations.  The latest version can be found on the reverse side
of this paper. It should be noted that learning is used in the
broadest sense and is not just schooling.  









The path has five identifiable components:

	


	A point of entry. 
	
	


	Exploration during which the student gathers information, observes
	others, undertakes assessment, seeks counselling and may even
	attempt th...

title: 04-OBE
summary: The June 15, 2013 fourth issue provides Don Glendenning's guest editorial on Outcomes-Based Education (OBE), a student-centered, results-oriented approach founded by sociologist William Spady. Don explains OBE's premise that all individuals can learn, with outcomes written for traditional, transitional, or transformational goals. He details learner-centered principles: clear identification of learning goals, progress based on demonstrated achievement, accommodation of individual needs through varied instructional strategies, and provision of time and assistance for students to reach potential. The newsletter also covers skill training reforms in Britain, year-round schooling innovations in Holland, and Project HIPPY. Don's thoughtful explanation of OBE reflects his engagement with contemporary educational research and commitment to student-centered pedagogy.

title: 05 FOREWORD
summary: Foreword by Lawrence Coffin recommending the DACUM competency-based education model booklet. Emphasizes that Coffin worked with DACUM for 25 years at Holland College and beyond, positioning it as proven methodology for vocational education. Provides context for Don's pioneering role in implementing this transformative educational approach institution-wide.
content_preview:
FOREWORD




Competency based education and training has moved from the concept to the implementation stage. Many schools, colleges, business and industry training departments are using or have adopted competency based training techniques.




One approach being used to deliver competency based training is the DACUM model. This model is not new; its initial development began in the mid 60's. What is new is the move away from traditional education to competency or outcomes based education. The DACUM model is being adopted by training institutions and industrial training departments on a world wide basis.




The need for information on how the DACUM model works is acute. This re-presentation of the DACUM model may be timely and will provide educators and trainers with information on developing and implementing a competency based education system.




As one who has worked with the DACUM model at Holland College and elsewhere for 25 years, it is a privilege to recommend the reading of this booklet.  It should assist educators and trainers in the development and delivery of competency based training and education.







Lawrence Coffin

Education Consultant

title: 05 fundamental skills
summary: The July 15, 2013 fifth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, explores fundamental employability skills developed by The Conference Board of Canada. Don outlines five core competency areas: communication (reading, writing, listening, sharing information using technology); information management (locating, gathering, organizing, analyzing knowledge across disciplines); numeracy (measuring, calculating, data recording); and problem-solving (assessing situations, seeking perspectives, identifying root causes, implementing and evaluating solutions). The newsletter discusses parents' frustration with curriculum outcome-based report cards and advocates for clearer parent communication. Don emphasizes that parents need specific information about learning problems to provide effective home support, and highlights the Atlantic Provinces' common outcome system available on provincial education websites. This issue demonstrates Don's commitment to accessible educational communication and parental engagement.

title: 05 Standards A Real Test
summary: A comprehensive examination of how schools should define and measure success through exit expectations. Glendenning argues that schools exist to help learners become better individuals, learners, producers, consumers, family members, and citizens. Rather than traditional discipline-based organization, he advocates for identifying key skills—particularly communication—and assessing students based on actual performance. He references Michigan's competency-based graduation requirements as a model, emphasizing outcomes like proficiency in communication, technology use, critical thinking, and personal responsibility. This document establishes the framework for competency-based assessment.
content_preview:
SCHOOL STANDARDS – 101




Exit Expectations – the Last Test




We’ve established schools as a resource for people who want to be better in the roles they will fill in adult life in their communities, that is better individuals, learners, producers, consumers, family members and citizens.  Schools provide a protective and supportive environment where learners are allowed and encouraged to improve existing skills and learn new ones.  It’s a tall order.  




Traditionally schools organize instruction around disciplines; students are required to gain credits in a variety of subjects in order to graduate from high school including language arts, mathematics, science, social studies, art, physical education and health, technology and some electives.  With aknowlede of a range of disciplines we infer that students will have the needed skills.  







An alternative, and a better way, is to identify key skills and, based on performance, to infer that they rest on a sound foundation.  The ability to communicate comes quickly to mind and, in the writer’s view, is key to success in all life roles.













Schools certainly can provide such help but schools cannot be everything to everybody.  Choices will be required.







The State of Michigan, on the other hand, states their high school graduation requirements as (State of Michigan on August 22, 1990):

 

Students will be proficient in listening, speaking, reading, writing, mathematics, and the use of technology. 

Students will apply knowledge, concepts, and processes acquired through the study of the arts, sciences, and social sciences. 

Students will demonstrate a healthy self-esteem. 

Students will select and use thinking skills, individually and in groups, to solve problems and to make decisions. 

Students will be able to find, evaluate and use information. 

Students will demonstrate respect and co-operation within a community of individual and cultural differences. 

Students will demonstrate personal, s...

title: 06 Principles
summary: A foundational document outlining thirteen guiding principles for educational reform. Key principles include: education's role is coaching and support; learning is demonstrated through doing; testing serves diagnosis and measurement; standards must be clearly defined and life-based rather than discipline-based; learners should challenge for credit anytime; assessment reflects performance only; and previous learning receives credit. These principles reveal Don's learner-centered, pragmatic approach emphasizing flexibility, clear communication, and practical demonstration over traditional institutional hierarchies.
content_preview:
Some Guiding Principles




Role of education is provide assistance to learners – coaching, demonstrations, practice, information, counsel, advice, direction, explanation and 

We demonstrate learning through doing

Testing is an important part of the education process – diagnose weaknesses, measure performance, establish levels, basis for learning plans

Sorting learners is not an educational responsibility

Standard must be clearly defined and be available to all stakeholders

Standards shall be life based not discipline based – life roles, identified by people from community

Learners should be able to challenge for credit any time

A student’s level will be determined only on performance

Credit will be given for previous learning

Testing for learning is an integral part of the learning process

Standards in the sense of a technical specification and standard as an approach to testing, and standard definition, standards for data exchange, labour mobility, coordination

title: 07 CHOICE AS AN AGENT OF CHANGE
summary: Written from Panama City Beach, Florida in February 2005, Don advocates school choice as an educational reform mechanism. He notes that consumers choose churches, doctors, lawyers, and mayors but have limited school choice and no teacher choice. He argues choice increases product range, competitive pricing, and service quality—principles applicable to education. Don proposes four intervention points: school choice, teacher choice, flexible study time (including part-time and summer), and exams on demand rather than schedule. He emphasizes that choice empowers learners and increases accountability while removing excuses for non-performance.
content_preview:
CHOICE AS AN AGENT OF CHANGE







I’m writing this from Panama City Beach, Florida.  The topic arises from an item in this morning’s paper - a half-page advertisement by the Bay County School Authority, which read in part as follows:




Where do you want your child to attend school?

School Choice

Open enrolment will be held February 1-28,2005




The advertisement goes on to say that the following must complete a “School Choice Selection Card”:

Parents of children entering kindergarten, 6th and 9th grade

Parents of children wishing to change schools

Parents of children new to the area




I thought back to when our children were young and we were purchasing a home; our choices were limited in part because we had to send our children to the nearest school.  Where we lived and where our children went to school should be separate decisions.  I understand that learners today have some choice as to where they attend school and are not as restricted to the schools nearest where they live.  Canadian and US newspapers have been carrying articles on the results in the recent OECD international testing program, and the need to do better.   In the context of that debate, I suggest that we consider increased choice as an agent of change in the educational system.




Freedom to choose is an important right; at the highest level, we favour a system of government that provides a large degree of choice ay the governed as to who will govern – not a perfect system but a good system. 




Significant consumer choice, I believe, has a positive effect on suppliers of products and services – and education is a service.  In the retail trade, for example, choice increases the range of products and services available, introduces more competitive pricing, lowers costs and improves service.  Stop and think for a moment, we can choose our church, dentist, lawyer, mechanic, mayor, retail outlet and doctor but we have limited choice of schools our children attend and no choice in their ...

title: 07 Components
summary: A technical but accessible exposition of the four components comprising a true educational standard: competencies (observable, measurable, community-drawn actions people can perform); criteria (quality measures like consistency, speed, safety); levels of performance (distinguishing how well someone performs, not just whether they can); and benchmarks (community-based reference points anchoring performance levels to real-world contexts). Glendenning critiques the vagueness in existing educational standards and provides his own "Glendenning version," arguing that effective standards must integrate all four components. He uses practical examples like editing or driving to illustrate how performance levels vary independently from basic competence.
content_preview:
STANDARDS




Should note be two standards school and community or employment




Everyone seems to have a favourite story about school standards.  Most seem to involve reading, writing, geography, Canadian History and work habits. It has ever been thus; criticisms go back at least to the time of the Greeks but that is not to say that the issue should be ignored.  




Old timers seem to think that school standards have deteriorated.    Based on some of my old exam papers that I came across recently, I think that my children were more advanced in their school studies than I was at that stage of schooling,  Maybe; I really don’t know.  The reason I am not sure is that, to my way of thinking, educational standards have never been well defined.




For the purpose of this article::

The terms outcome and competency interchangeably

I distinguish between testing for the purpose awarding improving learning from testing for the purpose of granting recognition.

I have focused on the public school system although much of what I say applies to postsecondary education as well.

Since school systems profess to be outcome based, this article will focus on outcomes or competency based education.




Although I have browsed many a bulletin from Departments of Education, I have not found a satisfactory description of what constitutes a standard – at least not one satisfactory to me. So, hers is the Glendenning version.  By educational standard I refer to the level of performance required of a student in order to receive recognition.  




An educational standard includes four components:




Competencies 




We demonstrate what we have learned by what we can do.  Statements of what we are able to do are known as competencies.  Competencies:

.

Describe an observable action

Drawn from the community being served 

Are attainable

Are measurable

Be stated in clear 
















2	Criteria




Criteria are the unadorned measures used to assess a person’s performance on a compe...

title: 07 Helping someone learn
summary: The September 19, 2013 seventh issue, edited by Don Glendenning, presents practical guidance on supporting learners. Don draws parallels between parental health support and educational support, arguing that intentional engagement in learning builds lifelong habits. He outlines concrete strategies: creating new learning opportunities, teaching new skills, providing practice opportunities, directing learners to relevant media, offering feedback, recognizing achievement, encouraging engagement, fostering dialogue about innovations, modeling active learning, promoting self-assessment, demonstrating procedures, and supporting discovery. The newsletter includes discussion of "The Secret Teacher" column's critique of data manipulation in education systems and addresses the "word gap" - research showing children from lower-income homes hear millions fewer words than affluent peers by age three. Don advocates for awareness of poverty's impact on achievement and highlights the Lena Research Foundation's digital language processor supporting parent-child interactions.

title: 08 Critical issues
summary: Don recounts a contracted report on critical secondary education issues, prepared with a former university president, school superintendent, and deputy minister. The report identified six critical issues and proposed fourteen demonstration projects addressing application of information technology, teacher preparation, accountability, school leadership, poorly served students, and linkage/coordination. Proposed pilots included alternative school models, competency-based programs, student part-time employment guidelines, and an open system allowing exam challenges without coursework. Don notes many suggestions remain valid for demonstration projects and references the Canadian Restructured School Project (CRSP) arising from this work.
content_preview:
Critical Issues in Secondary 

Education in Canada




A decade ago I was contracted to prepare a paper on critical issues in secondary education in Canada.  This became the forerunner of a major project led by the Canadian Vocational Association known as the Canadian Restructured School Plan. As part of the process, I brought together a former university president, a former superintendent of schools and a former deputy minister of education.  The result was a brief paper, some 10 to 12 pages; the paper was prepared under contract and was not published.  The ideas which follow are drawn directly from that report.




The ideas included in the paper were based on the following assumptions:




That Canada’s future economic prosperity and standard of living will be determined in a large degree by the degree to which its educational system develops the nation’s human resources, thus enabling it to compete successfully in the global economy.




That rapid technological change will continue to impact on the world of work and our secondary schools for the foreseeable future.




That secondary education should operate to serve the needs of all youth in the age bracket normally accommodated in Grades 10 through 12.




The paper then went on to identify the following issues:




Application of information technology in secondary schools

The preparation of teachers

Accountability

Leadership at the school level

Poorly served students

Linkage and coordination




The authors suggested that strategies and interventions should meet the following criteria:




Evidence, based on experience and research, that the project is likely to be successful in addressing the issues

Interventions should be possible within the financial limits of the agencies involved and should seek to maximize existing resources

Strategies should be seen as credible by educators, school boards and government

Reasonable assurance that the intervention, if successful, could easily be applied ore bro...

title: 1-01 Autonomy
summary: Detailed examination of school autonomy's relationship to student performance, citing OECD PISA research establishing the correlation between autonomy and achievement. Proposes specific autonomy measures for schools (hiring staff, setting calendars, allocating budgets) and teachers (grading decisions), with analysis of PEI's limited principal autonomy under provincial legislation and examples of innovative school models utilizing autonomy.
content_preview:
About Education

No. A-1							            		4-1-Auto

School Autonomy




Simply stated, there is a direct relationship between school performance and school autonomy.  In the words of the OECD Report, Pisa in Focus, 2011:

  
“In countries where schools have greater autonomy over what is taught and how students 


are assessed, students tend to perform better. 

  
In countries where schools account for their results by posting achievement data publicly, schools that enjoy greater autonomy in resource allocation tend to show better student performance than those with less autonomy. 
  
In countries where there are no such accountability arrangements, schools with greater autonomy in resource allocation tend to perform worse.” 


In support of the concept




Ideally, a school should have autonomy on how to resolve all learning matters as they pertain to students In practical terms, autonomy at the school level means giving each school the freedom to:

  
recruit, hire, assign and supervise any and all instructional staff whether full-time, part time, teachers, teacher aides or volunteers
  
Set their own calendar  
  
Adjust the school day
  
Allocate funds within a budget to reflect the needs and priorities of students and the community.
  
decisions about curricula and assessment, course offerings and textbooks. 





But autonomy and accountability needs to be shared with teachers as well.  Teachers should have freedom to:

  
Make decisions as to how best serve each individual
  
Assign grades at their sole discretion 





Students should have freedom to:

  
Select any school; other Provinces allow it.  
  
Challenge any course for credit


.

title: 1-3 Discussion points
summary: Talking points document from February 12, 2017 outlining key concepts for discussing proficiency levels in education. It defines proficiency as determined by two elements: what one can do and how well one can do it. The document identifies employers' inability to rely on high school grades as measures of competency and references Wolff's assessment framework. It contrasts assessment (learner-centered, interactive, formative) with evaluation (grades-focused). Includes Glendenning's core beliefs: diplomas are inadequate for proficiency indication, grades confuse age and proficiency, grading is not a school function, employment mobility requires recognized qualifications, and most developed countries have external qualification authorities. The document concludes with a proposal to develop an independent assessment service for math and communication skills proficiency.

title: 1- CMEC -Atlantic
summary: This letter (undated) addresses the Council of Ministers of Education, Canada (CMEC) regarding school-to-work transitions, disagreeing that the problem is primarily student-focused; Don attributes it to school system rigidity. He recommends surveying employers about needed competencies, consulting educators during curriculum outcomes identification, examining various curriculum development options, and switching assessment from traditional grades to externally-referenced criteria (matching school and real-life standards), as advocated by outcomes expert William Spadey. He urges CMEC to disconnect performance levels from grade levels and disconnect assessment from credentials in favor of qualifications, referencing qualification frameworks used in most developed countries.
content_preview:
Dear Editor:

Transition from school to work




The Council of Ministers of Education, Canada (CMEC) is concerned about the transition of students from school to work (CMEC, July 8, 2016); so am I, and so are many parents, grandparents and employers that I talk with.  The media release implies that it’s a student problem; I see it differently and believe that the problem stems from the rigidity of the school system.  The CMEC plans to address the transition problem through a “pan-Canadian student transitions reference framework’; I’m not sure what the phrase means but it sounds complicated, expensive and bureaucratic.  Based on the above alone, I don’t hold out much hope for improvement, however, in support of the Ministers’ efforts, here are some observations on the matter arising from my experience in education and conversations with employers.

If schools are preparing young people to enter employment, why not survey employers as to competencies that they want or need in their workforce?  Educators may also consider consultation during the identification of outcomes, representation on advisory committees, surveys of new workers and informal contact on regular basis. We need a more open curriculum development process; for example, I’ve been looking for a description of the curriculum development process, a curriculum development handbook, standard lists of outcomes and/or competencies and even plain research on the various options. So far, I’m still looking.  

The use of outcomes as a basis for curriculum development demands changes in the way we measure and report student achievement. William Spadey, an outcomes guru, refers to the need for   “externally referenced criteria” when measuring performance; that means using the same or similar criteria in school as are used outside school (in real life).  The switch from traditional assessment is not an easy one but the benefits of using outcomes cannot be realized without it.




More needs to be done to remove the...

Suffice it to say that, based on our working relationship, I have no hesitation in providing this recommendation. 




Sincerely







Don Glendenning, C.M.

title: 1-Not the Fault of Teachers
summary: An essay written March 20, 2005 (last updated December 14, 2005) in which Don defends teachers against systemic education shortcomings. He argues that public complaints about education—rigidity, lack of relevance, poor standards—are unfairly attributed to teachers when nearly half the education budget goes to non-salary items and system-level decisions constrain individual teacher autonomy. Don advocates for system-level changes from senior leadership (ministers and deputies) to empower teachers as professionals and improve educational resources available to learners.
content_preview:
First Draft: March 20, 2005

Last Update:	 TIME \@ "MMMM d, yyyy" December 14, 2005







NOT THE FAULT OF TEACHERS







It doesn’t take long in any conversation to uncover a litany of complaints about education; it is rigid, lacks relevance, has low standards, does not accommodate individual needs, is expensive, does not prepare students for advanced levels, trains followers not leaders, lacks accountability, is weak on communication skills, poor work habits, and the list goes on.  The most recent litany usually starts with the low standing of Canadian schools on recent OECD tests.  I am sitting in the USA as I write this and, for what it is worth, OECD test results are of great concern here also.




In the second breath, most complainants point to the causes as a short work year, short work days and time lost because of bad weather, holidays, teachers’ conventions and staff development and student-teacher ratio.  To these, I would add accountability, relevance, flexibility, delivery model and standards. 




We ae more comfortable talking in some depth about health care needs such as strokes, gallbladders, breast cancer and obesity than we are about vocabulary, listening skills, self-learning and work habits.  




Shortcomings of our education system are quickly laid at the feet of our teachers.   We seem to forget, or do not realize, that nearly half the education budget is spent on items other than teacher’s salaries and benefits.  In our discussions we refer to all as teachers when many educators should be more accurately labeled principals, guidance counselors, Board staff, Superintendents, Department Specialists and even the Minster or Deputy Minister not to mention the many people who provide administrative support, transportation, building maintenance, etc. While teachers may share the blame, they should not be held accountable for matters outside their control.  In the eyes of the public, all are teachers.




This assignment of blame to teachers is u...

title: 1-Proposal
summary: The grant proposal for the DACUM project submitted to Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island. Documents the historical context: post-WWII industrial expansion relying on skilled European immigrants, 1960 Technical and Vocational Training Assistance Act funding, mid-1960s Canada NewStart Corporations demonstration projects, and Robert Adams' development of the DACUM (Developing a Curriculum) competency analysis model in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia. Notes Holland College's 1970 adoption and adaptation of DACUM into the STEP model, and describes the proposed event: a commemorative gathering at Haviland Club in Charlottetown (1:00-4:00 pm) featuring DACUM panel discussion, remembrance of Robert Edwin Adams, book presentation to Holland College, and reception.
content_preview:
CANADA
150

DACUM:
A CANADIAN ACHIEVEMENT











Background:

The
decade of industrial expansion immediately after WW2 was only
possible because of the influx of skilled immigrants from Western
Europe.  By the late 1950’s it became evident that Canada could no
longer depend on this source of supply. Furthermore, large numbers of
Canadians remained unemployed even though Canada suffered from a
shortage of skilled workers.  The Technical and Vocational Training
Assistance Act (1960) provided massive funding to remedy the problem






In
the mid 1960’s, TVTA administrators joined with officials working
on the issue of high unemployment and slow economic growth  and
pooled their efforts in support of a series of demonstration
projects.  These projects, called Canada NewStart Corporations were
funded by the Federal Government but given a large degree of
independence as to their clientele and  focus of their research.






One
of the NewStart Corporations was established in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia
with Tom Jones as Director and Robert Adams as Director of
Occupational Training.  Given Adams experience in occupational and
functional analyses, it was not surprising that analysis was a
cornerstone of  programming in his projects.  The foundation of Adams
work was a competency analysis of the occupation for which training
was being provided with competencies being drawn from skilled
practitioners under the leadership of a trained facilitator.  This
resulted in a single-sheet presentation of competencies which could
be used by a variety of users.  Adams went further and outlined a
training model based on the DACUM model.  The model was adopted and
adapted to become the STEP model of Holland College effective
September 1, 1970






Purpose:
To recognize the DACUM analysis process as a Canadian achievement, to
promote the model  and to recognize Robert Edwin Adams, its
developer.

Location:
Grand Hall, Haviland Club, Charlottetown

title: 10 Context-the times
summary: Don's contextual chapter for DACUM at 40, tracing vocational training policy from WWI through 1960s federal expansion. Establishes historical background for DACUM's emergence as response to skilled worker shortages and education system evolution.
content_preview:
Context




The actual origin of DACUM can and will be pinpointed with considerable accuracy later in this book.  This chapter, however, attempts to place its origin in the context of the times.  In so doing, the author acknowledges that he was a participant, not in the early development of DACUM, but in the broader general expansion of training at the time.  This chapter attempts to identify some of the activities of the period giving rise to DACUM.




The Second World War saw Canada change from an agrarian to an industrial economy.  The decade of industrial expansion immediately following the War was possible only because of the significant influx of skilled people from Western Europe.  By the late 1950's, however, it became evident that Canada could no longer depend on this source of supply.  Furthermore, large numbers of Canadians continued to be unemployed while the economy suffered from a shortage of skilled workers.




The Government of Canada has long been interested in vocational training and in 1910 established a Royal Commission on Industrial Training and Technical Education.  Before the Royal Commission had completed its work, however, federal funding was provided under the Agricultural Aid Act of 1912 and was continued under the Agricultural Instruction Act of 1913.  The Royal Commission tabled its report in 1914; however, before the Report could be acted upon, Canada found itself engaged in WW1.at war.  Consideration of, and action on, the report was delayed.  The Technical Education Act of 1919 initiated the first broad-based program of federal support for training and federal financial support has continued ever since, except for a brief period in the early 1930's.  







Technical and Vocational Training Assistance ACT




During the 1960's, technical and vocational training programs exploded in Canada primarily as a result of leadership and massive funding by the federal government.  .  New institutes of technology were built in every Province ...

content_preview:
Is grade inflation the culprit?

According to data provided by the Harvard Business school, “Grade inflation is imperiling jobs in the manufacturing, retail, accommodation, food service, health and social assistance’, This startling statistic is found in an article by Lawrence  Lanahan on skill-based hiring.  But this is grade inflation by employers not by schools, colleges and universities.  Seems that many employers have policies calling for new workers to have degrees even though the nature of the work itself cannot support that view.  The resulting  grade inflation has a substantial upward impact on the cost of doing business. Accord one Island educator with whom I spoke with whom I spoke, the practice of requiring new employees to have a degree, whether needed or not is alive PEI as well.

Some employers, it is said, use degrees a a simple screening device; it is also thought that degrees adds prestige to the company, sometimes reflects high rates of unemployment, people wanting to remain on PEI; potential for company growth and perhaps to give priority to Islanders. Many employers associate degrees with a better level of soft  skills,

The article certainly raises questions about whether degrees aare needed or are simply a preference. As one questioner pointed, “Jobs don’t require college degrees; employers do.”

title: 100-3 Learners and Learning-paper
summary: Detailed examination of the gap between PEI educational system delivery and community expectations, identifying widespread concerns about basic skills, bureaucracy, individualized learning, and responsiveness. Distinguishes education from schooling, advocates learner-centered models with external qualification authorities, and reflects on Don's personal educational journey from rural one-room schoolhouse through his career transforming higher education in PEI.
content_preview:
100-

August 3, 2013

Learners and learning

By

Don Glendenning




Education

Education is a lifelong process of engaging in experiences that have a formative effect on the way we feel, think and act; this effect is usually expressed in terms of a person’s attitudes, skills and knowledge.  Major contributors to one’s education include one’s self, one’s home and extended family, schools and the community at large.   Schools play a unique role in the provision of education in that they are the only provider of educational services allowed to award credentials, the folded paper, so esteemed by our society.

It is widely recognized that education is a key factor in determining one’s quality of life; in the same way, the collective education of our citizens will determine to a significant degree the future of our community and country. Because of this, we are among the world leaders in our investment in ensuring that our citizens, especially our youth, have access to a variety of educational activities and experiences.  Our education system developed over decades and served us well, however, there are significant changes occurring around us that demand some different responses; our education system is unlikely to make the desired changes by itself.  But there is a gap between what Islanders have and what they want in the way of education.  Not only is there a gap, but Islanders want meaningful engagement in bringing about the change. There is no panacea in sight and there is not likely to be one, however, change must be immediate, significant and continuous, but planned. Most comment is focused on changes to the school system, however, the issue is broader than that, it must encompass not only schools, but the broader education including the role of the home and community; any review must also include a variety of issues including expectations, the need for collaboration and engagement, credentials and standards, personal freedom and accountability.

I’ve spent most of...

title: 100-4 Learners and Learning-paper
summary: Comprehensive paper synthesizing Don's lifetime thinking on learners and learning, building on his Road of Life model and Oregon life roles framework. Addresses the gap between community expectations and educational system delivery, emphasizes learner-centered development over standardized testing, identifies systemic barriers and opportunities, and includes personal reflection on his 50+ years working in education as teacher, principal, trainer, consultant, and administrator.
content_preview:
100-

May 15, 2014

Learners and learning

By

Don Glendenning




Learners and Learning

At birth, we are launched on the road of life; whether the journey is long or short, it is an individual journey, our journey, and is likely to be complex and sometimes rocky.  The good news is that there is help available, help may be in a number of forms, but the pages that follow deal with help in the form of education. 




The heart of education is learning;.  Learning is a lifelong process that engages us from birth to death. it is a process of growing, changing and developing. What we’ve learned or not learned, determines to a large degree who we are, and the life style available to us.  Learning is not limited to what we do at school; much of our learning  happens outside school.  Some of our most important learning occurs at home, at church, in our communities, through sports, conversations around the kitchen table, from family and friends.  







Birth______________________________________________________________Death

Road of Life













The road of life may be described in many ways; I’ve adopted the Life roles” model developed in 1990 by the State of Oregon it is easy to visualize, simple  to understand and easy to explain.  




Life roles* 

  
Individual 
  
Learner 
  
Producer
  
Citizen
  
Consumer
  
Family member


*Oregon Educational Act, 1990




From the moment of birth to the moment of death, each of us is engaged in one or more of those roles, and usually several simultaneously.  The boundaries are fuzzy, the emphasis changes, success is not easy to define, some roles are crowded, and navigation may not be easy.  All of us fill some roles; most of us fill all roles.  We do so at different ages and stages and we do so in different emphases and combinations.  While we may travel the road with friends, most of the important decisions will be made alone – and we must deal with the consequences.




The road is crowded with people of all ages, stage...

title: 100-Final
summary: The December 21, 2020 special issue 100 of Open Education serves as both a milestone and farewell. Don shares a profound personal memory: departing home on January 2, 1947 at age 17 for Teachers' College in Fredericton with a plaque reading "I shall pass this way but once / Any good thing therefore that I can do or kindness that I may show / Let me do it now / Let me not defer it nor neglect it / For I shall not pass this way again." Don notes this inscription guided his decision-making throughout his life. The final issue sends season's greetings to readers and friends worldwide, marking the conclusion of a newsletter that began in 2013 and evolved through 100 editions. This poignant closing document captures Don's lifelong commitment to educational excellence and his belief that each moment offers opportunity for meaningful contribution. It reveals the spiritual and philosophical foundation underlying his professional career.
content_preview:
Open
	Education
	

	No. 100	                                        	
	               			December 21, 2020
	
It
	came upon a midnight clear



	


	
	

	A
	SEASONAL MEMORY
	

	I left
	home for Teachers’ College at age 17 on January 2, 1947; I started
	teaching in September still in New Brunswick and still at the age of
	17.  I had not planned to be a teacher but teaching and nursing were
	inexpensive transition routes in my community for young high school
	graduates. Besides that, my mother thought that study beyond high
	school would be good even if I never taught.
	

	


	
	

	On
	that January morning as I packed for Fredericton, my mother handed
	me a little plaque for my bedside table. I still have it; it reads:
	

	


	
	

	I
	shall pass this way but once
	

	Any
	good thing therefore that I can do or kindness that I may show
	

	Let
	me do it now
	

	Let
	me not defer it nor neglect it
	

	For
	I shall not pass this way again
	

	


	
	

	While
	I may not have always followed the advice, it has been a factor in
	my decision-making ever since.

title: 100 pei Issues.
summary: Don's comprehensive analysis of critical systemic issues facing PEI's education system: lack of clarity in terminology, unclear purpose, fragmented services, poor organizational structure, insufficient autonomy for teachers, weak accountability mechanisms, professional isolation, limited transparency, and inadequate documentation. This document represents Don's final assessment of obstacles to education improvement and his call for urgent public action.
content_preview:
`About
Education

Glendenning
Notes

	100

KEY
ISSUES	___________________________________________________________________________

It is widely
recognized that education Is a key factor in determining a person’s
quality of life. In the same way, the collective education of our
citizens determines ,to a significant degree, the qualities of the
communities in which we live. Education is complex, made so by the
fact that each person is unique in so many ways – unique in basic
physical, emotional and mental make up, unique in the range and
nature of previous experience; unique also in perceived futures and
unique in terms of learning style, interests, pace and needs.

Given these
complexities, some system-wide issues are not surprising:

	

Clarity
	– a common terminology improves communication throughout the
	organization; the most obvious example, according to the World Bank,
	in the practice of using  the terms “education” and ‘going to
	school” interchangeably.
	

Purpose
	– purpose
	sets the stage for
	what we do and how we organize to do it. The
	PEI PEI education literature refers to helping people find “a
	place” in society’; we need to better define that “place”. 
	People are said to fill six life roles, that of an individual,
	citizen, a producer, a consumer, family member and student. All
	roles can benefit from education but all may not need the same
	amount, mix or time. 
	
	

Services
	–
	Learning is complex;
	support services include: information, counselling, instruction,
	products and technology, quality assurance. governance, funding and
	human resources. Services should be publicly available as needed. . 
	
	

Structure

Autonomy
	- front

title: 100 skills based hiring
summary: An incomplete draft exploring Harvard Business School research on degree inflation and skills-based hiring practices. Don cites Lawrence Lanahan's article showing that over-credentialization is driving costs in manufacturing, retail, and service sectors. Notes that PEI employers also require degrees regardless of job requirements. Questions whether this reflects bias, screening convenience, unemployment rates, or retention preferences. Reflects Don's concern about the gap between educational credentials and actual workforce needs.
content_preview:
Growing interest in skills based hiring  - Draft 100

According to data provided by the Harvard Business school, “Grade inflation is imperiling jobs in the manufacturing, retail, accommodation, food service, health and social assistance’, This startling statistic is found in an article by Lawrencee

 Lanahan on skill-based hiring.  Some employers, it seems, have policies calling for new workers to have degrees even though the nature of the work itself cannot support that view.  The resulting  grade inflation has a substantial upward impact on the cost of doing business. Accord one Island educator with whom I spoke with whom I spoke, the practice of requiring new employees to have a degree, whether needed or not is alive PEI as well.

The emphasis, it is said, arises for a number of reasons – degrees adds prestige to the company, are a simple screening device, sometimes reflects high rates of unemployment, people wanting to remain on PEI; potential for company growth and perhaps to give priority to Islanders. Many employers associate degrees with soft  skills,

The article certainly raises questions about whether simply  preference. As one questioner pointed, “Jobs don’t require college degrees; employers do.”




Media reports on difficulty of finding candidates with skills they need but no evidence they are hiring based on skills needed.




Article caused me to skim  PEI job advertisements  

 Susanna Williams was quoted in one of the articles as pointing out that

title: 100-What is education-1
summary: Don's foundational essay on education from May 2014, challenging the confusion between schooling and education. Uses life roles model (Individual, Learner, Producer, Citizen, Consumer, Family member) to argue education is lifelong development across all domains.
content_preview:
100-

May 1, 2014







An Introduction







From time to time I am asked where I got my education.  As an example, recently I was asked by an organization to provide some information for their files – introductions, promotions and birthdays mostly, but increasingly it seems for obituaries.  I decided to respond on the spot, sat at a nearby table, whipped out my pencil and started filling in the blanks.  It was a short form; tombstone data came quickly, name, address, date of birth, etc.  Then there were several boxes devoted to education.  I reported that my work ethic came from my family, my knowledge base probably was a combination of formal study, travel and from reading, moral compass probably reflected my initial home community, etc. I turned in the form and was about to move on when the form was handed back indicating that what was wanted was the list of schools and universities attended.  And herein lies the first challenge in improving education, the confusion in both the public mind and that of educators, as to what we mean by education and what constitutes an education system.

At birth, we are thrown somewhat unceremoniously onto the road of life and thereafter, and as long as we live, will continue to dealing with personal and societal needs, fears, hopes and the ups and downs of life.  A road of life may be described in many ways; I’ve adopted the Life roles model developed in 1990 by the State of Oregon; it identifies life roles as that of an Individual, Learner , Producer, Citizen, Consumer and Family member.  Our education is all the things we learn to do to help us on the road of life. Our education is the of all those changes 













Each person is unique, we have different stages of health, different interests, different kinds and levels of previous learning, different attitudes and learning style. We may have lived in a different culture, had mor or less secure and loving families 

Education is a lifelong process; it is a process of gr...

title: 102-3 Role of Gov
summary: A revised version of File 17 narrowing focus to the need for public education goal-setting. Don emphasizes that education systems require clear foundational documents and references Robert Mager's classic "Setting Instructional Objectives," asking "If you don't know where you're going, how will you know when you get there?" Argues that government should initiate this process but with public consultation and independent development rather than bureaucratic control.
content_preview:
Re-setting our  direction

	

An education system is an array of programs and services put in place by a community to encourage and support the education of its citizens. Governments provide support for two reasons; (1) to support the education of jndividual citizens and (2) because communities need skilled people to ensure their viability.   Typical education services include funding, regulation, information,  counselling, instruction, quality assurance, education products. 

But there is a gap, some say a widening gap, between services wanted (needed?) by the community and services provided by the education  system – problems of structure, mandate and mission, government practices, bureaucracy, autonomy and accountability  - and that gap is interfering with both quality of service. 

The situation calls for action; step one, I suggest, is an overview of what is intended – a public process resulting in a public document setting out of basic beliefs an underlying principles on which our education system will operate.  The initiation of such a document falls naturally to Government; the development of the framework, however, should involve public consultation and independent generation. 

As I write, I am reminded of a quotation in a book, Setting Instructional Objective, popular sixty years ago.  In making the case for cler objectives, the author asks  “If you don’t know where you’re going, how will you know when you get there?” It’s time, I suggest, for education in PEI to review and restate where “it’s going”

Sincerely




Don Glendenning

A long-time student of education

  								102-3

title: 106-Issues in Education

content_preview:
About education




Issues in Education			     			

No. 01					 					          February 10, 2014







BACKGROUND

              

Issues are topics, problems or concerns of importance to groups of people; they are the big questions.    Issues are not simple problems for which definitive answers can easily be found.  On the contrary, they are complex and of significance. Once understood, the simpler questions can be dealt with and progress resumed.   It’s not always easy to describe an issue in precise terms; sometimes we confuse issues with symptoms and incidents.  An issue may be current, that is a problem of today; emerging and potential issues, on the other hand, focus on those threats and opportunities that are like to impact on life tomorrow.  But the field is messy.  Issues arise in a variety of ways but often become of concern when they impact on personal interests, activities or events, or are related in some way to concerns of friends or family.  When trying to sort through issues, it is often useful to begin one’s analysis with the basic questions of who, what, when, where and why.  It may also be useful to browse or skim broadly in the field, such as browsing the internet, to get a feel for the issues.  In the case of education, while the organization is mine
