title: 11 Learning About Learning
summary: Don reflects on his teaching journey, commencing at age 17 at Teacher's College Fredericton, then teaching rural one-room schools and secondary/post-secondary levels. He laments insufficient focus on the teaching-learning process during his training and advocates every school should publish a learning model focused on learner activities (not teacher activities). He provides a practical exercise: sketch steps from course entry to exit, sequence them, identify optional paths, and ask how you know the sequence is correct. Don emphasizes that developing a learning model takes minutes initially but lifetimes to perfect—and wishes he'd developed one before his teaching career.
content_preview:
Learning About Learning




In preparation for a teaching career, at age 17, I attended Teacher’s College in Fredericton, N.B.  Given the need for teachers, the Province then enrolled students twice a year for a six months training program.  While still only seventeen, I commenced teaching in a one-room rural school.  It was an experience I will never forget.  The students and I survived; whether they learned is another matter.

The years which followed were filled with teaching and summer school as I went on to complete the requirements for a teacher’s license.  During that period, also, my teaching career included experience at both the secondary and post-secondary levels.

I still recall, at least some of the information and instruction received in Teacher’s College about developing lesson plans, using audio visual aids, maintaining the school register, school law, psychology, teaching methods, etc.  But I do not recall much about the teaching-learning process.  This process has since become an interest of mine and is the subject of this column.

The heart of schooling is, or should be, the teaching-learning process.  We should spend much more time learning and thinking about it.  It provides a framework for the teaching we do; it provides a framework for our decisions as teachers.

In our study of the teaching learning process we need to consider the teacher, the learner and the process.  Our starting point should be the learner.  If we get the learner’s role and activities right, the rest will follow. 

Organizational theory suggests that every organization needs a mission statement and it should be published.  The process of developing a mission statement is important for an organization and is usually highly consultative.  Many organizations have such a statement prominently displayed throughout their premises.  Schools, colleges and universities should have them too.  So should training departments.

Even more important for training and education organizatio...

title: 11 PISA again
summary: The January 20, 2014 eleventh issue, edited by Don Glendenning, examines PISA (Program for International Student Assessment) results and their implications. Don cautions that while PISA provides useful feedback and international comparison, test results should not drive all educational decisions. He highlights an OECD survey of 11 participating countries showing that schools with greater autonomy tend to perform better on PISA. Critically, Don notes that when schools account publicly for results through achievement data, greater autonomy correlates with better performance, but without accountability arrangements, autonomous schools can perform worse. This balanced perspective reflects Don's sophisticated understanding of educational governance. The newsletter reminds readers of the January 20 workshop on youth preparedness and directs readers to OECD resources. Don recommends the Vancouver Sun article on British Columbia school report card reforms.

confuse education with intelligence - Einstein

title: 111 EXPECTATIONS OF HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES
summary: Don questions what a high school diploma should signify and whether graduation requirements adequately prepare students. Critiques rigid curriculum requirements that deter exploration and examines disconnect between employer expectations and diploma meaning.
content_preview:
EXPECTATIONS OF HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES




High school graduation is an important event in our lives.  We look forward with anticipation and backwards with considerable satisfaction and nostalgia.  Graduation marks a turning point in our lives.  For many, it means parting with long-time friends, entering college or university, moving from home or finding a job.  Graduation exercises and the related social activities also play a part in our nostalgia.  A high school diploma helps us make many of these transitions.




But what does, or should, a graduation diploma signify?  Or for that matter, a college or university diploma or degree?  A person with a diploma should be different that one without, or else why have diplomas.  The distinguishing characteristics between a person having a diploma ;and one who does not are not clear to me.  Should we be able, for example, to distinguish between a graduate and a non-graduate without seeing a transcript or diploma?




Employers like their new employees to be high school graduates.  Why?  What do they see in a graduate that they do not find in a person who has not graduated?  Or is being a graduate simply a handy screening tool?  If it is the latter, employers are missing out on a vast pool of potential employees.




A high school graduation diploma is granted on the basis of having completed a specified group of courses and some options for, I believe, a total of 18 credits.  The requirement also includes an acceptable grade.  Prizes and honors go to those who excel.




Current graduation requirements are quite rigidly adhered to and, I am told, although some choice is possible the pressure is on students to take as many of the “traditional” courses as possible I understand the reason for this since schools are judged by the number of students who go to college or university.  The rigid pattern of requirements deters students from broadening their education and exploring areas of interest.  The reason for not encouraging ...

title: 112 Essential skills
summary: Don identifies nine essential skills for work and life: reading, document use, numeracy, writing, oral communication, working with others, thinking skills, computer use, and continuous learning. References Government of Canada research and PEI Literacy Alliance framework.
content_preview:
About education




Essential skills			     			

No. 01					 					          August 1, 2014







Not the same as essential graduation learnings




Literacy and essential skills:

•are needed for work, learning and life;

•are the foundation for learning all other skills; and

•help people evolve with their jobs and adapt to workplace change.




Through extensive research, the Government of Canada and other national and international agencies have identified and validated key essential skills for the workplace. These skills are used in nearly every job and at different levels of complexity. They provide the foundation for learning all other skills and enable people to evolve with their jobs and adapt to workplace change.







Literacy is the ability to identify, understand, interpret, create, communicate, compute and use printed and written materials associated with varying contexts. Literacy involves a continuum of learning to enable an individual to achieve his or her goals, to develop his or her knowledge and potential, and to participate fully in the wider society. — UNESCO




The PEI Literacy alliance lists the following essential skills:

  
Reading text
  
Document use
  
Numeracy
  
Writing
  
Oral communication
  
Working with others
  
Thinking skills
  
Computer use
  
Continuous learning

title: 12 Experimental Projects
summary: Don describes experimental projects branch involvement during 1960s Canadian vocational training expansion. Discusses federal-provincial initiatives addressing unemployment and undereducation, particularly for youth in rural areas following Prime Minister Pearson's 1965 proposal.
content_preview:
EXPERIMENTAL
PROJECTS BRANCH







The
opening chapter recorded some of the events surrounding the rapid
expansion of technical and vocational training in Canada during the
1960’s. a period during which the writer had an inside view as a
member of the Training Branch, Department of Labour, Ottawa.  From
that vantage point, the writer remembers frequent discussions about
the need for research into manpower training.  both within the Branch
and between Training Branch officials and Directors of Vocational
Education among the provinces.   While not directly involved, the
writer was aware of the rising attention being assigned to the
subject as evidenced by some staff being seconded or contracted to
further develop the idea. 








Within
the federal government generally, partly because of a change of
government, officials soon became aware of increased concern about
the high levels of unemployment and the inadequate readiness of so
many Canadians to enter the employment mainstream.  Increased
investment was called for in programs and services designed to
increase both education and educational opportunity for unemployed
and under educated youth many of whom were in rural areas.  In July,
1965, the Government of Canada convened a Federal-Provincial
Conference at which time Prime Minister Pearson proposed to designate
some areas of the country for “an intensive effort in practical
research designed to determine the best methods of meeting the
training needs of adults in designated areas.”  The proposal
received general approval and federal and provincial officials began
to shape the initiative.







Also
during the late 1960’s, the Technical and Vocational Training
Assistance Act came to an end and, consistent with the thinking of
the government generally, the focus changed quite dramatically as to
an appropriate federal-provincial delivery arrangement for manpower
training.  Under the Technical and Vocational Training Assistance
Act, the Federal cost shared a numbe...

Typical  Education Services 


Occasional

An education system is an array of programs and services put in

title: 12 Outcome framework vital to succeeding
summary: Don discusses recent outcomes-based education conversations with national Sectoral Councils and colleagues. He reports good news: outcomes are universally accepted as the educational design starting point. However, he identifies two critical gaps: need for common outcome terminology and need for an outcomes structure/framework. Using a farm shed-building analogy, Don explains that having clear architectural design before selecting lumber (outcomes) accelerates progress. He connects DACUM (occupational analysis) to broader "life roles" (learner, producer, citizen, family member, consumer), proposing a outcomes hierarchy: life roles, occupation, general competencies, specific competencies, elaborations. He emphasizes that outcome architecture knowledge pays "great dividends."
content_preview:
Outcome framework vital to succeeding




During the past two weeks I have been party to a number of discussions about outcomes-based education and, more especially, about the nature of outcomes.




One discussion was in the context of the CRSP Project; another was with the chair of one of the national Sectoral Councils; other conversations involved colleagues, both long standing and new, who have a responsibility, experience and a major interest in outcome- or competency-based education, training, standards or performance assessment.




	The good news is the extent to which outcomes are viewed as the starting point for the design and development of both training programs and performance standards.  During our discussions, no one questioned outcomes as the place to start.




	It appears to me that, except for the university sector, the good ship education is trying to set a new course ― a course based on desired outcomes.  Although there are many views about how we get there or how we will know when we arrive, none surfaced about the ultimate objective.




Determine need for outcomes structure




	During our discussions, however, two things became quite clear.  The first is the need for some definitions of terms related to outcomes.




	Having said this, however, I am aware of the jurisdictional propensity to dream up unique terms.  I understand this and am also aware of how quickly terms lose their “freshness” and assume baggage that reduces their acceptability and even their effectiveness.  But work on common terminology, we must.




	The second observation concerns the need for an outcomes structure.  The importance of such a structure can be related to a construction project which I engaged in last year on my farm.




	I decided to build a small free-standing shed.  I took account of the lay of the land, selected a site and sketched out an appropriate building design.




	Only after my ultimate design was clearly established did I go to the woods, cut l...

title: 14 Accountability_En and Fr
summary: The March 26, 2014 fourteenth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, distinguishes responsibility from accountability through columnist Arthur Sherren's framework. Don notes that employees are "responsible for their actions, behaviours, attitudes, decisions, work and performance" - they own and correct mistakes. Accountability represents "the process of making, keeping and managing promises and expectations… being liable or answerable for overall outcomes." Applying this to schools, Don argues teachers are responsible for ensuring students learn, while principals as instructional leaders are accountable for students gaining skills needed for postsecondary education or employment. Students and parents also bear responsibility for school success. The bilingual issue includes discussion of professional development, highlighting James Kempton's argument for teacher-controlled continuing education (100 hours annually) modeled on Royal College standards rather than school-mandated in-service days that research shows have limited impact. This issue demonstrates Don's sophisticated management thinking and commitment to clarity about educational roles.

Life is not about how much you
get, but how much you give – Author unknown  



	Accountability
	

	


	
	

	I’ve
	had many conversations about accountability and responsibility over
	the years but never have I seen a better explanation than that by
	offered by Arthur Sherren (“The buck stops here”, Charlottetown
	Guardian, Saturday, March 8, 2014.)  Although not about education,
	his comments certainly apply to that field as well as others.  
	
	

	


	
	

	Sherren,
	a columnist and specialist in management effectiveness who was born
	in PEI, says that employees are “responsible for their actions,
	behaviours, attitudes, decisions, work and performance.” 
	Responsibility means taking ownership and corrective actions.  
	
	

	


	
	

	Accountability,
	on the other hand, is described by Sherren as “the process of
	making, keeping and managing promises and expectations… being
	liable or answerable for the overall outcomes.” 
	
	

	


	
	

	Although
	the article makes no mention of schools, from his article one can
	conclude that teachers are responsible for seeing that students are
	taught.  On the other hand, principals, as instructional leaders,
	are accountable for students getting what they came to school for,
	the skills needed in order to gain entrance to postsecondary studies
	or employment. Of course, students and parents also have
	responsibilities for success in school.
	

	


	
	

	Sherren
	provides much food for thought.  It is a timely topic and one that
	would likely liven up any discussion.

title: 14 Overhaul
summary: December 2020 paper analyzing structural impediments to educational improvement, drawing on World Bank research and Don's experience chairing community education discussions. He identifies political context challenges (politicization within government departments affecting long-term planning), mission ambiguity, organizational structure limitations, insufficient autonomy, unclear accountability, fragmented culture treating education as product rather than service, and inadequate instructional support materials. Don argues that many functions should delegate to schools and intermediary bodies, citing OECD evidence that student performance improves with school autonomy. He advocates treating education as a service to learners rather than a product to deliver, emphasizing learner-centered rather than teacher-centered support materials. The paper calls for clear vision-setting as prerequisite for structural reform.

title: 15-EDC-2 Early Childhood Development-2
summary: Analysis of early childhood development emphasizing the critical period spanning first 6-8 years of life when rapid growth occurs across all developmental domains. Argues that early childhood experiences establish foundation for later life, advocates holistic development through family-centered services, and highlights evidence-based benefits including improved health, education, literacy, and economic outcomes.
content_preview:
Lens-15cvCurrent 04


January 21, 2012







Early Childhood Development






Early
Childhood 







Early
childhood usually
encompasses the first 6-8 years of life and is a period of rapid
growth in all domains, learning, social, emotional, cognitive,
language, and physical.  Early childhood experiences set the
stage for what each person becomes in later life






Early
Childhood Development


It should be pointed out that many of the services to young children
already exist but are usually provided by separate agencies and often
unfortunately operating  independently of each other and sometimes
under the rubric of preschool programming.  Yet, experts in the field
 tell us that, children at this age, experience learning is
holisticly.  Early childhood  development encompasses all aspects or
components of development, psychological, economic, physical and
social well-being, and it does so through a family lens.  To be
successful, early childhood development must both engage and empower
all family members and service providers.  The end result is
individuals contributing to and enjoying this great country we call
Canada. 


Benefits






Effective
early development programs provide many benefits to both the
individual and the community.  A review of the literature provides
compelling evidence that investment in programs and services for
children in the early years pays particular dividends in terms of
health, education, literacy and the economy.






Delivery



The
concept of early childhood development promotes/envisages an the
coordination of services, but not a single provider, at the community
level; it also includes significant support for parents and other
family members.

title: 16 - Grouping learners -En & Fr
summary: May 2014 exploration of alternative student grouping models: peer grouping (age-based), ability grouping, setting (subject-level differentiation), and independent programming. Don presents evidence-based alternatives to traditional grade-level structures, including an observation of a school where students study different subject levels based on proficiency rather than age. This reflects his progressive stance on educational innovation and flexibility.
content_preview:
Open
Education					



16										
           May 20, 2014








“Regrets
are the natural property of grey hairs.” ― Charles Dickens 




	


	



	Grouping learners
	

	


	
	

	It
	is probably time to revisit how we group students.  A quick review
	of the literature suggests the following alternatives:
	

	


	
	

	Peers
	– Students stay with their age group throughout their school
	years.  This results in a wide range of performance levels in each
	grade; it also increases pressure on standards and the likelihood of
	social promotion.
	

	


	
	

	Ability
	– Students grouped by aptitudes for school studies; appears to
	lead to improved performance, however, it also  has  the potential
	for negative impact on a student’s self-esteem, especially for
	students in the “lower” level streams. A closer examination is
	necessary, however, the negative effect may be a labelling problem
	that could be readily offset by some restructuring of the
	curriculum. 
	
	

	


	
	

	Setting
	–
	It is a new term to the writer but results in each subject being
	divided into a number of levels with students taking the level they
	need irrespective of their age.  The writer visited such a school
	where at 9:00 o’clock, all students studied English, with each
	student taking the level best suited to his or her own needs. At
	10:00,
	students
	switched to mathematics and at 11:00, they switched to science. 
	After lunch, students remained with peers for other studies.
	

	


	
	

	Independent
	programming – “Groups
	of one person each” work with a learning manager and take
	advantage of learning opportunities both inside and outside school.
	

	


	
	

	Guest
	Editor: Don Glendenning

title: 16 Holland College
summary: Manuscript chapter detailing Holland College's founding (1969) under Don's presidency. Documents 14 core principles adopted: student responsibility, skills identification by practitioners, individualized learning, year-round operation, flexible entry/exit. Shows DACUM implementation in institutional context.
content_preview:
DACUM AT HOLLAND COLLEGE







Holland College, a College of Applied Arts and Technology, was established in Prince Edward Island in 1969 with a mandate to serve all Islanders except those seeking university credit.  Donald Glendenning was contracted as president Designate and his position confirmed when the College Act was proclaimed.  Glendenning was committed to implementing a flexible, relevant and student-centred approach to education.  The College opened its doors to students on September 2, 1969 and operated during the first year in a traditional mode.  




During the first year, Glendenning and  staff engaged in regular and disciplined discussions about an instructional model for the new institution.  By early 1970 the following set of principles not only emerged but had significant if not full support: (Figure 8).

































































































	Figure 8:  Principles Adopted by Holland College

  
    
      
        


        
1.	Skills required by an occupational field should be identified by persons in the field.
      
    
    
      
        


        
2.	Students are responsible for their own progress.
      
    
    
      
        


        
3.	Learning should be stressed instead of teaching.
      
    
    
      
        


        
4.	The role of the instructor shall be to assess, diagnose, prescribe, tutor, but not to be the sole conveyor of information.
      
    
    
      
        


        
5.	Programs shall be individualized to the extent that resources allow.
      
    
    
      
        


        
6.	The College should operate on a year-round  basis.
      
    
    
      
        


        
7.	We should schedule resources rooms, materials and instructors instead of students.
      
    
    
      
        


        
8.	Evaluation should be as realistic and meaningful as possible in keeping with evaluation in the work environment.

title: 18 On Reflection
summary: Concluding chapter of DACUM manuscript presenting 10 conclusions: distinguishes DACUM model from charts, credits Canadian development, highlights Adams' competency analysis rigor, documents BC documentation, and notes Holland College's institutional adaptation of DACUM.
content_preview:
CONCLUSIONS




The following summarizes the writer's conclusions:




1.	A distinction should be made between the DACUM model and a DACUM chart. The writer proposes the following:




o	DACUM is a systems model for planning, developing, organizing and managing competency based training and education. 




o	A DACUM chart is a single sheet presentation of the skills included in an occupation or field which results from a structured brainstorming session of practitioners from the field. 

2.	DACUM, as practised today, is essentially a Canadian development.




3.	The single page course presentation at Clinton, Iowa was only one such model available to people of the day.  The other major contributor was the presentation of OCCupational and functional occupational analyses prepared by the Government of Canada.




4.	Howard Clement saw the value of a single sheet presentation of curriculum and introduced it to colleagues and friends.  The first DACUM Chart produced in Canada was quite different in both process and product than that used in Clinton, Iowa.




5.	Robert Adams established the idea of a disciplined competency analysis by practitioners as the basis of the DACUM model.




6.	The early implementation of DACUM in British Columbia reflected the model described in the document Designing a Curriculum.




7.	The BC Division of Technical and Vocational Curriculum, under the direction of Derek Franklin, under contract to the Department of Regional Economic Expansion, provided the first significant documentation on the approach to curriculum development and presentation based on the Clinton approach.




8.	Robert Adams of Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation developed an entire CBE systems model under the DACUM acronym using a rigorous performance based analysis as the foundation document.




9.	In recent years, the differences between a DACUM analysis prepared in BC and analyses based on the Nova Scotia model have been significantly reduced.




10.	Holland College ...

title: 2-5  CBE
summary: Comprehensive notes on Outcome-Based Education (OBE) and Competency-Based Education (CBE) dated March 2013. Don distinguishes between the two approaches and traces OBE's influence on curriculum development globally. He credits William Spady as the main proponent and examines definitions, outcomes at multiple levels (societal, community, school, program, course), and characteristics of effective OBE systems. The document outlines DACUM methodology, provides rating scales and performance levels, lists strengths (shifting focus from content to learner) and weaknesses (confusion between outcomes and levels), and includes Atlantic Canada's Essential Graduation Learnings and verb taxonomy aligned with Bloom's taxonomy. Reflects Don's systematic approach to educational philosophy and methodology.
content_preview:
OBE-1

About

March 11. 2013

Some notes on Outcome
Based Education

By

Don Glendenning







NOTE:	Part of my learning style involves putting ideas and
information on paper; these notes reflect my stage of knowledge and
thinking about Outcomes Based Education.








Background


Outcomes
based education (OBE), like competency based education (CBE) seemed
to be a major  focus of educational conferences during the latter
part of the twentieth century.   In my own mind, the two are soul
mates with OBE being the broad descriptor when speaking of education
and competencies being a description of the outcome at the interface
with a learner.  I must hasten to add, however, that this is a
personal view rather than one shared broadly in the profession.  It
is not surprising, therefore, that even a quick scan of websites of
Provincial Departments of Education, quickly reveals the extent to
which educational planning has been influenced by the Outcomes Based 
Education movement, especially in the area of curriculum development.








Academic
educators then, and mostly still today, focused on content,  that is
dividing subjects such as mathematics, literature, science  and so
forth into courses and lectures for the purpose of teaching and
learning. At the time was that small cadre of educators who laboured
in the field of vocational education; their instructional efforts
always started with an occupational analysis and the adoption of CBE
was a natural fit with their practice.








Promoters
of OBE proposed to organize education, or perhaps more accurately
that part of education that occurs in schools, around educational
outcomes and to measure change based on performance regardless of
when the learning took place.  The proponent, and self-proclaimed
expert, was William Spady, a sociologist xxxat the University and for
a while, a professor at the Ontario Institute for Studies in
Education in Toronto.  According to Spady, outcomes could be written
with “traditional,
t...

title: 2-Sch. Resp. forCharacter building
summary: Don's 2005 commentary on school responsibility for character building and student conduct, questioning whether schools bear sole or shared responsibility for troublesome student behavior off-campus and advocating clear written stakeholder accountability.
content_preview:
First Draft:	March 26, 2005

Last revision:	 TIME \@ "MMMM d, yyyy" March 26, 2005




SCHOOLS AND TROUBLESOME STUDENTS







Again, we have some episodes of troublesome students harassing local businesses while on noon break.  Schools are blamed but can schools solve the problem?  I think not - but they do have a role to play in solving the problem.  Is it a leadership role?  The answer to that question is less clear.




What is the attribute we want to encourage?  Is it taking responsibility for one’s actions?  Showing respect for others? 




Schools should askthemselves:




What responsibility is assumed, implied or taken on by schools in this aspect of a learner’s education ?

Is it a sole responsibility or is it shared?

Are schools responsible when students are off campus?

Is it a school’s responsibility to lead, participate, support or simply to report?

If not the school, who should lead in resolving the issue?

If a school is responsible, shouldn’t it be part of a student’s record? 







And the answers should be written and made known to all stakeholders.

title: 2 speaking single
summary: Speaker biography highlighting Don's career from age-17 teacher through Holland College founding presidency to international consulting. Emphasizes his passion for learner-centered, flexible, transparent education systems and his consulting firm Education 20/20.
content_preview:
THINKING
	OTHERWISE:
	

	A
	CONVERSATION ABOUT EDUCATION
	

	WITH DON
	GLENDENNING
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	Inspire
	Centre
	

	WWW
	Street, Smmerside
	

	12:00-1:00
	pm

	2018
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	NEED
	A SPEAKER 
	
	

	


	
	

	FOR
	YOUR NEXT MEETING?
	

	


	
	

	Don
	Glendenning grew up on the banks of the Miramichi in New Brunswick.
	He began teaching at age 17 and ended up as the Founding President
	of Holland College in Prince Edward Island. Along the way he was a
	principal, a Teacher Trainer, and Training Consultant with
	Department of Labour in Ottawa.  He also studied at Bradley
	University, University of London (Eng.) and Indiana University.
	

	


	
	

	After
	retirement he formed his own consulting firm and worked both in
	Canada and overseas. 
	
	

	


	
	

	His
	passion is education, which he views as the act helping people learn
	new attitudes, skills and knowledge in order to thrive on the road
	of life.  He’d like to see our education sstem become more focused
	on learners and their needs, more flexible and more transparent.
	

	


	
	

	So, if you
	want a speaker, are interested in education and other approaches,
	see below:

title: 20-1-3 OBE paper
summary:
Latest version of OBE analysis with identical background, premises, and characteristics to File 18, suggesting iterative revision process. Maintains comprehensive treatment of Spady's paradigm, definitional clarity, OBE system characteristics, strengths and weaknesses. Includes same examples of exit outcomes from Saranac Lake and recommendations regarding PEI's commitment to OBE. Adds final section on "Opportunities for external interventions" listing: continuing consultation, increasing public information, grants for selective innovations, strengthening non-school educational activities, expanded referral systems to specialists, encouraging non-aligned associations, and help for parents of young children. Final item "Tyranny of time" appears as standalone concept reflecting Don's critique of time-based education systems. Document represents culmination of Don's thinking on OBE and its implementation challenges in PEI context.
- **Key People**: Spady, William
- **Key Organizations**: PEI Department of Education and Early Childhood Development, Saranac Lake Central School District, Atlantic provinces
- **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, MANUSCRIPT, POLICY
- **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Final comprehensive analysis showing Don's mature thinking on OBE as educational reform strategy for PEI. Demonstrates his role in shaping provincial educational policy discourse during post-retirement consulting phase. Particularly valuable for understanding his specific recommendations for improving PEI education system.
content_preview:
20-1-3


Outcomes Based Education














Background














Traditionally
schools focused on content to be learned, whether it be on the arts,
science or business.  Fields are divided into subjects, courses and
units and lectures or lessons for the purpose of teaching and
learning. Assignments and assessment followed suit.  One’s
education, at least the part experienced in school, became the study
of a series of discrete experiences too seldom integrated into a
coherent life related whole.  Vocational educators, on the other
hand, based their planning and teaching on an analysis of skills of
an occupation , and more recently, skill programs focus on
competrencies.  Perhaps the best known approach, DACUM, was developed
in Nova Scotia and has since spread world wide








OBE
changes the focus of education from content to learners and organizes
teaching and learning around outcomes and measures change based on
performance regardless of when the learning took place.  According to
William Spady, a sociologist xxxat the University and one yime
professor at the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education in
Toronto, outcomes could be written with “traditional,
transitional, or transformational goals in mind”.   It appears that
the leadership in OBE dealt with broad principles only; as a result
there are no recognized standards for identifying out comes or
implementing OBE. As a result, there are many versions of OBE, most
focusing on outcomes only. 








Spadyʼs
“OBE Paradigm” (1994) is based on three premises and four
principles.


The
premises are:


1.
All students can learn and succeed but not on the same day and not in


the
same way;


2.
Successful learning promotes even more successful learning; and

3.
Schools control the conditions that affect directly affect successful


learning.


The
four “power principles” are:


1.
Clarity of focus on culminating outcomes of significance;


2.
Expanded opportunity and support for learning success;


3.
Hig...

title: 2005-Task Force on Achievement
summary: Speaking notes from Don's June 2005 presentation to the Task Force on Achievement, discussing competency-based education. Notes his dual academic and vocational teaching credentials and his belief in educational standards as key to improvement, setting up discussion of the May 2005 commission document.
content_preview:
TASK FORCE ON ACHIEVEMENT




Monday, June 6 at 7:45 pm

Queen Charlotte School




Opening comments




Thanks for opportunity to present.




While many of you know me for my work at the college level and in technical and vocational education, I am one of a very small number who hold both an academic and vocational teachers license 




Although I have been out of the formal field of education for a number of years, I have maintained an interest in the field generally.




Am of the view that educational standard is at the cutting edge of educational improvement




Tour work, therefore, I believe is both timely and important.







My focus/comments




Commission members who know me, will expect me to talk about competency based education.




Instead, however, I’d like to focus my comments on the discussion document dated May 2005.

title: 2006-Card 3
summary: Christmas 2006 family update letter from Don and Carol describing retirement activities, winter travel to Florida, autumn trip to New Mexico visiting family, and noting Holland College's honor in naming Glendenning Hall after him during his 18-year tenure. Personal reflections on family, travel, and his legacy at the college.
content_preview:
From our home to your home!




Greetings.  All are well.  A few notes about our family.   




We spent February in North Clearwater Beach, Florida; we like the north 

beach because there are fewer high rises and no through traffic – although 

that seems to change each year.  We were near but not on the beach and 

close to public transportation, a library, convenience stores, restaurants, etc.  

It fits our needs and style.




In October we flew to Denver and, after visiting the city, drove south 

stopping in Taos and Santa Fe before reaching Brian and Marie in Socorro.  

We had a great visit; first time ever in the Southwest USA during warm 

weather.  Brian and Marie have a lovely large home and, given the good 

weather, we were comfortable to limit ourselves to day trips.  Brian and 

Marie took some time off - and Brian and I actually built a house for the 

family cat.




Our trip also included a family gathering in Santa Fe in October – sort of 

a belated birthday party for Carol.   We had a great evening; Janet was 

New Mexico for a visit so we overlapped with her for a family dinner.  

Our granddaughter, Lisa, finished university and is working and Laura

finishes this year.













Earlier this year, Holland College, where I worked for 18 years, opened

 a new 96-bed residence and honoured me by naming it Glendenning Hall.




Carol and I keep well and busy.  We read, travel and garden; Carol loves

 her bridge and I still do some genealogy.




May the blessings of the season be with you in the New Year.




Warmest wishes.




























From our home to your home!

title: 2006 Laubach Literacy
summary: Don's June 2006 speaking notes to Laubach Literacy Council in Charlottetown. Reflects on his teaching career starting in 1947 at age 17, his mother's love of reading, and the importance of literacy beyond economic impact. Discusses the distinction between education and schooling and commends volunteers in adult literacy.
content_preview:
LAUBACH LITERACY COUNCIL

CHARLOTTETOWN, PEI- JUNE 3, 2006?




Speaking Notes







Thanks for invitation  and for the kind words of welcome

I am delighted to be here; miss contact with educators




Welcome delegates from across Canada

	Fortunate to travel to all Provinces

Each part this country is unique




Great country

Much to be thankful for

I am proud to be Canadian




After Carol invited me to be here this evening, I looked at the web page.  And browsed a number of articles.




Liked what I saw – not too much academic jargon







Commend you and the many volunteers for your efforts

Teachers in universities, colleges and schools system get considerable attention.

You are unsung heroes of education




Recognize some of the PEI names 




Graduated from Miramichi Rural High in 1946




Started teaching in a one room school in NB in 1947 at the age of 17

	Consider myself to have been in education ever since.




I enjoy the informality of this sized group

First time I spoke to a group in the west

Honour of your visit – holding gathering in the auditorium

Obviously delighted

Mentioned it to my boss when I returned

Boss pointed out the origin of auditorium

Audio-to hear; Taurus – the bull
















My mother although with limited schooling enjoyed reading 

In the country

No library

Take book she finished to church meeting and return with another.

All were well worn and cannot remember my mother having a new book




One Christmas, I believe it was in 1938, I received several books as gifts

Hard to get me out to do the chores; had my head in a book until they were all read







Importance of literacy




Those of us who read, take literacy for granted; you know the facts better than I

So I will not repeat them




Literacy is a crucial 

Key to coping and to a productive and satisfying life

Importance is far beyond the economic impact on our communities

	The key to success in school and to a good education is literacy

title: 2007 Letter
summary: Christmas 2007 letter reflecting on family blessings and retirement life. Reports 2007 family reunion at PEI shore, Easter trip to Virginia, and Danube cruise from Vienna to Black Sea. Updates on children and grandchildren: Brian and Marie in New Mexico, Janet in Ottawa, granddaughters' progress.
content_preview:
Christmas
Greetings from the Island


	


	
	



	
	

	

	

	Our
	Island Home
	



	
	
Thinking
	of you at Christmas!
	

	


	
	

	To set the stage for Christmas greetings, I bring forward
	cards and greetings from last year, re-read messages and reflect
	upon our associations and friendships.  (Obviously the process also
	brings tinges of both sadness and regret)  My first thought always,
	is how blest we are with a wonderful family and friends.  So, an
	up-front thank you to all for having added riches to our lives
	

	


	
	

	Where to begin?  Some new aches, pains and creaks; a few more
	senior’s moments (I call them brainstorms); longer and more
	frequent naps in front of the TV; but most all systems are
	functioning if only at a lower capacity.  For this we are thankful.
	

	


	
	
Peace
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	Joy
	

	


	
	

	We were delighted to have a full family reunion at the shore
	on PEI in late June – children, daughter-in-law, grand children
	and boy friends.  A great gathering and one that, unfortunately,
	happen all too seldom.  
	
	

	


	
	

	Our travel in 2007 included 2 weeks in Virginia at Easter
	(with unexpected and un-necessary snow) and a two week cruise on the
	Danube from Vienna to the Black Sea in early October.  The latter
	was most interesting and enjoyable.
	

	


	
	

	Brian and Marie continue to live in New Mexico where both work
	for the National Radio Astronomy Observatory;  Granddaughter Lisa
	and her significant other, Kevin, live and work in Los Alamos;
	Granddaughter Laura is at home at the moment  and planning her next
	career moves.
	

	


	
	

	Daughter, Janet, thrives in Ottawa where she earns money to
	support her travel habit including travel on a number of occasions
	throughout Canada (mostly for work), and to the USA, South America
	and Africa for pleasure. Her African travels included a hike to the
	top of Mount Kilimanjaro.
	

	


	
	

	Best
	Wishes in the New Year to you and all you love

title: 2008-29B Literacy
summary: Dated October 14, 2008, this document refines the literacy fund concept with specific grant parameters and priority areas. Don identifies regional focus (eastern and western regions), workplace literacy in private industry, First Nations projects, and adult skills training as priorities. He proposes consulting with MacNutt and O'Bryan for Board presentations and coordinating with other funders. This demonstrates Don's sophisticated understanding of community needs and commitment to collaborative, inclusive philanthropy that addresses underserved populations.

title: 2008-6 Living Trust
summary: A comprehensive February 5, 2008 proposal for the Living Memorial Trust environmental initiative. Don documents partnership with the Keuper Family to establish tree-planting sites across PEI, with donations supporting both immediate planting and permanent endowments. His detailed plan includes specific funding levels ($25 minimum donation, $100 for endowment, $250 for plaques), site selection criteria, partnership structures, and promotional strategies. This demonstrates Don's passion for environmental stewardship, community partnerships, and creative fundraising that connects emotional values (memorials, special occasions) with conservation goals.
content_preview:
COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND




SD-		2008-6

Date:		February 5, 2008	

Prepared by:	Don Glendenning




To:		Executive




Subject:	Living Trust




The Living Memorial Trust was established on the initiative of the Keuper Family; its purpose is to protect, expand and improve the “greening’ of public spaces in PEI.  The inaugural planting took place in 2007 through the planting of a cluster of three oak trees on each side of the Wood Islands entrance to Trails PEI.




Jeniene Peake, Donnie and I constitute a small committee to move the initiative forward including the development of guidelines for future plantings and actual planting in 2008.  Our plan is to turn the initiative over to the Granting Committee before yearend..




Our current thinking is as follows:

To quickly designate one site per county for planting trees; each site will have two areas one for general planting and another for named trees.  Eventually there may be 10, 20 or even more such sites on PEI  We will use these sites as part of our promotion but planting will likely not occur in all sites in any year.

We see Trails PEI as natural locations especially for initial plantings.  Based on last years experience and our discussion, ideally we would plant a cluster of three oak trees on each side of a trail entrance and somewhere close by have a spot for both general planting of unnamed trees and another for the planting of named trees.

Native species will be planted, likely with the trees at the entrance being Island Oak.  This should make for easy identification of entrances.

It is our hope that we can continue the partnership of last year, Transportation and Public Works, Trails PEI, Forestry, McPhail Woods, John Keuper and others in the initiative..

Planting at designated sites will be under the direction of CFPEI; CFPEI will identify the amount of money  available each year, decide which site or sites to be planted and issue a contract for the trees and the planting

That...

content_preview:
Leave
an 







Artistic








Legacy






















































































Once you get here, you’ll understand…



Mission Statement

To
actively preserve and promote Celtic culture and heritage, through
quality educational programming






Brief Description

Celtic
culture comes alive at The College of Piping & Celtic Performing
Arts of Canada!  Based in Summerside, and affiliated with The
College of Piping in Glasgow, The College has developed a world-class
reputation as an international school of excellence in Highland
bagpiping, drumming, Highland dancing and Island step dancing.  The
only year-round institution of its kind in North America, it attracts
students from all over the world who come to learn the traditional
Celtic arts, passed down from generation to generation.






Since
1990, The College of Piping has played an integral and accountable
role within the arts community, both regionally and nationally.  As a
high caliber training facility, The College supports the artistic
development of the next generation of Celtic artists in Canada.  The
College also
plays a significant leadership role by providing performance
opportunities to hundreds of emerging and established artists.  Given
that seventy percent of the Island’s population is
descended from Scots and Irish settlers,
Prince Edward Island is a particularly appropriate setting for this
unique organization.

title: 2008 Press Release 3
summary: Press release announcing designation of North Yorke River Road entrance to Confederation Trail as second Living Trust site. References inaugural Wood Islands planting of Dr. Keuper memorial oak trees in 2007. Describes expanded opportunities for individuals and organizations to support tree planting, remember colleagues, and mark personal milestones. Invites donations of any amount with charitable receipts and suitable notification cards. Indicates Foundation's plan to eventually designate sites across the island.
content_preview:
New Site Designated




The North Yorke River Road entrance to the Confederation Trail has been designated by the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (CFPEI) as a Living Trust site.  As a result, individuals and organizations who want to support the planting of trees, remember friends and colleague, mark a milestone in the life of a person or an organization or add to the beauty of a public space may do so and later check on growth while strolling the Trail.  




Last year, CFPEI planted a cluster of Island oaks on each side of the Confederation Trail entrance in Wood Islands in memory of Dr. Charles Keuper; this year the Foundation plans to plant trees at the Upper Yorke River road site; eventually, the Foundation will designate sites across the Island..




Donations may be made in any amount; in return the donor receives a charitable receipt.  If the donation is to recognize a person, a suitable card will be sent.to the person or the family.  For further information, or to make a donation, phone the Foundation (892-3440) or log on to  HYPERLINK "http://www.cfpei.ca" www.cfpei.ca, click Canada Helps and donate to the Living Trust




30-




Don MacDonald

892-3440

title: 2008 Talking Points 5
summary: Don's position paper on property access dispute at Glenway cottage community. Argues that Glenway is private property owned since 1971, emphasizes cottage owners' rights against encroachment, and questions the McInnis family's access request as a potential opening for further demands.
content_preview:
Meeting about McInnis Requests




Glenway is not a charity. It’s a property holding owned by its cottage lot owners

And should be regarded and treated like private property, just as your house and driveway in town are.




We have owned the glenway property since 1971 and legal access for the McInnis’s

to use our road had never come up until the winter of 2005, 34 years!




Giving someone who is not a property owner access to our road compromises our rights

as property owners. It increases our liability, road erosion, etc and  loss of control without any apparent compensation.

This was certainly not part of our plan when glenway was purchased. The full plan of glenway was apparent from the beginning to everyone who wished to purchase a lot;

Roadways, accesses .covenants, middle lots , common grounds.




Last year glenway roads, accesses, common ground was turned over to the association of lot owners in good faith that care would be taken for the benefit of the owners.




My take on Linda having access on our road  is this.

By now Linda would already have the 14 foot  road access on the McInnis’s own property

And her property lot if it were important  to any of them. They would not wait for

For us to change our mind. Therefore I think this request is a red herring and an opening for the McInnis’s to make further requests.

title: 2008 Wally 3

content_preview:
Perhaps
you are right, that a note on the figure might have clarified the
figure. The executive committee in our conversation confirmed that
most folk agreed that 20' was sufficient, when we were all standing
out at the corner. We used the phrase "approximate" to give
us some negotiating space to work with. For example, Annette later
proposed that one side be 20' and another 30' so that given the 16'
distance in from the pin, we would actually have a more balanced
corner. If the McInnis's are open to deeding the corner, I believe we
can press the case for the 20-30 solution.

 

On
another matter, you may recall that I offered to cut your grass while
you were in Ottawa. The offer is still open if you want it don.

 

Have
a good trip and enjoy the riches of the Capitol.

 

Wallace
Ford

title: 2009-03-New Directors
summary: A detailed January 23, 2009 analysis for the Nominating Committee on recruitment needs. Don identifies four core foundation roles (endowment building, grant-making, community leadership, small business management) and proposes specific new director qualities addressing identified gaps. He advocates recruiting from private sector, recruiting more women and younger people (40-60), and seeking individuals reflecting emerging PEI demographics (technology, manufacturing, youth, aboriginals, immigrants). His specific assessments of individual candidates reveal both shrewd judgment and knowledge of the PEI professional community. Don emphasizes proper orientation, role clarification, and early assignment of responsibilities to engage new directors meaningfully.
content_preview:
COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND




SD-		2009- 03

Date:		January 23 2009	

Prepared by:	Don Glendenning




To:		Nominating Committee




Subject:  	Directors




On receiving a copy of John’s note, I went to my trusty flip chart, with scotch in hand I might add, to doodle while thinking about who we are, what we do, our current status, our priorities for the next 3 years and the strengths to be added through new appointees.  What follows is the result of my analysis. 




A	Community foundations fill three roles: 

building endowments,

 making grants and 

community leadership (this one will increase in importance as we mature).




But we are also running a small but very public business and it should be run efficiently, therefore I would add:

Manage a small business (office operation, IT, records management, contact management, media skills, maintenance program for dono0rs, etc)




B	Based on a wide range of discussions about the future of CFPEI, there seems to be considerable agreement that our priorities should be:

Endowment development

Marketing/promotion

Efficient administration




To that I would add a strength in designing projects and interest funds which would include such strengths as:

Project management (think of IAHSP and literacy initiatives)

Community liaison and leadership




C	The Board should be broadly representative of the community; it is not.  We need:

More directors from private sector; most are now from the public sector

More women

More younger people – 40 – 60 years of age

People who reflect the new face of PEI – high tech, manufacturing, youth, aboriginals, immigrants. research










D	Some miscellaneous thoughts: 

While optics suggest that we should have a professional accountant on our board, the need is lessened because our Exec Director has such a designation

We have great name recognition

In appointing directors, we need to identify people who are potential Presidents and groom them for the role




...

title: 2009-04-Information management
summary: A February 2, 2009 memo proposing comprehensive review of information management systems including contact management, website, office records, and content organization. Don identifies software selection criteria emphasizing remote accessibility, security, backup systems, automatic correspondence generation, and expandability. He recommends surveying sister foundations, establishing written policies, developing RFP terms, and considering open-source and Google Apps solutions. This document demonstrates Don's understanding that organizational effectiveness depends on robust information infrastructure and his willingness to invest in technological solutions supporting institutional operations.
content_preview:
COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND

Prepared by:	Don Glendenning




To:		John, Donnie, Jeniene, Marla




Subject:  Information Management




I believe that we need to review our entire information management system including:

Contact Management

Website

Office records

Content (Policies, procedures, agreements, etc)

Human Resource needs




Hosting options:

Client (In house)

Remote

Web based meaning on our own computer but accessible remotely




General comments

Should try to find a commercial program and modify to suit needs

Identifying needs is usually the major problem; finding software, even free software, is usually not a problem

Human resource needs include someone to lead the conversion and people to enter data

Remote accessibility

24/7 accessibility

Secure

Back-up system

Automatically spawn correspondence

Expandable

Prepare terms of reference for an RFP

Google Apps a good program

Automatically spawning letters may be a costly option; depends on volume

Open source programs are usually light in documentation

title: 2009-1A Constitution
summary: Draft constitutional proposal by Don Glendenning addressing voting rights and board representation in Glenway Estates Association. Demonstrates his governance expertise applied to community association bylaw reform.
content_preview:
Draft 1




Date:		January 12, 2009




To:		Glenway Cottage Owners Association




From:		Don Glendenning




Subject:	Constitution and by laws




Members and Directors:




Article 10:06 states that “Members shall be entitled to one vote for each lot of the Glenway Subdivision owned at any meeting of the membership of the Association but no lot shall be entitled to more than one vote, at any meeting of the membership, notwithstanding the number of registered owners of the lot.  …




Article 6.05 states that “Each lot in the Glenway Subdivision shall be entitled to appoint  one representative to the Board of Directors for each individual lot as set out in the Survey Plan but no subdivided lot shall be entitled to have more than one representative on the Board.  In the event that a member or members own more than one lot, then that member or members may have more than one representative on the Board provided that the representative is a member of the Association.”







Proposal:  To amend article 6.05; Remove sentence in red; an amendment requires 14 days notice and a 2/3 majority vote

title: 2009-2 Wally-constitution
summary: Correspondence from Don to Wally on constitutional bylaw reform for Glenway Estates, written from Florida. Discusses philosophy of consultative decision-making and references his work with Community Foundation of PEI, showing his principles of inclusive governance.
content_preview:
Date;		March 19




To:		Wally




From:		Don




Subject:	Glenway Bylaws




Greetings from Clearwater Beach; we’ve been here a couple of weeks and enjoying it.  Weather has been great.  Not doing much but enjoying it anyway.




We have been having much difficulty with our internet while in Florida; mostly a problem with the hotel internet service but, besides that, I am able to receive messages but not send them except via my web mail.  It is a nuisance to say the least.  We usually visit the library daily to read the papers and use the internet.  As a result, this note comes as an attachment rather than just an Email message.




I’ve finally gotten back to the subject of my earlier Email and I thank you for your comments.  In fact, I have immersed myself in reading the bylaws and recasting some key Articles consistent with your thoughts; I am satisfied that we can make it work as you propose but also think that expanding the number of Directors is also an alternative.  Let me recap.




The residents of Glenway brought into being an Association to protect its interests and carry on its business.  We did this through lengthy discussions; participation was both encouraged and allowed.  I recall at least some participants expressing an interest in retaining the model, a view that I certainly support.  




Since then, and on reflection, I am of the view that our current constitution and bylaws interfere with the consultative process rather than foster it; furthermore, I believe that a broader consultative process should be restored and reinforced.  I would like to see all/most business concluded directly by residents rather than delegated to some and ratified by all later.  The issue, therefore, really about the extent to which we want to open the decision-making process to all residents.  To do this, changes in, or interpretations of, the constitution and by laws will be required.  




As you know, I am active in the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island ...

title: 2009-3 response to Wally
summary: Don's detailed editorial comments on proposed bylaw revisions for Glenway Estates, focusing on governance mechanisms and voting thresholds. Illustrates his attention to procedural detail and democratic principles in association management.
content_preview:
Date:		July 22, 2009




To:		Wally




From:		Don




Subject:	Glenway revisions




Thanks for the draft; it looks good.




Some comments, suggestions, questions and proposed changes:




3.01 l (g) should that be “in the opinion of the members”?

4.05 should the statement be broadened to include “the power to conduct all such business as may benefit the Association”?

7.02 (1)  should that statement not be presented at annual meetings, special meetings or when requested by members?

7.02 (2) If we remove this, who will supervise contractors or employees?    Would think that this should be left in.

9.03 “shall hold office” or “may hold office”?

10.03 (1) confirm or approve the minutes?

10:03 (v) confirm or approve?

14.01 sets out a 2/3 majority for to borrow or mortgage and 15.01 requires 2/3 majority to amend the bylaws. It seems to me that there are other significant issues that should require a 2/3 vote such as the issue of access of last year.  Should we have also have a clause that allows/requires a 2/3 majority for any non-recurring or out-of- the- ordinary motions?

14.01 sets out a 2/3 majority for to borrow or mortgage and 15.01 requires 2/3 majority to amend the bylaws. title: 2009-9 Paper trails
summary: Dated March 8, 2009, Don alerts the Executive Committee to gaps in organizational record-keeping, particularly regarding personnel and board operations. He notes insufficient documentation of staff matters (pay increases, maternity leave, performance reviews, benefits) and missing board/committee minutes, especially those of the Investment Committee. Don emphasizes that directors bear responsibility for record maintenance even when others handle physical filing and recommends a comprehensive board review of record-keeping practices. His concerns about auditor scrutiny and organizational accountability demonstrate his attention to governance and documentation standards.
content_preview:
COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND




SD-		2009- 

Date:		March 8, 2009	

Prepared by:	Don Glendenning




To:		Executive Committee




Subject:  	Paper trails




In the course of working with Donnie and Marla on some office related matters, I became aware of a couple areas where our paper trails are incomplete.




Personnel




I’ve asked Marla to create a personnel section in both our paper and electronic files to include Executive Director, Office Administrator, Volunteers, and Community members of committees and I believe that she has done this already.  I believe that we must have documentation on all of these but others may not.  Marla has been both a volunteer and employee now for some time but I find little, I would say insufficient, information about our dealings with her pay increase, maternity leave, performance reviews, benefits, etc.  The same applies to Donnie although his term with us has been much shorter and simpler.  Based on my brief examination, I would be embarrassed if our auditor should look for a personnel audit trail.




Board and Committee Minutes




In doing my personal yearend review of files, I came across some Board and Committee minutes which I did not plan to keep; I turned them over to Marla and, although many had my notes on them, apparently they filed gaps in our current files.  While I have not checked these files, I have the impression that they are far from complete.  While all should be complete, I am especially concerned about those of the Investment Committee.




General




Directors are responsible for the maintenance of records even though they do not actually maintain them.  




Recommendation




That the Board initiate a review of our record keeping especially those related to personnel and board operations.

title: 2009-Appendix
summary: Guidelines appendix for the Catherine Callbeck Legacy Fund establishing how grants should be directed. The appendix defines literacy broadly to include reading, writing, oral communications, numeracy, problem-solving, and computer skills. Importantly, it focuses funding on adults who have left the formal education system or haven't yet entered it, supports specific initiatives rather than ongoing operational costs, encourages partnerships and team-based approaches, and explicitly excludes research funding. These guidelines reflect Don's pragmatic philosophy of targeted, action-oriented literacy improvement.
content_preview:
APPENDIX B




COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND




The Honourable Catherine Callbeck Legacy Fund







Further to Clause 3 in the agreement to which this attached, the following constitute further guidelines for the making of grants:




For purposes of this agreement, literacy is broadly meant to include reading, writing, oral communications, numeracy, problem solving and computer skills.

The focus of granting is on people who have left the public system (elementary, secondary and postsecondary) or have not yet entered it.

Grants may be made for any relevant activity including the granting of bursaries.

The fund is not intended for the purpose of funding research.

Grants normally will be made in support of an initiative and not simply to support ongoing operational costs of an organization

When feasible, partnerships and teams will be harnessed.

title: 2009-Development Committee TOR-2
summary: Revised Terms of Reference dated November 22, 2008 updating Committee mandate with more focused priority areas: Converting friends to donors, developing donor retention strategy, acquiring trusts administration, establishing community funds, pursuing special initiatives, and increasing awareness. Emphasizes Board recommendation to prioritize existing relationships and fund growth, reflecting refined strategic thinking by November 2008.
content_preview:
November 22, 2008

Development Committee Structure




Board:	




A major function of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island is to build endowments for the purposes of making grants in support of worthy causes throughout Prince Edward Island




Directors:




Directors are expected to seek out and engage people with financial resources in conversations about the Foundation and causes that matter with a view to them becoming friends 




The Development Committee: 




The Development Committee reports to the Board and is tasked to develop and implement a strategy and initiatives to increase Foundation endowment with a particular emphasis on endowment owned by the Foundation.   Based on Foundation experience to date, The Board recommends that priority be given to the following:




1          Friends - to convert to donors




2	Donors - to develop and implement a strategy that encourages donors to continue to use CFPEI services to meet their charitable objectives.  




3	Trusts - to seek out not for profit organizations, that may of may not be registered charities, with an investment portfolio or a desire to establish an investment portfolio with a view to effecting a transfer of investment funds to CFPEI for administration.  Foundation interest is first of all, for unrestricted or restricted funds followed by agency or managed fund.




4	Communities – to encourage the establishment and growth of community funds.




5	Special initiatives – to seek out opportunities and exercise leadership in tapping funds for the benefit of the not-for-profit sector.	




6	Information – to increase the awareness of relevant populations as to the role of CFPEI




Administrative/volunteer Support




8	Promotion – to provide customized support to initiatives described above

title: 2009-Jan-Cva 1
summary: Don's reflective essay 'DACUM at Forty' crediting Canadian innovation and his own role in developing the DACUM (Developing A Curriculum) methodology beginning in 1967-68, tracing its origins and international adoption as a curriculum development approach.
content_preview:
Jan 11, 2009




DACUM AT FORTY




 

As I write this I am reflecting on a recent phone call from a former colleague now retired and living in Alberta by the name of Dave Bell.  It is probably 30 years since we last spoke and at that time he worked for CEIC and was most supportive in the early stages of Holland College.  Not surprising he asked about both CVA and DACUM

 

The DACUM enquiry got me to thinking so I “googled” the internet to find out what is happening and was truly amazed at the apparent interest and commitment to the DACUM approach. In addition, I examined a few charts, or fragments of charts found on the internet , and was amazed at how closely they followed the original criteria. It was interesting to notice how frequently Canada was mentioned in DACUM entries and I certainly concluded that having been trained or certified by the CVA gave practitioners a leg up on the competition.




The view that DACUM originated in Iowa is widespread, and incorrect. Neither the term DACUM nor the process of identifying competencies has any roots in Iowa.  If Iowa is to be given credit for anything it is for using a single sheet of paper to show modules to be learned.  Here’s what my research turned up:




In the mid-1960’s Canada decided to establish an experimental project in each province aimed at unemployed youth; each project was given considerable freedom to operate at the local  level;  probably in late 1967, Robert Adams, an occupational analyst in the Federal Training Branch in Ottawa, was appointed as a member of the Nova Scotia NewStart team

To support the experimental projects initiative, the Federal Government established a project support unit in Ottawa; probably in 1968, Howard Clement, a former Director of the Vocational Curriculum Development Branch in British Columbia became Director

Officials from Ottawa visited a number of training sites in the USA including a Job Corps Program in Clinton, Iowa.  There they saw a one-sheet curriculum, used...

title: 2009-Montgomery
summary: Formal thank you letter dated after May 9, 2009, from Don to Dr. Roy Montgomery for hosting heritage equipment collectors. Don expresses appreciation for Montgomery's detailed knowledge of equipment origins, specifications, and model variations. Letter reflects Don's respect for collectors' expertise and his own background in farming in Northeastern New Brunswick. Shows Don's gracious leadership style and genuine appreciation for community collaboration in heritage preservation.
content_preview:
Dr. Roy Montgomery

176 Willy Birch Road

Birch Hill, PEI

C0B 2C0







Dear Roy:




On behalf of the many interested heritage farm equipment collectors, I want to thank you and Diane for your hospitality on Saturday, May 9, 2009.




Although not a collector myself, I am of the view that not enough is done to preserve our agricultural heritage; seeing your collection and knowing of others who also squirrel away antique equipment and implements, makes me feel better.  Yours is a significant collection and I was impressed by your detailed knowledge of the original owner and year together with detailed specifications and differences by model and year.




I know that I speak for all when I say thanks to you and Diane.  As a practicing medical doctor, I know that your personal free time is scarce but you gave generously of the little available to you.




It was a great day and brought back many memories of my early years on a mixed farm in Northeastern New Brunswick.  I enjoyed the day.







Sincerely







Don Glendenning

Director

title: 2009 Sustainability Program
summary: Major strategic proposal by Don Glendenning (dated September 22, 2002) for CFPEI's Sustainability Program addressing organizational capacity-building in PEI's charitable sector. Based on 2001 survey identifying issues: fiscal sustainability, community profile, volunteer retention, board development, and training. Proposes customized support through HRD coaching, technical consulting, training, workshops, and special-purpose grants to strengthen charitable organizations' effectiveness and community capacity.
content_preview:
August 8, 2009




Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island

119-121 Queen St, Suite 105

Charlottetown, PEI  C1A 4B3




PROPOSED SUSTAINABILITY PROGRAM




BACKGROUND




The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (CFPEI) was incorporated in 1993 and has a Revenue Canada charitable tax number (89001 1190 RR 001) and a charitable tax number for the USA. ( 30-0050801).  CFPEI is one of 140 community foundations in Canada.  It has a Provincial mandate and is governed by 12 Directors from across the Province who are representative of the Island community.  The Foundation is committed to enhancing the quality of life in Prince Edward Island and operates with maximum transparency and public accountability.  




Community foundations provide an infrastructure for people with many different charitable interests to make long-term contributions to their communities through the establishment of endowments.  Foundations solicit and accept charitable gifts for the purpose of establishing endowments, pool the funds for investment and management purposes, and make grants, which reflect the wishes of the donors.  A second major focus is to provide leadership and support to other Non-Governmental Organizations including charitable organizations.  It is the latter issue being addressed by this proposal.




Need




In 2001, the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island conducted a survey of some 40 community groups and organizations with a view to learning more about their organizational needs.  In response to the survey, organizations identified the following major issues:




$	Fiscal sustainability

$	Increasing Community Profile

$	Volunteer Recruitment and Retention

$	Board Development

$	Training and Development




Participants in the survey suggested that the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island could be helpful by:




$	Providing grants to assist organizations with capacity building initiatives

$	Offering or arranging training and development oppo...

Minutes of the Annual Meeting 

                                    Glenway Association Estates




The Annual meeting of the Glenway Estates Inc. Was held on Wednesday, August 4th,2010 at the cottage of Paul Norris, a quorum was present.




Paul Norris, President called the meeting to order and outlined the agenda.  The minutes of the last general meeting held on July 30th, 2009 were read.  Ian Gallaway moved the approval of these minutes, seconded by Thoran Brule.  Motion carried




Liz Lang handed out the Treasurer’s report showing a bank balance of 1649.96.  Moved by Wally, seconded by Don Glendenning that this report be accepted.  Motion carried.




Under New Business:

 It was agreed that Pius McInnis scrape the upper road again in early spring.  Moved by Liz and seconded by Karen.  Motion carried

There was discussion regarding the cutting of an interior swath around the road on the interior side for better visibility as well as trimming the bushes in the bog area.  To be discussed again next year.

The matter of 1 vote per lot or 1 vote per cottage owner was brought up again.  Wally pointed out that the By-Laws were suspended last year for the purpose of the road assessment costs.  They were applied to cottage owners only.  Wally made the motion, seconded by Don G.:     That the present Executive review the existing by-laws and propose changes to be voted on at the next general meeting.  Changes will include the voting procedure(1 vote per lot or 1 vote per cottage owner) The Past President was noted as being a member of the Executive.  The term of office for Executive to be 3 years instead of 2.  This proposal is to be in the hands of the Association members by June 1st, 2111.  Motion carried.




The assessment of 25.00 per lot for the year for the road  was proposed and moved by Wally, seconded by Karen..Motion carried




There being no further business, Wally adjourned the meeting.




Respectfully submitted

Brenda  Reid(Acting Secretary)

title: 2011-2 Hallmore Tractor in Illinois
summary: Continuation of Don's Hallmore tractor research documenting the Illinois search effort. Records how neighbor Dr. Arleon Kelley visited Glenn Heim near Chicago in 2006 and discovered a "nearly mint condition" Hallmore tractor conversion on an Oakland chassis. Documents Don's efforts to locate the tractor for repatriation to PEI and correspondence with museum contacts. Demonstrates Don's collaborative research methods and persistence in heritage preservation across borders.
content_preview:
CF1-Agric-2

The Hallmore Tractor




The Search in Illinois 

by Don Glendenning 




Hall and Stavert was a partnership of Harold Hall and Stanley Stavert established in Charlottetown the 1930s.  They operated a foundry and produced equipment primarily for the agricultural and fishing industry.  Around 1940, they produced a conversion tractor...




Most farm tractors were purpose built, however, during the 1920-1930 period, a number of companies built conversion kits that allowed a farmer to convert his auto (whether a Model A, Chevrolet, Oakland or whatever) so that it could be used as a tractor.  The conversion kit usually consisted of a sturdy rear axle with rear wheels having strong cleats/lugs and was bolted to the car front end just behind the transmission. It was sometime referred to as the poor man’s tractor.   




Although aware of conversion tractors generally, I only became aware that such equipment was manufactured in PEI in 2004 or 2005 through a conversation with Jim Stavert, son of one of the founders of the company.  Jim told me of a phone call from a Mr. Heim from Chicago enquiring about Hall and Stavert.  




Mr. Heim did not respond to Jim’s Email, however, a search of the internet and found an address for Mr. Heim, 15065 Bruce Road, Lockport, Illinois, 6049. (Home:815-838-5015; Work: 708-496-7450; Cell;708-372:7721)




The scene shifts to a summer evening in 2006 at my cottage and a conversation with a neighbour, Dr. Arleon Kelley, now living in Elgin, Iowa.  Knowing that Dr. Kelley traveled frequently on Interstate 80 between Iowa and Indiana, and that Mr. Heim lived outside Chicago and close to that highway, I wondered if Arleon would visit Mr. Heim if the opportunity arose.  On Arleon’s return to Iowa at the end of the summer, he and his wife took time to look up Mr. Heim.  Through a telephone call and later correspondence I learned more about the visit.




Arleon pulled into the Lockport home and, fortunately, Mrs. Heim was home early ...
