title: 2011 Hallmore Tractor
summary: Don's historical research article on the Hallmore Tractor, a 1940s PEI-manufactured conversion kit enabling farmers to convert automobiles into tractors. Demonstrates his interest in local industrial heritage and detailed investigative research.
content_preview:
CF1-Agric-1 



Agricultural Heritage Project


Hallmore Tractor 



By Don Glendenning






	


	Harold Hall and Stanley Stavert, employees of Bruce Stewart
	manufacturing, founded Hall and Stavert in Charlottetown in the
	early 1930’s.  Whereas Hall Manufacturing, established by Harold
	Hall’s father, was widely known for its threshers, fanners, and
	horsepowers, Hall and Stavert was known for its “Marine Hardware
	and Motor Boat Equipment.  Their catalogue No. 21, undated, carries
	such items as hoists, stuffing boxes, steady bearings, pumps and
	fittings, and propellers.  By 1940 they had branched into making
	farm tractors, Hallmore tractors – or to be more precise,
	conversion kits so that farmers could convert their old cars into
	farm tractors.








	


	Most farm tractors were
	purpose built, however, during the 1920-1930 period, a number of
	companies built conversion kits that allowed a farmer to convert his
	auto (whether a Model A, Chevrolet, Oakland or whatever) so that it
	could be used as a tractor.  The conversion kit usually consisted of
	a sturdy rear axle with rear wheels having strong cleats/lugs and
	was bolted to the car front end just behind the transmission. It was
	sometime referred to as the poor man’s tractor.   A farmer
	usually removed the back half of the body of his automobile, from
	the windshield back, detached the rear end and bolted on a tractor
	rear end, the conversion kit, and voila, he had a tractor.  The car
	could be driven in high gear because the gearing found in the new
	rear end gave the tractor the required pulling power.








	


	Around 1940, Hall and Stavert
	produced a conversion tractor.












	


	Although aware of conversion
	tractors generally, I only became aware that such equipment was
	manufactured in PEI in 2004 or 2005 through a conversation with Jim
	Stavert, son of one of the founders of the company.  Jim told me of
	a phone call from a Mr. Heim from Chicago enquiring about Hall and
	Stavert....

title: 2012-07-11 Smittys

The document reflects Don's leadership philosophy emphasizing independent, transparent action and market-based educational reform.

Education:

  
An important factor in determining one’s quality of life
  
Education of our citizens collectively will determine to a significant degree the future of our community and country.  
  
Education is a life-long process of engaging in experiences that have a formative effect on the way one feels, thinks and acts, and is usually expressed in terms of a person’s attitude, knowledge and skill.
  
Our education system is focused on schooling  
  
Credentials and qualifications are not synonamous
  
The public wants meaningful engagements in bringing about changes in education  
  
Change must be immediate, significant and continuous, but planned.

Discussion Paper

September 17, 2012







Education:

Is an important factor in determining one’s quality of life
  
Will determine to a significant degree the future of our community, country and ourselves
  
Is a life-long process of engaging in experiences that have a formative effect on the way we feel, think and act.  
  
As  a system is focused on schooling
  
Benefits from parent and public engagement, politicians and? want meaningful engagements in bringing about the transition.  
  
Needs mechanisms that encourage continuous, but planned change.  
  
Depends upon quality input from all providers but especially the home, the school and community at large.


Credentials and qualifications are not the same. (Not sure where this fits but is very important, can it be said another way?)

Vision:   An education system that is

  
Learner centered


  
Flexible
  
Transparent
  
User friendly
  
Responsive

title: 2012-10-17 Donald's notes
summary: Meeting notes from October 17, 2012, at an Education First Canada Inc. consultation in Stratford, PEI, where Dr. Glendenning participated with Alice Taylor, Wayne MacMillan, and others. The discussion focused on critical educational issues: teacher training for social/emotional development, the role of schools in changing student environments (bullying, drugs, police presence), inflexible systems lacking accountability, and the need to balance schooling versus education. Notes suggest consultation with external stakeholders and establishing baseline assessments before implementing organizational changes.
content_preview:
Education First Canada Inc.

October 17, 2012 meeting

Stratford, PEI




Present: Dr. Don Glendenning, Alice Taylor, Wayne MacMillan, Garth Staples, Donald Arsenault




It was suggested that teacher training should include an orientation related to how to change attitudes particularly in relation to students’ social/emotional development. 




The importance of defining the role of schools in society was noted.




The environment that students experience today is changing: police officers stationed in schools, texting, code of silence, drugs, bullying, ...




Teachers are expected to take on a variety of roles and responsibilities and some teachers are reluctant to engage as they don’t see some of these as being their role.




With bullying, there is a reluctance to respond, to confront. Both sides need help and to learn skills. However, we tend to want to rescue the child who is being bullied and they can become a victim which perpetuates the situation. 




Students and teachers are operating in a stressful environment. With diminishing resources, people are over-worked and they are trying to do the best they can in the context of increased funding pressures and increased expectations (with declining enrolments and program pressures, teachers are handling more programs).




Discipline has become an issue as the school environment can contribute to “acting out” and some teachers may be threatened by students and parents.




There is a need to get back to teaching and to training that reflects the public’s philosophy and values (need more experiential learning until Grade 3 – approach to teacher training should be reviewed: university vs teachers’ college). Mentoring new teachers is perceived as being critically important.




It was suggested that a group of people who are making educational decisions need to have a discussion regarding these issues that also engages people from outside the system (what are the alternatives? Are there success stories that sh...

title: 2012 Charlottetown Royalty Rotary
summary: Don's acceptance remarks for Charlottetown Royalty Rotary Mentor Award (November 2012), acknowledging his wife Carol's support and his colleagues at Holland College and Community Foundation, reflecting on his 45-year Island tenure and gratitude for Islander generosity.
content_preview:
Charlottetown Royalty Rotary

Mentor Award

November 21, 2012

President Catherine, Rotarians, Friends All

Thank you, Norman, for your kind and generous words, and thanks to the Charlottetown Royalty Rotary Club for the honour you have bestowed upon me.

While my mother taught me many things, how to respond to this kind of generosity was not one of them.  All I know to say, therefore, is thank you, thank you, thank you.

While the award is given in my name, I would like to recognize the many people who enabled whatever I was able to do.  

  
First on the list is my wife, Carol, who tended our home and cared for our two children while I did my thing.
  
Then there were the many colleagues at Holland College, at the Community Foundation, and other organizations with whom I worked.  Among my list would be literally hundreds of Islanders who served in a variety of advisory roles in the development of Holland college programs.


In 1968, we were living in Ottawa when I came to the conclusion that it was time for a change.  Two opportunities came to my attention, one in the west coast and the other in the east, and both were to bring a new college on stream.  An offer came first from the west; it didn’t fit right, I turned it down.  Then an offer came from PEI.  I accepted.  My wife often remarked that she knew, when I returned from my interview in Charlottetown, if offered, that was the position I would accept.  The Island was welcoming and I was impressed with the College Planning Committee and their commitment to the challenge of providing an alternative form of education for the youth of PEI. 

At the time, we thought that we would be here for 3-5 years and then move along.  But the Island has a way of taking contro, and here we are some 45 years later

As I have said before, I am in awe of the generosity of Islanders, and as a past Rotarian, I know of at least some of your community activities.  I commend and thank you; our community is the richer for your many con...

NOTES FOR CONVERSATION 

DM, INNOVATION AND HIGHER LEARNING

January 24, 2013




Why am I here:

Education is most important issue of the day

Being retired, I am more free to call attention to things that need change

What the Premier, your Minister and Minister of Education say is important

What I say reflects  what I am hearing

Some of the solutions are my own




My comments:

Could say about any Province

Faults are in the system that we created

No self-correcting mechanism 

In education, decisions are bureaucratic




Institutions 

A school system and not an education system

Bureaucratic

Time based – more students could gain an A if given more time

Batch process

Reading special problem –levels of literacy; parents paying both taxes and tuition




Ideas

Challenge for credit

Qualification authority

Public advisory committee

Massive Open On-Line Course

Community based education advisor



















General

Need external education body/association to raise issues




Priorities

Identify outcomes or competencies (Handout)

Define standards – Rating scale for writing

Establish external qualification authority 

Pass operational control to Units – let them be accountable

Choice as an agent of change




Closing comment:

Is the one I gave my successor

When making decisions, ask yourself how that will impact on individual learners that you know throughout the Island

title: 2014 Premier
summary: Revised speaking notes for Premier conversation emphasizing system deficiencies, absence of self-correcting mechanisms, and proposed solutions including educational think tank and school autonomy. Demonstrates Don's systemic approach to education improvement.
content_preview:
NOTES FOR 

CONVERSATION PREMIER

Date




Why am I here:

Education is most important issue of the day

What the Premier, your Minister and Minister of Education say is important

What I say reflects  what I am hearing

There is a fear among educators about making their vires public

I am happy to tell you what I am telling others




My comments:

Could say about any Province

Faults are in the system that we created

No self-correcting mechanism 

In education, decisions are bureaucratic




Conclusions: 

System is not capable of changing itself

Because government runs schools, every decision becomes a political one

Only sector where no one benefits from an improvement in productivity

We do not have educational standards

No excuse for levels of preparedness of our young people.




Ideas

Challenge for credit

External qualification authority

Educational think tank

Public advisory committee

Apply fog index

School autonomy

Choice as an agent of change




Action by Premier:

Prince Edward Island has a long and proud history in/of education and many have made their mark elsewhere in Canada and, indeed, internationally

The world is changing around us; all sectors need to change to survive and even change dramatically to  thrive; 

Our entrepreneurs compete internationally, so should our schools

I recognize the importance of education; in fact, I consider myself to be an education Premier.

Asking the Minister to put in place a broadly consultative process to develop a vision statement for education for the next 50 years.




Closing comment:

title: 2014 Response from Bridge
summary: September 5, 2014 response from legal counsel Richard Bridge to Don's Question 11 draft, offering technical advice: use "purposes" not "objectives"; follow CRA sample wording; avoid references to "policy makers" (potential political content); provide 4-5 pages of prose rather than bullets; and study CRA guidance on charitable purposes and political activities. Professional legal guidance on navigating CRA requirements.
content_preview:
Response from Bridge

Good evening Don, 




Here are some initial thoughts: 




1. CRA is interested in your "purposes" and activities. The word "purposes" is also used in the Canada Not-for-profit Corporations Act under which you are incorporated. Your purposes appear in your Articles of Incorporation and Articles of Amendment when you revise them. They are the formal legal words that define what you are all about. 




I recommend you not use the words "objective," "mission" or "vision." This causes confusion for the CRA. 




2. Have you studied the CRA's sample purposes wording? Here is a link http://www.cra-arc.gc.ca/chrts-gvng/chrts/pplyng/mdl/mdl-bjcts-eng.html that gives examples of what they look for. They are very particular about the way the purposes are crafted. I recommend you follow the samples as closely as possible.




3. CRA  may not like your reference to policy makers in your purposes. They may consider it to be a political purpose, which is prohibited. Here is the guidance that addresses this topic: http://www.cra-arc.gc.ca/chrts-gvng/chrts/plcy/cps/cps-022-eng.html




4. I think the CRA will want more than bullets describing your activities. I generally craft 4 or 5 pages of prose to tell the story completely and clearly. 




That's all for now.




Richard




On Fri, Sep 5, 2014 at 4:21 PM, Don Glendenning <pei@education2020.ca> wrote:

As discussed, attached is a copy of my response to Question 11 – Objectives and activities; 

I am also attaching a copy of our Vision statement.

 

As I understand it, in return fro your review and comments, you will invoice us for an hour of your professional time.  

 

I look forward to hearing from you

 

Thanks and regards

 

Don Glendenning

The invitation acknowledges DACUM's origins with Robert E. Adams during the 1960s and notes that the discussion would be led by Don Glendenning, Lawrence Coffin, Alice Taylor, and Gaylene Smith, all with extensive DACUM experience. This reflects Don's deep expertise in competency-based curriculum development methodology and his leadership in promoting Canadian educational innovations across PEI.

On
behalf of Education 20/20 Inc. 


I
am pleased to invite you to a presentation 


on










DACUM:
A CANADIAN ACHIEVEMENT






The
event is informal and will provide opportunities to meet and talk 


to
others who share an interest in education. 

The
session, the second of a series of conversations with Island
educators, 



will
be held at the 







Haviland
Club from 4-6:00 pm 


Thursday,
February 12, 2015  







DACUM
(Developing a Curriculum) is a competency based approach to
curriculum development; it was the brainchild of Robert E. Adams,
Director of Training at the Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation,
Yarmouth, Nova Scotia during the late 1960’s.  The presentation and
discussion will be led by Dr. Don Glendenning, Lawrence Coffin, Alice
Taylor and Gaylene Smith, all with extensive experience in using the
model.

















I look
forward to seeing you on January 12.

Don
Glendenning, President






Space
is limited so an early RSVP is requested

pei@education2020.ca






















Education
20/20 inc. is an
independent, broad based, national, not-for-profit education
organization located in Charlottetown; its mission is to support a
quality education for every Canadian.

title: 2015 Description (En)
summary: Description of Excellence in Education Award program established through Education 20/20 Inc., emphasizing engagement between families, schools, and communities. Outlines criteria and philosophy for recognizing effective schools and family involvement.
content_preview:
Excellence
in Education Award – 2015






BACKGROUND






Our
future as individuals and as communities depends to a large degree on
the quality of our education.  Providing a quality education should
be the focus of every government, supporting a quality education the
objective of every teacher and school, and gaining a quality
education a major focus of every citizen.






Thanks to the
generosity of an Island family, Education 20/20 Inc. has established
an awards program as a mechanism to call attention of the public to
important characteristics of effective schools and to provide
recognition to schools for their efforts to implement them.  The
focus of the award is on engagement for, as the National Parent
Teacher Association points out, “when families, schools, and
communities work together student achievement improves, teacher
morale rises and communication increases”. Study after study show
the dramatic impact parental involvement makes to a child's success
in school. In fact, engaging families in their children’s education
improves school achievement, attendance, behaviour and graduation
rates.  The focus of the award will be on the daily operation of the
school and on those items over which the school has substantial
control.    







ELEMENTS OF
ENGAGEMENT






Education 20/20
supports a broad engagement across the institution including:

	


	Student to student based on respect, cultural
	competency, caring, courtesy, tact, honour, cooperation and
	collaboration. 
	










	


	School environment that is welcoming and
	one that is safe and physically and emotionally comfortable, and is
	based on the assumptions of fairness, respect, trust, care, optimism
	and intentionality; a school where
	levels of learning are obvious and pathways well defined, where
	learning cuts across and beyond courses and invites
	students to discuss “big questions” that matter beyond the
	classroom and; teachers who  are on the leading edge of current
	teaching practices...

title: 2015 Description (Fr)
summary: French version of Excellence in Education Award program description, documenting Education 20/20's objectives on family engagement and school effectiveness in French-language context.
content_preview:
Prix
d’excellence en éducation – 2015






Contexte






La
qualité de l’éducation joue un rôle important dans notre avenir,
tant individuel que collectif. Les gouvernements devraient avoir une
éducation de qualité à cœur, l’appui à l’éducation de
qualité devrait être l’objectif de chaque professeur et école et
chaque citoyen doit viser l’obtention d’une éducation de
qualité. 


 


Éducation
20/20 Inc. a établi, grâce à la générosité d’une famille
insulaire, un programme de prix pour sensibiliser le public aux
caractéristiques importantes d’écoles efficaces et de reconnaître
les écoles qui démontrent un effort vers l’application de ces
caractéristiques. Le prix reconnaît surtout l’engagement puisque,
selon le National Parent Teacher Association, « lorsque les
familles, les écoles et les collectivités travaillent ensemble les
résultats des élèves s’améliorent, le moral des professeurs
augmente et la communication augmente ». De nombreuses études
démontrent que l’engagement parental joue un rôle important quant
au succès des enfants à l’école. Quand les familles sont
engagées dans l’éducation de leurs enfants on peut noter des
améliorations dans le rendement scolaire, l’assiduité, le
comportement et les taux d’obtention de diplômes. Le prix vise le
fonctionnement quotidien de l’école et les éléments sur lesquels
l’école exerce un certain pouvoir. 












ÉLÉMENTS
DE L’ENGAGEMENT






Éducation
20/20 appuie l’engagement dans plusieurs aspects à l’intérieur
de l’institution :

	


	Entre élèves :
	le respect, la compétence culturelle, la bienveillance, la
	politesse, le tact, l’honneur, la coopération et la
	collaboration;










	


	Un environnement scolaire
	accueillant, sécuritaire et agréable
	aux niveaux physiques et émotionnels; qui repose sur les principes
	d’équité, de respect, de la confiance, de l’optimisme et
	d’intentionnalité; une école qui définit bien les niveaux
	d’apprentissage et le cheminement, où l’apprentissage dépasse
	les cours et où ...

content_preview:
_____________________________________________________________________________








For immediate release








Open
for nominations








Nominations
are now being accepted by Education 20/20 Inc. for the Excellence in
Education Award.  The award in the amount of $2,500, donated
anonymously in 2014 will recognize a school or learning centre in
Prince Edward Island that best demonstrates engagement in its day to
day activities.  Anyone may nominate and the the award is open to any
school or learning center operating at the K-12 level  









Last
year’s call for nominations, the first for the award, resulted in
11 nominations resulted in made last ear to kinkora Regional High
School


The
Award is based on the view that student achievement improves, teacher
morale rises and communication increases when schools and communities
work together.
 The focus of the award is on engagement in the daily operation of
the school and only those items over which the school has substantial
control such as: communication
with family, culture, community; frequency of community based events
and parent/community involvement in curriculum development and
planning








Education
20/20 Inc. believes in the importance of engagement and the value of
recognition, and has instituted the awards program as a mechanism to
call the attention of the public to important characteristics of
effective schools and to provide some financial support to schools
for their efforts to implement them.  For
the purpose of the award, the following five areas of engagement will
be considered: student
to student engagement, student to teacher engagement, student to
learning materials, student to community partnerships, and parental
involvement. 








An
Awards Committee will be established to review nominations and
recommend a recipient; decisions will be made solely on the basis of
information presented. Anyone
may nominate a school or learning centre, further information and
nomination papers ar...

title: 2015 Minutes of Annual General Meeting  of Glenway Estates Association (1)
summary: Glenway Estates Association meeting minutes from September 2015 with Don as President conducting meetings on road maintenance, property improvements, and community decisions. Shows local community leadership and involvement.
content_preview:
Minutes of Annual General Meeting of Glenway Estates Association

The Annual Meeting of Glenway Estates Assoc. was held at Paul Norris’ cottage on Sept. 2nd 2015 with a quorum present consisting of Don Glendenning, Elizabeth Lang, Donna Tolusso, Arlie Kelley, Donna Meinhard, Ian Galloway, Brenda Reid, and Rollie McInnis.  Donna T. had a proxy vote for the Brulé’s.  David Cairns sent his regrets.

Meeting called to order at 9:30 am by Paul.  The minutes of the last meeting (2012) were approved as written. Moved by Paul, Seconded by Brenda. Carried

President’s Report:  A few informal meetings have been held throughout the year.  Concern has been express over pot holes on the road and ruts on the back road.  Don priced cost of filling them in at $250.00 per load.  Pius’ cost is $235/load.  Consensus is to investigate other companies with a view to putting two (2) layers of fill for pot holes and ruts.  Priority is to fill pot holes on east side with a BobCat (bladed tractor).  Donna M. moved and Rollie seconded to have this work done this Fall.  Motion carried.

Estimate to be obtained for north part of road (ruts) to be done in Spring of 2016.  A friend of Paul is to be approached re the above.

Don Glendenning will contact Dept. of Forestry about planting trees across the back north line 

Treasurer’s Report:

Liz handed out her report indicating a balance of $1037.98.  After a discussion re dues, she moved acceptance of the report and that $50.00 be the dues for 2015.  This was seconded by Iain. Carried.

Cottagers are encouraged to pay dues in a timely fashion.  Make cheques out to Glenway Estates Assoc.  Thank you.

Other business:

A memorial tree for Karen Brulé was discussed.  Donna will pursue the matter with Owen, Madeleine and Mark regarding details.

Erosion on the corner where the entrance road swings towards cottage properties is a concern.  We need to speak to Pius as to how it would impact him if trees were planted.  Donna Meinhard will follow up on th...

title: 2015 Wrap up
summary: Comprehensive post-program analysis document authored by Don reflecting on the inaugural 2014 Education Award and proposing improvements for 2015. Don observes that engagement comes more naturally to early childhood centers than other educational levels and recommends considering this in future awards. He notes wide variation in documentation quality and proposes providing feedback to future applicants about the importance of engagement. Recommends expanding the program to include engagement with community organizations like 4H and Junior Achievement. Suggests media strategy improvements and potential expansion to neighboring provinces. Demonstrates Don's reflective, continuous improvement approach to leadership.
content_preview:
EDUCATION 20/ 20 INC.

Awards Program

Background:




Objectives in launching awards




Nomination Process




Criteria




Scoring




Response

Committee composition and TOR

Selection Process




2014 Award

  
 Institutions nominated spread from east to west, Every level of institution is included  Nominators include staff, parents and the public at large
  
Some were broad based while others focused on a single activity
  
Eleven nominations from across Island representing all levels
  
Most nominations were based on extent to which school met all criteria, however, a few nominations focused on a single event
  
Awardee:  Kinkora Regional High School 54 Anderson Road, Kinkora, PE  C0B 1N0, Tel: 982-887-2424
  
Presentation at Graduation exercises in Kinkora of cheque ($2,500) and award (Wall hanging) 


Observation

  
Engagement comes more naturally to ECE than other levels of schooling.; should we, can we take that into consideration
  
Documentation varied from a single page to four  three-ring binders plus photos 
  
The literature on engagement identCould we add a category about engagement with other community organizations such as 4H, JA, Can Do, and others. Engagement in curriculum developmen
  
We’ve actually been asked to share our “scoring on categories”; while I do not think we should do that, from an educational perspective, some feedback could be useful. Could we prepare a letter or statement about engagement that would be helpful to applicants next year? 
  
Some proposers asked for  a hard copy of documents
  
Our call  for nominations came at the same time as we were announcing our website and starting our workshop series thereby leaving the media unsure of what to report. 
  
The award lends itself to several opportunities – announcement, call for nominations, selected  school and presentation – and maybe others including a follow-up story on how the award money was actually used..

title: 2016 CVA Strategy Summit
summary: These notes from a 2016 CVA Strategy Summit reflect Don's perspective on the association's history, current status, and future directions. Don notes the CVA's unique individual (not institutional) membership model, broad cross-sector participation, historical government partnership roles, and the 1970 emergence of ACCC which drew administrators toward institutional funding. He observes vocational education's shift from content-based to performance-measured definitions and the federal government's reduced leverage for change. Don argues the CVA could become a catalyst for educational change, particularly around "transition" from school to employment. Responding to summit questions about high points, current functioning, and future vision, Don emphasizes the value of personal networking and provincial connections developed at annual conferences. He proposes federal-provincial initiatives using "transition" as an organizing concept and questions whether the CVA could help coordinate training initiatives across regions.
content_preview:
2016 CVA Strategy Summit




CVA

About CVA:

  
CVA Is unique in That It has individuel not institutionnel or corporate memberships, and the focus was very much on ways and means of helping people prepare for and maintain income generating employment.  
  
Members are/were from all provinces, all kinds of institutions, all levels,  employers, schools, colleges, universities and industrial trainers, public and private.
  
In the early days, the federal and provincial governments were more like partners in training the working force ; later it became a buyer-seller relationship; it appears now that the Federal government has simply transferred funds to provinces and influences quality through some consultative arrangement, employer based programs and special NGO arrangements.
  
Advent of ACCC in 1970 drew administrators away from CVA (administrators who controlled funds); focus changed from individuals to institutions and getting a fair share of federal dollars.
  
The Federal government maintained a small core of staff officers (small busniness, industraial training, testing, occupational analysis) ; they were good sources of information about who was doing what and where.





About education:

  
Vocational education can no longer be defined by content;  It differs from general education by way performance is measured
  
Federal government has lost much of its leverage ito effect change ; CVA could become a catalyst for change. 
  
Transition may turn out to be a useful concept around which to initiate change.
  
Need to spark discussion at another level of debate see my letters


Summit questions:

  
What has been a high point experience in the CVA when you felt this association most alive, successful and effective?


For me, the high point was the exchange of information networking which occurred mostly at the annual conference and especially during the informal events.   As a result, I had “friends” in every Province that I could contact about specific matter...

title: 2016  Workplan notes
summary: Project workplan for the Preparedness-2 math competency mapping initiative. Outlines purpose, guiding principles based on DACUM methodology and Bloom's taxonomy, and detailed steps for developing competency-based assessment. References Holland College and reflects Don's expertise in educational competency analysis and workforce readiness—core themes from his Holland College presidency.

Preparedness-2

Workplan  for math map




PURPOSE:

To identify basic math competencies needed by young people proceeding from the public school system to postsecondary education or seeking entry level employment in the local labour market.




GUIDING PRINCIPLES:

  
Competency based
  
DACUM style analysis
  
Criterion referenced
  
 Levels reflective of Bloom’s taxonomy





STEPS

  
Establish a small steering committee


  
Prepare work plan
  
Review existing analysis
  
Develop math rating scale 
  
Identify profiles
  
Develop and test an assessment process

summary: This March 2017 report details Education 20/20's Canada 150 programming plans with five DACUM-related events: Reception, Experience OBE (Outcome-Based Education), Presentation of book to Holland College in memory of Adams, Public presentation on CBE (Competency-Based Education), and CBE Roundtable. Newsletter No. 50 generated mailing list requests. A public meeting on Skill Development is scheduled for April 5 with Bill and Tim at Stratford Town Hall. An "Experience OBE" public workshop is planned for May 16 where participants will identify competencies, determine criteria, and evaluate skills. The Handle with Care program is completed with thanks to Alice Taylor, Eileen Conway-Martin, and Hincks Delcrest Centre. Transition discussions are scheduled with college, university, and education department representatives on April 6 at Royalty Centre to explore mathematics education standardization through a common skills analysis. Only one award nomination has been received (by April 30 deadline). Don is traveling April 14-28 and attending an event on May 9.

title: 2018-Rotary ask
summary: Grant request letter dated October 26, 2018, to Rotary Literacy Foundation requesting financial assistance for numeracy skills mapping project addressing employment/further education transition for young Islanders. Proposes that improved mathematics skills require multi-sector approaches beyond schools alone. Argues analysis benefits multiple users: program planning, qualifications, position descriptions, curriculum development, achievement levels. Emphasizes transparent development process. Acknowledges existing math skill analyses while noting absence of numeracy-specific analysis. Shows Don's focus on practical, evidence-based solutions to specific educational gaps.

Charlottetown. PEI

	October 26, 2018

Dear Sir:

Numeracy
(math) map

Attached is a
request for financial assistance for a project in support improving
numeracy levels of Islanders especially young people in transition to
employment and/or further studies.  It addresses, we suggest, some of
the issues found in found in our media in recent days both in PEI and
elsewhere.






This proposal is
based on the view that:

	

Improving
	skills in mathematics cannot be accomplished only through changes in
	the public schools alone,
	

Communication
	about the issue suffers from the lack of examples of alternatives.
	

An analysis of
	the kind proposed will serve many users and not just public
	education  – program planning, qualifications, position
	descriptions, job classification, curriculum development, levels of
	achievement, etc.
	

It is important
	not to confuse skills and levels 
	
	

The attached
	proposal provides a transparent development process







Whereas we have on

we were unable to secure any analyses of numeracy skills.






I
would be pleased to provide additional information about the proposal

fully.  I commend the Rotary Club of Charlottetown for your many
contributions to our community. 







Sincerely 












Don Glendenning

The document shows Don's commitment to evidence-based, internationally recognized definitions of educational quality and his systematic approach to recognizing schools making quality improvements.

Specifies a three-person local board representing community interests, not education providers. Gentlemen:

An invitation




I am pleased to invite you, as leader of the Xxxxxx Party,along with leaders of other official Parties, to a conversation on the future of public education on Prince Edward Island.  I extend this invitation because of the importance of the subject and the key role to be played by  Government in bringing about improvement.  The conversation, I suggest, should focus on a framework for organizing and managing educational services in the 21st century.

title: 2019-Rural Youth Strategy
summary: Proposal for Employment Skills Centre targeting rural youth in Souris. Program elements include literacy, numeracy, self-management, relationships, IT, and fabrication technologies. Emphasizes practical, hands-on, employment-related instruction using on-the-job training and community-based, competency-based curriculum with performance-based rating scales. Three-person local board provides governance. Shows specialized focus on youth employment skills within broader education initiative. Demonstrates Don's attention to specific demographic needs.

title: 2019 Update-3
summary: **Written by Don.** Dated August 24, 2019, this extended update covers delayed road repairs due to construction industry demand, erosion consultation with PEI Environment Department, a tree removal project at the corner involving Don's family (Mike and Janet), and outlines alternatives for corner reconstruction including stump removal options. Shows Don's practical approach to problem-solving and family involvement in community maintenance.
content_preview:
GLENWAY ESTATES

 Glenway Update-2




  
Gravel for Road: Still waiting; apparently this has been a very busy year for the construction industry; others, including myself, have had slow responses.  Paul is monitoring.
  
Talked with Sherry Pelkey, Belfast Watershed Group,  (902-219-1582) a few days ago, she plans to visit Glenway hopefully this fall and still interested in  some planting at the corner to slow erosion.  
  
Sought some leads and/or recommendation from Sherry as to erosion on cottage lots; also know from the experience of others that repair is somewhat tricky; some interesting information at “PEI Shoreline Erosion”
  
Visited Environment Department, Dale Thompson (902-368-5049) about erosion; He gave me a list of firms that take on erosion projects; he would be happy to tour the Point but they do not recommend individual companies
  
Mike, Janet and I cut down the tree at the corner and removed the wood and am investigating removal of stump; the remaining stump was hollowed out by ants. Thanks to Paul for adding a temporary reflector. The road at the turn has worn down considerably and likely needs some gravel. Spoke with Don MacRae  (902-393-0099) ; probably cost $150-$200 to remove stump)
  
Alternatives for the corner include:


  
Leaving the stump
  
Removing the stump
  
Adding about a foot of gravel
  
Sinking a small stake beside the pin
  
Adding a panel of wooden fencing; anyone driving to the cottage may have note the white wooden railing at the end of a driveway almost directly across from Busters


  
Steps a corner, next to Elizabeth and Gordan, disappeared in recent storm. 
  
Path to west beach no longer passable due crumbling of wooden span across ditch.
  
Misc. items


  
Dead trees cross the back line should be removed; I have a contact in the forestry Department who has agreed to take a look at replanting
  
Suggestion that we find someone (Pius?) who would cut a swath on each side of our road a couple of times each summer – say ...

title: 20220 Minutes of Annual General Meeting of Glenway Estates Association 2020 parts 1and 2
summary: Glenway Estates Association meeting minutes from August 2020 with Don as President overseeing road work, beach access planning, and property maintenance decisions during pandemic. Demonstrates his ongoing community leadership.
content_preview:
Minutes of Annual General Meeting 

of 

Glenway Estates Association 

August 4, 2020

Part 1

The Annual Meeting of the Association was held outdoors at the home of Don and Carol Glendenning.  Social distancing was practiced.  Meeting commenced at 4:00 pm. Don Glendenning as  president called the meeting to order.

Attendees were: Don Glendenning, Elizabeth Lang, Sergio Tolusso, Annette Galloway, Brenda Reid, and Carol McInnis and Paul Norris.

The Agenda was approved as circulated.. 

Brenda moved that the minutes of the last meeting (2019) be approved as written. Seconded by Liz Lang. The motion was carried

The treasurer’s report was presented by Liz and it was reported that the balance was  $1893.82 as of May 31, 2020.  A further $150.00 was received since making a balance of $2043.82.  Extensive road work (laying gravel) was done this spring amounting to $2218.00.  This left a shortfall of approximately $200.00 . The group thanked Paul Norris for organizing this work.  Liz moved that the treasurer’s report be accepted as presented.  Seconded by  Brenda;  Carried.  Sergio moved we assess dues of $100.00 per cottage owner for this year; Paul seconded the motion and carried. 

Projects to be considered for next year:

Beach access on east side: much discussion regarding need.  Carol McInnis suggested each cottage owner should be responsible for his or her stairs.  It was pointed out that the Tolussos cannot do that as at  high tide their stairs would always be under water.  Also renters and guests have used the east access to the sandier beach.  Brenda will obtain an estimate of the cost of these stairs.

Stump removal on east beach corner.  Don or Paul will put a reflector as a  temporary marker.

Gravel:- the common road to the west and south developed serious pothole problems this spring necessitating repairs. 

Brick Gates at entrance:  Carol McInnis brought to the group’s attention that these are in need of repair/refurbishment.  Carol McInnis and Annette G....

title: 21 Mathematics occasional-2
summary: Occasional paper No. 100 by Don examining mathematics education, basic skills deficiency concerns, and comparative analysis of educational systems. Advocates for improved public dialogue on math education and teacher-community collaboration.
content_preview:
Improving
Math

Occasional
paper No. 100							            July 14, 2014	









There is a problem
with basic skills; whether it’s real or imagined, one cannot be
sure but whichever the case, it needs to be dealt with.  It arises
frequently and in a number of contexts; for some there is the concern
about PEI test results, but it is also about getting into
postsecondary studies or securing work, but I also encounter it from
the public at large.  It is not always easy to understand; it hides
under different labels such as basic skills, essential skills,
employability skills, BTSD, literacy and numeracy. I decided to try
to learn more about it and have been talking  with others and
searching the literature to see what pops out.  







My first conclusion
is that exploring basic sills is more than I can handle so I’m
focusing on mathematics I’ve been looking through the literature
and talking with people.  For my exploration, I decided to focus on
the field of math, not that it is a subject of special interest or
study, but because, at least in my experience, it is easier to keep
the conversation on track.  The chances are that, what I learn about
math, will help me understand other subject areas as well.  The
following observations arise from my reading, discussing and
reflecting on the subject:






	

One quickly
	concludes that, compared to other fields, there is a paucity of
	information about mathematics education available in the public
	domain, and the information that is provided is usually somewhat
	peripheral to the issue of improving education, let alone improving
	math: in addition, there is little dialogue between educators and
	the public they serve.  This in spite of the fact that there is a
	significant improvement in the quality of education when teachers,
	parents and the public work together in fostering education.  My own
	review of education studies, for example, did not reveal a practice
	of inclusion of community members  as commission memb...

title: 22 Levels of education
summary: Educational document proposing framework for measuring education levels based on DACUM model, moving beyond credential-based assessment to competency-based evaluation across life roles.
content_preview:
Levels of education				22




Levels




.  The popular method is to measure one’s education by the number of years of formal study, but we all know that that is not a meaningful measure.  Some people add to that the list of ones credentials, high school graduation, Bachelors, Masters degree or Ph. D.  But the value of credentials is declining, perhaps because of the job market, the numbers of people with credentialsm and some would say because of declining standards (social promotion) on which they are granted.  Credentials, professional designations and other third party qualifications are also used as a measure of one’s education.  Readers, I am sure have their own criteria.




Determining  levels, I suggest, depends on a couple of things.  First  are the things a person knows or is able to do; the other is the level of each of ones skills




Leadership, communication skills, languages spoken




Here is an approach based on the DACUM model.  Discernable levels of education:

  
Exercise leadership in some aspects of one or more life roles
  
Functions well in most life roles with obvious special abilities in some
  
Functions adequately in life roles with minimum and occasional support from community
  
Able to function in most life roles with assistance and direction
  
Unable to function in life roles without assistance and direction
  
Unable to function in life roles

title: 23 News Let Puzzler-questions
summary: Don's reflective essay framing education practices as "puzzlers"—areas that don't make logical sense, such as educators predicting learning timelines before meeting students, time-based rather than competency-based progression, and schools being allowed to set their own standards. He lists eight specific puzzles including the absence of family education advocates, teachers being paid for knowledge rather than results, and formula-driven systems. His tone is critical but constructive, suggesting all issues are explainable and defensible but need addressing.
content_preview:
Puzzler=questions ItEducation: it’s a puzzler




I have a friend who often refers to something he cannot understand as being aa puzzler.  While we’ve not actually had this conversation, I think that he would find the education practices as puzzlers;




  
The ability of educators to predict how long it will take for a person to learn a given subject – and to do so even before having met the student.
  
Why young people are required to attende school for a stated length of time rsther than to reach a stated level of learning,
  
Why a sector is allowed to set and apply its own standards
  
Absence of a family advocates: Most families, it seems, have advisors to call on for help, a doctor, lawyer, clergyman, accountant or a banker; we have no equivalent for advice about education.
  
The practice of paid for what they do; teachers, it seems, are paid for what they know.
  
Quality: Time: constant with quality: variable
  
Autonomy: The fact that schools are run directly by a government politicizes most discussion of educational issues
  
Roles and expectations of front line deliverers of educational services are not clear
  
Incentive No recognition for better service or product, or for the same level o seriice or product in a shorter time
  
Formula driven
  
Customer service





As the saying goes, making this connection may be a long stretch but, collectively, I’ve encountered all of them in conversations, I am sure that all are explainable and; many are defendable may be defendable in the interest of better education, all should be dealt with.

.

title: 25-4  Change Real change in education
summary: This foundational document outlines Don's vision for meaningful educational transformation focused on learner outcomes rather than system structure. It emphasizes the critical need for change in PEI's education system, advocating for outcome-based education, flexible scheduling, establishment of a separate qualification authority, and professional education advisors. Don contrasts the gap between what Islanders have and what they want in education, calling for immediate, significant, and continuous planned change. The document proposes bundled interventions including criterion-based assessment, flexible schedules enabling learners to progress at individual pace, and separation of teaching from qualification functions. Don positions himself as an experienced educator and concerned citizen ready to suggest practical improvements based on decades in the field.
content_preview:
Real change in education

To serve learners better

Learner support initiative




  



Education is a lifelong process of participating in experiences that have a formative effect on the way we feel, think and act; this effect is usually expressed in terms of attitudes, skills and knowledge.  The process is called learning; the result is education.  Learning, and  thus our education, can take place anywhere and at any time and may arise from something we do, our family does, an organization we belong to or a school.  Schools play a unique role in our education in that they are the only provider of educational services allowed to award credentials, the folded paper, so esteemed by our society.  Partly because of this, people often think of schooling and education being the same; they’re not but the belief exists.  The practice of measuring 

ed by years of formal education, is a key factor in determining one’s quality of life; in the same way, our collective education will determine to a significant degree the future of our community and country. Because of this, we are among the world leaders in our investment in education to ensure that our citizens, especially our youth, have access to quality educational activities and experiences that will enable them to participate fully in a changing world.  




Our school system developed many years ago; times were different then to meet the educational needs of an earlier age but that age has disappeared; life long employment tending machines and systems has given way to rapidly changing economy with frequent swings, less certainty, greater demand for creativity, flexibility and mobility.  While educators understand these changes, they remain locked into a delivery model they cannot seem to change.  There is a gap between what Islanders have and what they want in the way of education, a gap that is unlikely to make the desired changes by itself.  Not only is there a gap, but Islanders want meaningful engagement in bringin...

title: 25-5 Change 3 Notes
summary: Dated April 11, 2012, this document presents Don's comprehensive framework for enabling educational change. It identifies widespread calls for reform both within and outside the profession, listing systemic issues including bureaucratic governance, lack of learner centeredness, and insufficient innovation support. The paper details critical change elements (change agents, action systems, innovation proposals, action plans) and outlines implementation steps from identifying problems through evaluating progress. Don discusses organizational change theory, emphasizing cultures fostering innovation, collaboration, and risk tolerance. The document includes the "Education First" framework based on the Oregon Education Act of 1991, defining education as formative life experiences and quality as functional ability across life roles. It proposes enabling changes through public engagement, external qualification authority, modernized delivery models, and market forces introduction.

title: 25   Levels
summary:
Detailed educational document presenting three different frameworks for assessing learning and performance levels. Example 1 shows Bloom's Revised Taxonomy (six cognitive levels from Remembering through Creating). Example 2 provides a rating scale for writing (6-level rubric from disorganized/unfocused to creatively written with acceptable standards). Example 3 presents the DACUM rating scale for task performance (6-level scale from satisfactory with constant supervision to performing with initiative, adaptability, and ability to lead others). Demonstrates Don's systematic approach to learning assessment.
- **Key People**: Lorin Anderson (Bloom's Revised Taxonomy)
- **Key Organizations**: None explicitly identified
- **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL
- **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Don's sophisticated understanding of assessment methodologies and learning measurement, essential to his educational leadership.

title: 29 Educators and time
summary: Variant version of File 15 with minor textual differences, including slightly different phrasing ("school as factory" vs "school as a factory") and some editorial variations in the discussion sections. Content and philosophical substance remain consistent with the primary version.
content_preview:
Open
Education					
    




No. 29 										            June 18, 2015






“We
have a powerful need to grade – Hargis”

   



	Make
	time a variable
	

	


	
	

	Most
	service based organizations have found a way to adjust their
	operations to meet the needs of clients.  Courts sit until the case
	is over; patients stay in hospital until they are well enough to go
	home or elsewhere; strawberry growers adjust to late seasons and
	poor weather, and pick strawberries as they ripen.
	

	


	
	

	But
	not schools; they’ve not yet found a way to set a standard, or
	series of standards, and adjust the time and support needed until
	students reach it.  Schools seem to devote a disproportionate
	portion of their time and energy dealing with class schedules, PD
	days, spring breaks, instructional periods, school openings and
	closings, graduations, storm days, absences and attendances, credit
	hours, years of schooling, first year courses, and the list goes on.
	 Schools act as though all students learn at the same pace and, in
	effect, need the same “unit of instruction’ at the same time.  
	
	

	


	
	

	The
	above items need to be dealt with, but they pertain to the operation
	of the “school as factory” rather than school as a centre
	intended to help people develop their full capacities; they are
	important, but they tell nothing about the quality of the product.  
	                                                                 
	
	

	


	
	

	Students
	learn at different rates and there will always be significant
	differences in what people of any age “know and are able to do”.
	 What is needed is a restructuring of the school system in order to
	provide the help students need when they need it.    It can be done;
	it must be  done; it should be a priority.  
	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	Award
	to Prince Street Elementary
	

	


	
	

	Prince
	Street

	Street Elementary School is this year’s winner of the Excellence
	in Educati...

Total budget is $13,775 with detailed breakdowns for committee establishment, background research, skill mapping using DACUM format, rating scale development, profiling, assessment testing, and reporting.

title: 3 ABOUT EDUCATION
summary: Third iteration maintaining core Road of Life framework while expanding content on issues in education. Discusses gaps: ownership/accountability, professional autonomy, market forces, compulsory schooling relevance, quality assurance challenges. Critiques current delivery model as inflexible, bureaucratic, time-based, and administratively convenient rather than learner-centered. Proposes employment preparation transition models and alternative assessment approaches to current static rating scales.

title: 3 Learning Map
summary: Don uses the analogy of roadmaps to learning, recalling childhood journeys with his family from Black River Bridge (New Brunswick) through Chatham to Bathurst (his father's birthplace), traveling via the Frances Ullock ferry across the Miramichi. He advocates for "learning maps" to guide students through educational pathways, noting that Holland College introduced DACUM Charts in 1970 to provide students with overview of learning possibilities and progress tracking. This piece demonstrates his innovative approach to educational planning and student engagement.
content_preview:
About Education

	3

--------------------------------------------------------------------

A learning map

I cannot remember when I saw my first roadmap but it seems to me that it came out of the glove compartment every time we drove beyond Chatham, Nw runswick. Our map  revealed the road from home to Chatham, across the Miramichi on the ferry (Frances Ullock) and north on Route 8 to Bathurst – my father’s place of birth.

My father seldom looked at  the map; he had travelled this road many times before, but it was a point of conversation for other family members.  I still remember conversations about the Little Eskadellic, Big Eskadellic and Tabisintac Rivers and hills as we travelled northward. I sometimes wish my school had provided equivalent maps of the path through British History and the intricacies of algebra. My book case today contains a variety of maps, traditional and learning. They provide a record of where each student had been and some places yet unexplored.

In i970 Holland College introduced leaning maps (called DACUM Charts) to incoming students. They provide an overview of learning possibilities in the emerging learmning learning journey

learning maps provide learners with  the many individual components of their emerging education journey. They also were a place to review and record progress. Report the trip tor family, friends and other institutions and employers. They also provide  a ready reference should you need to recall the experience. 

 Doc/Col/ 3

title: 3 support letter from Rebecca MacPhee@2016-04-30T15;06;23
summary: Support letter from early childhood educator Rebecca MacPhee endorsing Down to Earth Child Care's need for technology funding. Describes how tablets and cameras would enhance outdoor learning documentation, enable child-directed research, support independence, and allow educators to better track developmental progress in natural learning environments.
content_preview:
Dear Selection Committee:










As an early childhood educator employed at Down to Earth Child Care, I believe that the centre (staff and children alike) could benefit greatly from increased opportunity to use technology. 




	Outdoor play is a core piece of our philosophy and combining technology with this could only enhance it. Every day the children play outdoors and discover all that it has to offer; including flowers, insects, birds, tree climbing, and so much more. Adding technology to this experience would allow children to document the things that interest them through photos and research areas of interest with the help of educators to produce immediate results and learning about a breadth of topics chosen by children. Currently this cannot happen as promptly or readily as we would like as we do not have many pieces of technology and children can change activities and focus very quickly, particularly outdoors. We are not able to conduct any research outdoors with the children other than taking photos with a camera.




	Technology can also be used as a tool for accessing songs, books, or videos for the children. The children could choose the thing that they wanted to listen to or watch on their own. This could be used if a child feels they need a break from others, wants to sing, dance, do something new or has an idea they want to explore. This would provide a great opportunity for independence and choice for the children, for example, they would not have to ask an educator to play a certain CD for them. 




	Gaining these tools would allow children to learn the skills to complete a goal or plan they have in mind along with the cognitive skills necessary to gather information and think more deeply about what it is they are doing and want to do next. They will also be able to carry a topic from one day to another as it will remain there for them to return to, unlike something such as a toy which must be cleaned up at the end of the day.




	Increased t...

title: 35 Bi  Basic Skills Gap
summary: Glendenning addresses the gap between school graduates' competencies and employment/post-secondary requirements. He notes limited data on the nature and scope of this gap. The newsletter lists citizenship skills (critical thinking, communication, collaboration, decision-making) and identifies learning partnerships being established in PEI. Glendenning promotes the concept of "rhizomatic learning" from Dave Cormier and announces the screening of "Most Likely to Succeed," a film about project-based learning at High Tech High in San Diego.
content_preview:
Open
Education					
    




35										    December 15, 2015






“The
object of teaching a child is to enable him to get along without a
teacher.” – Elbert Hubbard


	


	
	

	The
	basic skills gap
	

	


	
	

	Recently,
	I was part of a discussion about students who graduate without
	having the skill levels needed to enter employment or further their
	education; we were not long into the discussion before we realized
	that there is not much hard information available about the nature
	of the gap or the number of people affected.  
	
	

	


	
	

	Participants
	took the view that the role of schools is to help young people
	develop the skills of citizenship, but whether the skills of
	citizenship and the skills needed to fill the gaps are the same,
	remains to be determined.  
	
	

	


	
	
A
	search on the Internet revealed the following citizenship skills:
	critical thinking, critical enquiry, making judgements, active
	participation, representing your views to others, evaluation,
	decision making, collaborative working, negotiation, tolerance,
	advocacy, planning and communication.  I am not sure just how one
	teaches or measures citizenship skills but at least the discussion
	has begun.  I’ll report again after our next meeting.

title: 37 - Questions
summary: Glendenning frames educational discourse around essential questions from multiple sources: Neil Postman's teaching questions, Connecticut superintendents' manifesto, and local islanders' concerns about priorities, accountability, and government spending. He reports on Lizzie Yan's UPEI survey of 500+ islanders on large-scale assessments (PISA, PCAP), showing disconnect between actual improvements and public perception. Islanders were unaware that PEI students moved from bottom to middle rankings on PCAP, highlighting importance of education communication and public understanding.
content_preview:
Open
Education					



37										      February 12, 2016










“If you give people good
information, they’ll make good decisions”. – Unknown 



	


	
	

	Some
	interesting questions
	

	


	
	
I
	believe it was Neil Postman in his book entitled Teaching
	as a Subversive Activity
	who suggested that teachers post the following questions where they
	could be seen each morning as they got ready for work:
	



	
	
		


		What
		will I do today that will make a difference for my students?
		


		What
		difference will it make?
		


		How
		will I know?
	
	

	


	
	

	The
	New York Times dated Saturday, March 21, 2015, reported on a
	manifesto published by a dozen school superintendents in Connecticut
	in the form of the following four questions:
	

	


	
	
		


		“What are the most
		worthy outcomes of our public education system?
		


		Are we preparing our
		students for the world they will enter when they graduate?
		


		Is our public
		education system positioned for continuous improvement, as opposed
		to ranking, sorting and punishing?
		


		To what extent do our
		laws increase conformity at the expense of innovation?”
	
	
And,
	here are some questions posed to me by Islanders in recent
	discussions:
	



	
	
		


		Given
		limited dollars, what should our school priorities be?
		


		Who
		decides what services a school will provide?
		


		What
		educational services should our Government pay for?
		


		Why
		should postsecondary dollars be spent on teaching high school level
		subjects? 
		
	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	Large-Scale Assessment
	



	
	
Large-scale
	assessment, one of the measures of school accountability, was
	explored recently by Lizzie Yan, a M.Ed. student at UPEI; her
	survey, of more than 500 people across Prince Edward Island, was
	designed to explore the public’s knowledge and perceptions of
	PISA, PCAP and provincial large-scale tests. Based on the survey,
	Ms. Yan reported that Islanders:

		that students...

Subject:	TOR Executive Committee




The Executive Committee is comprised of the President, Past President, Vice President, Treasurer  and Secretary with the President as Chair.




The role of the Executive committee is to:




Provide leadership to the Foundation




Establish policies and procedures




Monitor and implement agreements




Provide for facilities and administrative support services




Recommend strategies for short and long term operational financing




Identify and manage partnership opportunities




Review and monitor revenue and expenditures




Establish committees




Ensure that the Foundation carries out its mandate

title: 4 Mission-1
summary: Critical analysis of mission statements across Canadian education departments, including PEI, New Brunswick, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, and comparison with Maine and Alberta. Reveals that PEI's mission focus on "developing and delivering high quality programs and curriculum" is narrowly operational rather than transformational. Don argues this reflects incomplete understanding of education's role and suggests PEI confuses school administration with education leadership. Contrasts provincial statements with broader definitions encompassing lifelong learning, democratic citizenship, and personal fulfillment. Concludes with recommendation that PEI reconsider and restate its education mission with greater clarity and ambition.

title: 4 Numeracy
summary: Letter from Don distinguishing between mathematics (theoretical study of number, quantity, and space) and numeracy (applied confidence in using numbers for practical life purposes). He argues that citizenship education would benefit from emphasis on numeracy rather than pure mathematics, drawing on definitions and frameworks from Learning Wales, Ontario, and New Zealand education ministries. He suggests a curriculum shift from math to numeracy could significantly improve mathematical literacy levels in PEI.
content_preview:
Editor:

Let-4

Background




All schools, it seems, teach math, the study of the science of number, quantity and space. it is considered a key skill in all life roles, doing so is designed to “prepare students to solve problems, communicate and reason mathematically, appreciate the value of mathematics, make connections between mathematics and its applications, commit themselves to lifelong learning and become mathematically literate adults using mathematics to contribute to society.” 

Numeracy, on the other hand, has been described as “having the confidence and skill to use numbers and mathematical approaches in all aspects of life - at work, in practical everyday activities at home and beyond, as consumers, in managing our finances, as parents helping our children learn, as patients making sense of health information, as citizens understanding the world about us.”  While I’ve not found a standard list of components, the following seems typical:

“Interpret data, charts and diagrams

Process information

Solve problems

Check answers

Understand and explain solutions

Make decisions based on logical thinking and reasoning.”




Math skills and numeracy skills come from different places. the skills needed for citizenship; should come from a survey of citizens and not from mathematicians, math teachers and others who work in the math  field  - but one hires math teachers to teach them.

On the face of it, it seems   that our needs as  citizens is for numeracy rather than math, Perhaps this would be a better field of study for Islanders that the study of math.  




A switch from math to numeracy would go a long way towards improving math literacy levels in PEI

Sincerely




Don Glendenning 

A long-time student of education

title: 4 Reading Occasional-1
summary: Dated February 28, 2013, this paper documents reading through a learner rather than teacher perspective. Don emphasizes reading as the golden skill and tool for lifelong learning, positioning it as community problem requiring partnership approach. The paper provides comprehensive reading definitions and situates reading within broader communication contexts (listening, writing, speaking). Don creates detailed reading competency lists and performance criteria (range of material, comprehension, fluency, independence, speed, vocabulary, flow). He proposes custom rating scales reflecting public understanding of reading levels, from Level 6 (wide variety of complex materials) through Level 0 (no word recognition). Includes detailed appendix with reading competencies from North Carolina Conference of English Instructors covering comprehension, analysis, interpretation, language/style, and research competencies. Proposes practical activities (Ooka Island programs, tutor lists, common rating scales, reading clinics) and specific recommendations: replace outcomes with competencies, provide personal reading records, establish minimal performance levels, ensure consistent assessment criteria and benchmarks.

title: 4 Reading statistics
summary: Concise compilation of critical reading/literacy statistics documenting problem magnitude: 42 percent of adults lack Level 3 literacy, literacy rates unchanged 1994-2003 despite investment, early Grade 3 reading difficulties linked to later dropout risk, 30 percent of Grade 6 students inadequately prepared, college remediation widespread (three-quarters of community college freshmen need reading/writing/math help, quarter need help in all three subjects). Document reinforces Don's data-driven approach to problem documentation.
content_preview:
READING STATISTICS




Reading: Magnitude of Problem




The magnitude of the problem

  
42 percent of the adult population does not possess level 3 literacy – the level thought to be needed to take full advantage of opportunities present in the global economy.  
  
IALSS Study “Literacy rate did not change between 1994 and 2003
  
Globe and Mail Sept 15, 2009:children who aren’t reading well by the end of Grade 3 are at risk of dropping out or failing to graduate
  
Globe and Mail Sept 15, 2009: estimates that by the end of Grade 6, at lest 30 percent of Canadian students can’t read or write well enough to succeed in school
  
New York Times, March 4, 2011: “About three-quarters of the 17,500 freshmen at the community colleges this year have needed remedial instruction in reading, writing or math, and nearly a quarter of the freshmen have required such instruction in all three subjects. In the past five years, a subset of students deemed “triple low remedial” — with the most severe deficits in all three subjects — has doubled, to 1,000.”
  
Many articles in the Guardian
  
Many grandparents have told me that they have paid or are paying for private instruction in reading
  
That should not happen – unless a specialist says that the child cannot learn to read

title: 4 Reading
summary: Comprehensive April 9, 2013 synthesis of Don's reading education research and advocacy. Positions reading as golden skill and tool for lifelong learning within education framework emphasizing individual potential development across life roles. Emphasizes reading as community problem requiring partnership approach beyond school boundaries. Catalogs extensive statistics on reading challenges, identifies performance levels from emerging pre-reader through expert reader, and details key performance criteria (comprehension, material variety, syntax, fluency, vocabulary, sound-decoding). Documents reading competencies, development strategies, benchmarks, and intervention points. Includes practical proposals: reading as separate report card subject, consistent standards, rating scales, flexible scheduling, summer/evening/Saturday classes, tutoring, reading clinics. Catalogs issues (emphasis gaps, funding continuity, jurisdiction divisions, specialist shortages, professional association absence, parent support gaps, reporting inconsistency). Proposes comprehensive improvement strategy incorporating information, engagement, innovation, recognition, research, early diagnosis, and modernized delivery. Reflects Don's commitment to making reading improvement systematic, community-wide effort.
content_preview:
My Notes

April9, 2013

ALL NOTES ON READING










Our futures, as individuals and as a community, depend, to a large degree, on the nature and level of education available to, and actually attained by, our citizens.  Education helps us to develop our individual potential to the fullest and prepares us for our many life roles* that of an individual, family member, learner, citizen, producer and consumer.  This means engaging in a variety of activities with a view to assembling a variety of skills, knowledge and attitudes supportive of functioning in those life roles.   Based on this thinking, the quality of one’s education would be measured by how well one is able to function in the various life roles.  




One’s education is the result of everything that we learn in our lifetime that has had a formative effect on us.  It starts at birth with some of our most important learning occurring in the first few year of life; skills learned at that time, to a large degree, determine what we become in later life.  Learning is a partnership and nowhere is that partnership more important than in improving the reading level of every citizen. 




Key to success in education generally, is reading, the golden skill, and a tool for lifelong learning.    Statistics reveal the magnitude of the task.  We are aware of the attention given by our Ministers of Education in Atlantic Canada to increasing literacy rates, including reading, and this increased attention appears to be paying dividend.  Reading is a community problem; it cannot be solved by schools alone. Early childhood development sets the stage for reading.  




We recognize that learning to read, and learning to read better, occurs in the context of learning to communicate generally and includes learning to listen, to write and to speak.  We also believe, however, that it is important to understand  each component separately, and propose to commence our examination with the field of reading.  




Written for parents ...

content_preview:
Draft

July 31, 2012

SOME NOTES ON SPEAKING

By

Don Glendenning




About this paper:

This paper is intended as background to discussions about the improvement of communication skills among Islanders of all ages.  Our review of the literature, discussion with people both inside and outside the formal education system and our own beliefs support the view that communication skills are important, that they can be learned, and can be improved through formal instruction.  For the purpose of this initiative, we view the key components as reading, writing, speaking and listening; while usually taught in combination, for the purposes of clarity, each will be dealt with separately.  This is a draft document and expected to continue in that form as we learn more and more about the subject and improvements that are likely to arise are in place and working effectively. 




Speaking:

  
The act of conveying information in spoken language.





Background:

Good listening skills result in better communication skills overall, for listeners and for speakers. Evaluating listening skills requires knowledge of what constitutes good listening--attention given to the speaker, active listening by note-taking, avoiding external distraction, body language and asking follow-up questions.

summary: Extended discussion of criterion-referenced testing principles with emphasis on consistency and bias reduction through separation of teaching and assessment. Glendenning photo thanking Roger Birt for ongoing support. Announces UPEI's Digital Pedagogy Lab Institute (#DigPed) July 13-15, 2016, bringing educators together for hands-on digital tools and pedagogical innovation. content_preview:
Open
Education					
    




41										             June 25, 2016








It is the nature of knowledge
that no one knows everything – Author unknown


	Criterion-referenced
	testing
	

	


	
	

	Criterion-referenced
	testing is an approach to assessment in which a student’s
	performance is compared to a predefined set of criteria or standards
	and not with the work of other test takers.  Criterion-referenced
	tests are used to determine whether a person has reached a
	predetermined level of achievement and results are usually reported
	in terms of pass or fail, a driver’s test or an apprentice exam
	are good examples; all who take the exam may pass or all may fail.
	

	


	
	

	The
	goal with these tests is to determine the level that a candidate has
	achieved on a certain skill or set of skills and to use it as a
	basis for making decisions about job entry, certification, or
	licensure.  The key to criterion referenced testing is
	clearly-stated outcomes, a set of clearly defined levels, an
	external benchmark and the consistent application of the assessment
	process.
	

	The
	assessment process must be transparent and the grades derived should
	be defined in terms a student understands – students should be
	able to trace their grades to the specifics of their performance on
	the tasks that were set. In fact, it is well understood that the
	discussion between teacher and learner about the grade assigned is
	an important part of the learning experience; criterion-referencing
	provides a framework for students and teachers to fully engage in
	the learning process. 
	
	

	Separating
	the teaching and grading process increases consistency and minimizes
	bias.
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	
Presentation
	


	
Don
	Glendenning (right) thanks Roger Birt, President, R. Birt and
	Associates, for his ongoing support for Education 20/20 Inc.

	Pedagogy Lab Institute

	Faculty of Education is hosting PEI's inaugural Digital Pedagogy Lab
