title: 46 2016-11-16 - no. 46 - Challenge
summary: Glendenning reflects on educational reform as "challenge rather than accomplishment," citing UNICEF's 2000 "Quality in Education" report. Two key characteristics remain problematic: relevant curricula/materials and trained teachers using child-centered approaches in well-managed schools. Despite decades of discussion, students still taught in age-level groups, irrelevant content persists, and school-to-postsecondary transitions remain problematic. He discusses Quebec's three-fold school mission: knowledge imparting, social development fostering, and qualification assurance—providing a clear, measurable role for public schools.
content_preview:
Open
	Education                           
	

	

	No. 46										    November 15, 2016
	

	


	




	“Students
	are the main agents of their own development” – Quebec Ministry
	of Education




	


	



	STILL
	A CHALLENGE
	



	
	
Many
	years ago, as part of a performance review, my evaluation leader
	described one of my goals as a “challenge rather than an
	accomplishment”; it was a fair statement and one that often guided
	me in later years.  As a lifelong student and interested observer of
	the education scene, that phrase captures my assessment of
	educational reform in Canada today.   
	
	



	
	
Back
	in 2000, UNICEF published a report   on” Defining Quality in
	Education”.  (See Newsletter No. 15) Although the report includes
	five characteristics, today I address only two: 
	
	



	
	
		


		“Content
		that is reflected in relevant curricula and materials for the
		acquisition of basic skills, especially in the areas of literacy,
		numeracy and skills for life, and knowledge in such areas as
		gender, health, nutrition, HIV/AIDS prevention and peace; 
		
		


		Processes
		through which trained teachers use child-centered teaching
		approaches in well-managed classrooms and schools and skillful
		assessment to facilitate learning and reduce disparities.”
	
	

	


	
	

	Both
	are at the heart of what and how we teach, the core of our
	profession, I would say.  Yet, these are characteristics, I am sorry
	to say, where we’ve made the least progress – students are still
	taught in age level groups, large chunks of time are still consumed
	by content considered by many for not being e relevant and gaps
	still exist in the transition from high school to postsecondary
	education and work. 
	
	

	


	
	

	Until
	we do better concerning these criteria, quality education will
	remain a challenge rather than an accomplishment.

	FOR

title: 5-1 Components of an Education System
summary: Defines education system as community-implemented services supporting citizen education, identifying six key components: governance (leadership, planning, research, coordination), information systems, financing, human resources, essential products and technologies (textbooks, internet access), and service delivery mechanisms (community agencies, counseling, instruction, qualifications).
content_preview:
Ref/5.1

title: 5-Achievemment levels
summary: Strategic problem-solution document identifying gaps between school-provided education and community/employer needs. Frames three possible purposes: better define the gap, narrow the gap, or provide alternative instruction. Raises critical questions about education's purpose on PEI, schooling objectives, subject-specific goals, and school responsibility to employers and postsecondary institutions. Identifies potential interventions: common skill/competency analysis, recognized achievement levels, improved reporting, and independent assessment bodies. Distinguishes between communication interventions (stakeholder engagement), gap-narrowing strategies (partner engagement, employer testing, independent qualification bodies), and research approaches (meeting with ministers, undertaking research). Represents Don's systematic thinking about educational system change across multiple intervention points.

title: 5 Education servicces
summary: A framework document defining teaching as a service—creating experiences that facilitate learning. Don identifies key education services (information, counselling, instruction, quality assurance, learning products/technology, funding, human resources) that should be available to all learners. He emphasizes that schools are facilities designed to support learning and teaching, not the learning itself, drawing parallels with healthcare models.
content_preview:
About Education

EDUCATION SERVICES




Education is a service with a focus on creating circumstances or experiences that will help people learn; surprisingly, the literature seldom mentions them. The literature suggests the following typical forms of help:

We talk often about teaching but we seldom describe what teachers actually do; here’s how I see it.

Teaching is a service; it is a matter of creating experiences that allow or cause others to learn. Typical education services as identified by the Business Roundtable:

•	Information 

•	Counselling. 

•	Instruction  

•	Quality assurance 

•	Learning products and Technology 

•	Funding 

•	Human resources

The above services should be available to all learners




Learning and teaching can take place most anywhere; schools are rooms or facilities designed and equipped to support learning and teaching. Teachers in those schools provide the services listed above.

Health has such services as xray, medicine, exercise, rest, referrals





































Doc/Col  5

title: 500 CRSP
summary: Don describes his most ambitious consulting project: designing the Canadian Restructured School Plan to provide an alternative to lock-step, teacher-centered classroom systems. The model emphasizes personalization, competency-based content drawn from real life, computer-assisted delivery, flexible structure, and site-based management. CRSP tracks students from entry through exit based on competency mastery rather than time served. The methodology included a national steering committee, literature review, focus groups, visits to innovative schools across Canada, and consultation with 40 educational leaders. The model identifies major shifts from time-bound to flexible curricula, graded to continuous progress, and teacher-centered to learner-centered instruction.
content_preview:
DACUM







	DACUM has come a long way since the first analysis was undertaken in Ottawa in January of 1968.  For people not familiar with the term, DACUM is an acronym for Design A Curriculum and is a widely accepted approach to identifying competencies being practiced or to be learned – and it is no longer limited to an analysis of traditional occupations. And it is a Canadian idea at that.

 

DACUM is most widely used  as a rigorous, relevant, inexpensive and internally consistent approach  to identifying competencies in a field or occupation.  A major strength is the reliance on practitioners as the major source of information and a presentation of the competencies of a field on a single sheet..  As a result, DACUM escapes the semantics of the academic.  It is life based rather than research based and, therefore, is readily understood by people in the field since it reflects what they do and is stated in a language that the field understands.




The performance-based rating scale proposed by Adams is unique.  It includes all the required elements of a good rating scale ─ competencies, performance criteria, a scale, and benchmarks.  While it does not have rubrics or exemplars, they can easily be prepared.  On the other hand, it has benchmarks (industry-based ones) which are missing in most other assessment systems I’ve seen.  In my reading and discussion, I have not found an assessment system as complete.




A DACUM analysis is a tremendous tool for identifying and planning learning resources.  For each competency, one can identify the kind of human resource expertise required; facilities, equipment and supplies; appropriate learning activities; assessment techniques and strategies; and the best location for learning whether it be a classroom, laboratory, shop or actually in a real work situation.  




The model provides recognition for prior learning, self assessment, instructor confirmatiob of achievements,  a tool for career planning, a basis for learning...

title: 500 DACUM
summary: Don provides comprehensive analysis of DACUM (Design A Curriculum), a Canadian innovation for identifying competencies in occupations and fields. He credits its rigor, relevance, low cost, and internal consistency. DACUM's strength lies in consulting practitioners and presenting competencies on a single sheet in language practitioners understand—life-based rather than academically abstract. Don praises Adams' performance-based rating scale with benchmarks and competency-based criteria. He describes DACUM's applications in resource planning, prior learning recognition, career planning, and certification. However, wider adoption suffers because the acronym includes "curriculum" (DACUM is a planning tool, not curriculum), its origins in adult education rather than academic settings, its shift of control from teacher to learner, and its demand for more rigorous rating scales than traditional schools employ.

title: 500 If the Learner Hasn
summary: Don reflects on his teaching journey and the moment when his understanding of the learning-teaching process crystallized. He recalls being a teacher before understanding pedagogy deeply, attributing this partly to his circumstances: small high school background, brief six-month initial training, youth, and one-room schoolhouse experience. Later, through formal study and varied professional experiences, his understanding deepened. Don describes using the provocative statement "If the learner hasn't learned, the teacher hasn't taught" in teacher education settings, which animated debate. He defends this principle against objections by noting that while learning may occur in groups, it is inherently individual—teachers must succeed with each learner, not groups.
content_preview:
If the Learner Hasn’t Learned







Unfortunately, at least for my students, I taught for several years before I began to understand the teaching-learning process.  I say this, not in the sense of blaming my professors but rather because of the likely negative impact on my early students caused by my deficiencies.  Perhaps it was because I was a graduate from a small high school, because my initial teacher training was only of six months duration, because I was still not 18 years at the time or even because I was in a none-room school – or most likely because of some combination of the above.




In any case, my understanding of teaching and learning only jelled yeas after my teaching career was well under way.  Thanks to additional formal study, learning on the job, and a variety of both learning and life experiences, I began to gain a better and deeper insight into the teaching-learning interaction.




At one point in my career, I was fortunate to play a role in the teaching of teachers both on a full-time and part-time basis it was an experience that I thoroughly enjoyed and will always treasure.  The following statement always brought animated discussion:




If the learner hasn’t learned,

The teacher hasn’t taught.




I believed the statement then and still believe it now, a fact that tended to sharpen debate.




The role of a teacher is to help others learn; if the learner in question hasn’t learned what he/she was being taught, then it is obvious that the teacher hasn’t taught.  But, my students would counter, surely some of the learners in my class would learn.  My point, however, is that groups do not learn.  Granted individuals may learn in a group-setting but learning is an individual matter.  When you refer to learning, you are referring to specific individuals.




The reason for a learner not learning may reside outside a learner; the learner may not be ready, not be motivated or even have a learning impediment.  Whatever the reason, if a student ...

title: 500 Not a competition
summary: Don argues schools should not operate on competitive principles despite teaching competition. He advocates for individual learning progress without public grade posting or student ranking, which he views as sorting rather than educating. Don contends that reaching an "A" level is achievable for most students with additional time, questioning why schools artificially limit achievement through time constraints rather than allowing flexible completion. He critiques schools for penalizing students by forcing them to advance before achieving mastery. Notably, he reports that over 50 percent of US high schools had discontinued ranking by the time of writing. Don's own memory of a grade 8-9 ranking ceremony lasting impression, prompting lifelong reflection on its impact. He advocates discontinuing ranking and redirecting resources toward raising performance levels for all students.
content_preview:
School is not a Competition 







Whether I stand first or last in my school class is my business and only my business.  I go to school for help with my learning, and I resent my grades being posted for all to see.  If I want someone to know what my grades are, I will tell them.  I have no evidence that posting my grades helps my education.




On the other hand, if I enter a competition, I expect to be ranked, and have my rank made public.  But enrolling in an educational institution is not a race, not a competition – or it shouldn’t be.  Institutions that rank students and publicize the results are doing their students a disservice.  While schools may teach competition, it should not be run on a competitive basis.




Reaching an A level of performance in any subject is within reach of most students if given a few more hours of instruction.  If an A is important, why not give students time to reach it?  How long it takes to learn a skill and how quickly one can perform it are quite separate issues. Grades, at least theoretically, point to how much and how well a student learned in a given period of time; grades do not tell how much a student can do or how well in a given time – and it is the latter that counts outside of school.  .  Unfortunately, schools place limits on the achievement of many students by making time the constant and achievement the variable.  Instead of designing a system that allows all students to reach the top level, Schools impose time limits that force some students to quit before they reach the level of which they are capable.  Our current arrangement is to allow only one student to reach the top of the mountain each year and is the student, not the school that gets penalized.




Now I am not against student competitions and the recognition of high standing gained therein or for awarding prizes and publicity to winners.  In fact, I think that there should be more competitions and rewards for educational accomplishments.  My view, howeve...

title: 6 Education, Meaning
summary: Philosophical exploration of education as concept, encompassing personal development across the lifespan. Defines education as aggregate of experiences that measurably change how people think, feel, believe, and act. Explains that education is multifaceted, occurring anywhere and anytime, and depends on self, family, community, travel, and schools. Includes definitions from international sources including OECD, UNESCO, World Bank, and provincial ministries. Warns again that World Bank identifies "going to school equals education" as problematic in developing countries and PEI. Provides recommendations for PEI to establish common terminology, define education comprehensively, and implement system-wide clarification efforts for meaningful community conversation.
content_preview:
About

EDUCATION

title: 6 PurposeDoc
summary: Don discusses the Oregon Department of Education's "life roles" model (individual, family member, citizen, student, producer, consumer) and applies it to education's purpose. He criticizes the lack of clear purpose in government education investment, advocating that governments explicitly define what they hope to accomplish through education to enable system effectiveness. This reflective piece dates from around 2023.
content_preview:
About Education

	

Purpose

We all have our own reason for pursuing, improvingand  growing our education. For most people, improving education increases their likelihood of surviving and thriving in future years; it may also increase salary and ensure long term employment. Communities also support education in the expectation that it will improve the community as a place to live.

In thinking about education, I use the “life roles” model developed by the Oregon Department of Education. According to Oregon, we each fill six life roles: individual, family member, citizen, student, producer and consumer. Presumably education contributes to all.

But it is unclar just what our Government hopes to accomplish through its investment

•	The transmission of knowledge, skills and character traits

•	The act or process of imparting or acquiring knowledge 

•	The knowledge or  training acquired by the education process

I write this in order to encourage the Department to review and clarify its purpose because the Department’s definition is not clear and, furthermore, a clear purpose is required to have a strong system.







Educ Col 6

title: 6 Qualifications
summary: One of Don's most important conceptual contributions, this document meticulously distinguishes between credentials (diplomas and degrees signifying program completion) and qualifications (actual demonstrated competencies and ability to perform). Don argues that schools have become confused about their role, conflating the awarding of credentials with certifying qualifications. He proposes establishing an independent "Qualification Authority" (AQUA) to assess and certify actual competencies separately from educational institutions. This would reduce bias, enable lifelong learning, and allow educators to focus on teaching rather than sorting. The AQUA would operate on fee-for-service basis with advisory panels and serve all Atlantic Canada, potentially based on PEI. The document includes extensive discussion of how this confusion hampers both education and employment.
content_preview:
Qualifications







Introduction











Canadians
are great travelers, many have passports.  Passports are issued by
one’s home country, provide basic information about the bearer and,
if examined, provide some insight into the exciting places travelled.
  Many Canadians also hold visas, but they differ from passports. 
Visas, on the other hand, are issued by a receiving country, involve
a more detailed level of scrutiny by the receiving country, specify
the purpose of the visit and provide some detail as to activities to
be carried on; often travelers require both a passport and visa. 
Seems to me that similar statements could be said about credentials
and qualification

and
are welcomed  all over the world.  







Credentials




Definition,
characteristics, origin, who needs, how used


Diploma,
according to Wikipedia, is of Greek origin meaning  "folded
paper", and is a document issued by an educational institution
indicating that the holder has completed a certain programme of
studies; degrees are also granted by educational institutions on a
similar basis.  Degrees and diplomas are considered credentials in
that they may provide entrance into an arena but are not an indicator

title: 7 Rating Scale -DACUM
summary: The DACUM (Developing A Curriculum) rating scale presents a six-level performance assessment framework ranging from 0 (cannot perform satisfactorily) to 6 (can perform with initiative and can lead others). Intermediate levels assess supervision and assistance requirements, speed, quality, and adaptability. This competency-based assessment tool was central to Holland College's outcomes-based education model and demonstrates Don's commitment to measurable performance standards in technical and vocational education.

title: 7 Tomorrow 1
summary: Don identifies likely changes in education including increased school autonomy, personal profiles replacing grades, learning guides replacing lesson plans, self-rating as assessment, learning maps, outcome-based tracking, and better documentation. He argues that educational change is glacially slow, requiring more than forty years to implement, reflecting his long experience observing education systems.

title: 74 Games wih Grades
summary: This newsletter presents Don's analysis of government's role in education systems. The document outlines typical education functions including governance, leadership, quality assurance, instruction, learning products, technology, information/counselling, funding, human resources, and grading. Drawing on Friedman's economic framework, Don explores which services government should provide versus which should be market-driven. He discusses voucher systems, self-governing schools, local education authorities (LEA), and the tension between denationalization and universal access. The piece reflects sophisticated thinking about education infrastructure and government responsibility. Text appears partially incomplete due to document formatting issues.

title: 75 School functions
summary: Don articulates his vision of teacher roles for innovative schools in 2020. Rather than including grading and evaluation, he identifies twelve core instructor functions: assisting in program design, informing and counselling, creating learning environments, evaluating resources, supporting self-learning, communication, community interaction, learning management, resource development, competency building, administrative duties, and needs diagnosis. Notably absent from this list is grading, which Don designates as a regulatory rather than teaching function. He references international practice where qualification bodies handle assessment, noting Canada and USA as exceptions. Includes brief discussion of federal government's lapsed leadership in vocational training and historical technical education programs (Technical Education Act of 1919).

title: 76 school Assessment,,,
summary: Comprehensive article by Don on school assessment, defining three grading elements (formative assessment/feedback, summative evaluation, and ranking) based on Robert Paul Wolff's 1969 "A Discourse on Grading." Don argues that assessing for proficiency assignment and ranking may conflict with teaching functions, citing examples from apprenticeship, International Baccalaureate, and qualification authorities where teaching and grading are separated. He proposes using "Level" terminology rather than "Grade" to distinguish achievement levels from administrative groupings, addressing student, parent, and teacher stress about testing and grading.

title: 79 Not a teaching function
summary: Don distinguishes between assessment (gathering information for improvement in dialogue with learners) and grading (applying standardized measurement to determine achievement levels). He argues grading is inherently a regulatory function and may damage teacher-student relationships if teachers perform it. Notes grading's high-stakes nature demands fairness and objectivity, which is why many developed countries use independent qualification authorities. Proposes an Atlantic Qualification Authority to serve the region, potentially hosted in PEI. Reports significant reader response to his earlier "Grades as Capitalism" article with mixed support and varying viewpoints. Discusses student absenteeism, citing Washington Post research showing 40% of high-absence students from low-income families benefit from sense of belonging, academic purpose, relevant instruction, career pathways, homework support, and strong relationships.

Open

	2019
	
“…
	let's end the cultural bias against
	vocational education” -  Westacott (Australia)



	


	
	

	NOT
	A TEACHING FUNCTION
	

	Assessment
	is an integral part of teaching; it is a process of gathering
	information about a performance for the purpose of initiating
	improvement.  Results are the subject of discussion between learner
	and teacher and play a role in formulating the next steps in the
	learning/teaching process.  
	
	

	


	
	

	Not
	so for grading; it  is a process of applying standardized 
	measurement to determine a person’s level of achievement. Grading
	is a regulatory function and, if administered by teachers may even
	damage the teacher student relationship.  
	
	

	


	
	

	Grading
	is a high stakes function; it deserves  fairness and objectivity,
	that’s why many developed countries have turned to qualification
	authorities.  Apprenticeship presents an appropriate separation
	between the teaching and grading function.  Perhaps it’s time for

title: 8 Math levels
summary: A refined proposal document (dated July 15, 2015) further developing the mathematics proficiency assessment system. This version distills key findings: current education lacks recognized subject analysis and separates teaching from assessment functions. Don proposes a systematic approach using mathematics as a pilot: analyze the field, identify proficiency levels, produce assessment models, and establish independent assessment bodies. Services would be independent of schools, employers, and government; non-competitive; and confidential. The document cites successful existing models (Apprenticeship Red Seal, Red Cross Swim Program, Royal Canadian Conservatory of Music) demonstrating that subject-specific proficiency certification is viable and beneficial.

title: 80 Information
summary: Brief introductory document serving as a preamble to a collection of Don's observations about significant education movements, projects, initiatives, and developments he encountered as observer and participant in the education field.
content_preview:
80 – INFORMATION










As an observer and participant in the education field, I have encountered many movements, projects, initiatives, developments and ideas of interest.  The following pages describe briefly some that remain relevant and significant to education for and in the future.

title: 80 Turmoil in Curriculum
summary: Open Education No. 80 (September 15, 2019), authored by Don Glendenning discussing curriculum reform movements in Canada and internationally. He notes Ontario's introduction of math teacher testing, Alberta's curriculum overhaul emphasizing essential skills, UK and Australia adding numeracy courses. Don identifies key questions: content expansion vs. fluency improvement; competency versus content base; community input on practical math needs; student practice application; support material format; teacher math application training; citizen numeracy requirements. He proposes overarching curriculum principles: separate teaching and grading; replace credentials with qualifications; base programs on needed/practiced skills; implement dynamic assessment; modernize report cards; improve accountability; introduce differentiated staffing; ensure professional autonomy.

title: 80 Turmoil in Education
summary: Don welcomes the education system upheaval occurring across Canada. Ontario plans to introduce math teaching assessments for new teachers; Alberta undertaking curriculum overhaul with focus on essential skills and past-practice review. UK and Australia adopting numeracy initiatives. PEI communities express concern about youth math skills. Don advocates for systemic reforms including replacing curriculum outcomes with competencies, aligning competencies with citizen needs, switching from credentials to qualifications, adopting dynamic progress-rating approaches, clarifying accountabilities, increasing stakeholder dialogue, and extending learner practice time. His optimism about educational "turmoil" reflects belief that these disruptions enable meaningful systemic improvement. Demonstrates Don's long view of education transformation.

Open

	No. 80					   			                     September
	15,  2019
	
“Education

	IN EDUCATION

title: 81 Report cards

Notes dynamic/holistic rating scales appeared in 1960s and are now trending upward. Includes anecdote about Holland College's early years wrestling with resource allocation between support for Islander education versus local employment. Reflects his professional experience with educational reform timelines.

title: 81docx
summary: French-language column by Don on workforce transition and professional training. Written as editor of "Pédagogie Ouverte," discusses the distinction between occupational training and academic education, workforce shortages in PEI construction trades, and the need for continued learning services. References the recent Green Book on New Brunswick education reform. Reflects Don's post-Holland College consulting work and advocacy for career-responsive education systems.
content_preview:
PÉDAGOGIE OUVERTE

No. 81										20 octobre, 2019

Nous devons réorienter notre système d’éducation pour répondre aux besoins et défis du marché du travail d’aujourd’hui. – Atlantic Business




					Transition vers l’emploi

Je suis un diplômé de la première école secondaire rurale du Nouveau-Brunswick. Malgré la taille réduite de cette école, le curriculum comprenait le jardinage, le travail manuel en atelier, l’éducation ménagère et l’artisanat. Je fais également partie d’un petit groupe d’individus formés au Nouveau-Brunswick pour l’enseignement des matières académiques et professionnelles. Il m’a fallu un peu de temps pour différencier les deux.

À mes débuts, les matières professionnelles consistaient à remplir des locaux d’élèves occupés à étudier avec des équipements ou machines. Au fil du temps, au Holland College, j’ai pu observer des adeptes du passe-temps occupés à utiliser les mêmes types d’appareils ou équipements servant à la formation professionnelle. J’en ai conclu que la formation professionnelle, en soi, n’est pas définie par les équipements utilisés mais plutôt par les objectifs de leur fonction éventuelle en formation. Ces  objectifs, semble-t-il, déterminent l’éventail, le niveau et la nature de leur utilisation.

Alors que l’avancement d’années scolaires est relié surtout aux examens annuels, les cours visant l’accession à l’emploi doivent habituellement se concentrer sur des caractéristiques telles que :

  
La qualité du travail;
  
Le volume de travail;
  
La résolution de problèmes;
  
Le leadership;
  
La fiabilité;
  
L’encadrement et
  
le besoin d’assistance.


Veuillez vous attendre à davantage de discussion sur cette question.

					Pénurie de main d’œuvre

L’Île-du-Prince-Édouard connaît une pénurie de main d’œuvre dans les domaines de la construction, notamment en menuiserie, en électricité et en soudure; l’atelier de carrosserie qui s’occupe de l’entretien de ma voiture connaît également des difficultés dans le recrutement de pe...

title: 86 Peformance factors
summary: Don outlines shift from student grades to learner performance appraisal. Performance on a subject depends on four factors: number of competencies mastered, range demonstrated, clustering nature/extent, and performance levels on specific competencies. Individual skill performance differs based on: consistency across skills, assistance needed, completion time, math fluency, discussion comfort, complex problem-solving, and result accuracy. Dynamic rating scales include significant judgment components that some record systems cannot accommodate. References Harvard study of 6,000 college freshmen showing algebra, geometry, and trigonometry (not calculus) predict college success. Chicago schools developing soft skills produced students with higher grades, fewer absences, better behavior, improved graduation rates, and increased college attendance. London Times reports secondary math often as irrelevant as ancient Greek; National Numeracy head proposes dividing math GCSE into classical (optional) and modern tracks.

title: 88 Learning
summary: This undated piece (April 15, 2020, No. 88) presents Don's foundational beliefs about learners and education, again referencing Dewey's emphasis on understanding people's beliefs. Key beliefs include: learning is personal, most people can learn needed modern-economy skills, teachers design experiences for behavioral change, grading is not an educational function, and qualifications differ from credentials. The document also lists government investment rationales and responsibilities, emphasizing that learners need advocates, schools lack self-correcting mechanisms, and instruction should prepare students for qualifications rather than just credentials.

title: 89 Accoubtability
summary: Article No. 89 (June 4, 2020) titled "PEI Ignores Recommendations to Improve Education" restates PEI's official education goals (from policy documents) and provides formal definitions of accountability from the Canadian Oxford Dictionary. Don lists 15 official education goals (ranging from developing intellectual curiosity and critical thinking to understanding gender equity and human rights) and notes that although family and community roles are important, the school curriculum is considered prime in addressing these goals. He emphasizes that accountability is essential to any sustained human relationship and requires both parties (educator and learner) to account for their actions.

title: 9 DACUM rating scale
summary: Presents two complementary frameworks for assessing learning outcomes: Bloom's Cognitive Domain levels (6-level scale from remembering to creating) and DACUM competency rating scale (0-6 scale from cannot perform to can lead others). The DACUM scale emphasizes progression from supervised task performance to independent excellence to leadership capability. This reflects Don's focus on practical competency development and his belief that learning should enable people to contribute productively and lead in their communities.

visuals

Cognitive Domain

  
    
      
        
1 Remembering: Recall previous learned information.

 and interpretation of instructions and problems. State a problem in one's own words.

title: 90-- Foundational Bellief
summary: Article No. 90 (February 20, 2020) outlines foundational beliefs (learning is behavioral change, observable and measurable; education is gestalt of formative experiences; teaching creates behavioral-change strategies; groups don't learn but individuals learn in groups; most people can learn modern-economy skills). The piece references OECD research on teacher quality, noting that "the largest source of variation in student learning is attributable to differences in what students bring to school" and that teacher factors are more important than school variables influencing achievement. Don emphasizes that teacher quality matters more than academic knowledge alone—conveying ideas effectively, creating learning environments, enthusiasm, and creativity are equally important. This piece synthesizes research with his educational philosophy.

title: 90 Modest proposals
summary: Brief introductory document indicating this section contains Don's proposals for educational ideas he believed should be tried. Serves as organizational preface to proposal-based essays.
content_preview:
90 - SOME MODEST PROPOSALS







From time to time, I have thought about some ideas that I would like to see tried.  The pages that follow briefly describer a  few of those ideas.

title: 92- Challenge for Credit
summary: Don proposes that all schools, colleges, and universities offering courses for credit should allow students to challenge for credit without formal enrollment. Educational institutions already assess prior learning (especially experiential), award advanced standing, and allow some students to skip grades. Don's personal experiences include exemption from a foreign language course and direct university entry from Grade 11. His proposal extends these practices universally. He argues this is crucial because society is "driven by credentials" available primarily through educational institutions, yet individuals acquire knowledge outside formal enrollment. Allowing challenge examinations would enable students to validate learning from any source—work experience, self-study, non-traditional training—and obtain essential credentials.
content_preview:
92 – CHALLENGE FOR CREDIT







Schools, colleges and universities not only teach those who enroll but they also sort.  That is, these institutions assess what has been learned and certify the student’s level of achievement.  What is to be learned is grouped into subjects and credits and achievement is measured in a formal way at least twice a year and sometimes more often.  In addition, achievement is measured throughout the school year through assignments, projects and short tests or quizzes.  




The end result is that twice a year each student’s achievement on each subject is formally measured and a rating or grade established.  A procedure for assessment and recording results is in place and appears to work smoothly.  Based on the results, credits may be awarded or withheld.




In addition, some institutions allow selected students to skip grades or take two grades in one year and some offer opportunities for students to enter with advanced standing.  Institutions also assess a student’s prior learning, frequently experiential learning, and may give credit towards a diploma or degree.




Personally, I have experienced the process on a number of occasions.  In one case, I was was excused from taking a foreign language course as a result of my standing on a language proficiency test.  In another instance, I certain entrance requirements to a program of studies based on a comprehensive set of examinations covering a number of subjects.  My son went directly to university from Grade 11 rather than the customary requirement for Grade 12.  These instances demonstrate, I believe, that educational institutions have both the capacity and flexibility to allow students to challenge fro credit for courses it offers.




My proposal is that all schools, colleges and university offering courses for credit be required to allow students tot challenge for credit whether or not they have enrolled in or completed courses.  




Our society , to a large degree, is driven by cr...

title: 95 School  transcripts
summary: Don advocates for more comprehensive student transcripts that detail specific competencies achieved rather than just overall grades. Using Math 421A as an example, he proposes breaking down transcripts into component skills (sequences, polynomials, geometry, trigonometry, data management) and rating progress on individual outcomes. He suggests personal profiles and common rating scales across all grade levels and subjects would improve communication throughout the education system. This reflects his broader commitment to outcome-based education and transparency in student achievement reporting.

title: 96  j Courses
summary: Don explores the historical J-Course system (Job Instruction Training, Job Relations Training, Job Methods Training) from WWII Canada, designed to rapidly upskill workers entering manufacturing. These focused, brief courses emphasized practical job skills with reference cards for worker review. Don advocates reviving this model for modern workforce development, seeing parallels with contemporary mini-credentials and apprenticeship programs. He draws on personal experience teaching instructors at community colleges and trade institutes, emphasizing the value of focused, skills-based education for employment and lifelong learning.

title: 97 NZ
summary: Don analyzes emerging approaches to post-secondary funding in Ontario and Australia, focusing on performance-based funding mechanisms and employment outcomes. He reports Ontario's shift toward accountability metrics including skills development, graduate employment earnings, experiential learning, graduation rates, and community/economic impact. He then details Australia's restructuring of university fees, reducing costs for teaching, nursing, clinical psychology, and languages while increasing fees for humanities and communications—a strategy explicitly designed to align incentives toward workforce needs. The piece illustrates Don's ongoing interest in international educational trends and alternative funding models.

title: 98 Fuller transcripts
summary: Don proposes replacing traditional grades with detailed competency-based transcripts that break down subject areas into specific skill categories. Using Math 421A as an example, he suggests reporting grades for each math category (sequences, polynomials, functions, geometry, trigonometry, data management) and proposing numeracy competencies (numbers, decimals, money, time, measurement, data analysis, chance). He advocates for "personal profiles" with common rating scales across all educational levels and subjects, arguing this would improve communication throughout the education system and give students clearer roadmaps for tracking individual progress.

title: 98 Skill training
summary: Don laments the decline of quality skill training in PEI, tracing history back to the 1912 Agricultural Aid Act and noting how federal leadership maintained standards through stringent requirements. He observes that for fifty years PVI and PCVHS provided entry-level work training that often launched small business entrepreneurs, but this gap persists with limited employment training now available. Quoting Herbert Spencer on how social needs have historically subordinated individual needs in education, he questions why skill development training is not available on PEI and calls for official response, emphasizing that practical work-ready education remains essential to community economic development.

title: A 1 Going to School or Getting an Education
summary: A foundational piece distinguishing between schooling and education, fundamental to Don's educational philosophy. He contrasts schooling (formal institutional training) with education (broader development of abilities and positive behavior values in society). Don uses educational dictionary definitions and references George Bernard Shaw and Canadian business leaders to illustrate the confusion between these concepts. He argues that education encompasses learning from home, church, community, and experience—not just schools. The essay explores why credentialing systems emphasize degrees over actual capabilities, and proposes that education should be measured by one's ability to apply knowledge, demonstrate citizenship, communicate effectively, solve problems, and maintain ethical responsibility rather than by institutions attended or credentials held.
content_preview:
Going to School or Getting an Education







Recently my wife mentioned that a daughter of a friend had difficulty finding employment, especially well paid employment.  This puzzled my wife and she added that the young lady in question”had a good education”.  I asked “How do you know?”  My wife replied, “She has a master’s degree from…” and she named the university.  “That tells me about her school, I said, but how do you know that she as a good education?”  Need I say more?.




The above points to one of the critical issues in education – the confusion between schooling and education.  This thinking is prevalent both inside and outside the system.  We do not similarly confuse health and hospitalization, religion with church attendance or citizenship with court appearances.  Why, therefore, do we continue to speak of education when we mean schooling?  We have a school system but not an education system.  Educators, at least, should know the difference.  Is it just sloppy thinking or is it part of a deliberate plan to blur the lines?  




Good’s Dictionary of Education defines schooling as “individual training or education received in an educational institution, military or civilian.”  Education, on the other hand, is defined as “the aggregate of all processes by means of which a person develops abilities, attitudes and other forms of behaviour of positive value in the society in which he lives.”  Schooling is that part of one’s education resulting from ones experiences while in school.




George Bernard Shaw is reputed to have said, “At a very early age, I had to interrupt my education to go to school”.  Bud MacDougall, a Canadian business icon now deceased, once said, “I left school at 14 and I’ve regretted it all my life.  Biggest mistake I ever made.  Should have left when I was 12.”  It has also been said that we should bestow a bachelor’s degree on all newborns so that the process of education will not be disturbed in later life.




I am not knocking the ...

title: A-13 Undesignated Grants

Document reflects institutional values likely influenced by Don Glendenning's leadership philosophy as Foundation director.

Subject:	Undesignated Grants




Our Philosophy




The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island seeks ways to enhance the quality of life on Prince Edward Island.  The Foundation is committed to seeding, nurturing, supporting and strengthening our community and focuses on assets and capabilities  rather than needs and problems 




Grants are made available to:




increase the capacities of organizations, communities and individuals to respond to challenges and opportunities

develop local leadership, promote self-reliance, emphasize prevention, and mobilize civic participation and resources

improve effectiveness in the use of the applicants and the community’s resources

encourage and sustain collaboration between citizens and organizations

strengthen the financial stability and management capacity of voluntary sector organizations




Criteria for Decision Making




Grants are awarded for definite purposes and for projects covering a specific period of time.  In considering any project, the Foundation will take into account the extent to which a project:




addresses issues and opportunities rather than needs and problems

demonstrates inclusiveness and respect for cultural diversity

reflect a well governed and well-managed sponsoring organization

title: A 2 The Teaching Learning Process
summary: Drawing on his early teaching experience in a one-room rural school at age seventeen, Don reflects on the critical gap in his teacher training regarding the teaching-learning process. He emphasizes three components: learner, teacher, and process. Don rejects the "empty vessel" metaphor for learners, arguing instead that teachers create conditions for effective learning. He defines learning as behavioral change across cognitive, affective, and psychomotor domains. A key insight is that "a teacher hasn't taught if a learner hasn't learned," applied to each individual learner. Don advocates for schools to develop and publish learning models showing the steps learners take from course entry to exit, with multiple pathways accounting for different starting points and paces. He provides practical guidance for drafting such models and argues this understanding would have made him a better teacher.
content_preview:
11-The Teaching Learning Process







At age 17, in preparation for a teaching career, I attended Teacher’s College in Fredericton, N.B.  Given the shortage of teachers after the War, the Province offered a six months training program twice a year  at the newly named Teachers’ College in Fredeiricton, New Brunswick.  While still only seventeen, I commenced teaching in a one-room rural school.  It was an experience I will never forget.  We survived; I learned; whether students learned is another matter.  me.




I still recall, at least some of the information and instruction received in Teacher’s College about developing lesson plans, using audio visual aids, maintaining the school register, school law, psychology, teaching methods, etc. but I recall little if anything about the teaching-learning process.  Learning about learning, unfortunately for my students, came much later.  I am not even saying that it was niot included in the curriculum; what I am saying is that, if offered, it certainly did not register with




I believe that a clear understanding of the teaching-lerning process is critical; there are three components – the learner, the teacher and the process.  Let’s start with the learner.




Some believe that a learner is an empty vessel waiting to be filled – from a big pitcher, the teacher, to a small pitcher, the learner.  Others view learners as tender plants needing protection and nurturing with a teacher as the gardener.  While I like the latter image, in my view, it portrays the learner as much too passive.  Simply stated, a teacher is a person who helps another person to learn; a person whose role it is to create conditions for effective learning.




Learning is a process of change.  When a learner learns, learner has more or different knowledge, skills or attitudes.  In educational jargon, changes may be in the cognitive, affective or psychomotor domains.  More simply put, a person who has learned has new attitudes, skills or information or s...

title: A 3 A Snow Job
summary: Don critiques blanket school closures during winter storms as administratively convenient but educationally disruptive and disrespectful of parental authority. He observes that PEI weather is unpredictable and that many students walk or are driven to school and could attend safely despite storms. Don argues that schools should remain open and parents should decide whether their children attend based on individual circumstances and information. He identifies the various stakeholders (parents, bus drivers, school facilities staff, teachers) and their respective responsibilities. Critically, he notes that treating all students as identical ignores the reality that students operate at different levels and learn at different paces. Don concludes that school closures reflect an inability to accommodate individual differences rather than genuine safety necessity.
content_preview:
20 – A Snow Job







When I first moved to PEI, I lived directly across the street from a Registered Nurse who worked, I was told, in the operating room of the local hospital; about 6:00 am each morning, she would leave her house and walk to the hospital in fair weather or foul.  About the same time, the local radio would announce school closings because of snow, ice, or high winds.  Frequently, by 9:00 am the storm would have subsided or not developed and traffic along our street would be almost normal.  And shortly thereafter, children would be building forts or tunnels, or pelting snowballs at passers by.  




Schools closings are usually based on a concern for student safety; that I understand.  There are days when it may not be safe for anyone to be on the road except emergency vehicles.  On such days, buses should not venture out either – but all students do not arrive at school by bus.




Many students walk to school, others are dropped off at school by parents; some may even have their own vehicles while others may be transported by parents even on fine days.  Why should schools be closed to these students?  My own children, for example, walked to school and could have done so even on stormy most days.




In closing schools, the education system is taking away (another) decision that should, in my view, be made by parents.  A school closing policy is not as simple as schools closing or staying open; there are many interested parties and actual decision makers; each has an interest in the issue.  To name a few:




Parents have the ultimate decision as to whether a child goes to school on any day – and that is as it should be.  That decision is based on a range of information including the child’s safety.  The fact that the day is stormy or that a bus is not operating is only part of the decision-making process – but it is a parent’s decision.  Even if the bus runs, a parent may make a decision not to send a child – and that is as it should be.

Bus driv...

title: A-5 Newsletter 33 Achievement Levels
summary: Newsletter article as Guest Editor for Open Education (Pédagogie ouverte) published October 20, 2015. Don critiques Australian and PEI classroom achievement disparities reported by the Grattan Institute, arguing that schools conflate grade level with achievement level. He challenges the assumption that wide achievement ranges are inevitable, proposing instead that schools choose whether to make time or standards the constant in education.
content_preview:
Open
Education					
    




33										        October 20, 2015


“Criterion-referenced
testing is typically the most useful way to assess learning 



progress towards
learning goals” – unknown 



	


	



	


	
	

	School
	Achievement Levels  
	
	

	


	
	

	The
	Sydney Morning Herald of Saturday, July 22, 2015, carried an item
	based on a report by the Grattan Institute on the wide range of
	achievement levels in a typical classroom in Australian schools.  In
	Math, for example, the range could be as much as 8 years.  I’m
	told that the same applies to classrooms in PEI and results in both
	frustrated teachers and frustrated students. The article concludes,
	and I quote: “… it is not possible to remove the spread of grade
	levels and, therefore, teaching methods must be adjusted.”  
	
	

	


	
	

	There
	are at least two flaws in that line of thinking: 
	
	
		


		Grade
		level and achievement are not the same:
		 Grade levels are primarily administrative arrangements for
		counting students, recording the amount and nature of instruction
		provided, and the length of time students are under instruction.
		Achievement levels, on the other hand, refer to the level of
		learning reached in a field, subject or topic by a student
		irrespective of age, where learned or length of time spent in
		study.
	
	
		


		Which
		constant?  Schools
		have a choice: set a standard and adjust the time needed to reach
		it, or set time limits and measure achievement in the time
		available. Schools have chosen to make time the constant; the
		result is varying levels of achievement.  
		
	
	



	
	
Time
	or standards? Which is more important?
	



	
	

	Watch
	for

title: A Credentials losing market value
summary: Analysis of shifting market dynamics for educational credentials. Don argues that degrees and diplomas—historically "blue chip stocks" of personal portfolios—are declining in value because they reflect readily available knowledge rather than demonstrated competence. Institutions have been protected monopolies with little incentive to innovate or compete. The emerging problem: credentials don't mirror community needs, are inflexible and front-loaded, expensive to produce, and haven't adapted to technology. Discusses alternative credentials ("knock-offs") and discerning consumers demanding better value. Written April 2014.

title: A Gap
summary: Don's substantive paper proposing family education advisor concept. Argues education extends beyond schooling and families need guidance navigating complex choices; proposes education system equivalent to family doctor for health matters.
content_preview:
The 

Glendenning Page

October 1, 2013										No. 5







A Family Education Advisor

It is widely recognized that education is a key factor in determining one’s quality of life; in the same way, the collective education of our citizens will determine to a significant degree the future of our community and country. Because of this, we are among the world leaders in our investment in ensuring that our citizens, especially our youth, have access to a variety of educational activities and experiences. there are significant changes occurring around us that demand some different responses; our education system is unlikely to make the desired changes by itself.  

Education is complex, greater than just going to school, there are many choices, each has its own set of consequences, options, Decisions are complex  Assistance/advice readily available to studentsEducational advice to people not in school is limited and mostly focused on employability  Nature of our economy allowa people who are innovative to leap to the top, employers looking at other attributes other than formal education, technology allows people to learn from world experts without leaving home  Education is also complex, even schooling has become complex, and people need help to navigate the system. At least in schools, we have guidance counsellors to provide help; the education system has nothing, however, equivalent to the service of a family doctor for matters of health or a lawyer for matters of law. 




  
Education includes all our learning experiences; schooling is an important part but only a part. While schooling is emphasized when entering the labour market, it is the often other parts of one’s education that allow one to flourish. 
  

  
For people not yet of school age or no longer part of the school system, support for individuals is patchy and focused primarily on finding employment. 





Families need help

title: A Home on the Island
summary: Don's personal narrative of moving to PEI in December 1968 as President-designate of Holland College. Details house-hunting process, meeting real estate agents, selecting home at 6 Johnston Avenue, and selling Ottawa property—key transition moment.
content_preview:
A Home on the Island




My appointment as President-designate was announced in early December, 1968. What I did not realize until much later, was that I was not expected to assume the role until summer.  If I was made aware of that, it completely slipped past me.




Immediately after the appointment, I subscribed to the Charlottetown Guardian so that I could monitor events.  I also contacted some real estate agents about available housing.




During the second week of December, Carol and traveled to Charlottetown by train to secure a home.  We had arranged to meet with Pat Torrens, a real estate agent, on a Saturday, but we encountered a major snow storm, our train was delayed and, as I recall, we did not arrive until Sunday.  I am not sure but think that Pat met us on Sunday and drove us around the city although, it being Sunday, we did not actually inspect any houses.




It turned out, however, that Pat was also an instructor at the Marine Training Centre, then on the third floor of the old bank on Great George Street, and by Monday was unable to meet us on Monday because of his teaching duties.  We contacted other agents and Stanley Mol picked us up, toured us around.  




How we actually made contact with Wilbur Willis I cannot recall but Wilbur had a house under construction at 6 Johnston Avenue; we settled on it, agreed to some changes in the original plan, and signed papers with Wilbur on Wednesday morning.  Because of the tiring train ride, we decided to fly back to Ottawa and Wilbur delivered us to the airport about noon.  The house would be ready for occupancy by the end of February. Only much later was I made aware of a dispute between Pat and Stanley as to which agent had shown the property first and how the commission would be shared.




Flying on a Dart Herald was not our preferred choice, but in view of our experience by train, opted for air travel anyway.  On return to Ottawa, we put our house on the market and sold it within a couple of weeks,...

title: A Learning About Learning
summary: An extended essay in which Don reflects on his early teacher training and the absence of teaching-learning process instruction. He emphasizes that learning models should focus on learner activities, not teacher activities. Don advocates that schools adopt published learning models as part of program planning and teacher education—finding most schools lack them despite their fundamental importance. He provides a step-by-step guide for drafting an "ideal" learning model: marking entry and exit points, mapping all steps and their sequences, including optional and required components, and identifying alternate pathways. Don asks critical questions during model development: What steps should students take? In what sequence? How do we know? He notes that revising learning models throughout one's career reflects growing knowledge and experience, and expresses regret that he didn't understand this process earlier in his teaching career.
content_preview:
Learning About Learning




In preparation for a teaching career, at age 17, I attended Teacher’s College in Fredericton, N.B.  Given the need for teachers, the Province then enrolled students twice a year for a six months training program.  While still only seventeen, I commenced teaching in a one-room rural school.  It was an experience I will never forget.  The students and I survived; whether they learned is another matter.

The years which followed were filled with teaching and summer school as I went on to complete the requirements for a teacher’s license.  During that period, also, my teaching career included experience at both the secondary and post-secondary levels.

I still recall, at least some of the information and instruction received in Teacher’s College about developing lesson plans, using audio visual aids, maintaining the school register, school law, psychology, teaching methods, etc.  But I do not recall much about the teaching-learning process.  This process has since become an interest of mine and is the subject of this column.

The heart of schooling is, or should be, the teaching-learning process.  We should spend much more time learning and thinking about it.  It provides a framework for the teaching we do; it provides a framework for our decisions as teachers.

In our study of the teaching learning process we need to consider the teacher, the learner and the process.  Our starting point should be the learner.  If we get the learner’s role and activities right, the rest will follow. 

Organizational theory suggests that every organization needs a mission statement and it should be published.  The process of developing a mission statement is important for an organization and is usually highly consultative.  Many organizations have such a statement prominently displayed throughout their premises.  Schools, colleges and universities should have them too.  So should training departments.

Even more important for training and education organizatio...

title: A Pay for
summary: Don proposes a health-care-model approach to publicly-funded education, specifying which educational services government should cover (essential skills, entry-level occupational training, counselling, qualification exams, management training after five years employment) and which it should not (such as calculus). He argues this focus on learning outcomes rather than school operations would shift educational policy fundamentally. The document also discusses emerging trends: learning pods gaining permanence, interest in mini-courses for continuing education especially during pandemic-related layoffs, and context-based learning (citizen, personal, health, career) drawing parallels to magnet schools like PCVHS and PVI.

title: A Snow Job
summary: An expanded version of the earlier "Snow Job" essay with refined arguments about school closures during winter weather. Don maintains his position that blanket closures undermine parental decision-making and accommodate institutional convenience over educational responsibility. The revised version emphasizes that school closures represent another instance of the education system removing decisions that should belong to parents. Don reiterates that students operate at varying levels and that schools must develop better skills at addressing individual differences. He notes that "there is no such thing as group learning" but individuals can learn in group settings. The piece concludes that administrative convenience should not drive educational policy and that teachers should develop capacity to manage disruptions caused by student absences due to weather.
content_preview:
A Snow Job











When
I first moved to PEI, I lived directly across the street from a
Registered Nurse who worked, I was told, in the operating room of the
local hospital; about 6:00 am each morning, she would leave her house
and walk to the hospital in fair weather or foul.  About the same
time on stormy days, the local radio would announce school closings
because of snow, ice, or high winds.  Frequently, by 9:00 am the
storm would have subsided or not developed and traffic along our
street would be almost normal.  And shortly thereafter, children
would be building forts or tunnels, or pelting snowballs at passers
by.  







Schools
closings are based on a concern for student comfort and safety; that
I understand.  There are days when it may not be safe for anyone to
be on the road except emergency vehicles.  And there are days when
some busses shouldn’t be on the road but other could be - but all
students do not arrive at school by bus.






Many
students walk to school, others are dropped off at school by parents;
some may even have their own vehicles while others may be transported
by parents even on fine days.  Why should schools be closed to
students w3ho are able to reach school?  My own children, for
example, walked to school and could have done so even on stormy most
days.






In
closing schools, the education system is taking away (another)
decision that should, in my view, be made by parents.  A school
closing policy is not as simple as schools closing or staying open;
there are many interested parties and actual decision makers; each
has an interest in the issue.  To name a few:






	


	Parents have the ultimate decision as to whether a child goes to
	school on any day – and that is as it should be.  That decision is
	based on a range of information including the child’s safety.  The
	fact that the day is stormy or that a bus is not operating is only
	part of the decision-making process – but it is a parent’s
	decision.  Even if the bus runs...

title: AA-3 26-5 Interventions School autonomy
summary: Major policy document on school governance based on Don's Indiana University assignment analyzing university governance through Kant's philosophy. Defines governance as "who makes what decisions, and in what manner." Highlights confusion between education and schooling, credentials vs. qualifications, and professional accountability. Presents a case from OECD research showing direct correlation between school autonomy and student performance. Proposes decision-making framework: learners/parents choose schools, teachers manage individual learners, principals lead instruction, trustees/superintendent operate schools, Deputy Minister ensures quality, Minister delegates operational roles. References Alberta school board decisions and proposes immediate PEI changes including consolidating educational responsibilities and delegating to lowest appropriate levels. Includes section on "Thoughts on School Governance" (May 25, 2012 draft) emphasizing freedom to teach with accountability to those served.
content_preview:
School Autonomy 



My introduction to governance included the following assignment many years ago by Professor Gibson at Indiana University: "Propose a university governing structure based on the writings of Emmanuel Kant". That project provided a foundation for my interest in the subject but also for a number of important turns in my educational career. These notes simply reflect that interest, my reading on the subject, and both my persona! experience and philosophy. 

Definition 

I like the definition of governance provided by Governing America's Schools: Changing the Rules - 

"governance is defined as who makes what decisions, and in what manner. In education, the 'who' is 

everybody from state legislators to parents. The 'what' covers everything from standards to parent 

involvement. The 'in what manner' or 'how' is everything from decisions made autonomously to those 

made within a framework established by others 

Underlying issues 

In recent months, the writer has become aware of a some issues that contribute to the confusion about 

education and, therefore, about governance. 

  
Educators and the public alike use education and schooling interchangeably; the most frequent 

example, probably, is encompassed in the question "Where did you get your education?". 


What the questioner really wants to know "Where did you go to school?" or even 11 where did 

you get your degree?" One's education is the result of a broad range of learning experiences 

that may occur at home, at church, in the community at large, at school, through travel, in 

sports and recreation, etc. It really is the result of all one's formative experiences of which 

schooling is only a part. If we can differentiate hospital and health care, surely we can do the 

same for education and schooling. This view is reinforced by the fact that many Departments of 

Education are responsible for public schools only with adult and post secondary education in a 

different one. Even furthe...

title: About schools
summary: Don's Open Education piece applying Dewey's principle of relating school to life. Advocates schools prepare students for multiple life roles (individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member, citizen) rather than singular employment focus.
content_preview:
Open Education

03______________________________________________________________________________________







TIDBITS







“an educational system changes the face of a country quicker than anything else” - Unknown










“My conviction is that we must do now what we should have done 20 years ago; that is, imagine that we have no national structure in place, start from scratch  and design a structure that will meet the realities of today and stop trying to fit a round peg into a square hole by rearranging things …” Presbyterian Record 







“We have record-low confidence in our public schools,” - Kevin Johnson, the mayor of Sacramento













________________________

Open Education is an informal and occasional electronic newsletter about education published at the whim of the Editor, Don Glendenning.    Its purpose is to provide information, provoke debate and encourage public discussion.  Comments are welcome at theopener@hotmail.com




ABOUT SCHOOLS




John Dewey, in School and Society, said “Relate the school to life, and all studies are of necessity correlated”.  In spite of this advice,  schools operate on a model far different from the world outside their doors.   Dewey’s “life” may be interpreted or described many ways.  I like the model put forward in the Oregon Education Act of 1991 which identified the following life roles: individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member and citizen.  




Although the significance of each role varies from individual to individual and changes as we mature, we all want our children to reach an acceptable level of performance in each role.  But helping our youth prepare for each role is more than most parents can handle so we’ve established schools.  The community thinks education is a such a good thing that taxpayers foot the bill.  




In our lifetime, everything seemed to work well.  People who went to school or stayed in school for longer periods found jobs and earned more money.  This worked so ...

title: Action 1
summary: Action-oriented paper addressing PEI education's communication and organizational failures. Don claims lifelong education engagement and notes definition confusion between education and schooling (World Bank 2018 citation). Criticizes Department's narrow curriculum-development focus when its true role is helping Islanders gain information, insights, and skills. Notes missing education definition in revised PEI Schools Act. Advocates structuring around function (helping Islanders thrive) rather than school operations. Proposes "form follows function" organizational principle. Argues Department should frame role expansively beyond school operations. Dated Feb 18/24, signed Don Glendenning. Emphasizes implementation as "daily business" rather than disruptive change.
content_preview:
Educ/PEI


   one






PEI
EDUCATION 


Action
1






I
have been in education all my life; recently I have been exploring
public education; not many days pass without my having a conversation
about the subject. 








Education is a large,
multifaceted, people centered set of services. That in itself
complicates communication but understanding is “fuzzified”
further as per the following:	

	

There
	is a tendency to use education and school/schooling interchangeably;
	World Bank called attention to it in their 2018 report. It is
	causing problems on PEI as well.
	

Seems
	to me a Depatrment of Education needs a definition of education. My
	search of Department literature did not turn up a definition of
	Education. In fact,  I was informed that  a definition of education
	was left out of the PEI Schools AcL during a recent revision. A
	working definition is needed for clarity and should be developed and
	distributed generously throughout the system.
	

The
	Department describes its role as one of “developng and delivering
	high quality programs and curriculum.”  While the Department does
	this, I suggest that the the Department’s role is much, much
	greater, that of helping Islanders gain new information insights and
	skills.
	

 Government
	structure Departments around branches or fields of work;  In the
	case of education, however, structuring is based on levels of
	schooling – a major diversion from its real role.
	

“Form
	follows function “is an organizational maxim. The function of
	public education, I suggest, is to help Islanders gain knowledge,
	attitudes, skills and other attributes needed to thrive in future
	years. Instead, The Department of Education seems to be organized
	around the running of schools 
	







The
proposed changes should simply be introduced as part of the daily
business of the Department.






Sincerely

Don
Glendenning.












										Feb 18/24
