title: Along the DACUM Trail
summary: Personal narrative by Don recounting his involvement in DACUM's origins and development (1968-1970s). Describes meeting Robert Adams in Yarmouth, visiting with Howard Clement and Derek Franklin, and Holland College's 1970 decision to adopt DACUM for all programs. Clarifies competing BC and Nova Scotia models, credits Adams with competency-based analysis innovation, and positions Holland College as the only institution to fully implement DACUM learning model. Reflects Don's central role in a major educational innovation.
content_preview:
Along the DACUM Trail




In the field of education, the DACUM trail is a short but interesting one.  Still less than fifty years of age, well-travelled, international in scope, still being built and used for a great many purposes., its origin still somewhat shrouded 




As one who walked the trail even before it was named

Knew the early bulders and was a contributor DACUM trail




Late in life I decided to revisit the DACUM Trail  Search of the internet shows how popular it has become.  Many o have left the trail without realizing it still carrying their backpack with the name on it




"The DACUM handbook arrived a few days ago.  Thanks.  It certainly documents your process and I appreciate your thoughtfulness in sending me a copy.

 

Your manual make a couple of  references to the origin of DACUM.  As you may recall, sometime after my retirement from Holland College, I decided to review the origin of DACUM; my interest was in trying to understand how two such different models could have sprung from the same source.  You may want to amend your comments about the period preceding your involvement.  My review included:

My own knowledge of what was happening in the field at the time. 

Visiting Howard Clement, then retired and living in Victoria, BC,  who worked in the Ottawa office during the 1960-70 period providing support for the various NewStart projects.   

Both direct discussion and exchange of information with Derek Franklin  who replaced Clement as head of the BC Curriculum Unit when Clement moved to Ottawa.  Franklin also particiipated in the preparation of the chef training chart in 1968 and led the implementation in BC afterward. 

Robert Adams, a former colleague and occupational analyst prior to moving to Yarmouth, Nova Scotia. 

Dr. C. R. Ford, under whom Clement implemented the BC version of DACUM in Zambia.  I distinctly recall a discussion with Ford at a CVA conference in Edmonton, Alberta about his application of DACUM.  It was only then that...

title: AQUA (2)
summary: A proposal document outlining AQUA (Atlantic Provinces Qualification Authority), an independent organization designed to assess and certify performance-based qualifications separate from educational delivery. Don conceptualizes AQUA as addressing the problem that acquiring education and certifying qualifications are conflated but should be separate functions. AQUA would operate on a fee-for-service basis, accept direct applications or referrals, issue certificates based on demonstrated performance, and provide information on competency gaps. The proposed benefits include removing barriers to certification, focusing certification on performance rather than time served, encouraging self-study, allowing educational providers to focus on teaching while separating certification functions, and eliminating length of learning time as a certification component. Implementation would involve feasibility study, business planning, pilot testing, and full service launch.
content_preview:
EDUCATION 							Issue No.

20/20  		AN AQUA* SOLUTION       _______________________________________________________________________Background




The acquiring of an education and the certification of qualifications are two separate functions although the two are closely linked and frequently one is thought to be the other.  The fact that the delivery of both functions is, to a large degree, provided or driven by educational institutions often works to the individual’s disadvantage in terms of both education and certification.  While separate certification bodies exist, they appear to place undue emphasis on results of study and too little emphasis on what has been learned outside the formal education system.




Concept




The idea behind this proposal is to establish an independent, private sector driven body with authority to assess and certify a person’s level of performance on a task or set of tasks such as found in an occupation or field.




Characteristics




AQUA will:




Be an independent organization with its own governing structure

Operate on a fee for service basis

Accept clients on direct application or by referral

Issue certificates based on demonstrated performance

On request, provide applicants with information on gaps to be filled to meet certification requirements. 

Make extensive use of advisory/working panels.




Benefits/Advantages




It is anticipated that the availability of AQUA will:




Remove barriers to certification encountered in the current approach

Focus certification more clearly on performance

Encourage more self study

Allow educational providers to focus on the teaching function

Allow a certification body to focus on certification without regard to teaching.

Removes length of learning time as a component of certification







Implementation Steps




Undertake feasibility study

Prepare a business plan

Conduct a pilot of the model

3	Implement the service




	

*Atlantic Provinces Qualification Authority

title: Assessing Student Performance
summary: A reflective account of Holland College's innovative STEP (Systematic Training and Education Program) approach to student performance assessment. Don credits Robert Adams of Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation with developing the DACUM-based performance rating scale, distinguishing it from traditional school evaluation. The essay outlines seven principles of expert supervisory judgment that informed DACUM development: supervisors sense satisfaction through simultaneous factors; they assess by observation and subjective judgment; competent supervisors recognize good work; they avoid single-instance judgments; they base recognition on demonstrated performance, not knowledge; they observe problem-solving processes; and they don't require rigid criteria. Don describes Holland College's implementation: learners self-rate upon entry and throughout, engage in learning plans with instructors, receive confirmation ratings, and understand greatest learning occurs when ratings change. He credits instructors' occupational backgrounds for understanding this performance-based approach, establishing a best practice for competency-based training.
content_preview:
Assessing Student Performance







Perhaps the most unique aspect of the STEP approach was how student’s performance was rated; it was truly performance based.  No other educational institution that I know had implemented a performance based rating scale and, based on a survey of private industry, industrial based training programs do not use competency based rating either.  Along with the DACUM analysis, Holland College adopted and later modified the DACUM rating scale.




Traditionally, school evaluation systems relate only to the acquisition of knowledge in a school setting.  Performance based rating is different; it is based in the reality of the real life work situation where application of knowledge, or performance, is the rule.  The criteria and levels of learner performance are the same as, or at least reflect, those of the workplace.  Learning is measured by observable behaviour of the kind that an immediate supervisor would recognize in a work situation.  The evaluation process is simple, clear, easily understood by both employer and employee alike and is directly applicable to trainees preparing to work in an occupation or field.




Robert Adams of Nova Scotia NewStart corporation, the primary architect of the DACUM system, developed a performance based rating scale based on the view that: 




1.	Supervisors are able to sense their satisfaction or dissatisfaction with a task being performed. A number of factors may be combined simultaneously, such as speed with which a task is performed, the quality of the work that is visible, and the usefulness of the product being built, yet the good supervisor is able to make judgments about his satisfaction with performance involving a number of such assessment factors.




2.	Supervisors assess performance by observation, followed by a rather subjective expert decision or judgment. They seldom administer tests, and, in other than in the most simple or repetitive jobs, they seldom have an opportunity to measure ...

title: Assessment Based College (2)
summary: Don proposes "Canada College," an assessment-based institution addressing fragmentation of lifelong learning credentials. He notes schools no longer monopolize education delivery; employers, unions, professional associations, and others provide training through various channels. Lifelong learners accumulate certificates from multiple sources but lack unified recognition. Don observes educational institutions resist crediting education dissimilar to their offerings or even their own extension courses. He proposes Canada College as a credit bank rather than educational provider, aggregating learning from schools, universities, colleges, work, self-study, seminars, and community activities. References include the Open Learning Agency in British Columbia and New Zealand's Qualification Authority model. Don suggests his own experience—building bridges, drainage systems, road work—could be assessed toward civil engineering credentials through portfolio submission. The proposal addresses time-based credit limitations, advocating for performance-based alternatives.
content_preview:
AN ASSESSMENT BASED COLLEGE




Schools no longer have a monopoly on the delivery of education and training.  Employers, labor unions, trade and professional associations, consulting agencies, and many others now deliver courses, workshops, and other training sessions to employees, members and the public at large.  Some agencies deliver a series of courses which result in a credential; other organizations simply deliver stand-alone short courses.  Some large US corporations offer their own degree programs.




The trend towards a multiplicity of delivery agencies is now well established in Canada and, given the current constitutional discussions, the proliferation will likely continue.  Canadians who are life long learners will have even more choices from which to choose training, including creating their own.  To this we can add self study and the rich experiences of participation and leadership in community activities.  Lifelong learners, therefore, can end up with a large number of certificates recognizing participation or achievement in individual courses but none which recognizes the continuous and collective achievement of the learner.




While educational institutions may consider previous educational and other experience when accepting students, they are not very anxious to and less than generous in giving credit for education dissimilar to that which they offer in their own institution.  Some schools are even reluctant to give credit for courses taken through their own extension departments.  A sheepskin curtain separates credit and non credit courses.




Why shouldn’t learners be able to accumulate credits earned in school, university, college, at work, through self study, seminars, workshops, etc. and have these credits aggregated and counted towards an appropriate educational qualification?  Is it possible to do?  Difficult to administer?  Or do we lack the incentive or will?




The idea of educational credit banks is not new.  The Open Learning Agenc...

title: Assessment
summary: Concise assessment service proposal addressing practical employment gaps. Documents conversations with local employers revealing that while new hires are expected to have high school education, they frequently lack basic skills in mathematics (making change, mental arithmetic) and communications (written messages, giving directions). Notes that high school graduation requires 20 credits including 4 language (English/French), 2 math, 2 science, 2 social studies, with courses at 110 hours and 50% pass mark. Proposes establishing an independent assessment service to certify basic skill levels for individuals wanting or needing proof of competency—particularly for entry-level employment access. Specifies service characteristics: fee-based, open to individuals/companies/schools. Represents practical application of Don's assessment philosophy to immediate labor market needs.

title: Autonomy
summary: Condensed policy brief on school autonomy directly citing OECD PISA research establishing positive relationship between school autonomy and student performance. Argues schools need autonomy over curriculum, assessment, staffing, calendar, and budget allocation; teachers need freedom to make individualized instructional decisions and assign grades; students should choose schools and challenge courses for credit. Includes PEI-specific analysis noting School Act limitations on principal authority and proposes expanding decision-making at school level. Discusses Arizona school transformation converting teaching positions to assistant roles and Vancouver "Miniversity" alternative model. Emphasizes benefits including stronger community links, improved student results, and educational quality. Practical document synthesizing research evidence into actionable governance recommendations.
content_preview:
About Education




No. A-1							            		4-1-Auto

School Autonomy




Simply stated, there is a direct relationship between school performance and school autonomy.  In the words of the OECD Report, Pisa in Focus, 2011:

  
“In countries where schools have greater autonomy over what is taught and how students 


are assessed, students tend to perform better. 

  
In countries where schools account for their results by posting achievement data publicly, schools that enjoy greater autonomy in resource allocation tend to show better student performance than those with less autonomy. 
  
In countries where there are no such accountability arrangements, schools with greater autonomy in resource allocation tend to perform worse.” 


In support of the concept




Ideally, a school should have autonomy on how to resolve all learning matters as they pertain to students In practical terms, autonomy at the school level means giving each school the freedom to:

  
recruit, hire, assign and supervise any and all instructional staff whether full-time, part time, teachers, teacher aides or volunteers
  
Set their own calendar  
  
Adjust the school day
  
Allocate funds within a budget to reflect the needs and priorities of students and the community.
  
decisions about curricula and assessment, course offerings and textbooks.  





But autonomy and accountability needs to be shared with teachers as well.  Teachers should have freedom to:

  
Make decisions as to how best serve each individual
  
Assign grades at their sole discretion 





Students should have freedom to:

  
Select any school; other Provinces allow it.  
  
Challenge any course for credit


.  

Part of the dilemma stems from the uncertainty as to the function of principal – a teacher or administrators.  The health field settled the question by 

Context of provincilpolicies

Local history

Teacher autonomt

 Professionalism, 

Parents

title: B2 Instructing
summary: Reference document compiling definitions of "instruct" from multiple English dictionaries, thesauruses, and foreign language sources. Establishes primary meanings: to teach/train methodically; to give orders/directions; to furnish information. Traces etymological roots to Latin "instruere" (to construct, equip, teach). Includes extensive synonym lists, usage examples, and comparative translations across Spanish, French, German, Italian, and multiple other languages. Provides thorough definitional framework for "instruction" covering educational provision, formal ordering, and procedural directions. Reflects author's practice of building conceptual clarity through linguistic analysis and cross-cultural comparison. Demonstrates commitment to precise terminology as foundation for educational discourse and policy development.
content_preview:
September 29, 2013

Instructing and learning

.

1. To provide with knowledge, especially in a methodical way. See Synonyms at teach.

2. To give orders to; direct.




1. to direct to do something; order

2. to teach (someone) how to do (something)

3. to furnish with information; apprise

4. (Law) Law chiefly Brit

a.  (esp of a client to his solicitor or a solicitor to a barrister) to give relevant facts or information to

b.  to authorize (a barrister or solicitor) to conduct a case on a person's behalf to instruct counsel

[from Latin instruere to construct, set in order, equip, teach, from struere to build]

1. to furnish with knowledge, esp. by a systematic method; teach; train; educate. 

2. to furnish with orders or directions; direct; order; command. 

3. to furnish with information; inform; apprise. 

4. (of a judge) to guide (a jury) by outlining the legal principles involved in the case under consideration. 

[1375–1425; late Middle English < Latin instruere to equip, train, set in order =in- in2 + struere to put together]







  
    
      
        
Verb
      
      
        
1.
      
      
        
instruct - impart skills or knowledge to; "I taught them French"; "He instructed me in building a boat"
        
teach, learn
        
train, educate, prepare, develop - create by training and teaching; "The old master is training world-class violinists"; "we develop the leaders for the future"
        
indoctrinate - teach doctrines to; teach uncritically; "The Moonies indoctrinate their disciples"
        
drill - teach by repetition
        
catechise, catechize - give religious instructions to
        
reinforce, reward - strengthen and support with rewards; "Let's reinforce good behavior"
        
spoonfeed - teach without challenging the students; "This professor spoonfeeds his students"
        
induct - introduce or initiate; "The young geisha was inducted into the ways of her profession"

title: Background 1
summary: Foundational background document establishing the transition problem context. Uses CMEC quote on transition as critical education success measure. Identifies performance factors: skill range, performance levels, clustering, and relevance to planned role. Catalogs typical transition dilemmas: high school graduation without program prerequisites, having credits but no diploma, graduating but not meeting further study requirements, lacking employment skills despite graduation, maintaining employment challenges, and rejection despite skill possession. Lists contributing factors: communication, entrance requirements, assessment practices, reporting practices, benchmarks, institutional role conflicts, credentials versus qualifications. Acknowledges issue cannot resolve itself or through educators alone, requiring urgent community action. Shows Don's comprehensive problem framing.
content_preview:
Transition/1

TRANSITION








“A
student’s ability to transition from secondary school to
post-secondary education and the labour market is a key measure of
the education system’s success for students” – CMEC, July 2016






The above statement
by the Council of Ministers of Education Canada (CMEC) highlights a
concern that is shared by many educators, employers, certification
agencies and the community at large. The issue  will not resolve
itself and cannot be resolved by educators alone, but resolve it we
must - and soon.  Although not a simple issue, there appears to be
some agreement that the performance level of a person in a field of
study or employment is determined by:

	

The nature and
	range of skills that a person can demonstrate, 
	
	

The level of
	performance at which each skill can be demonstrated, 
	
	

Degree of
	clustering, and 
	
	

Relevance to
	the planned role 
	







Typical examples
of the transition dilemma include a person who: 


	

Graduated from
	high school but lacks specific course(s) required for entrance to
	program of choice.
	

Has high school
	credits for specific course(s) required for entrance to
	postsecondary studies but lacks a high school graduation diploma.
	

Graduates from
	high school and later decides to pursue postsecondary studies but
	does not meet postsecondary entrance requirements.
	

Graduates from
	high school but lacks essential skills to enter employment
	

Graduates from
	high school, secures employment but lacks essential skills to
	maintain or progress in employment
	

Does not
	graduate from high school and, therefore, is rejected for employment
	or further study even though he/she may have the required skills.







Likely
contributing factors include:

	

Communication
	between and among the parties involved
	

Entrance
	requirements to postsecondary institutions
	

Assessment
	practices
	

Reporting
	practices
	

Benchmarks
	

Conflicting
	views on role of educational institutions
	

Credentials...

title: Background Feb-2017
summary: Meeting notes from February 8, 2017 discussion facilitated by Don Glendenning as Chair. Documents attendance by Tamara Hubley-Little and Katherine McQuaid. Discussion covers wide-ranging topics including communication among educational stakeholders, institutional entrance requirements, cost of re-teaching high school subjects at postsecondary level, variance in standards between schools, achievement levels, coordination with other provinces, and CMEC initiatives on competencies. Don's conclusions outline the need for inclusive groups spanning educators, employers, registrars, and certification bodies; proposes graphing the transition process; identifies major transition points (Grade 10 entry, college/university entrance, work entry); emphasizes advanced notice requirements. Meeting adjourned with continuation at Chair's call.
content_preview:
Transition/2

TRANSITION 

Notes from discussion of February 8, 2017




Note:	Due to weather and out of Province travel, a number of invitees were not able to attend.




Present:	 

  
Tamara Hubley-Little
  
Katherine McQuaid
  
Don Glendenning





Notes:

The conversation was wide-ranging and included the following: 

  
Communication among interested parties,
  
Institutional and program entrance requirements, 
  
Cost to the system of re-teaching high school subjects at adult level, 
  
Variance in standards from school to school; 
  
Achievement/performance levels,
  
Coordination of content with other Provinces,
  
CMEC initiative in developing common competencies and reporting progress.





Conclusions of the Chair:

  
Group should include educators, employers- registrars/admissions officers and certification bodies
  
It would be useful to graph the transition process from school entry to work entry
  
Major transition points entry to Grade 10, entrance to college and university, entrance to work from high school or postsecondary.
  
Need to provide more advanced notice


 

Next meeting:

  
At the call of the Chair





Don Glendenning

Chair

title: Barriers to reform
summary: A concise outline identifying seven fundamental barriers to educational reform: limited view equating schooling with education; prescribing education into rigid degrees, diplomas, and courses; monopolistic institutional control; time-based rather than performance-based frameworks; organization designed for industrial era production; overemphasis on qualifications over actual learning; and systems incapable of self-correction. This outline distills Don's critique of conventional educational systems into its essential components, suggesting his systematic analysis of why reform remains difficult. The brevity and clarity of this list indicate it may have served as foundational thinking for his more extensive reform proposals including AQUA and Canada College.

Emphasis on qualifications

title: Basic skills dilemma
summary: Concise policy brief outlining the basic education gap as an ongoing, economy-impacting issue. Don proposes defining basic skills (focusing on math and communication) and recommendations for schools to prioritize skills-based graduation criteria with benchmarks. The tone is direct and solution-oriented, advocating for systemic change in assessment and reporting practices.
content_preview:
Basic skills dilemma




It is time to address the issue of basic education

  
Ongoing issue
  
Consuming a great deal of attention
  
Impacting our economy and quality of life
  
Question about quality of our education
  
Most often raised in the context of citizenship and employment





Issue 1:  We do not have a common understanding of the term nor a recognized list




Definition: Range and  level of skills thought to be needed by every citizen to function in our community




In my discussions with Islanders, math and communication skills are the first to come up in any conversation; Remainder of these notes, I will refer to math skills




Are learnable by practically all people; they are teachable and most likely most are now being taught in PEI schools




Recommendations:

  
Role of schools – assist people to learn skills of citizenship
  
Define graduation in terms of skills learned not time spent in school
  
Priority to basic skills
  
Clearer definition of achievement levels
  
Benchmarks
  
Reporting

title: BC Schools-Vancouver Sun
summary: Vancouver Sun report card/opinion piece on B.C. Education Minister George Abbott's education transformation plan. Summarizes five key elements: personalized learning, quality teaching, flexibility and choice, high standards, and technology empowerment. Discusses previous work by Margaret MacDiarmid and Abbott's continuation of dialogue with stakeholders. Reflects broader education modernization efforts in provincial education systems.
content_preview:
Transformation
of B.C. public schools


October
24, 2011. 11:09 am • Section: Report
Card

ShareThis
 1
 1
0



 


  

Education
Minister George Abbott and students, PNG files 









BC
College of Teachers – collision course?


The
Liberal government has been promising significant changes in
B.C. schools for a couple of years. Former minister Margaret
MacDiarmid started the
dialogue but didn’t implement anything of significance. Now George
Abbott
has picked up where she left off.


Earlier
this month, he produced an op-ed titled B.C.’s
plan for education transformation.
In it, he says he’s been having discussions with students, parents,
teachers and other education partners about how to make a good
education system great.


“To
do that, we need to first acknowledge that every student has their
own unique learning style, as well as individual interests and
passions, and we need to give them opportunities to achieve their
goals,” he wrote.


His
plan has five key elements: personalized learning for every student,
quality teaching and learning, more flexibility and choice, high
standards and learning empowered by technology.


While
schools will continue to teach core skills, curriculum will be
redesigned to encourage critical thinking and teamwork, and there
will be greater recognition of outside activities such as arts,
sports, science and leadership programs..


“We
will also support families by creating better opportunities for
parents to engage in their child’s learning with more flexibility
and choice with respect to what, how, when and where their child
learns.”


The
public will hear more about the plan very shortly, he promises,
adding that it will “move education forward, hand-in-hand with
teachers, parents, students and all those who share an interest in
ensuring our province’s bright future.”


That
will be a sight to behold indeed. Find Abbott’s statement from Oct.
13 on the
Education Ministry website.

title: Bishop Carroll-The Five Pillars
summary: Descriptive document outlining Bishop Carroll High School's (Calgary, Alberta) educational model based on five pillars: independent study using self-directed learning guides, teacher advisor roles providing mentorship and individualized support, continuous progress allowing self-paced learning, individualized scheduling with no master schedule/class bells, and differentiated staffing. The approach emphasizes student responsibility, personalized education, flexible pathways, and collaborative learning. Represents alternative/progressive secondary education model with significant student autonomy.
content_preview:
The Five Pillars

Bishop Carrol High School

Calgary, Alberta










Independent Study

All material for courses is assembled into self-study packages known as Learning Guides. These guides tell students exactly what they must learn, show them how to learn it and prepare them for testing and evaluation. Some activities that are included as part of the Learning Guides are: reading books, viewing videos, responding to questions and assignments, completing self-tests, conducting experiments and various other educational activities depending on the subject.




The Learning Guides also provide many opportunities for students to collaborate with each other by directing them to engage in team work, seminars and group presentations which are aimed at enhancing the student’s learning.




Independent learning is supported through one-to-one consultations with teachers that are subject area specialists. They are always available and willing to meet with students to help them achieve their learning guide objectives.




The ultimate goal of independent study is to foster a sense of ownership of the knowledge learned. If successful, the student will understand how to learn, which is an important skill for post-secondary education.




Teacher Advisor (TA) Role

In Bishop Carroll’s unique learning environment students must exercise a considerable amount of responsibility in order to be successful. However, students are not alone in this responsibility. Their success is also the responsibility of their Teacher Advisor who works with them to develop an academic plan which reflects the student’s unique needs and goals.




Each of our students are assigned a TA who they will remain with until graduation. Students will meet with Teacher Advisors twice daily and for a longer period every week. It is the TA’s duty to help the student set goals, motivate them, make sure they are keeping on track with their learning program and stay in touch with parents. The TA will also record lea...

title: Bloom Levels of learning
summary: Don applies Bloom's Taxonomy to educational progression, advocating for mastery-based systems over time-based grading. The document explains six cognitive levels: Remember (lowest), Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, and Create (highest). Don argues this framework allows students to reach needed performance levels at individual paces, addressing his concern that "students learn at different rates" and that "how quickly one can perform is different from how long learning takes."
content_preview:
About Education

Glendenning

LEVELS OF LEARNING

D-

One of the areas on which I disagree is that of the school grading  system. Given thatstuents learn at different rates, it is highly unlikely that all will have reached the same lvel of performance in the same lwngth of time. I favoura  system that allows a student to attaing a needed level even if it takes a bit more time.  How quickly one can perform a task is one thing; how long it takes to learn it is quite another.




I favour a system that shows progression such as Bloom”s Taxanomy shown blow:




  
5 Create - In the revised Bloom’s taxonomy, creating something 


original or substantially new is considered to be the highest level 

of thinking. Verbs such as ‘generate’, ‘plan’ or ‘produce’ tell learners

 that they are required to work at this level.  

  
4 Evaluate - Learners working at this high level of thinking may 


be asked to ‘critique’ or ‘check’ materials.  

  
3 Analyze  - At the analytical stage, learners are commonly 


asked to ‘differentiate’, ‘organize’ or ‘attribute’ facts, data or 

subject matter.  

  
4 Apply - If learners are asked to ‘implement’ or ‘execute’ a task


 or action, they would likely be wo rking at this level of thinking.  

  
Remember - Action verbs such as ‘recognizing’, and ‘recalling’ tell 


     the learner that the learning is at the lowest level of thinking.  

  
Understand - Work at this level is likely to require actions such as ‘interpreting’, ‘exemplifying’, ‘classifying’, ‘summarizing’, ‘inferring’, ‘comparing’ and ‘explaining’.

BACKGROUND
	



	
	
Education
	is a lifelong process involving participation in experiences that

title: Boutique Academies
summary: Article examining the trend of specialized boutique academies in Canadian schools (arts, sports, heritage, advanced academics, tech) designed to keep disengaged students in school while filling seats amid declining enrollment. Discusses policy debate in York Region regarding an elementary arts program facing closure over concerns about early specialization and equity/access. Features opposing perspectives from educators, researchers (Donn Poll, Leonard Sax, Nina Bascia), and school trustees. References Edmonton Public Schools and Toronto District School Board's successful expansion of alternative programming. Explores tension between specialized programming and foundational education.
content_preview:
Boutique Academies tamara baluja undated

They are a trending topic in education right now: boutique academies in areas such as arts, sports, heritage, advanced academics and tech that keep bored students engaged while filling seats in school boards facing declining enrolment.

The demand for specialized programs is high across the country, with parents seeking cheaper alternatives to programs typically offered in private schools. The Toronto District School Board added nine elementary academies last month to its arsenal of 41 boutique schools, while Peel, one of Ontario’s fastest-growing boards, is looking at expanding its suite of specialized programs. In Alberta, the government has responded with enthusiasm to the idea that since 1994, non-profit organizations and companies have created dozens of charter schools. There are also a range of specialized public schools, including some just for hockey devotees.

Yet, in a school board north of Toronto, an arts program is faced with closing because some trustees say it is elitist and not the right fit for children of elementary school age.

The arts program at Baythorn Public School in York Region has integrated a blend of dance, music and visual art with the Ontario curriculum for 25 years, and the demand for entry remains high. However, the administration has raised concerns that Grade 5 may be too early to specialize, and the school’s audition requirement means it’s not equally accessible to all children.

Parents are fighting tooth and nail to save their arts school – so many showed up at a public meeting on the issue last week that they couldn’t fit in the meeting room. They say that, instead of facing the chopping block, the program should be expanded across the region. On the issue of access, they suggest the admissions criteria be replaced by a lottery system.

On the opposing side, trustee Diane Giangrande says elementary schools should be focused on broad-based foundational skills. Specialization, she says, s...

Don also outlines classification systems for educational objectives and proposes specific reforms including competency-based approaches, community education centers, area directors, and eliminating attendance enforcement requirements.

title: C-2 Education and Schooling-2
summary: Major essay differentiating education from schooling, arguing that confusing the two limits policy thinking and discourages lifelong learning. Don traces his personal education journey and advocates for broader service models. Central to his education reform philosophy.
content_preview:
About
education


Education
						
   	









No.
01										          June 1, 2014


C-@



	


	
	
Education
	- Any and all experiences that have a formative effect
	
 on
	a person’s attitude, knowledge or skill.



	


	
	
Background
	



	
	
We
	often confuse schooling and education; we do not similarly confuse
	health and hospitalization, religion with church attendance or
	citizenship with court appearances.  Seldom do we conclude that a
	person is healthy because they spent time in a hospital or are
	religious because they attend church, mosque or synagogue regularly.
	 Why, therefore, do we continue to speak of education when we mean
	schooling?  
	
	



	
	
To
	make my point, I was asked recently about my education.  I proceeded
	to tell about the work habits learned on the farm, authors of
	influence, the impact of a university course in philosophy,
	backpacking in Europe, a consulting project in Nairobi, etc. all of
	which had an impact on me.  It turned out, however, that all my
	questioner wanted to know was where I went to school.  
	
	



	
	
Blurring
	the differences between schooling and education is likely to:
	
		


		Discourage
		lifelong learning
		


		Create
		dependence rather than promote self-reliance
		


		Limit
		learning to what is available in school or organized by teachers
		


		Reinforce
		the notion that education is limited to the study of traditional
		disciplines,
		


		De-emphasize
		the importance of personal skills such as self-reliance, problem
		solving, entrepreneurship and creativity.
		


		Blur
		accountability
	
	



	
	



	
	
Education
	



	
	
As
	for definitions, Good’s Dictionary of Education defines education 
	as “the aggregate 
	
	
of
	all processes by means of which a person develops abilities,
	attitudes and other forms of behaviour of positive value in the
	society in which he lives.”  A persons education is often
	described in terms of such skills as creativity, citizenship, social
	and civic responsi...

title: C-3-A Learning Path
summary: Education 20/20 document synthesizing panel discussions with young people about learning pathways. Presents multiple learning steps and emphasizes that individual paths differ based on learning styles and purposes. Reflects Don's learner-centered and empirical approach to education design.
content_preview:
About
education








Learning
path			
    				About C-3-A				
					               	 November6, 2014






To
learn is to change behaviour, to engage in experiences that have a
formative effect on the way we think, feel and act.  A person who has
learned has new knowledge, new skill or a changed attitude.  To help
us better understand the learning process, Education 20/20 invited a
panel of young people to tell us how they went about learning and
what kinds of support were most helpful.  After considerable
discussion panel members settled on the following steps on the
learning path:






	


		Gather
		Information			
		


		Attend
		lecture				
		


		Seek
		counselling			
		


		Observe
		demonstration			
		


		Attempt
		task				
		


		Undergo
		assessment			
		


		Motivate
		self
		


		Observe
		others
		


		Use
		resource material
		


		Reflect
		on experience			
		


		Take
		diagnosis				
		


		Obtain
		feedback			
		


		Take
		instruction
		


		Self
		evaluate
		


		Coach
		others
		


		Practice
	




	


	
	

	Students
	were asked the order in which the help was needed or provided; not
	surprisingly, individual paths differed.  For example, one student
	said his first step would be to Google the topic; another said if it
	involved a new skill, he would probably attempt it first, while
	others liked the traditional lecture as a place to start.  Since
	panel members were in school or recent graduates, much of the
	discussion revolved around gaining new knowledge rather than skills

	learning did not substantially change the nature of the help

The

title: C-3 Education or Schooling system
summary: Advocacy piece calling for renaming the Department of Education to reflect that it manages schooling, not education. Uses health system analogy to argue for expanded educational services beyond schools including assessment, counseling, and specialized services.
content_preview:
EDUCATION 							Issue No.C-3

20/20  	 	A 21st CENTURY EDUCATION SYSTEM      _______________________________________________________________________It is called a Department of Education but it functions as a Department of Public Schooling; it is time to either change the name or change the function. Although I write this of Prince Edward Island, for the record, the same could be said about every Province across the country. 




Education is a broad term encompassing what we learn from many sources and in many situations.    While what we learn in school is an important part, it is not our education; we should call it what it is.  To some, this may appear to be only semantics but confusing the two limits our thinking about the services needed.




Think of our health system for example.  The hospital is only one service provider.  Depending on individual needs, one may seek help from a pharmacy, a doctor or a clinic.  We may also seek information or actual assistance from a health agency, and there are many.  Some services may even be delivered to our homes.  




Educational services, however, are delivered generally in or through schools, colleges and universities; that is the equivalent to operating a health care system through our hospitals.  It seems to me that education could benefit from some additional services that are not school based such as diagnosis, assessment, guidance and counseling, visiting teachers and specialized clinics for help with reading. I am sure that readers will think of many others.




While we must “do schooling” better, many of the shortcomings we attribute to schools would be better served by resources outside the school system..




While I commend the Minister for improvements implemented to date, I urge him to consider ways to broaden his portfolio from schooling to education. 










__________________________________

Readers may contact the publisher at  HYPERLINK "mailto:education.2020@hotmail.com" education.2020@hotmail...

title: Canada Treasury Board Service Standard
summary: Canada Treasury Board guidance document defining service standards and their importance in government operations. Defines service standard as public commitment to measurable performance levels clients can expect under normal circumstances. Addresses what constitutes normal vs. special circumstances (holidays, emergencies, natural disasters). Explains importance of service standards for client service, performance management, expectation clarity, service improvement, results-based management, and government accountability. Describes two key purposes of service standards though full text is truncated. Relevant to institutional management and accountability frameworks.
content_preview:
Canada Treasury Board Service Standard

What Is a Service Standard

A service standard is a public commitment to a measurable level of performance that clients can expect under normal circumstances.

What are "Normal Circumstances"?

When developing service standards, the organization should consider its resources and expected level of demand for regular day-to-day service operations (normal circumstances). Special circumstances where regular service standards may not apply include holidays, the end of April for tax filing, natural disasters, or emergencies. These are circumstances that are typically not within the organization's control.




Why Are Service Standards Important?

Service standards are integral to good client service and to effectively managing performance. They help clarify expectations for clients and employees, drive service improvement, and contribute to results-based management. Service standards reinforce government accountability by making performance transparent, and increase the confidence of Canadians in government by demonstrating the government's commitment to service excellence.




Service standards serve two key purposes:




To provide staff with performance targets ("Phone must be answered within three rings"); and

To inform clients what to expect ("Waiting time is less than 10 minutes").

Many organizations have implemented service standards that serve these purposes. Examples are included in Appendix A.




A service standard should be linked to an operational performance target or the frequency to which the organization expects to meet the service standard. The target takes into account the risks associated with process delays and uncertainties arising from factors such as workload fluctuations, staff movements, and seasonal variations.




The purpose of the target is to help manage operations and track progress against overall delivery objectives. The target is typically designed for management use but can also be made availabl...

title: Carver-Jim Travers
summary: (Don's work with Community Foundation on Carver Scholarship Trust).
content_preview:
Jim Travers




Orin Carver Scholarship Trust










In 1992, the Province of Prince Edward Island established the Orin Carver Scholarship.  To administer the scholarship, the Province established two committees, one to administer the funds (Annex 1) and the other to select candidates (Annex 2).   On August 15, 2000, the Province transferred administration of the Trust to the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (Annex 3)




As the Foundation gained experience administering the trust agreement, it became evident that some changes to the agreement are required and others would simplify the administration of the Fund.  Consequently, on June 3, 2003, the attached letter (4) was sent to the Minister of Education who was then responsible for the Agreement.  In the meantime responsibility for the Agreement was transferred to the Attorney General’s Department. The requested changes have not been dealt with yet.   




I have discussed the Foundation’s interest in changes to the agreement with the Deputy and, during our most recent discussion, offered to expedite the process through providing a draft agreement for his consideration.  




On reflection, I drafted two agreements.  The first provides administration of the Carver scholarship as an “Agency Fund” which means that the Government of Prince Edward Island can withdraw the funds from the foundation at any time. (Annex 5).  The other is our more standard agreement under which the Foundation would administer the Carver Scholarship in perpetuity (Annex 6).  We are comfortable with either but prefer the latter.




A copy of both agreements will be sent to you electronically.




We would appreciate your advice on the wording of the agreement and, frankly, any assistance you can give to bring the matter to an early resolution.




Please do not hesitate to let me know if you need further information.




Sincerely




Don Glendenning

Director

title: Carver MacKay
summary: (Don as Director of Community Foundation, scholarship administration).
content_preview:
Gordon Mackay




Further to our discussion of January 16, this is to confirm that we are putting forward proposals to the Government of Prince Edward Island for changes in the Agreement covering the Orin Carver Scholarship Trust.  The proposed changes do not infringe upon the operation of the Orin Carver Scholarship of which you are the Chair.




As a result of our meeting, however, I have since discussed the Carver Scholarship with the Registrar of the University of Prince Edward Island and have copies of the brochure, application and poster.  It appears  that we all agree that it is appropriate for the applications to come directly to the foundation rather than to UPEI.




I will write a follow-up letter shortly outlining the planned changes to all parties involved.







Sincerely







Don Glendenning

Director

title: Carver-revised procedures
summary: (Don's institutional work with scholarship administration).
content_preview:
Alan Buchanan, Registrar




Orin Carver Scholarship 



This is a follow-p to our discussions about the administration of the Orin Carver Scholarship.




The current arrangement for administering the agreement is for applications to be sent to UPEI.  Following the closing day, applications are bundled together by UPEI and sent to The Community Foundation following which, in consultation with Gordon, Chair of the Selection committee, applications are copied, and a date set for the committee to meet , review and select.




Once the selection is made, the Foundation informs the successful candidate, issues a cheque and, usually at a later date, publicizes the award as part of our awards ceremony.




We all agree that the handling of applications by the University is an added step which can and should be eliminated.  We also want to ensure that students are safeguarded during the changeover.  Consequently, and effective immediately, I propose that:







Both the Foundation and the University distribute brochures, posters and applications as in previous years. (I realize that there may be some overlap but better that than to miss someone)

Before doing so, however, that the return address on each be changed from UPEI to the Community Foundation

That the Registrar of Holland College be briefed about these changes.

Applications received by UPEI or Holland College be forwarded immediately to the community foundation.

At the end of this term, surplus brochures, applications and posters be forwarded to the Foundation for distribution in future years.

Addresses be changed when supplies are being reprinted.




I believe that these changes reflect our discussions; if not, please let me know immediately.




Sincerely




Don Glendenning

Director







Cc Gordon MacKay

title: Challenge for credit
summary: Minister's Directive 2011-01 establishing External Credentialing Policy for PEI high schools. Policy allows students (grades 10-12) to earn high school credits for external programs, courses, and assessments meeting or exceeding provincial standards. Key provisions include: maximum one non-compulsory credit via external credential toward 20-credit (English) or 25-credit (French) graduation requirement; external credentials cannot fulfill compulsory credits; equivalency restrictions apply; external credentials must contribute to Essential Graduation Learnings (aesthetic expression, citizenship, communication, personal development, problem solving, technological competence); students pay costs and fees; schools verify credentials and maintain records; department maintains approved provider list; External Credentialing Advisory Committee monitors implementation. Document includes detailed requirements for program providers regarding organizational profile, course profile, essential graduation learnings, and principles of learning. This represents significant curriculum flexibility policy allowing recognition of learning in multiple contexts.

title: CHOICE AS AN AGENT OF CHANGE
summary: Major essay (May 11, 2014) advocating choice as educational reform mechanism. Don argues individuals differ in experiences, interests, learning styles; choice-making is an important educational skill; individuals should take responsibility for choices; consumer choices drive service improvement. Contrasts limited educational choice with choice available in other sectors (church, professional services). References Bay County (Florida) School Authority 2005 open enrollment example. Proposes four choice dimensions: School choice (location), teacher choice (chemistry between teacher and student), scheduling choice (flexibility in time spent in school), and graduation date choice (based on competency not age). Argues choice removes excuses, increases accountability, and creates window of opportunity for system transformation. Notes Alberta's variety of school types (public, private, charter, religious, specialty arts/hockey) all open to residents. Emphasizes that most other services are similarly limited in small communities, so rural constraints shouldn't prevent choice. Well-reasoned argument with practical implementation suggestions.
content_preview:
CHOICE AS AN AGENT OF CHANGE







I’m writing this from Panama City Beach, Florida.  The topic arises from an item in this morning’s paper - a half-page advertisement by the Bay County School Authority, which read in part as follows:




Where do you want your child to attend school?

School Choice

Open enrolment will be held February 1-28,2005




The advertisement goes on to say that the following must complete a “School Choice Selection Card”:

Parents of children entering kindergarten, 6th and 9th grade

Parents of children wishing to change schools

Parents of children new to the area




I thought back to when our children were young and we were purchasing a home; our choices were limited in part because we had to send our children to the nearest school.  Where we lived and where our children went to school should be separate decisions.  I understand that learners today have some choice as to where they attend school and are not as restricted to the schools nearest where they live.  Canadian and US newspapers have been carrying articles on the results in the recent OECD international testing program, and the need to do better.   In the context of that debate, I suggest that we consider increased choice as an agent of change in the educational system.




Freedom to choose is an important right; at the highest level, we favour a system of government that provides a large degree of choice ay the governed as to who will govern – not a perfect system but a good system. 




Significant consumer choice, I believe, has a positive effect on suppliers of products and services – and education is a service.  In the retail trade, for example, choice increases the range of products and services available, introduces more competitive pricing, lowers costs and improves service.  Stop and think for a moment, we can choose our church, dentist, lawyer, mechanic, mayor, retail outlet and doctor but we have limited choice of schools our children attend and no choice in their ...

title: Choice
summary: A brief but forceful argument for expanding learner choice in education. Glendenning observes we choose churches, dentists, lawyers, mechanics, and doctors, yet education provides minimal choice. He argues choice improves quality, introduces competitive pricing, lowers costs, and improves service across all sectors, so why not education? The document reflects his market-oriented perspective on educational improvement, suggesting that consumer power drives institutional accountability better than bureaucratic oversight.
content_preview:
COMPETITION







I write this while in the USA where the media reports and comments almost daily on school reform including the takeover by the State of  ”troubled”  schools,  majors and minors for high school students, settling the length of the school year, the distribution of new and experienced teachers among schools, high school graduation requirements, incorrect FCAT scores, and school vouchers.  Instead, I suggest that we think outside the box and try increasing learner choice.  




Significant consumer choice, I believe, has a positive effect.  Choice increases the range of products and services available, introduces more competitive pricing, lowers costs and improves service.  Stop and think for a moment, we can choose our church, dentist, lawyer, mechanic, mayor, retail outlet and doctor but what choices do we really have about the education of our children?  

  

If choice improves the quality of service in other sectors, why not put it in play in education?

title: Chtn Handout
summary: Comprehensive public handout contextualizing the youth preparedness issue. Don frames youth challenges (high debt, low incomes, unemployment, emotional stress) alongside systemic issues (sluggish economy, low literacy rates). He emphasizes that these are community issues requiring concerted stakeholder action. His call for joint effort among learners, parents, employers, and community members exemplifies his inclusive leadership philosophy.
content_preview:
____________________ ____________________________________________




Education and Preparedness




Youth today are facing many issues including high debt load, low incomes, temporary employment, emotional stress, lack of jobs and high unemployment; the good news is that there is growing recognition that something needs to be done, and soon.  On the one hand, a sluggish economy reduces opportunity for employment; on the other hand young people lack skills and experience needed to take advantages of the opportunities that do come along.  As a result, our young people are at risk of an uncertain future.  




Low rates of youth literacy are at play in the issue.  For example, an International Adult Literacy and Life Skills survey in 2003 revealed that nearly half of our youth have low literacy rates and, in fact, the rates had not improved during the previous 10 years. Until these figures improve significantly, PEI will have difficulty in attracting high skilled industries and retaining our young people.




In order to better understand the issues of youth, The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (CFPEI) undertook a survey of over 200 Island youth on a number of issues that directly affect them; the report, Taking the Pulse of Island Youth, available on the Foundation website, www.cfpei.ca, provides a snapshot of findings.  Bright spots include a positive sense of community, emerging entrepreneurial opportunities, volunteerism and new postsecondary offerings.  Main concerns include lack of jobs, surviving on low paying jobs, educational deficiencies and drug and alcohol addictions.  On the subject of education and learning, the study reports a high rate of completion of high school and postsecondary education, a high level of inclusivity and relatively affordable tuition costs.  In terms of “preparedness”, however, participants report relatively low levels of achievement on PISA tests in reading, mathematics and science. 




These are serious issues, but t...

title: Chtn Press Release
summary: Post-event press release (January 21, 2014) reporting on the Charlottetown workshop, which attracted 35 participants. The release highlights an emergent theme: courage—both for young people transitioning to work, educators making hard decisions, and community members supporting education. Don is identified as workshop chair, and the release notes plans for similar workshops across the island.
content_preview:
January 21, 2014

Preparedness on the hotseat

Courage was an unexpected word in the discussion on education Monday evening in the Stratford Town Hall.  It came up independently at a number of round tables; at one it was used to describe a quality needed by young people as they transition from school to work, at another the word was used to describe community members who take a stand for education, while the third application was to school leaders who have the courage, not only think outside the box, but to act on that thinking.

The workshop, organized by Education 20/20 and chaired by Don Glendenning, first heard a presentation on the findings of a recent survey of over 200 Island youth between the ages of 15 and 25.  The survey, Taking the Pulse of Island Youth, dealt with youth concerns about health, education, employment and social well-being.  The presentation, led by Steve McQuaid, VP of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island and Katherine MacDonald, Researcher, provided details about the methodology and results.  

The group then turned their attention to one of the findings, the preparedness gap, and how it could be narrowed.  Ideas were many and included the need for action not further study, the need to review and perhaps redefine the role of schools, and the declining value of high school diplomas resulting from social promotion.   Similar workshops are planned for other Island communities in the coming weeks.  People interested in future activities of Education 20/20, or to be placed on the mailing list for the monthly newsletter, should send an email to pei@caneducation2020@.com

  
 30    -


Information: 	Don Glendenning

		pei@caneducation2020.com

title: CITIZENSHIP EDUCATION IN THE CONTEXT OF SCHOOL MATHEMATICS
summary: University of Alberta academic paper by Elaine Simmt exploring mathematics education's role in citizenship education. Argues mathematics has potential to help students understand society and their role in shaping it. Examines mathematization of society (quantification, statistical thinking, mathematical modeling) and questions whether math education develops critical citizens who understand these invisible structures. Critiques traditional math instruction (facts/skills, right/wrong emphasis) as subverting citizenship goals. Proposes instructional approaches: variable-entry prompts encouraging problem-posing, demand for explanation/justification, mathematical conversations emphasizing collaboration and collective problem-solving. Positions math as essential to informed, active citizenship in mathematized society.
content_preview:
CITIZENSHIP EDUCATION IN THE CONTEXT OF SCHOOL MATHEMATICS

Elaine Simmt, University of Alberta

Abstract




This paper suggests that mathematics has a role in citizenship education because it has the potential to help us understand our society and our role in shaping it. Through an examination of ways the study of mathematics can help students to identify and pose problems, the author argues that mathematics education is crucial in the development of informed, active and critical citizens in a society whose structures are largely mathematical.

What does mathematics education have to offer civics education?

On one hand, if we believe that mathematics is harmless and innocent because it has little to do with the world we live in, then we might simply respond that mathematics education does not have a role in civic education outside of offering some form of mental stimulation or exercise for the mind. However, even the pure mathematician agrees that mathematics is part of our human experience (Hardy, 1967; Davis and Hersch, 1981). As Keith Devlin notes, "the study of mathematics is ultimately the study of humanity itself" (Devlin, 1998, 9).

On the other hand, the applied mathematician would claim that his or her work is all about the world in which we live (Davis and Hersch, 1981) and that the role of mathematics in society has grown more and more significant in recent decades (D'Ambrosio, 1999). At the same time, one could argue that the mathematization of society "has become more and more hidden from view, forming an invisible universe that supports much of our lives" (Devlin, 1998, 12). If either the purist or the applied mathematician's observations about mathematics reflect the nature of mathematics, then it is important to consider the role that mathematics education could play in citizenship education because either an education in mathematics will help us understand ourselves or it will help us understand the world in which we participate. Of course, it co...

title: Clarity 2 ocx
summary: Don explores the fundamental distinction between "education" and "going to school," arguing they are often conflated. He notes that the World Bank warns against treating these as synonymous, yet the practice persists broadly. Don defines education as encompassing life experiences in home, school, and life itself, and argues a good education prepares people for everyday life decisions. He criticizes the absence of definitions in provincial education literature and compares nonprofits in health (more focused on health issues) versus education, suggesting education lacks definitional clarity present in other sectors.
content_preview:
EDUCATION

Doc 5 clarity

Education has a clarity problem and it is interfering with our ability to upgrade the educational level of our citizens. And it is not limited to Prince Edward Island

Take the matter of education. Many people believe that going to school and getting or having an education are one and the same. In fact, the length of time in school is frequently used as a measure uof one’s education. I don’t believe it; neither does the World Bank. But the belief continues. 

Education is an umbrella term; it is the result of our life experiences, first in the home, then in school and finally in life itself. Being educated means different things to different people. It is suggested that a good education is one that prepare you to make everyday life decisions.  Definitions are hard to come by in the education literature; I’ve googled a number of Provinces without success.  I’ve also searched other provinces, CMEC, CAMET and the CEA. Whether or not  I agree is not an issue, the fact that definitions are missing from provincial literature is another.

The practice of dealing with education under a school umbrella is diverts or detracts from the business at hand; Iif done deliberately would be considere a questionable practice.




A few wees ago, while discussing tis matter with a friend, he pulled out his phone tcck the number and nature of nonprofits first in education and ten in health. Non profits in health greatly outnumbered those in education but, more telling, yhose in health were more focused on the issues of health . title: Clarity 2

Compares provincial/jurisdictional educational purposes: Alberta ("preparing citizens for tomorrow"), Newfoundland (quality care/learning), Nova Scotia (confidence/contribution), Maine (best learning opportunities), Alberta (knowledge/skills for changing economy), OECD (whole person development). Analyzes PEI graduation requirements' focus on traditional subjects versus 21st-century skills.

title: Clarity 3
summary: Letter-format argument for clear educational purpose in PEI. Contrasts actionable purposes (Alberta's "citizens of tomorrow," New Brunswick's "lifelong learner attributes") with PEI's vague "find a place in society," noting difficulty designing curricula around such abstractions. title: Clarity-4-C docx
summary: Near-identical letter to File 18, containing same argument about PEI's education/schooling conflation and Department's narrow focus. Appears to be second draft or alternate version with identical core content and identical urging for immediate mission clarity and community conversation initiation. Both versions emphasize schools as resource locations (comparing to hospitals/spas) and argue services delivered matter more than facilities themselves.
content_preview:
Dear Editor:

A Call For Clarity - 4

Dear Editor

Education is complex.   Learners have different interests, capabilities, experiences and needs; They also fill a number of life roles, that of an Individual, family member, citizen, student, consumer and producer; education is needed or may help with any and all.

Education is also an umbrella word; a person’s education includes all the experiences that have changed a life and is demonstrated by our actions; Our education depends, to a large degree, on our experiences at home, in our community, through travel, interactions with others, personal exploration and roles we play in life. A good education has been described as one that provides a person with the knowledge, skills. attitudes and other attributes needed to deal with circumstances that confront us in our- every day lives; but there are other definitions as well 

 An education system consists of programs and services put in place to organize and deliver education services; typical tools of change include information, instruction; diagnosis, counselling, quality control, products and technology. 

Schools are an important component of any education system; they focus on instruction.  Attendance is required by law. Like a hospital or spa, schools are purpose-built facilities that house the people and services needed to support education. Having a well-equipped school is important but it is the service that impacts one’s education.  

It is said that education should help us develop the attitudes. skills, knowledge and other attributes that will allow us to thrive in later life but, to borrow a phrase from a sister Province, should each child leave school “having mastered the tools to learn”?

Sincerely




Don Glendenning


































Based on its documents and compared to other Provinces, The Department of Education is sending mixed messages about its educational interests, services and plans. 

  
It seems to treat education and school a...

title: Clarity - A
summary: Variant version of clarity essay emphasizing that Don offers "a call for clarity rather than proposing my set of definitions." Discusses how learning complexity, variable learner needs, and multiple life roles (citizen, family member, individual, student, consumer, producer) require clear terminology. Proposes specific benchmarks: by Grade 9, students should have essential skills for democratic participation. Compares provincial approaches and notes PEI's failure to specify what "education" means in contemporary context.
content_preview:

Education

A CALL FOR CLARITY -A




As a frequent participant in conversations about education, I am struck by the absence of definitions and boundaries; communication and understanding may suffer as a result. Conceptual clarity is a must to understand the people we serve, the services we provide, learner needs, product, processes and values especially when the subject carries layers of subjectivity. The Dictionary of Education (Good) defines definition as “the process of determining the definition or meaning of a word, idea or proposition in general and within a given context; the process of assigning meaning enhances both precision and clarity.”




Education is complex; information plays a key role.  Learners have different interests, experiences, capabilities and needs; they also fill a variety of life roles. Those who teach, or other-wise serve learners, must be very clear in their communication. Conceptual clarity heightens our understanding of key words and concepts; lack of clarity is a significant issue for public education.  It must be addressed directly so that the concept of education won’t become d-luted and potentially ineffective. Lack of clarity may arise form an idea itself, from the person promoting the idea or from the person receiving the idea; Lack of clarity could also signal conflicting ideas and levels of discomfort or disagreement from within the education family group itself and some say  “clarity” is also related to self confidence.    Conceptual clarify is also a must in planning and assessing performance. Education has a reputation for generating “educationese”; in fact, one can purchase an education “jargon generator”.

Calls for clear definitions, comparing PEI's approach unfavorably to Alberta's ("preparing citizens for tomorrow") and New Brunswick's ("attributes for lifelong learning").

title: Column 2 Learner
summary: A reflective column recounting an anecdote where Don was asked about his education at a social group. When he provided a comprehensive answer about farm upbringing, teaching training, and industrial arts education, his questioner dismissed it, wanting only formal school information. The piece illustrates Don's philosophical point about the limited, conventional understanding of "education" versus his holistic, lifelong view encompassing practical experience and skill development.
content_preview:
About Education




Where did I get my education?

I was asked not long ago where I got my education. I had joined a new group and expected to be a regular so I assumed that they wanted a bit of information for their records or in case someone needed notes to introduce me.  I was happy to comply. My questioner handed me a form to complete.

There were the usual questions, name, address, telephone number, Email address, where I was born, name of spouse, etc., etc, etc. not too difficult. Then came a space labelled “Education”.

Now that’s a question that invokes views. so I decided to elaborate in my answer. I mentioned growing up on a mixed farm which meant some involvement  with animals, vegetables and general  farm practices and, o course winter work in the woods.   I also mentioned that we each had chores to do and they varied  depending on the time of year.  I mention that I had traineed as a eacher, and separately as an industrial arts teacher,  but did not say for how long.I thought that I had given a reasonable view of my educational background.




Soon my friend returned to the table, picked up the paper and walked away; two minutes later he was back.  With a curt “I just want to know what school you went to”.

title: comp.Char
summary: Reference document outlining ten characteristics of a competency in standards context. Competencies must be action-oriented, preceded by "A person is able to...", derived from occupational analysis, verifiable through performance, observable, readily understood, expert-driven, and assessed against criteria. Core framework used throughout Don's standards work.
content_preview:
CHARACTERISTICS OF A COMPETENCY










1	Can be preceded by “A person is able to ...




2	Derived from an analysis of a field, discipline, or occupation




3	Verifiable through performance




4	Begins with an action word




5	Readily understood by relevant community




6	Expert driven




7	Performance of a competency is observable




8	Action oriented




9	Reflects the application of knowledge




10	Assessed against performance criteria

title: Competencies, global
summary: A concise reference defining global competencies as interdependent, interdisciplinary skill sets applicable locally and globally. Identifies six Canadian national competency categories: critical thinking and problem-solving, innovation and entrepreneurship, self-directed learning, collaboration, communication, and global citizenship/sustainability. Emphasizes competency as attitudinal and practical rather than purely knowledge-based.

title: Compton letter
summary: August 2, 2006 letter from Don Glendenning to Simon Compton seeking financial support for an agricultural equipment display project at Orwell. Don references their shared interest in preserving Island-made equipment and their previous site visits together, requesting contributions to the museum project.
content_preview:
August 2, 2006




Mr. Simon Compton

223 Sundance Cove

Stratford, PE

C1B 1L9




Dear Simon:




We’ve talked on occasion about a common interest in finding, retrieving, restoring and housing agricultural equipment made in Prince Edward Island.  One of the major problems, shared by all museums, is that of storage space.




The Prince Edward Island Museum and Heritage Foundation already has a number of pieces of Island-made agricultural equipment and is interested in developing a special display if suitable space were available.   The Community Foundation has been assisting them in their quest and attached is a brief description of the project.




Given our discussions, this letter comes to ask if you and/or other Compton family members, has an interest in contributing financial support to such a project?




You and I visited the site at Orwell and viewed the building a year or so ago.  I would be delighted to tour the site again with you and/or members of your family, and to meet with Museum Staff, if that would be helpful in the decision-making process.




I will contact you again in a couple of weeks to see if you have any questions.




Sincerely







Don Glendenning

Director

title: CRSP
summary: Glendenning's retrospective on designing CRSP, a competency-based secondary school model combining personalized, competency-based, and computer-based components with flexible structures and site-based management. Developed in his post-retirement consulting work (after 1987), the model was designed to be an alternative to "lock-step, teacher-centered, classroom-based delivery." The document describes major shifts embodied in CRSP: from fixed admission schedules to flexible entry/exit; from time-bound to competency-based curriculum; from graded to non-graded continuous progress; from teacher-centered to learner-centered; and from percentage-based to competency-based reporting. Glendenning claims it's "the only model which includes all components of a competency based system."
content_preview:
CRSP

The CRSP model is:




· Personalized in that it responds to and supports individual learners as they become increasingly self-motivated and independent learners. The model is built around non-gradedness, continuous progress and individualized instruction and tracks each student from the point at which they enter the program to the point at which they exit with a credit.

· competency based in that it draws content from real life rather that cut across traditional subject lines of academic disciplines. Competencies written as applications of knowledge, skills and attitudes judged necessary to function in adult life.

· computer based in that it makes use of technology to deliver and manage instruction. The use of technology also allows the learner and advisors to manipulate large numbers and quantities of resource materials with a focus on that which is most valuable to an individual learner.

· a flexible structure is needed to support large numbers of individual learners.

Characteristics of the model include a flexible school day and flexible school year, the multiple entry and exit of students, variable instructional and learning time to accommodate the view that more students can succeed if additional time is allowed.

· Based on site-based management allows planning and decision-making to occur at the school level so that day to day administration can be collegial and collaborative.




While the writer recognizes his biases, CRSP is thought to be the only model which includes all components of a competency based system.




* Canadian Vocational Association, Canadian Restructured School Plan, and Ottawa: The Association, 1993,221 pp. 






Although I retired from the college system in 1987, I was active as a consultant for a number of years thereafter. One of the most interesting assignments was a contract to design a competency based model for implementation at the secondary school level. It was both a stimulating and challenging assignment. The resul...

title: Culture
summary: Glendenning examines school culture as a historically-rooted cognitive framework of shared assumptions, values, norms, and practices that shape organizational behavior. The document argues that school cultures embody stable, long-term beliefs about organizational priorities, with written rules and unspoken norms influencing how members perform their roles. This analysis reflects his interest in the anthropological and sociological dimensions of educational reform—recognizing that transforming education requires addressing deep cultural beliefs, not merely structural reorganization.
