title: Curriculum-2 `Notes
summary: Synthesizes curriculum development research and Don's personal analysis of PEI education needs. Reviews provincial education literature (Alberta, Ontario, BC, Canada 2020) and emerging competency-based approaches. Discusses William Spady's philosophy that practitioners, not educators alone, should identify outcomes. Notes that curriculum-based outcomes appear unique to Canada. Reports conversations with Island employers, parents, students, and educators revealing gaps in understanding of curriculum terms (outcomes, competencies, skills). Addresses mathematics education as key competency for new economy while remaining underperforming goal. Provides detailed observations and recommendations for PEI system improvements, including adoption of competency basis, dynamic rating scales, and independent assessment body.

title: Curriculum-4 Description-calculate pay
summary: Practical competency description applying curriculum platform framework to workplace numeracy skills. Focuses on calculating gross and net pay in context of gig economy where workers have multiple employers, irregular hours, and varied income sources. Identifies rationale (payment accuracy and reporting complexity) and elaborations covering employee wages, salaries, contract income, commissions, and piecework calculations. Specifies typical learning activities including aggregating pay slips, interpreting company policies, reporting errors, and recording transactions. Outlines performance assessment requirements including familiarity with tax law and use of actual pay records. Demonstrates practical application of platform framework to real-world employee needs.

title: Curriculum 5 Math
summary: Comprehensive analysis of mathematics education in PEI, examining curriculum definitions, components, and implementation issues. Identifies problems in current approaches: blurred definitions of curriculum, outcomes, and competencies; inconsistent curriculum bases (OBE vs CBE); lack of universal standards; and disconnects between educational providers and employers' needs. Proposes competency-based curriculum platform with analysis, profiles, assessment criteria, rating scales, and benchmarks. Provides extensive observations and conclusions, including recommendations for PEI to adopt competency-based approaches, improve assessment reliability, and increase coordination among education providers. Based on literature review and author's experience.

title: Czar
summary: A creative thought experiment where Glendenning imagines himself as education czar with absolute authority to implement five transformative changes: (1) assigning each student a permanent educational advisor (like a family doctor) responsible for guidance through K-12; (2) separating teaching and credentialing functions into distinct organizations (like City and Guilds); (3) allowing learners choice of any teacher/school with student transportation; (4) replacing teacher compensation based on knowledge and experience with performance-based pay reflecting work done, complexity, and merit; and (5) replacing Department of Education bureaucracy with accountability to teachers for student learning. The piece reveals Don's frustrations with institutional inertia while offering concrete reform proposals grounded in his philosophy.
content_preview:
45 Czar for a Day or maybe even two days




It would be fun to be Czar for a day; Putin is not likely to step aside so I’ll limit myself to being an educational Czar.  As Czar, one could make significant changes knowing that they could not be over-ruled by the Minister, watered down by the superintendent or principal or rejected by the teachers' union. I find that it is not teachers but rather administrators and teachers' unions that are most likely to oppose change.




My initial list was a long one and included such changes as placing more freedom and accountability at the individual school level, clearer standards, clearer differentiation of levels of performance, clearer lines of accountability, more freedom for teachers to make professional decisions, changing the emphasis from time served to performance, emphasizing communication skills and merit pay.  Introducing those changes would be more than one could accomplish in one day so I decided to limit myself to five.  Here they are: 







First would be to require each student to have an “education advisor” with a role similar to that of a family doctor.  Most of us would not be very happy if we had a new family doctor each year, especially if it was not of our choosing.  The education advisor would, for the most part, provide advice and direction for at least K through 12, however, students could elect to change advisors but advisors would have no choice in selecting students except because of a heavy workload.  As with a family doctor, the educational advisor would work with a learner and advice and direct the learner in a course of action intended to meet the learner’s educational goals; an educational advisor would also have authority to place students with specialist teachers as necessary.   Student transcripts would be signed off by the educational advisor.  







Second, I would separate the teaching and the sorting functions, that is, if degrees and diplomas are thought to be important, set up one ...

title: D 01 Gates
summary: This ambitious proposal to a major philanthropic funder (Gates Foundation implied) articulates a comprehensive vision of education system transformation. Don argues that education improvement requires three foundational changes: increased public engagement through unaligned organizations (like those prevalent in health), market-based delivery systems enabling school choice and teacher innovation, and continuous progress models replacing age-based cohort systems. He critiques the current system as bureaucratic, inflexible monopoly failing to accommodate individual learner needs or employ customer service principles. The proposal argues for early childhood as distinct from education, expanded life skills focus, and structural separation of instruction from assessment/credentialing. This document represents Don's most ambitious systemic reform articulation.
content_preview:
Potential Funder




Dear Sir:




This letter comes to introduce an idea which will exert a long-term positive impact on public education.  In saying this, I refer to the establishment of a mechanism that will increase both public information and public engagement in the education field; I am speaking of a public unaligned organization of the kind so prevalent in the field of health, but practically non-existent in education.




The nature and quality of our education will, to a large extent, determine our future as individuals, communities and countries and, while most countries and education systems, are instituting changes, the changes fail to deal with a number of underlying  weaknesses in the system.  I am of the view that the long-term improvement of education requires:

 

  
Increased public engagement





Even a cursory examination of education reveals that the system, especially when compared with health, is a cumbersome, bureaucratic, inflexible monopoly than can accommodate individual learner needs only with great difficulty; the concept of good customer relations is a foreign concept.   Sources of information are generally aligned with existing providers of educational services (Home and School, etc  ) rather than with  the sector as a whole.  Educators writing for the public are non-existent, at least in our community, documentaries deal with the operation of schools rather than with teaching and learning,   




  
A delivery system based on normal market principles





It can be demonstrated that competition or choice in a sector improves both products and service.  By choice, I refer to the ability to choose ones school, allowing schools to develop specialties such as the arts or sciences, allowing a significant ortion of the education budget “follow the student”, and even allowing teachers to open clinics outside a school.   In addition, teachers’ salaries are based on credentials rather than qualifications and do not acknowledge increased pay ...

title: D 16 Reading Improvement Proposal
summary: A detailed proposal identifying weaknesses in the current reading support system and proposing comprehensive improvements. Don identifies systematic gaps: lack of early detection, poorly defined outcomes, inflexible delivery, and inadequate assessment. His improvement strategy is holistic, including emphasis on reading as a separate subject, extended learning hours through summer and night classes, reading specialists and clinics, technology integration, and community engagement. He proposes learning passports, benchmark systems, community reading discussions, and awards to incentivize improvement. The document showcases Don's capacity for systems thinking, his understanding of learner-centered design, and his belief in combining professional expertise with community participation.

title: D-17-C Noverhaul-2
summary: Paper titled "Restructuring Called For," proposing specific organizational changes to PEI's Department of Education. Argues that education should serve 160,000 PEI citizens across all life roles, not just youth under 17. Advocates for "form follows function" principle with 8 departmental functions reporting to Deputy Minister: Instruction, Standards, Program Support, Information and Counselling, Learning Products and Technology, Quality Assurance, Finance, and Administration. Critiques current structure for burying important functions in bureaucracy and limiting professional autonomy. Calls for glossary of education terms and clearer statement of departmental purpose.

Calls for conceptual clarity, particularly distinguishing "going to school" from "getting an education" based on World Bank cautions. Advocates for organization following "form follows function" principle. Repeats call for glossary, clear purpose statement, and organizational structure with specific functional areas. Notes that structural impediments must be addressed before improvement steps can begin.

title: D-2 Credibility
summary: Brief occasional paper examining credibility problems in education research and practice. References philosopher John Wilson's observation that educational studies lack coherent discussion, psychologists noting teacher credibility's strong effect on student learning (trust, competence, dynamism, immediacy), and Joel Levin's work on education research credibility gaps. Notes that education has a quality problem and that PEI Education Act defines school narrowly as "structured learning environment through which education program is offered."

title: D-2
summary: The second issue of "Open Education" newsletter, focusing on reading as a key skill and "golden tool" for accessing knowledge. The document provides multiple definitions of reading from different perspectives, discusses the two types of reading performance differences (range of materials readable versus depth/fluency), acknowledges widespread community concern about reading levels, and proposes interventions including early detection, better outcome definitions, criterion-referenced assessment, inclusion on report cards, and professional early childhood support.

title: D 20. Restructuring
summary: May 2020 paper on reorganizing education services structure. Argues current system reflects "schooling not education." Proposes function-based management with six key service components: (1) Governance & Leadership (planning, liaison, advocacy, quality control); (2) Instruction (teaching, demonstration, coaching, diagnosis); (3) Information & Counselling (assessment, referral, advocacy); (4) Quality Assurance (credentials, qualifications); (5) Funding (capital, operating); (6) Learning Products (texts, technologies, MOOCs). Represents mature articulation of systems thinking about educational delivery.

title: D-20020 83
summary: A brief letter contrasting employment-based assessment criteria (quality, quantity, problem-solving, leadership, dependability) with academic grading practices based on written tests. Don suggests employment-preparatory education courses should use employment-based rating methods more aligned with real-world expectations. Fragment of larger discussion on assessment practices.

October 20, 2019

102

Editor,

Charlottetown Guardian

Charlottetown, PEI	




Dear Sir: 

Assessing education for employment




We up our education for many reasons – we want to increase or income, change jobs, be more mobile, understand our origins or surroundings, etc. etc. etc. many reasons are simply to meet our own circumstance and needs some reasons reflect the wishes or requirements of other; further education and education for paid employment fall under the latter.




Employment preparatory courses us usually use employment-based criteria when performance, such as:

•	Quality

•	Quantity

•	 Problem solving

•	Leadership, and

•	Dependability

Some employment-based rating scales in-clude both assistance and supervision; rat-ing on academic subjects tends to be based on written tests. And, therefore, are less applicable to employment.




Don Glendenning

A long-time student of education

title: D 2016-Independent assessment
summary: Policy advocacy piece proposing separation of testing and grading from teaching function. Glendenning observes employers find high school graduation inadequate indicator of essential skills. He argues grading inconsistencies arise from variable assessment practices and proposes independent assessment organization separate from schools, comparable to apprenticeship models. References international qualification frameworks in developed countries. This sophisticated policy argument demonstrates his systematic thinking about assessment reform and his willingness to propose structural changes to educational systems.
content_preview:
,


    




___________________________________________________________________________


For immediate release


Date: July 8, 2016








Separate testing service needed








Some employers are wondering if they should have
job applicants take an achievement test before offering them a job;
some employers already do.  The reason is simple.  Employers find
that “high school graduation” is not an adequate measure of 
basic skills, especially such skills as measurements, writing work
reports, making change, mental arithmetic, reading maps or giving
directions. When asked what math skills should be taught, one
employer replied “Teach them logic”.  The skills people
identified are also referred to as essential skills, employability
skills or even the “skills of everyday living”. 








Many employers ask for “high school graduation”
in their advertisements, but that’s too large a “mesh” thinks
Dr. Don Glendenning, President of Education 20/20 Inc. “there are
too many variables in the way school grades are determined for that
to work: confusion between school grades and  achievement level,
wording of outcome statements, social promotion, assessment process,
rating scales and the nature of benchmarks, to name but a few.”
Glendenning thinks that grading should be separated from schools,
removed from teaching responsibilities and handled by an independent
organization – “the way we do with apprenticeship.”  








Glendenning came to the realization that testing
and grading were separate functions about a year ago in conversation
with a group of students about the kind of help they needed with
their learning.  “We plotted student comments in the form of a flow
chart or path and the separation between teaching and grading became
crystal clear.”  A simple achievement test would likely give most
employers all they need to know to make employment decisions. Most
developed countries, other than Canada and the USA, have national
qualification framework help solve these ...

title: D 25 Skill DevelopmentNews
summary: A letter critiquing educators' neglect of "skill development" in favor of knowledge focus. Don observes that teacher compensation and student grades emphasize knowledge acquisition (lowest level of Bloom's taxonomy) rather than ability to apply knowledge. He defines skill development as "an educational process of increasing a person's ability to do something" and argues it applies across all programs and subjects. The letter advocates for higher achievement standards and greater precision in educational terminology to increase accountability.
content_preview:
February 12. 2017




Editor,

Charlottetown Guardian

Charlottetown, PEI	




Dear Sir: 

		  

Skill Development

Educators seldom talk about skill development; it seems at odds with their culture.  An educator’s life seems to revolve around knowledge; teacher pay scales are  based on their level of knowledge rather than their skill or complexity of task.  Student grades are based on tests of knowledge, one of the lowest levels of learning.  Published grading requirements re waivd   through ”social promotion”.  No wonder high school diplomas have lost much of their value as a screening device for postsecondary institutions or employment. 




 On the other hand, the federal government pay for tithe latest example is that of “skill development”.  It’s almost as though being accurate or precise is not important or too confining or perhaps; a suspicious person may think it is avoided to reduce accountability.  My definition is a simple one; “Skill development is an educational process if increasing a person’s ability to do something.”      And it is applicable to any program and any subject.




In my understanding, undertaking a skill development program could include increasing one’s level in public speaking, mathematics, coding, or teaching. It is more than increasing one’s knowledge it is about being able to apply that knowledge to solving additional or more complex problems.  Bloom’s taxonomy lists the lowest level of cognitive learning as knowing




Skill development programs require a higher level of achievement on common skills than







Sincerely

Don Glendenning

A long-time student of education

title: D 3 Quality Check
summary: March 1, 2018 synthesis of international quality education standards from UNICEF (2000), UNESCO (2017), OECD PISA (2011), Glaze Report (2016), and other sources. Identifies consensus principles: learner health/readiness, safe/protective environments, relevant curricula and basic skills, trained teachers using child-centered approaches, outcomes linked to national goals. Emphasizes school autonomy correlation with better performance (OECD), importance of accountability plus autonomy (Bedard), and student transitions as success measure (CMEC). Includes Bennett's governance recommendations and function-based management. Represents Don's commitment to evidence-based educational policy informed by international best practices.

title: D 31 Reading
summary: A comprehensive three-stage strategy for establishing non-aligned public community groups focused on reading improvement. Stage One emphasizes public engagement through discussion papers, workshops, and media outreach. Stage Two includes establishing a federal charter society with membership, identifying reading as a separate subject in teacher training and certification, and creating qualification authorities for reading assessment. Stage Three involves creating training programs, publications, and community services like reading round tables and library tutoring. Don's proposal encompasses teacher professional development, system redesign through report cards and benchmarks, community information campaigns, and research documentation. This represents his most ambitious reading reform vision, integrating multiple intervention levels from policy to grassroots community action.

title: D 34 Employer based writing
summary: A November 2013 proposal for a tutoring service operating afternoons (4-6 PM) specifically for employed youth, with employers contributing one hour of paid time if employees contribute one hour unpaid. This cost-sharing model reflects Don's pragmatic approach to resource mobilization and partnership building. The proposal includes the Better Writing foundation philosophy statement, emphasizing reading and writing as foundational competencies and the organization's commitment to evidence-based, non-aligned advocacy for improvement. This initiative addresses a real gap—working youth's continued need for literacy support—and demonstrates Don's ability to design programs that fit within people's actual circumstances.

title: D 34 Innovators Conference
summary: A brief proposal to establish an Innovators Network supporting educational improvement through fostering innovation climate, identifying innovators, linking those with similar interests, recognizing contributions, and organizing annual front-line innovator conferences. Don's vision recognizes that innovation often happens at the grassroots level among practitioners rather than only in policy circles. By creating networking opportunities and recognition mechanisms, he aimed to amplify practitioner innovations and create communities of practice. This initiative reflects his understanding of organizational change dynamics and his belief in building from existing energy and expertise rather than imposing top-down reform.
content_preview:
Innovators Network

Background




Purpose

To support improvement in education by fostering a climate for innovation, , identifying innovators, linking innovators with other innovators with similar interests, recognizing their efforts and contributions, providing networking opportunities, by supporting collaborative initiatives, fostering a network of innovators, organizing annual conference for front line innovators.

title: D 34 Staff Development
summary: A concise proposal to support school-level staff development through a competitive grant process. Don proposes soliciting proposals from schools with support from principals and school boards, requesting submissions of one-page applications with budgets for development initiatives grounded in sound educational principles. Funding would have a cap and require local contribution in cash or kind. This modest initiative demonstrates Don's belief that effective change depends on school-level practitioners and his commitment to enabling innovation through thoughtful resource allocation. The requirement for local contribution ensures ownership and sustainability.

title: D 37 Engagement
summary: A proposal to engage young Islanders in documenting significant community events and decisions from the past 150 years through interviews with seniors and examination of local records. Objectives include increasing community knowledge and pride, building intergenerational relationships, recognizing community builders, and strengthening communication skills. Don proposes organizing groups in fourteen communities with priority for 14-year-olds (honoring the year 2014). Implementation includes a part-time coordinator and local organizers with honoraria, community group funding for materials and events, and a province-wide gathering to share findings. Reports would be placed in libraries and schools, with originals in provincial archives. This initiative combines educational benefit, intergenerational connection, and community history preservation.

Subject:  Community Engagement Through History




Background:







Proposal:	To engage young Islander in learning about significant events in their local community during the past 150 years.	

Objectives:

  
Increase level of knowledge an understanding of people about the community in which they live
  
Increase the level of pride in community
  
Build positive relationships among community members
  
Build relationships between generations
  
Provide a record to a community of its accomplishments
  
Help communities recognize their own community builders
  
Strengthen communication skills among participants.


Concept:

Engage Island communities in an activity that focuses on their history through a process of identifying key decisions, activities and events in the life of their own community. Information will be gathered mainly from two sources, newspaper reports of the day, records of community organizations, and memories of senior citizens.  




Workplan:

Communities will be identified, groups will be organized and information gathering begun in the fall of 2013; Community shaping events will identified and priorized, senior citizens interviewed, and reports drafted by Easter.  Reports will be released and presentations made to the community, including local groups and seniors’ residence, in May.  Reports will be finalized in June and reports released.  Organizers of local events will be encouraged to incorporate findings into their other community celebrations during the summer.  An opportunity will be sought for a province wide gathering in Charlottetown where participants can display their reports and meet an interested public.




Deliverables:

Copies of reports will be placed in local school libraries, local branches of the public library.  While much of the background information will be found in the public domain, it is likely that some will come from family scrapbooks, therefore copies of reports, int...

title: D-4 Gap
summary: Open Education No. 68 (December 17, 2016), authored by Don Glendenning discussing responsibility allocation in education between learners, parents, teachers, and government. He argues learners are responsible for their own learning (with parental support), but government's prescriptive education model shifts responsibility from family to bureaucracy. Don critiques that education leadership has imposed their model on citizens while assuming responsibility for defining what should be learned and when. He notes the gap: unlike health or justice, limited independent guidance exists for parents and learners about next steps, resulting in young people entering work or post-secondary education unprepared. Don questions what education services Islanders need and what delivery methods would serve them best, challenging fundamental assumptions about education's organization and purpose.

title: D 7 Student advocate
summary: Dated January 2, 2013, this proposal addresses the gap in educational support services for individuals outside formal schooling. Don advocates for a community-based educational support service with a student advocate position—a professional independent from schools who would help people navigate educational choices and access programs. The service would operate like a "family doctor" for education matters, providing information, counsel, advice, assessment, monitoring, and referral. The advocate would require education experience, occupational background outside education, strong communication skills, and maturity. This innovative model would serve community members of all ages seeking to improve their education.
content_preview:
January 2, 2013




Student advocate

Background




  
Education includes all our learning experiences; schooling is an important part but only a part. While schooling is emphasized when entering the labour market, it is the often other parts of one’s education that allow one to flourish. 
  
Education is also complex, even schooling has become complex, and people need help to navigate the system. At least in schools, we have guidance counsellors to provide help; the education system has nothing, however, equivalent to the service of a family doctor for matters of health or a lawyer for matters of law. 
  
For people not yet of school age or no longer part of the school system, support for individuals is patchy and focused primarily on finding employment. 
  
Another side of the issue is more support for individuals in school but likely to drop out.  Pathways to Education, http://www.pathwaystoeducation.ca/, a project operating in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, is such a project and deserves examination. 
  
Independent study and challenge for credit





Purpose:  

  
Assist individual Islanders of any age to access programs and services needed to meet individual educational objectives.  


Proposal:

  
Develop a community  based educational support serviceProvide assistance to individuals, and perhaps some parents, in the making of educational choice.  





Notes:

  
The office may well make use of part time staff and even volunteers.
  
Users may include parents of young children; local people wanting to return to school, graduates who realize that they need new skills, and many others. 
  
Serve a community not a school district
  
Provide information and advice about education. 
  
The officer would become the first point of contact for people seeking to improve their education and would work closely with the local schools, adult training programs, and community agencies but not simply be an arm of the local school.
  
Some of these services now exist, however, i...

title: D-8-2 Qualification Authority v2
summary: Occasional Paper D-8 proposing Canadian national qualification framework and independent assessment authority. Don argues for distinction between credentials (diplomas) and qualifications (demonstrated capability), using labour mobility examples and international models. Advocates for PEI government to lead development of qualification authority to improve school-to-work transition and economic competitiveness. Signature shows Don as author.
content_preview:
About Education			

A
	Qualification Framework

Occasional
paper D-8				            					June 28, 2015	



	________________________________________________________________________________________________
	



	
	
A
	Qualification Framework 
	
	

	Labour
	mobility is a fact of life; our ancestors practiced it, so have most
	of us.  The difference is that circumstances around us have changed,
	employment numbers have increased, the pace has quickened and people
	travel further afield.  Labour
	mobility
	refers to the movement of people from one part of the country to
	another. While many provinces experience high migrant and immigrant
	labour mobility, Prince Edward Island’s mobility pattern of
	interprovincial migrants from within Canada is one of the lowest.
	One example may be seen in the regular commute of Islanders between
	their home in PEI and their workplace in Alberta, another is the
	retraining needed when a town is devastated by a plant closing, and
	a third example of mobility is the education and experience that
	allows young people to live and work around the world. Labour
	mobility may be hampered geographic ties, absence of housing,
	unemployment benefits, licensing requirements, lack of portable
	qualifications, and lack of nationally recognized educational
	levels. 
	
	
Part of the
	mobility problem is the confusion between credentials and
	qualifications.  Diplomas and degrees are credentials; they are
	awarded to people who have successfully completed a prescribed
	number and pattern of courses in an institution. Given the huge
	variability of student expectations in each course and from one
	program of study to the next, it is understandable that graduates
	range in ability as is documented by grades spanning 50 to 100
	points. Graduates holding a credential do not necessarily mean they
	are ready for the demands of the workforce. We differentiate
	credentials from qualifications in that a qualification attests to
	the fact that the holder has de...

title: D Graduation
summary: Occasional paper from 2018 examining graduation's definition and purpose. Traces concept etymology (from Latin "gradus" meaning step), exploring multiple interpretations: program completion, years-of-study completion, meeting institution requirements, pay classification determinant. Articulates perspectives on graduation's meaning from parents (12 years schooling, essential skills, employment readiness), employers (communication skills), and post-secondary institutions. Questions what society expects of high school graduates. Demonstrates Don's careful analytical approach to taken-for-granted educational concepts and his commitment to rigorous definitional clarity in educational discourse.

title: D Math 3 ladder
summary: This proposal introduces the "math ladder" concept—a framework with clearly identified rungs representing known levels of mathematical achievement. Don argues that the practice of social promotion prevents meaningful comparison of skill levels across institutions and inhibits employers' ability to evaluate applicants effectively. The solution involves creating a mathematical ladder (comparable to music or skating certification levels) with independently assessed achievement levels. The ladder would establish common standards, aid labor mobility, and reduce curriculum development workload. Why math specifically: it has identifiable structure (numeracy through infinite series) but lacks widely accepted competency analyses and level agreements.

title: D Math 7 gap
summary: This detailed analysis documents the Mathematics Gap Initiative's scope and findings from Don's steering committee (including Duffy, Miller, White-Hassler, Greyborn, Francis). The committee established that the math gap is real and has severe economic consequences: reduced quality of life, lower productivity, higher unemployment, lower product quality, reduced wages, and poor customer service. Root causes identified include differing perceptions of institutional roles, silo mentalities, problematic curriculum development models, and education politicization. The proposal establishes an independent assessment service certifying proficiency in everyday mathematics skills. Services would be fee-based, age-neutral, providing certificates (not credentials) with results shared upon applicant request.

February
20,  2019


Kevin Murphy, President

Murphy
Hospitality Group

96
Kensington Road

Charlottetown
, PEI, C1A 5J4

		1-1-2DM






Dear

Math
on PEI






Although
PEI math scores on National and international tests have risen,
friends tell me that math has not improved on the shop floor; I’ve
been wondering why.






Islanders
need math; citizens may not need a  high level but they need to be
able to measure, sort, calculate, group and estimate numbers, space,
time  distance, etc.  and they need to do it quickly, easily,
accurately; and consistently.  This approach to math is called
numeracy and it involves the application of math to every-day lives.
Numeracy is being adopted elsewhere; usually in addition to
traditional math.  







But
we need more, to begin with we need an analysis of math skills used
by Islanders. Making an analysis involves bringing together a small
group for a two- day of brainstorming session.   It’s a proven
technique, we used it regularly at Holland College but apparently
there is no one on PEI now with the expertise.  We’ll have to bring
someone in at a cost $15,000.  I am approaching a few people who
might contribute $1-2,000 each to help cover the cost. The Community
Foundation, 121 Queen Street, Charlottetown, PE, C1A 4B3 will accept
donations on our behalf and issue charitable receipts. 







I
appreciate your consideration and would be happy to explain further
and answer any questions.  Thanks in advance






Sincerely,











Don
Glendenning

title: D-Qualification
summary: Don's essay on Atlantic qualification authority - (education reform).
content_preview:
Needed: An Atlantic Qualification Authority




Sometimes we need a piece of paper to prove what we’ve learned; this represents a sea change from the days when credentials, a high school diploma or college degree, would open most any door.  But diplomas and degrees are not enough, anymore, employers want evidence as to what a person can do with what he/she knows.  Welcome to the world of qualifications.




There’s some confusion as to the difference between qualifications and credentials.  My definitions are simple.  Degrees and diplomas are credentials; they tell what and where a person has studied.  A qualification, on the other hand, certifies that a person has the attitudes, skills and knowledge required to perform a role or a task.




Most countries have qualification authorities, except Canada and the US, that is; it’s probably because we don’t have a National Education Department.  I’m most familiar with the one in New Zealand which regulates the nature and quality of courses offered at both the secondary and postsecondary level. 













a person has stud degrees aIt’s true the world has changed; we must think globally even when planning locally. We are linked through investment, transportation systems, banking regulations, international agreements travel and instant communication.  Knowledge industries have exploded but the knowledge on which they are based is available at the end if the arm. Manipulation of information is the cutting edge. The importance of the omportance of the information deliverer has declined




Education is trapped by the cloak of its own success.  What it became good at yesterday is impeding its progress today.




Our post war expansopn was led by skilled people from western Europe




Education

 Still content oriented

Time based

title: D-Trustees

content_preview:
For Trustees, Help Available for Trustees













Many Islanders serve as trustees of their church, local cemetery or of a family or other trusts.  For many it is a family tradition; they are following in the footsteps of a father or grandfather.  They act willingly, however, I’ve talked to many during the past year who find themselves confronted with a dilemma.




That’s where the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island comes in.  For a small fee, the Foundation will accept cemetery funds as part of their investment portfolio.  Funds are managed by professional investors







The investment climate has changed; many feel uncomfortable.  They know they should invest for growth but the current market uncertain.  The larger dilemma, however, is that of finding a replacement when the step down.  The pool on which they draw is getting smaller and smaller each year as their sons and daughters move away.  And many of those who are left are not be willing to take on the responsibility.




Thhe Community foundation of Prince Edward island Based on My discussionsIn order to Earlier in the year

title: DACUM-50 Don
summary: Substantial historical essay dated October 15, 2017, documenting DACUM (Developing a Curriculum), a Canadian educational achievement. Chronicles post-WWII industrial training needs, Canada's Technical and Vocational Training Assistance Act (1960), and the Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation (1967) where Robert Adams developed competency-based curriculum analysis. Details Holland College's 1969 establishment and adoption of Adams' DACUM methodology, creating STEP (Self Training and Evaluation Process). Describes how Ohio State's Robert Norton helped spread DACUM throughout USA. Provides Adams' biography (1932-2016). Scholarly yet accessible, this document reflects Don's deep engagement with educational innovation history and his institution's foundational practices.
content_preview:
DACUM:
A CANADIAN ACHIEVEMENT






Draft

The
decade of industrial expansion immediately after WW2 was made
possible by the influx of skilled immigrants from Western Europe.  By
the late 1950’s, however, it became evident that Canada could no
longer depend on this source of supply. Furthermore, large numbers of
Canadians remained unemployed even though Canada suffered from a
shortage of skilled workers.  The Technical and Vocational Training
Assistance Act (1960) provided massive funding to remedy the
situation. During the 1960’s Canada and the Provinces mounted a
technical and vocational training program to prepare Canadians to
participate in the post war industrial expansion.  Cost were shared
by the federal and provincial governments and resulted in an
initiative that was the envy of many countries.  In the mid 1960’s,
TVTA administrators joined with officials working on the issue of
high unemployment and slow economic growth and pooled their efforts
in support of a series of demonstration projects.  These projects,
called Canada NewStart Corporations, were funded by the Federal
Government but given a large degree of independence as to the
clientele and focus of their research.






The
Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation was established in Yarmouth, Nova
Scotia in 1967 with Tom Jones as Director and Robert Adams as
Director of Occupational Training; the project focused on skill
training for rural youth.  Given Adams experience in occupational and
functional analyses, it was not surprising that analysis was a
cornerstone of his research.  In Nova Scotia, Adams worked directly
with local employers and unemployed youth to develop relevant
training for people wanting to improve their lot in life.  








BC
Version






Each
training program was preceded by an analysis of competencies
practiced by high performers in the occupation.  Adams convened a
group of practitioners and, those who supervised them, with Adams,
himself, facilitating the analysis process.  The ...

title: DACUM-HC Chronology
summary: A chronological documentation of DACUM implementation at Holland College from March 1970 to 1976. Records pivotal events: first DACUM analysis for Electronics in 1970, rapid expansion across Secretarial Arts and Commercial Design, full institution adoption by September 1970, national dissemination through conferences, and integration with vocational/trade education programs. Documents Holland College's pioneering role in DACUM adoption and international influence, with facilitator Bob Adams and later Lawrence Coffin introducing methodology to Ohio educational research centers.
content_preview:
March, 1970	First DACUM analysis (Electronics) prepared at Holland College with Bob Adams as facilitator.  Analyses quickly followed for Secretarial Arts and Commercial Design.  




July 2, 1970	Students in Secretarial Arts became the first to enrol under the DACUM model.  This included the use of the occupational analysis, modular approach to curriculum development, and student assessment and management.




Sept. 2, 1970	All new and returning students enrolled under DACUM model.  




1971		Article appeared in CV Journal about Holland College including its commitment to DACUM model.




1971		Holland College staff acted as resource people and presenters at meetings, workshops and conferences in other provinces. 




1973		Visit by staff from the Ohio Centre for Research in Vocational Education.




1974		DACUM introduced to staff of the Ohio Centre for Research in Vocational Education by Lawrence Coffin from Holland College.




1976		Holland College assumed responsibility for all trade, occupational, apprenticeship and adult education on PEI and began converting trade and occupational programs to DACUM model.




1976		Holland College instituted a DACUM based training program for its instructional staff.

title: DACUM-History Sequence
summary: A timeline visualization showing the evolution of DACUM methodology from 1952-1972 across multiple organizations: Federal Government occupational analyses, Holland College establishment and DACUM adoption, NewStart Corporations development, Pilot Projects branches, and BC Department of Education applications. Maps the convergence of federal vocational research, institutional innovation, and grassroots educational development that positioned Holland College as a leading adopter and innovator.

title: DACUM rating scale
summary:
Presents Bloom's Revised Taxonomy cognitive domain framework alongside a detailed DACUM (Developing a Curriculum) rating scale for task performance assessment. The DACUM scale uses six levels (0-6+) to measure competency in task performance: from "Cannot perform satisfactorily" (0) through "Can lead others in performing this task" (6+). This framework represents integrated approach to curriculum development and competency assessment used in vocational and professional education settings.
- **Key People**: Benjamin Bloom, Lorin Anderson, DACUM methodology developers
- **Key Organizations**: None specified

title: Described
summary: Practical guide to DACUM methodology based on Nova Scotia NewStart model. **Don writes as "Founding President of Holland College" (1969), noting College was first to adopt full DACUM model for all programs starting 1970.** Covers chart concept, rating scales, learning models, program planning. **Emphasizes DACUM's 10 characteristics including immediate feedback, learner self-planning, cumulative achievement approach, and learner-centered evaluation.** Positions Holland College as innovative leader in competency-based education.
content_preview:
FOREWORD




Competency based education and training has moved from the concept to the implementation stage. Many schools, colleges, business and industry training departments are using or have adopted competency based training techniques.




One approach being used to deliver competency based training is the DACUM model. This model is not new; its initial development began in the mid 60's. What is new is the move away from traditional education to competency or outcomes based education. The DACUM model is being adopted by training institutions and industrial training departments on a world wide basis.




The need for information on how the DACUM model works is acute. This re-presentation of the DACUM model may be timely and will provide educators and trainers with information on developing and implementing a competency based education system.




As one who has worked with the DACUM model at Holland College and elsewhere for 25 years, it is a privilege to recommend the reading of this booklet.  It should assist educators and trainers in the development and delivery of competency based training and education.







Lawrence Coffin

Education Consultant

INTRODUCTION




This book is about DACUM.  It is intended to be a short description of the DACUM approach to organizing and delivering training.  The book is based on the model developed by Nova Scotia NewStart Corporation in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia during the late 1960's. During the same time period, a different model of DACUM was developed and implemented in British Columbia; however, the approach developed by the Nova Scotia NewStart appears to be the one most widely followed.




The idea of writing a book or booklet about DACUM has been suggested many times.  In this regard, the first initiative by the writer was DACUM ROOTS which traced the origins of the DACUM concept.  A decision to write this book arises from numerous conversations and requests for information, not about the origins, but about the concept ...

title: Doc4a
summary: DACUM historical context quoted - (education methodology).
content_preview:
"During a period of orientation, each enrolee is aided by test batteries and staff interviews in assessing her abilities and her accomplishments and in choosing a vocation.  She is then introduced to her program advisor, with whom she selects an initial program of learning experiences.  Her program may include appropriate attention from the medical and counselling staff.  Thereafter, she meets at frequent scheduled intervals with her advisor to evaluate her progress and redesign her program.  The process is, in effect, a eries of contracts between the enrollee and the Centre, which continues until she and her advisor agree that she is ready to graduate."




"To provide a range of learning experiences adequate to the individual needs of some nine hundred young women of widely various backgrounds, abilities and accomplishments, the staff has developed the curriculum which is represented by the charts ..."  




Under the Clinton approach, a student and a learner sat together and sketched out a learning plan on a sheet of paper.  Each plan included only a few learning activities.  The process was intended primarily as a means of improving motivation through engaging students in planning the steps to be taken in the learning process.  Selected components of one chart are included as Figure 2.

title: Draft 81 Giving plans
summary: Draft newsletter (2008) presenting Glendenning's philosophy on personal giving plans. Advocates for intentional, strategic charitable giving rather than reactive responses to every solicitation. Shares personal anecdotes about different giving approaches and argues that donors should identify causes reflecting their values and capacity. Emphasizes targeting support toward projects creating systemic change rather than perpetual maintenance. This draft reveals his practical wisdom about charitable responsibility and individualized approach to community benefit.

title: Draft Teachers as Change Agents
summary: Don's education philosophy - (substantive).
content_preview:
Teachers as Change Agents







To learn is to change; to teach is to help others change.  In educational jargon, changes may be in the cognitive, affective or psychomotor domains.  More simply put, a person who has learned has new attitudes, skills or information or some combination thereof.  




Learning is an individual matter.  Only the learner can learn.    The stimulus for learning may be internal or external and the actual learning may take place in a group setting or when the individual is alone.  A teacher does not teach a class; a teacher teaches a number of individuals at the same time in a group setting.  




Readers have likely heard the statement “A teacher hasn’t taught if a learner hasn’t learned”.  That statement always brings vigorous discussion.  I believe that to be true but it must be applied to each learner.  A learner has learned only if there is a change of behaviour.  




The role of a teacher is to stimulate learning – to create a set of circumstances so that a learner learns the desired behaviour. To help a learner to learn is to help bring about changes in the learner.  Teachers need a variety of techniques in their tool chest – and they will likely require all of them.  Tools include setting an example, providing information, asking questions, setting time lines, assigning projects or home work, organizing field trips and assessing performance.  The trick for each teacher is to create a learning environment for each learner that will result in each learner having a favorable experience, even in a group setting.  Not easy but it is the crux of good teaching.




Teachers organize their teaching activities and strategies around academic disciplines, Language, social studies, science and art to name but a few.  Each discipline is assigned a number of hours and teachers with appropriate backgrounds and in appropriate numbers.  Teachers use a variety of methods to both motivate and teach students assigned to their care such as having stud...

title: ED-20221 Purposeditor
summary: A letter emphasizing importance of clear organizational purpose statements, which Don could not locate in PEI Education documents despite searching school websites. He argues such statements are crucial for providing direction and establishing frameworks for measuring organizational success, and should be publicly displayed. Notes uncertainty about existence of similar statements in New Brunswick. Reflects Don's repeated concern that education system lacks fundamental clarity about its mission and goals.

title: Education, Good
summary: Philosophical paper examining characteristics of quality education. Identifies three purposes: human fulfillment, employment preparation, and social progress. Emphasizes quality education provides range of skills enabling function across life roles. Discusses characteristics including whole-child development, value-based learning, proficiency standards, and knowledge retention. Notes quality education teaches thinking skills, meets high standards, and provides job-specific knowledge. Critiques current assessment practices focusing mainly on cognitive outcomes measurable through pen-and-paper tests while neglecting broader social and life skills development goals. Emphasizes alignment between broad learning aspirations and assessment mechanisms.

title: Education Report
summary: Glendenning proposes establishing a not-for-profit educational newsroom devoted to reporting on education matters, modeled on examples like CBC, the Hechinger Report (Columbia University), and AIMS think tank (Halifax). The proposal emphasizes keeping the public informed about education at all levels and for all citizens, distinguishing itself from lobbying or advocacy. The newsroom would publish reports, newsletters, and media items focused on education broadly conceived (not just schooling) with solution-oriented analysis. This initiative reflects Glendenning's belief that public understanding and engagement are essential to transforming education systems.

title: Educational Bureaucracy
summary: A critical analysis of educational bureaucracy, written May 4, 2004. Glendenning catalogs the extensive control systems schools maintain: determining students' departure times, bus behavior, lunch schedules, subject choices, room assignments, exam timing, and departure times. Teachers face comparable controls. He argues schools operate on obsolete industrial organizational models while other sectors have evolved. The document advocates learner-centered education beginning with educational assessment, permanent educational advisors (like family doctors), and individual learning plans—contrasting this with current group-based instruction assuming same-age students need identical lessons. He criticizes both bureaucratic control and the lack of individual attention in mass education.
content_preview:
16 - Bureaucracy

-




May 4, 2004




The education system appears to thrive on taking control. For a period of twelve years or more, our young people spend a large chunk of each day and each year in a school system. The system determines the time they leave home, when and where they get on a school bus, how they act while on the bus, where to get off, when they enter the school, where they park their lunch and clothes, what subjects they will study, what rooms they will be in and when, when and where they will eat lunch, which teachers they may have, the text books to be used, when and where exams will be taken, when they may leave the facility and the list goes on.




The system also controls what hours teachers work, where they work, what they can teach, what they are paid, when a teacher must release a student to another student, the teaching-learning model, etc., etc., etc. Not much freedom in the system.




Schools continue to operate on an industrial organizational model; most other organizations have moved beyond that style of operation. The Minister decrees and the system executes. While the system does not literally execute its students, in some ways it demands and reinforces a kind of behaviour not in the best interests of learners and the community they will live in.




Compare, for a moment, a Department of Health and a Department of Education, excluding the actual hospitals and schools, doctors and teachers.




Employees Professional Support Publications Printing budget School Units Professionals Support Budget




I let the reader draw his or her own conclusions.




With that kind and level of bureaucracy, what chances does a teacher have of being innovative? Exploring new approaches? And the lowly learner is even more disadvantaged. 






/-"




As a rule of thumb, we should not put control of any aspect of our life, including our education, into the hands of another~ we need to take control of our own affairs finances, health, happiness and...

title: Educational vouchers
summary: Glendenning's examination of educational vouchers as a market mechanism to improve education through competition and consumer choice. He finds the concept intriguing—students as consumers holding schools accountable through their funding choices and ability to leave. However, he notes vouchers remain experimental with inconclusive effectiveness data. He critiques limiting vouchers to poorly performing students, which stigmatizes the initiative. A genuine test, he argues, should provide vouchers universally, allowing all learners to vote with their feet regarding schools' effectiveness. The document reflects Don's faith in market mechanisms and consumer power as educational improvement levers.
content_preview:
Educational vouchers







The idea of educational vouchers is consistent with my philosophy; having said that, I have no experience with a voucher system.  The idea of the learner/client appearing at a school and plunking down money for services to be provided is intriguing.  The concept of the same student, getting up from their seat, walking to the principal’s office before departing a school with a refund in hand is even more interesting.  




The voucher idea has been around for my entire educational career but seemed to rise in prominence in the 1970s and 80s.  I consider them still in the experimental stages.  Do they improve education?  The jury is still out.




Education vouchers involve a system whereby learners, or their parents, provides a voucher to a Scholl for part or all of the cost of providing an education.  Instead of a school receiving a g rant as part of a funding formula, the learner receives a voucher for all or part of the cost of his schooling.  The learner   chooses a school and gives the school a voucher.  The learner is a consumer, a consumer with the ability to pay.  The idea being that schools must compete for learners, that competition is good for other sectors why not for e education.  The end result is improved accountability and improved education.




A major weakness that I have observed is that vouchers have been limited to poorly performing students.  This provides a negative image of the initiative.  Like placing less academically included students in vocational education.  A true test, I believe, should provide vouchers for all.

title: Essential Skills
summary: Glendenning proposes developing an integrated platform for curriculum and training in essential skills, arguing these form the foundation for all learning and life success. He identifies eight essential skill categories: literacy, numeracy, everyday science, self-management, information technology, personal relationships, community awareness, and emotional awareness. He recommends DACUM-style competency analysis with accompanying rating scales, enabling applications in learning guides, progress tracking, student self-assessment, training procurement, hiring, career planning, and achievement records. For mathematics specifically, he diagnoses fragmentation, lack of coordination among providers, inconsistent evaluation, and outdated instructional models—proposing a common curriculum format and coordinated pilot projects.

title: Evaluation
summary: A September 2004 performance review by Don of "Katy" (IAHSP Executive Director or staff member) addressed to Ken Gillis. Don assesses administrative skills, communications, fundraising, program operation, and personal qualities. He finds her improving in administrative and communication areas, notes her effectiveness with fundraising for a newcomer, and praises her commitment and interpersonal skills. Reflects Don's mentoring and administrative oversight capabilities.
content_preview:
Date:		September 2, 2004




To:		Ken Gillis




From:		Don Glendenning




Subject:	Performance Review




I have not been ignoring your email but simply reflecting how I can best contribute.  I decided, therefore, to send a few comments rather than simply provide a percentage.  While I am familiar with some of Katy’s work there are other areas about which I have no personal experience and have not had any feedback – either positive or negative.  Here are dome thoughts.




Administrative




IAHSP has certainly tested Katy’s administrative skills.  This was especially evident in the early stages as plans, schedules, forms and approaches were being designed.  She learns fast and has since strengthened her skills in this area.  I have always felt comfortable with her financial records.




Communications




While her language is descriptive and creative, project documents and descriptions usually require clear, concise and even mundane writing.  Again, there has been significant improvement.




Fundraising




Fundraising is a difficult task and is especially difficult for a newcomer to the task.  I am of the view that Board mdmbers should be the prime contacts.  Under the circumstances, I think that Katy has done well.  It is a skill that will develop with experience.




Program Operation




I am impressed with her understanding of the project and commitment to its success.




Personal Qualities




Katy presents herself well, is creative and a self-starter.  I’ve enjoyed working with her.  She seems to work well with people although I have no information about her working relationships beyond the Board and office level.




I trust that these comments are helpful.

title: Final Exams
summary: Published as "MY 200 WORDS" commentary, Glendenning questions the term "final exams," suggesting it contradicts lifelong learning ideology. He distinguishes between exams for learning (diagnostic, improving) and exams for qualification (certifying competence), arguing only the latter belong outside schools. Schools should assess ongoing learning; external qualification authorities should determine competence for employment or further study. He advocates making validation available to lifelong learners, so people acquiring skills outside school can have learning recognized. The document exemplifies Don's precision in educational terminology and his concern for validating learning wherever it occurs.
content_preview:
MY 200 WORDS




Final Exams




While browsing the morning paper (Guardian, January 25, 2010), my eye caught a reference to final exams; it seemed so ominous.  What, I wonder, makes exams in January, or any other time of the year, one’s final exams? Are they for students with a terminal illness?  Are these final in terms of individual students or final as far as the institution is concerned?  Then I wondered, if my doctor called my next exam my final exam, what would that mean?   Would that be even more ominous than a final exam for learning?




A final exam for students implies, at least for me, that students are not expected to learn anything further.  The term is at odds with the concept of life-long learning.  The day or week after exams are finished, a student may have a significant learning experience; maybe even while taking the exam.  The exams mentioned in my morning paper are more likely to be semester or year-end finals.  But they could also reflect the fact that the school will no longer offer that subject ad, therefore, the school will no longer assess student performance in it.




One’s record of learning in school plays a significant role, I believe, when seeking employment or acceptance to further study.  So where, in the scheme of things, can a student who has had significant learning experiences outside school have that experience validated, or measured and reported?  If we believe in lifelong learning and want to encourage it, and I think that most people do, we should make it easy for people who learn outside the school have that learning validated.  




Examinations are, and should be, an important tool in helping people learn.  The assessing of what has been learned for the purpose of  obtaining a qualification, or obtaining employment, is an entirely different matter, and has no place in schools.

title: Flipped classrooms
summary: Don's analysis of flipped classroom pedagogy emerging circa 2011. Documents example of advanced calculus teacher (Stacey Roshan) using digitally recorded home-viewing lectures to enable classroom discussion. Identifies three keys to success: students completing homework, quality of lessons (depth and methodology), and production quality. Discusses trade-offs between Dr. Scott Morris's advice to prioritize content speed over perfection versus Don's position that week-by-week delivery demands professional production. Emphasizes importance of engaging delivery: "if a lesson in class isn't engaging, you might still hold attention through classroom presence; a boring home lesson faces hundreds of distractions." Reflects that educators should maintain same quality standards for students as expected from students. Includes references to David Truss, Palmer Academy (Detroit), Promethean, TED talks. Demonstrates Don's continued engagement with emerging educational technologies and methodologies in later career.
content_preview:
So instruction becomes about dealing with the holes in student understanding, not giving them the whole enchilada beforehand. 

The flip isn’t just about delivering a lesson at home… it’s about a whole (not new, but) different way of teaching & learning too!

FLIPPED CLASSROOMS

I was introduced to “flipped classrooms” by an article in USA today on Friday, October 11, 2011.  Flipped classrooms wouldn’t be possible without the work of Steve Jobs; coincidentally,  the idea came to my attention at the time of his death, prematurely at age fifty-six.  Let me tell you more

The article in USA Today tells about a teacher of advanced calculus, Stacey Roshan, who expects her students to view her digitally recorded lectures as home work, and using class time for discussion.   It is a significant change in teacher’s  jobs, but it offers teachers “greater control of material and more face-time with students.  It certainly is not a panacea nor should it be used exclusively,  but appears to have potential for some learners, some teachers,  and for raising exam results.

David Truss, see reference below, identifies three keys to a successful flip, getting students to do their homework, quality of lessons (breadth vs depth and how vs why), and quality of production.  

Users of the flipped classroom report the “add-ons” to education being: coaching, trouble shooting, analysis, critical thinking, collaboration, 

3. Production Quality

Dr. Scott Morris advises, ”The key is to not get too bent out of shape about production quality; just bang it out.  It is more important to get it out there and online than that it be perfect.”

I think that if you are going to produce 1,2 or even 5 of these kinds of lessons in a 13 week course, then Dr. Morris’ advice might be valuable. However, if this is something you are going to do week after week, if it is something that delivers a critical amount of the syllabus, then production quality becomes vitally important.

I also think it’s great that ...

title: FR Summary
summary: An October 2004 memo from Don to Ken Gillis on IAHSP fundraising strategy. Don reports picking up fundraising packages from Katy, reviewing progress, and noting activities were at a halt with time running short. He expresses confidence in reaching the $200,000 goal with extra effort but emphasizes Ken's leadership role with key players, noting Katy is "too new to the business" to close deals. Don proposes a detailed five-part strategy including tidying up commitments, activating volunteers, organizing letter campaigns, and researching off-island foundations. The memo demonstrates Don's strategic thinking, fundraising expertise, and collaborative leadership style.
content_preview:
Date:		October 27, 2004




To:		Ken Gillis




From:		Don Glendenning




Subject:	IAHSP




I finally am back to focusing on IAHSP and a few days ago picked up packages from Katy and started to make my calls and follow-ups.  Triggered in part by Harry’s call and our discussion, I spent most of Wednesday morning with Katy reviewing a range of IAHSP matters but I would like to focus this memo on Fund Raising.  Since talking with Katy, I reviewed the tracking list and progress to date.




It appears that our FR activities were/are almost at a halt – and time is short.  Some notes are not dated and, therefore, I cannot tell just how much recent activity is taking place.  Having said that, however, I was more encouraged than I expected to be and I am confident that, with some extra effort, we could reach our $200,000 in the next few weeks.




I know from our recent conversation, Ken, that you are relying heavily on Katy to carry the bulk of the remaining fund raising.  Katy can play a role but the key to success, I believe, is your follow-up with key players and new contacts with a few others.  Katy can make some calls but is too new to the business and not well enough known by decision-makers to pull it off.  I know that this is a busy time for you with your civic responsibilities now compounded by family concerns in Cape Breton.




To cut to the chase, here is a proposed strategy:




You direct your efforts to tidying up two of the categories in Katy’s list – support promised no amount given and fall schedule

Katy activate Marion, Jeannette and I to do our follow-ups and finish our commitments.

Katy and I review, and likely add to, our list of individuals who deserve a visit and decide who can/will make the call.

Prepare for a letter writing campaign to folk who we will not visit but who, collectively, could put us over the top.  With Ron Irving’s help, we could probably put a list together fairly quickly but Katy may need help to gather addresses.  We would n...

title: framework
summary: Comprehensive working document organizing education system knowledge across multiple dimensions: essential graduation learnings, traditional subjects, PEI graduation requirements, essential skills, instructional models (with 13 specific implementation elements), curriculum platform (analysis, description, profile, rating scale, benchmarks, standards), education system components (from Frick, Business Roundtable, Georgia Vision Project), education services, learners/learning definitions, context, purpose, assessment, structural issues, culture, grading/standards. This 19-file represents Glendenning's most comprehensive synthesis document, serving as master framework integrating all preceding analysis.

CONTENT








ESSENTIAL GRADUATION LEARNINGS

	


	















TRADITIONAL SUBJECTS:

	


	Mathematics
	


	Trigonometry
	


	History
	


	Geometry
	


	Algebra















GRADUATION REQUIREMENTS (PEI)

	


	At least 20 credits, including
	12 from the following subjects:
	


	three (3) English credits, one
	of which must be a Grade 12 course (600 level)
	


	two (2) math credits
	(post-secondary institutions may require three or more math credits)
	


	two (2) science credits
	


	two (2) social studies credits,
	one of which must include Canadian content as listed in the Senior
	High Program of Studies or a social studies credit approved by the
	Director of the English Innovation, Education and Programs as a
	compulsory course credit
	


	one (1) physical education
	credit, which must be PED401A
	


	one (1) career education and
	personal development credit, which must be CEO or CARF
	


	one (1) credit identified as a
	creativity or innovation course, or one (1) French language credit
	


	five (5) credits must be from
	courses designated in the Senior High Program of Studies and List of
	Authorized Materials as Grade 12 courses (600 or 800 level courses)





















ESSENTIAL SKILLS


source

	


	Literacy

	Everyday Science 
	
	


	Self Management
	


	Information technology
	


	Personal relationships
	


	Community awareness
	


	Emotional Awareness

required for recognition

from community being served


•	Adopt a dynamic rating scale

competency by competency basis


•	Provide each student with a
master list of competencies as a basis for personal...

title: Funding-1
summary: Policy analysis document examining funding and systemic coordination of mathematics education in PEI. Establishes agreement on skill difference attribution through four factors: number of skills learned, nature of skills, student performance levels, and clustering patterns. Documents misalignment between public school outcomes-based curriculum and postsecondary competency-based approaches, arguing for unified framework. Identifies seven systemic conclusions: fragmented instruction delivery, skill-level-clustering differences, outcome-competency misalignment, instruction-grading conflicts, regulatory vs. instructional functions, teacher authorization inconsistencies, and lack of agreed-upon definitions. Addresses educational philosophy gaps (30-year-old, public school only), absent coordination mechanisms, inconsistent assessment criteria, and content description variations. Notes 2019 mathematics curriculum review timeline. Recommends standard definitions, common competency list, and independent achievement level determination body.

title: Funeral - Hesta
summary: Don's funeral oration for Dr. Hesta MacDonald, honoring her four decades of community service, educational advocacy, and their personal friendship. Demonstrates Don's reflections on civic engagement and his relationship with a significant figure in Holland College history.
content_preview:
Hesta Arletta (Baker) MacDonald

Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island

October 24, 2009







Today we celebrate the life of Hesta Arletta (Baker) MacDonald, a woman who, in a quiet and unassuming manner, was an icon of motherhood and citizenship in our community.  




One could list the many organizations to which she belonged and the honours and awards received, and the list would be long and impressive.  But Hesta did not join a group just to belong; she joined with others to make the Island a better place to live, work and raise a family.




The causes for which she worked are a good reflection of who she was, of her interests and contributions.  They include:

Working for a new Rural High School in Eldon where she lived

Speaking out on issues of drug use and child abuse, 

building bridges to the Aboriginal Community on PEI, 

advocacy for improved and more accessible public education,

leadership setting directions for Holland College 

Preserving our heritage

Putting on the record,  memories of earlier times

Establishment of a fund to purchase books for school libraries

And to this list, we must add her church







I’ve known and worked with Hesta for more than 4 decades, initially as the first elected chair of the Board of Governors of Holland College, later as our Information Officer and for the last two decades, as a friend.  During the latter period, we had many cups of coffee together and sometimes an actual lunch (although she was a very light eater).  I’d pick her up at her home, (she was always ready on time) and we would go some where we hadn’t been before.  Sometimes we arranged our schedule so that other friends from her Holland College days could join us. 




On reflection, our discussion topics were predictable




First was family – she rejoiced in the accomplishments of children and grandchildren and great grandchildren, and sometimes anguished over their current rough spots.   Her love, care, concern and pride always shone through.  O...

title: Gallup Student Poll measures and sample questions
summary: Article describing the Gallup Student Poll, an assessment tool requiring 10-15 minutes to complete. The poll measures three key dimensions: hope (energy and ability to achieve future goals), engagement (involvement and enthusiasm about school), and well-being (overall life satisfaction). The article provides sample questions for each dimension, including the "ladder" framework for measuring well-being on a 0-10 scale. Research indicates that "hopeful" students have higher GPAs and attendance rates, while engaged students perform better academically. The tool emphasizes how students' social and emotional lives affect academic performance.
content_preview:
What the Gallup Student Poll measures and sample questions

By Lynh Bui, Published: July 17 E-mail the writer 

What the Gallup Student Poll does 

The Gallup Student Poll takes about 10 to 15 minutes to complete. It presents students with a series of 20 statements or questions and asks them to indicate whether they agree or disagree, on a 1 to 5 scale.

Related

In Montgomery County, ‘hope’ to also define student success

Lynh Bui JUL 17

School superintendent says social and emotional lives affect academic performance.

More news about education

Read more

●Hope: Determines whether students have the energy and ability to achieve goals in the future. Results indicate whether students are “hopeful,” “stuck” or “discouraged.” “Hopeful” students tend to have higher grade-point averages and attendance rates.

Sample statements measuring hope: “I know I will find a good job after I graduate.” “I can find lots of ways around any problem.”

●Engagement: Determines how involved and enthusiastic students are about school. Results indicate whether students are “engaged,” “not engaged” or “actively disengaged.” High-performing schools tend to have more engaged students. 

Sample statements measuring engagement: “My teachers make me feel my schoolwork is important.” “At this school, I have the opportunity to do what I do best every day.”

●

●Well-being: Determines how students are doing in their lives. Results indicate whether students are “thriving,” “struggling” or “suffering.” “Thriving” students are better able to focus on academic work because they aren’t distracted by meeting basic needs or other life demands.

Sample question measuring well-being: “Please imagine a ladder with steps numbered from zero at the bottom to ten at the top. The top of the ladder represents the best possible life for you and the bottom of the ladder represents the worst possible life for you. On which step of the ladder would you say you personally feel you stand at this time?”

  
Reprints
