title: Governance-3
summary: Don's substantive draft on school governance and educational delivery models written May 2012. Critiques existing system, references his Holland College governance experience, and proposes learner-centered reforms—core to his education philosophy.
content_preview:
Draft-May 20, 2012

Thoughts on School Governance

Background

The Government of Prince Edward Island has decided to change from two English school Boards to one.  I’m of the view that the change by itself will do not thing to improve the education of our choldrenWhile I am sure that there are good reasons for the change but such a change by itself will do little, if anything, to improve the education of our youth.  On the other hand, making the change provides an opportunity to rethink the delivery model and make some long overdue improvements.

The system of delivery for educational services has remained virtually unchanged for decades.  Yes, schools have grown in size, new subjects have been added, small schools have disappeared, teachers have more formal training and facilities are wonderful.  But, with a few exceptions, the model is still teacher centered, the system allows little opportunity for teacher creativity, we still deliver to groups, defining success in terms of content, fail to integrate take into account learning outside the system or learning which results from independent study, and fails to take advantage of the benefits of 

While I am not an expert on school governance, it is an area of interest and I do have some experience.  In fact, it may interest readers to know that one of reasons why I chose PEI over another college in 1969 resulted, in part, from my view   as to how a college should be organized.  I also remember well the discussion among members of the College Planning Committee as to the nature of governance for the proposed college.  The decision was to go with a unicameral Board and the decision, I believe, allow us to concentrate on educational matters rather than in operating a bureaucracy.

As background, let me express some views about education:

  
Education is much broader than schooling.  Actually focused on school system rather than education, \no definitions of education, education system.  although ostensibly about educat...

title: Governance ERIC Digest 141
summary: ERIC (Education Resources Information Center) digest by Ron Renchler on new school governance patterns. Examines why school governance is changing: state centralization reducing local board authority (only Manitoba boards retain local taxation rights), board amalgamations reducing trustee numbers, and increased provincial control over curriculum and standards. Discusses accountability challenges, particularly for minority and urban students. Reviews proposed governance models including public operation with experimental strategies, independent school operations, policy governance approaches, and distributed decision-making. Notes mayoral takeovers of urban districts. Concludes that while empirical evidence linking governance structure to achievement is limited, educators continue experimenting with structural changes.
content_preview:
ERIC Digest 141 - October 2000
                
New Patterns of School Governance
                
By Ron Renchler
                
School governance has long been a political football, as local, state, and federal stakeholders work—sometimes cooperatively and sometimes at odds—to establish or influence policy and then implement accountability measures to track the quality of schools in the United States.
                
Proponents of change have recently recommended a number of new approaches—and variations on old ones—to meet the complex challenge of improving public education through different forms of school governance. However, as with change in any organizational setting, resistance has been strong, and the public debate on the appropriateness of new models for school governance continues.
                
This Digest explains why public-school governance is the subject of increasing scrutiny, identifies who is held accountable for results in the current governance system, and describes several recent proposals for transforming governance structures. 
                
Why Are Changes in School Governance Being Recommended?
                
Most of the past decade’s education reforms were initiated at the state or the school level, bypassing or ignoring the school board and district office. Now reformers are zeroing in on this neglected middle level of governance, hoping that some changes—perhaps a redefinition of the role of school boards, closer teamwork between board and superintendent, or experimentation with new governance structures—will indirectly stimulate improved performance at the school and classroom.
                
The latest round of debate about the most effective models for school governance was precipitated by the publication in November 1999 of Governing America’s Schools: Changing the Rules, a report issued by the National Commission on Governing America’s Schools and sponsored by the Education Commission of the States. 
                
T...

title: Governnannce-Keele Univ By not being part of a mission group
summary: Academic governance case study examining Keele University's governance structure and decision-making approach. Discusses implications of institutional autonomy vs. membership in larger mission groups or networks. Addresses governance challenges and opportunities for independent operation vs. collaborative affiliation structures. Relevant to understanding higher education governance models and institutional decision-making frameworks.
content_preview:
By not being part of a mission group, Keele University can shape its own identity and avoid group politics, says Nick Foskett

Nick Foskett 

Thursday 27 June 2013

guardian.co.uk

http://www.guardian.co.uk/higher-education-network/blog/2013/jun/27/mission-group-identities-stifles-university-innovation

----

As vice-chancellor of a British university, I recognise how vital it is for universities to support one another during a time of extensive reform in the higher education sector. Yet one question I am regularly asked is: why is Keele University not aligned to a mission group and never has been?

With mounting pressure on universities to lead the growth of our knowledge economy, it continues to surprise many of my contemporaries that being part of a mission group is a move Keele regularly considers, but has not yet been persuaded to undertake.

The simplest answer is that none of the existing mission groups provide a natural fit for Keele, a university founded on a principle to break away from established patterns. Keele is not unique in this respect, as a significant number of universities choose to be non-aligned, a fact frequently overlooked in the media and political engagement with the sector.

In an article for the Guardian earlier this year, Peter Scott surmised that universities are always going to be "more different and individual" than the identity they share with their mission group, and this is one of my main concerns with group alignment.

Yes, mission groups aim to highlight diversity in the sector, encourage collaboration and stimulate debate – the Russell Group provides the prevailing example of how a group can rally strength in numbers to create a powerful voice to stimulate change. Yet for me, being aligned brings with it greater risks of marginalising a university's own interests for the benefit of the wider group, which cannot be ignored.

Firstly, the very nature of group politics means that each group has clearly defined parameters, usually ...

title: Grade levels Profession takes lead on assessment after the end of levels
summary: Document addressing changes in educational assessment and grading systems, particularly regarding elimination of standardized grade levels. Discusses shift of assessment responsibility to educators/profession rather than centralized testing regimes. Addresses implications for student evaluation, teacher autonomy, and institutional approaches to measuring student achievement and progress.

title: GRADUATION RATES
summary: Glendenning critiques schools' time-based structure and advocates making graduation the objective while time becomes the variable. He notes schools measure achievement by how much students learn in fixed time, like measuring how far runners go in set time rather than how long they take to complete a course. Since learning rates vary individually and most students can master content with adequate time, extending the school year for struggling students would increase graduation rates. The proposal is modest—extra weeks for non-proficient students—but reflects his fundamental belief that time shouldn't constrain capability. The document demonstrates Don's capacity to identify simple, high-leverage systemic changes.
content_preview:
INCREASING GRADUATION RATES




Schools are time based institutions.  The system sets the number of days schools are open, the number of hours of instruction each day, days to be made up because of storms, the length of time available on a subject before you must move to another, they keep attendance, time missed may result in the lowering of a grade, teacher pay scales are related to years of training and years of experience.  I can think of no other sector that is so driven by time.




The curriculum carves up subjects to be learned into subjects, units and lessons.  




Rate of learning, on the other hand, is unique to each individual.  It is generally understood that most students can learn most subjects to the same level if given time.  




Learners enter school and are told, here is what is to be learned and here are the dates and times that teachers are available to help you learn.  And as you know, you are measured on ho much you learn in the time available.




It is a bit like conducting a race and, instead of measuring the time it takes each to run the course, it measures how far you can run in a set time. 


































ration the amount of teacher time available to students.  We organize schools around content to be learned and time available for instruction







We encourage students to stay in school and to graduate, and we should continue to do so.  Many more could graduate if they had a bit more time and help.  If this is so, why not give students the few extra days needed?  I am not suggesting that the school year be extended for all.  Students meeting graduation requirement should not have to stay longer; students not meeting graduation requirements should be allowed and encouraged to stay.  Let’s make graduation the objective and time the variable. 




One might be surprised on the impact of an extra couple of weeks of study on school graduation requirements.

title: Hall Stavert Potential Fund
summary: Formal letter from Don Glendenning (signed "D. Glendenning, C.M." - noting his Order of Canada designation) proposing the establishment of a Hall and Stavert Family Fund to commemorate the historic manufacturing, agriculture, and fishing company's legacy on PEI. Don suggests the fund serve triple purposes: reflecting family ideals, perpetuating the company name, and honoring employees' contributions. Proposes annual awards options including scholarships in mechanical engineering/design, innovation leadership awards, or public lectures on design and marketing. The letter demonstrates Don's historical awareness and ability to connect heritage preservation with contemporary philanthropic giving.
content_preview:
2010 06 23







Jim Stavert and Tom Hall




Dear Jim and Tom,

With the long history that Hall and Stavert has on Prince Edward Island, it seems fitting that the name  be recognized in a tangible way.  Though the firm, Hall and Stavert, is no longer active on Prince Edward Island, their contributions to the manufacturing, agriculture and fishing industries were innovative, substantial widely recognized.

Given the partnership and your interest in PEI history, we present an idea for your consideration.  We propose the establishment of a Hall and Stavert Fund with the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island to remember the name in perpetuity and to make an annual award to some worthy cause.  

The purpose of the fund would be threefold, to reflect the ideals and values of the Hall and Stavert families, to commemorate the Hall and Stavert name on Prince Edward Island, to honour Hall and Stavert employees for their contributions to the company, and to  make an annual award for some worthy cause.  To spark the discussion about an appropriate annual award, let me present the fllowing ideas for your consideration:

  
A scholarship for an Island student either entering college or  university or proceeding to advanced study in mechanical engineering, manufacturing or design;
  
An innovation or leadership award to an individual or company reflecting the Hall and Stavert history 
  
An annual public lecture on design, innovation or marketing of Island products.


I would be delighted to pursue these and other  ideas with you and will contact you shortly to set up a mutually convenient time.  

I hope you and your families are enjoying our Island summer and the many activities that it brings.

Sincerely,




D. Glendenning, C.M.

Director

Kensington Road

5J4






Dear:


Math on PEI

Although
PEI math scores on National and international tests have risen,
friends tell me that math has not improved on the shop floor; I’ve
been wondering why.






Islanders
need math; citizens may not need a  high level but they need to be
able to measure, sort, calculate, group and estimate numbers, space,
time  distance, etc.  and they need to do it quickly, easily,
accurately; and consistently.  This approach to math is called
numeracy and it involves the application of math to every-day lives.
Numeracy is being adopted elsewhere; usually in addition to
traditional math.  







But
we need more, to begin with we need an analysis of math skills used
by Islanders. Making an analysis involves bringing together a small
group for a two- day of brainstorming session.   It’s a proven
technique, we used it regularly at Holland College but apparently
there is no one on PEI now with the expertise.  The cost of
undertaking the analyses is $15,000.  







I
am approaching a few people who might contribute $1-2,000 each to
help cover the cost. The Community Foundation, 121 Queen Street,
Charlottetown, PE, C1A 4B3 will accept donations on our behalf and
issue charitable receipts. 







I
appreciate your consideration and would be happy to explain further
and answer any questions.  Thanks in advance






Sincerely,











Don
Glendenning   







1-1-num

title: Handout Version 5
summary: This is an evolved version of the educational framework, retitled "A Learning Framework" instead of "An Education Framework." It incorporates similar foundational content but with refined organization. It presents Don's comprehensive philosophy on learning, including key definitions, quality standards based on UNICEF criteria, and PEI-specific needs. The framework expands into detailed sections on typical education functions (leadership, instruction, care, qualifications, transportation, products/technology) and includes additional material on learning levels (primary through tertiary), life roles (individual, family member, citizen, student, producer, consumer), and learner needs. The document reflects Don's commitment to comprehensive, holistic education system design that addresses learner needs across all life domains.

title: Hesta-letter
summary: Don's 2006 letter to Dr. Hesta MacDonald establishing the Hesta MacDonald Legacy Fund through the Community Foundation to support school library book purchases. Reflects Don's work in philanthropy and educational resource development.
content_preview:
July 27, 2006




Dr. Hesta MacDonald

206 Spring Park Road

Charlottetown, PE

C1A 3Y9




Dear Dr. MacDonald:




Arising from our discussion of July 26, I am enclosing an agreement for the establishment of the Hesta MacDonald Legacy Fund to provide grants to schools for the purchase of library books.  I believe it reflects our conversation, however, if not I will be happy to make changes.  Please sign and return both copies to the Foundation Office and we will sign both copies and return one to you.




We also discussed the option of making grants even while the endowment is being built.  An additional contribution of $200 per year for the next five years would allow the granting process to begin immediately and also allow the endowment to build so that a similar grant can be made available in perpetuity.  




Since our discussion, I talked with both Dr. Sandy MacDonald and Mr. Tony Gould of the Eastern School District Office about procedures for making grants.  Both were pleased to learn of the potential grant and are comfortable with the Foundation working directly with the designated schools.  I will provide them with more detail once the agreement is concluded.




I commend you, Hesta, for your continuing interest and support for education in Prince Edward Island and thank you for choosing the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island to administer the Hesta MacDonald Legacy Fund.




If this letter reflects your interest, please sing one copy and return it to the Foundation office.




Warmest personal regards.







Don Glendenning

Director

title: Hesta
summary: Don's 2003 letter nominating Dr. Hesta MacDonald for honorary degree at UPEI, detailing her pivotal role in Holland College governance during his presidency and her ongoing community leadership in education and civic affairs.
content_preview:
April 10, 2003







Dr. Karen Smythe, Registrar,

University of Prince Edward Island

550 University Avenue

Charlottetown PE

C1A 4P3




Dear Dr. Smythe:




I wish to propose and support the nomination of Mrs. Hesta MacDonald for an Honourary Degree at the University of Prince Edward Island.




When I arrived on Prince Edward Island some thirty-four years ago, I soon learned of the community involvement of Hesta MacDonald – and that work has continued unabated.  A few months later she was appointed to the Holland College Board of Governors and elected Chair.   Holland College was a new institution, serving a previously unserved population and doing so by a performance based and learner-centered delivery model.  The Board of Governors was key to shaping this new institution, it’s offerings, locations and delivery model.  Hesta was a leader in shaping the College that emerged.  During her tenure on the Board, she provided encouragement, advice and direction to the work of this new institution.   Our association and friendship has continued ever since.




For a number of years Hesta served as the Information Officer at Holland College and prepared and edited a number of our publications.  As Information Officer, I found her to be a good ambassador throughout our multi-campus operation.  She was also able to identify areas needing improvement and bring these to the attention of the appropriate people.




As a mother and housewife, she was interested in her local school and later in the system of education for the Island in general.  Hesta promoted, and was an active member of, the PEI Home and School Association and was, I believe, its founding President.  She later went on to serve on the national body.  While she had an interest in all aspects of education, she maintained a special interest is the area of abused children.



















Her most recent endeavour, at least the ones of which I am aware, is the presidency of the Belfast Historical Society.  N...

title: Hometown Heroes
summary: Don's 2007 letter supporting nomination of Dr. Marlene Bryenton for Earth Day Hometown Heroes Award, praising her environmental stewardship and community foundation work—demonstrates Don's civic engagement and volunteer advocacy.
content_preview:
62 Queen Elizabeth Drive

Charlottetown, PEI, C1A 3A9

March 27, 2007







To Whom it May Concern:

Earth Day Hometown Heroes, 

111 Peter Street, Suite 503, Toronto,

Ontario, M5V 2H1. 




Earth Day Hometown Heroes Award




I am pleased to support the nomination of Dr. Marlene Bryenton for the Earth Day Hometown Heroes Award.




For a some time now, I have been aware of the personal efforts and drive of Dr. Bryenton in supporting many community projects in Prince Edward Island, one of which was to upgrade and maintain one of our city parks – the Joseph A.Ghiz Memorial Park.




While President of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, I was approached by Dr. Bryenton who wanted to set up a fund to ensure the future of the Park.  This was unusual; most of us work on projects and when our terms are finished we move to another.  Not Dr. Bryenton.  She wanted to ensure the sustainability of the Park that graces one of the entrances to the city.  In addition, it is a move, albeit a small one, towards the improvement of our environment.




Not being a person of means, Dr. Bryenton organized a great variety of events and activities to raise funds; her objective was to establishment an endowment of $25,000 in 3 years.  She has now surpassed the $15,000 mark and I know that she will reach her final  goal as well.




During the past two years I have observed her in operation; she brings a focus, dedication, commitment, level of energy and passion not common among volunteers.




I am pleased to support her nomination. 




Sincerely










Donald Glendenning  C.M.

title: IAHSP Follow-up brochure
summary: Memo proposing the "Leave an Artistic Legacy" promotional brochure concept. References Scott MacAulay's (College of Piping Administrator) suggestion to create a coordinated pamphlet for distribution in professional offices promoting legacy giving. Each organization has dedicated panel with mission, charitable numbers, board members, and website. Demonstrates collaborative approach to sustainable arts fundraising on PEI.
content_preview:
IAHSP Follow-up







Some time ago, I wrote to you, or your organization, exploring your interest in some follow-up to the IAHSP program.  At that time, I was thinking of a possible workshop.




There did not seem to be much interest, however, Scott MacAuley proposed, instead of a workshop, that the initial six organizations in the IAHSP program could benefit from a promotional brochure.  In Scott’s words “ 




“One thing I suggested at a previous workshop was for IAHSP Program organizations to come together in producing a pamphlet that would be circulated in the waiting areas and offices of Allied Professionals(doctors, lawyers, accountants, financial planners).

 

The pamphlet might be called…Leave An Artistic Legacy...and each organization would have their own dedicated panel describing their mission, reason for being, registered charitable number(if any) board members, web site, etc. 

 

This document would plant the seed in readers to consider leaving a legacy in their wills, through life insurance policies, stocks or properties etc. during their lives or in their estates.

 

The Community Foundation could be the catalyst bringing all of these independent groups under one umbrella or assist in marketing the organizations as separate Independent entities.”




Please let me know if you are interested and, if so, the Foundation will take steps to move the idea forward.




I would appreciate a prompt reply.

title: IAHSP Wind-up
summary: Strategic planning document for IAHSP wind-up (August 5, 2006) as the project approached conclusion on December 31, 2006. Don outlined three key planning questions: financial status projection, beneficial program activities beyond closure, and optimal use of remaining funds. He identified Lise Laneville (DOCH Program Manager), Harry Holman, and John Robinson as key contacts. The document shows Don's strategic thinking about project closure and stakeholder management.
content_preview:
IAHSP WIND-UP

August 5, 2006




Project ends on December 30, 2006; anticipate substantial unused funds.

Although some IAHSP Committee members have been asking for a wind-up plan, none has come forth for our consideration.

CFPEI has the contract with DOCH and, therefore, should propose/negotiate the windup of the project.

While there were three major donors, DOCH is the only one with which we have a formal contract.  Lise Laneville is the DOCH Program Manager in Ottawa and, I am told, is the person we work with on phase-out.

I think that we should also work with Harry Holmn on behalf of PEI but Bronfman only needs to be informed.

It is time for CFPEI to take the initiative and propose a phase out plan – obviously in consultation with IAHSP

To my way of thinking, there are three questions to be considered:

A	What is our best projection of the program status and financial status on

December 31, 2006

B	What program activities will be of most benefit to participants beyond

December 31, 2006?

	C	How can we best use the remaining dollars to make those things happen?

title: Innovation Bishop Carrol
summary: This document presents general notes on educational innovation, specifically referencing Bishop Carroll High School in Calgary, Alberta. It discusses a self-paced, unit-based learning system where students attend lectures and work independently to achieve mastery through units rather than traditional class attendance. The document notes concerning statistics about literacy (42% may not graduate with adequate reading ability) and includes information from the GFK Trust Index 2010, which ranked firefighters, teachers, and doctors as the most trusted professionals in a survey of 19 countries. Educational principles emphasize beginning education before formal schooling starts.
content_preview:
General Notes




Have student/parents sign a paper saying that they understand that there is a 42 percent chance that their child will not read well enough to graduate.

John – and they pledge that their child will not be in that 42%

Education begins before school starts

Wikipedia reports: In Calgary Alberta, Bishop Carroll High School has a system that is similar to university graduate school. At Bishop Carroll students do not attend classes like in many other high schools. They instead attended lectures and work at their own pace to achieve units. Each course as a set number of units which the student has to attain in order to get credit.

According to the GFK Trust Index 2010, a survey of citizens of 19 countries, firefighters have the greatest level of trust followed by teachers and doctors who are tied for second place.

title: Instruction model
summary:
(155 words):**
Don Glendenning presents a competency-based instructional model emphasizing practical skill development aligned with field practice. The model includes identifying work-relevant competencies, establishing performance standards, creating advisory committees from served communities, using dynamic rating scales, competency-by-competency progress reporting, learner profiles, self-evaluation, and community engagement. Key features include basing programs and assessments on demonstrated performance rather than time served, providing individualized tutoring as needed, and diagnosing learner progress through discussion and learning plans. This model reflects Don's belief that education should focus on demonstrated competency rather than seat time, addressing individual learner needs, and maintaining strong community connections—themes recurring throughout his reform proposals.

title: Instruction
summary:
(130 words):**
This document outlines teaching competencies and instructional steps necessary for educator development. Don identifies nine instructional competency areas: developing personal and professional competencies, instructional techniques, learning materials, learning environments, assisting self-directed and occupational learning, evaluating learner progress, administrative functions, and community interaction. The document compares Alberta's teaching competencies (communication, organization, classroom management, facilitation, assessment, collaboration, caring, flexibility) with broader instructional frameworks. The emphasis on community interaction and broad competency development suggests Don's view that teaching extends beyond classroom delivery to include community engagement and systemic responsibility.

title: Irving, Mary Jean-2
summary: Don follows up with Mary Jean Irving, CEO of Master Packaging Inc., on his education initiative. He apologizes for delays caused by family matters (a death in the New Brunswick branch) and updates her on ongoing efforts: consultations with education officials, an active reading improvement group, scheduled public discussion sessions, an upcoming visit from the Deputy Minister of Education, and plans for school awards and workshops. The letter demonstrates Don's commitment to persistence despite personal challenges and his ability to build momentum for his reform agenda.
content_preview:
Education 20/20 Inc.




101 Kent St., PO Box 624 

Charlottetown 

PEI C1A 1M0 Canada




Email: pei@caneducation2020.com

March 31, 2013




Ms. Mary Jean Irving, President and CEO

Master Packaging Inc.

23784 Trans-Canada Highway

Borden, PE C0B 1X0






Dear Ms. Irving:		




This is a follow-up to my letter of February 1 about an initiative to bring about change in education.  In that letter, I indicated that I would be back to you shortly; unfortunately the call got delayed due to a spate of bad weather, a death in the New Brunswick branch of the family and a trip south.  




I am pleased to report, however, that our efforts continue:

  
Consultation with officials is on-going
  
Our group on reading met last week and will meet again on May 2
  
Two public discussion sessions are scheduled for April
  
The Deputy Minister of Education will speak to our group in late April
  
We have plans for a school award and public workshops for later in the year.
  
We are also exploring our role in the matter of skill training.





I would welcome an opportunity to brief you on my findings and views on education, share future plans, answer your questions, but also solicit your support; I’ll be in touch in a few days seeking an appointment.




Sincerely







Don Glendenning

President

Tel: 892-2060

title: Issues. 100
summary: Comprehensive issues inventory establishing ten key problem areas for PEI education: terminology confusion (World Bank 2018), purpose ambiguity ("place" in society), service invisibility, structural organization ("form follows function" principle), teacher autonomy needs, accountability mechanisms, collaborative deficiencies, system vs. school distinctions, fear factor barriers, and information/documentation gaps. Dated 06/12/23, includes Glendenning attribution. Structured as bullet-pointed analysis suitable for policy presentations. References Paul Bennett on teacher isolation, Matthew Bedard's autonomy-accountability framework. Advocates for public discussion before implementation. Comprehensive yet accessible format suggests use for stakeholder engagement.

title: Issues 2-C
summary: Clarification document (Doc 5) focusing on terminology precision: differentiating education (experiences changing knowledge/beliefs/capabilities), school (physical space for learning), schooling (group learning approach), credentials (institutional certification), and qualifications (independent body certification). Also addresses purpose ambiguity, structural problems, autonomy deficits, and workplace climate issues including insufficient in-service training, degree-dependent advancement, and over-reliance on external experts. (Binder 5)
content_preview:
About Education

Glendenning:

Systemic Issues -2-C

		Doc 5

I talk with many people about education

It is not always clear that we are talking about the same thing; Issues appear to be:




A Clarity




1 Terminology

  
confuse education and schooling. – World Bank
  
Education is an umbrella word that describes experiences designed to change what one knows, believes and is able to do, 
  
A school is a building or a room where learners and teachers meet to pursue selected components of the learning-teaching process
  
Schooling is an approach to helping groups of people who want or need to learn specified conent.
  
Credential- a statement by an  educational institution certifying performance of a student by course and level
  
Qualification - certification by an independent body of level of performance of a person in a field or occupation


2 Purpose 

  
Not clear
  
Does not include preparation for life roles
  
“secure a place”





3 Structure

4 Autonomy 

5 Accountability

  
Not spelled out
  
See MEI and OECD





Workplace Climate

4 Climate/Fear/freedom

  
Little evidence of in-service training; 
  
Salary advancement depends on further degrees
  
Rely on outside experts








Research

Not arguing against what governments are trying to do but rather that the education component is unclear

title: Issues-2 Education
summary:
(160 words):**
Don Glendenning defines systemic education issues and proposes functional solutions. He reiterates that education—preparation for life roles—differs fundamentally from schooling and requires comprehensive service delivery (policy, governance, instruction, resources, information, counseling, quality assurance). Key issues include: inadequate public statements of educational purpose and principles; limited Department mandate focused narrowly on curriculum delivery rather than broad educational leadership; absence of comprehensive vision statements; underserved information functions; conflicting quality assurance approaches; and disconnection from communities served. Don advocates for independent certification bodies (as in apprenticeships) to separate teaching from grading, allowing teachers to focus on learning without compromising their role. He emphasizes that community engagement and clear functional organization are essential for system improvement. The document calls for collaborative conversations between educators and communities to develop shared understanding.
content_preview:
Issues Education -2

About 4-11

What is a systemic issue?




It is widely recognized that education is a key factor in determining each citizen’s quality of life; in the same way, the collective education of our citizens will determine to a significant degree the quality of the communities in which we live.  In recognition of its importance, governments provide massive support for public education. The investment is justified for two reasons, one to ensure a high level of personal growth and development for every citizen; the other is to ensure the common good




An education system is a set of services put in place by a community to encourage and support the education of its citizens. Given the numbers served and the wide range of prior experience, capabilities and interests of learners, designing and operating an education system is no easy task.  While gaps in understanding are to be expected, it seems to the writer that the gap between the providers and users of educational services continues to widen. 




Preparation for life’s roles is called education and the better prepared we are the better we are able to cope with all that we encounter, or create.  Educating is a complex matter made so by the fact that each person is unique in many ways, unique in basic physical, mental, emotional make-up; unique in the range and nature of previous experience, unique in perceived futures, but also unique in terms of learning pace, style and needs.  One’s education is often described as any experience that has a formative effect on the way we think, feel or act; the nature and level of one’s education is demonstrated of as what we can do with what we have learned.




A person’s education may be defined as any experience that has a formative effect on the way we think, feel and act; our education emerges each day, by accident or deign, through a normal life span. 




Typical education functions include policy and governance, Instruction, human resources, learning produ...

Emphasizes that individual learner uniqueness demands system-wide responsiveness. Notes emerging educational futures in Harrow and Hong Kong as reference points. (Dated November 4, 2024)

title: Issues-3, Schooling-1
summary: This lengthy document explores systemic issues in schooling, treating issues as complex problems requiring deep analysis. Don distinguishes between issues, symptoms, and incidents, and provides methodology for issue analysis (who, what, when, where, why). He addresses five major issues: Focus on Knowledge (learner-centered versus subject-centered instruction), Professional Freedom (autonomy and accountability), Delivery Model (administrative versus educational functions), Assessment and Standards (independence from teaching), and Credentials and Qualifications. The paper advocates for learner-centered approaches, teacher autonomy in instructional decisions, separation of coaching from referee functions (grading/ranking), outcome-based education, and independent assessment bodies. Implementation strategies include public campaigns, school autonomy, community advisory boards, and learner-focused policies.
content_preview:
About education




Issues in schooling			     			

No. 01					 					          February 10, 2014







BACKGROUND

              

Issues are topics, problems or concerns of importance to groups of people; they are the big questions.    Issues are not simple problems for which definitive answers can easily be found.  On the contrary, they are complex and of significance. Once understood, the simpler questions can be dealt with and progress resumed.   It’s not always easy to describe an issue in precise terms; sometimes we confuse issues with symptoms and incidents.  An issue may be current, that is a problem of today; emerging and potential issues, on the other hand, focus on those threats and opportunities that are like to impact on life tomorrow.  But the field is messy.  Issues arise in a variety of ways but often become of concern when they impact on personal interests, activities or events, or are related in some way to concerns of friends or family.  When trying to sort through issues, it is often useful to begin one’s analysis with the basic questions of who, what, when, where and why.  It may also be useful to browse or skim broadly in the field, such as browsing the internet, to get a feel for the issues.  In the case of education, while the organization is mine




1 Relevance

3 accountability

4 Inflexibility

5 Conflict – credentialing, ranking, sorting – 




ISSUE NO. 1: FOCUS ON Knowledge 




Each learner comes to a learning situation, whether at home or in school, with a unique set of health conditions and also a unique pattern of skills, knowledge and attitudes; but they also have a unique set of interests, plans and ambitions; both what they’ve experienced and what they plan to do will have an impact on their learning.  Some may simply need information or advice, some may want instruction, feedback or resource material; all need encouragement.  Most if not all of the help needed is available within the community including the local school.  We s...

title: Issues 4
summary: Extensive analysis of terminology confusion, purpose necessity, structural function-alignment, autonomy advantages (OECD PISA 13-country study findings), accountability systems (compliance, professional norms, results), standards application tensions (teaching vs. grading role conflicts), benchmarks (Grade 12 democratic society competency example), and collaborative engagement requirements. Proposes establishing independent qualification bodies separate from teacher assessment roles. Emphasizes education system modernization necessity. (Dated May 23, 2023)
content_preview:
About Education

Glendenning Notes




ISSUES IN EDUCATION-3

About 4-11

May 23, 2023

It is widely recognized that education is a key factor in determining each citizen’s quality of life; in the same way, the collective education of our citizens will determine to a significant degree the quality of the communities in which we live. Government support is justified for two reasons, one to support personal growth and development for every citizen; the other is to ensure the common good. Educating is a complex matter made so by the fact that each person is unique in many ways, unique in basic physical, mental, emotional make-up; unique in the range and nature of previous experience, unique in perceived futures, but also unique in terms of learning pace, style and needs.Given the numbers served and the wide range of prior experience, capabilities and interests of learners, designing and operating an education system is no easy task. These complexities have given rise to the following structural issues: 




Terminology – Educators are creative people; they try to accommodate a number of concepts with a single term. Learning excellence as an example. On the other hand, the writer seldom finds definitions in educational writings nd certainly  is left with the impression that going to school, in all its configurations, naturally leads to a good education. Confusing education and schooling

title: Issues-7 Education
summary:
(175 words):**
Don Glendenning presents a detailed analysis of structural issues requiring public dialogue about education's future in PEI. He emphasizes that education is fundamentally complex due to learner diversity, and systems require clear purposes, functions, and structures. Key issues: (1) Terminology—educators use single terms for multiple concepts without definitions, conflating education with schooling; (2) Purpose—PEI's purpose statements lack detail needed for development and assessment; (3) Structure—failing to organize around identified functions; (4) Autonomy—OECD research shows schools with operational autonomy achieve better PISA results; (5) Accountability—requires defining missions, values, goals, and ensuring transparent communication; (6) Standards and grading—conflicts arise when teachers both teach and grade; competency reporting preferred; (7) Human and social capital—isolated teachers lack collaborative culture. Don advocates moving from product-focused (credentials) to service-focused education, and calls for public engagement in systemic change, extending an invitation to Islanders (June 5, 2023).

title: Issues-8 Education
summary:
(125 words):**
This condensed summary presents eight key issues Don Glendenning identifies in the education system: (1) education and schooling used interchangeably; (2) absent taxonomy for educational concepts; (3) education functions/services unidentified; (4) system relies on schools rather than comprehensive education system; (5) insufficient school autonomy despite OECD evidence supporting it; (6) unclear accountabilities; (7) limited services for independent learners; (8) assessment dependent on written tests; inadequate achievement reporting; system lacks benchmarks. This brief outline captures Don's core concerns in structured format, suggesting preparation for policy discussions or public communication. The emphasis on missing frameworks, inadequate reporting, and system-wide communication gaps aligns with his central argument that educational clarity and purpose are foundational.

title: Issues in secondary educ
summary: Don's contracted paper on critical secondary education issues in Canada, which became the foundation for the Canadian Restructured School Plan. Working with a former university president, superintendent, and deputy minister, Don's group assumed education determines economic prosperity, technological change impacts schools, and secondary education must serve all youth in grades 10-12. The paper identifies six critical issues: information technology application, teacher preparation, accountability, school leadership, poorly served students, and inter-level coordination. Fourteen demonstration projects are proposed, ranging from technology implementation to teacher training models. This work was foundational to CRSP initiatives.
content_preview:
Critical Issues in Secondary 

Education in Canada




A decade ago I was contracted to prepare a paper on critical issues in secondary education in Canada.  This became the forerunner of a major project led by the Canadian Vocational Association known as the Canadian Restructured School Plan. As part of the process, I brought together a former university president, a former superintendent of schools and a former deputy minister of education.  The result was a brief paper, some 10 to 12 pages; the paper was prepared under contract and was not published.  The ideas which follow are drawn directly from that report.




The ideas included in the paper were based on the following assumptions:




That Canada’s future economic prosperity and standard of living will be determined in a large degree by the degree to which its educational system develops the nation’s human resources, thus enabling it to compete successfully in the global economy.




That rapid technological change will continue to impact on the world of work and our secondary schools for the foreseeable future.




That secondary education should operate to serve the needs of all youth in the age bracket normally accommodated in Grades 10 through 12.




The paper then went on to identify the following issues:




Application of information technology in secondary schools

The preparation of teachers

Accountability

Leadership at the school level

Poorly served students

Linkage and coordination




The authors suggested that strategies and interventions should meet the following criteria:




Evidence, based on experience and research, that the project is likely to be successful in addressing the issues

Interventions should be possible within the financial limits of the agencies involved and should seek to maximize existing resources

Strategies should be seen as credible by educators, school boards and government

Reasonable assurance that the intervention, if successful, could easily be applied ore bro...

title: Issues in Secondary Education
summary: Don convened colleagues in 1991 to identify critical secondary education issues. The group recognized education as vital to economic prosperity, human development, and international competitiveness. Don identifies critical issues: computer technology implementation, teacher role transformation, accountability systems, educational leadership, serving disadvantaged students, and inter-level coordination. Recommended demonstration projects include developing lifetime achievement records, improving communication skills, establishing open learning systems, challenging credits, autonomous agencies for 15+ students without certificates, and comparative teacher studies. Co-authored by Hall, Thomas, Glendenning, Baker, and Malmberg.

title: Issues underlying
summary: Don's critical analysis of systemic issues causing turmoil in education. Major problems identified: ambiguity (called "Education" but only operates schools), lack of user choice (providers control what/when/where/why/how), absence of family educational advocates, teacher pay based on knowledge not performance, quality variable while time constant, politicization through government operation, unclear roles for educators, lack of incentives for improvement, HR development gaps, formula-driven budgeting, poor customer service. Argues education narrows vision, leaves some unserved, focuses on subject knowledge over development. This represents Don's foundational critique of provincial education system dysfunction.
content_preview:
Ref/00/systemic

Underlying Issues




People often ask about, or comment upon, the constant turmoil in education; it’s a subject worthy of study, not just comment.  It has been a topic of conversation recently and my conclusion is that much of the turmoil stems from the fact that organized education flouts a number of every day norms.  Here are examples.




  
Ambiguity: Calls itself Department of Education but they only run schools; not clear whether it is providing a service or a product
  
Choice:  The what, when, where, why. and how of education are mostly determined by the provider of educational rather than the user of the services,
  
Absence of a family advocates: Most families, it seems, have advisors to call on for help, a doctor, lawyer, clergyman, accountant or a banker; we have no equivalent for advice about education.
  
Remuneration:  Most people are paid for what they do; teachers, it seems, are paid for what they know.
  
Quality: Time: constant with quality: variable
  
Autonomy: The fact that schools are run directly by a government politicizes most discussion of educational issues
  
Roles and expectations of front line deliverers of educational services are not clear
  
Incentive No rcognition for better service or product, or for the same level o seriice or product in a shorter time
  
HR development
  
Formula driven
  
Customer service





Education/schooling

  
Narrows vision
  
Leaves unserved
  
Retains focus on subject not development





Focus on knowledge

title: JG Section 6 Analysis (March 22)
summary: Section 6 (Analysis) of regulatory report on peanut/nut/sesame seed allergies on commercial aircraft for Canadian air carriers (appears to be formal government analysis). Document examines anaphylaxis risk, effectiveness of buffer zone accommodations, HEPA filtration, and recommends evidence-based mitigation measures. Don's involvement suggests continued policy work in his later years, likely related to government consulting or advisory roles.
content_preview:
6. Analysis

As noted earlier, the Agency was asked to examine the issue of allergies to peanuts, nuts and sesame seeds for commercial air passengers in respect of domestic and international flights using aircraft with 30 or more passenger seats operated by Canadian air carriers and by foreign air carriers operating flights in and out of Canada, by looking into these two matters:

  
The risk of anaphylaxis due to adverse contact with and/or ingestion of these allergens while on board the aircraft; and
  
The effectiveness of current risk-mitigation measures, as outlined in the Allergy Decision.


The research and evidence outlined in the previous sections of this report lead us to the answers to these two questions.

1. The risk of anaphylaxis due to adverse contact with and/or ingestion of these allergens while on board the aircraft

It is clear from both expert reports that the mostly likely route of exposure causing an allergic reaction that could lead to anaphylaxis onboard an aircraft is via accidental ingestion. Information presented in both the NRC Report and Dr. Greenhawt’s Report indicates that it is unlikely that peanut, nut, and sesame seed-based allergens can aerosolize and cause inhalation-based reactions. Dr. Greenhawt's Report notes while exposure via inhalation is commonly believed to be a route of exposure, there is no data to support this. Rather, data that does exist consistently shows that peanut allergens to not aerosolize; moreover, Dr. Greenhawt notes that there have been no oral or inhalation provocation studies to support the theory that nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal mucosal exposure can trigger an allergic reaction. It is possible, as the NRC report indicates, that allergic reactions attributed to inhalation  are being incorrectly attributed to unnoticed ingestion or dermal contact of allergens that have settled on surfaces.. 




In addition to the unlikelihood of an inhalation-based reaction, almost all large domestic air carriers oper...

title: Kaptein
summary: Don Glendenning's account of Anne Kaptein, a Berlin-born travel writer and WWII survivor who lived in Charlottetown. Don persuaded Tim Kaptein to donate her manuscript 'Those Tragic Years' to the Confederation Centre Library. Illustrates Don's community engagement and support for cultural/historical preservation.
content_preview:
Anne Kaptein, a travel writer lived in Charlottetown with her husband, Tim.  She grew up in Berlin and was a nurse-in-training during  World War 11.  A copy of her story about those early years now resides in the Confederation Centre Library.  




The book came to the attention of Don Glendenning, a friend of the Kapteins who persuaded Mr. Kaptein to give his only spare copy to the Library




Those Tragic Years tells about  the rise of Hitler, the tension with family member who supported the Nazis and the fear that a slip of the tongue could result in their being reported to the secret police.  Anne also tells of the early bombing of Berlin and the relocation of the school.




After the War, Anne married Tim Kaptein, from Holland  they and lived in Charlottetown until her death.  Tim has since moved to Niagara Falls, Ontario to be near his family.

title: Kelly  meeting
summary: Meeting notes documenting Don's discussion with Ella Kelly from Skills PEI about a proposed workforce and continuing education needs assessment project for Souris. Outlines project options, funding mechanisms through the Labour Market Partnerships Program, and Don's strategic thinking about incorporating technology needs analysis and DACUM-like skills analysis methodologies.
content_preview:
SOURIS PROPOSAL-1-C

Meeting with Ella Kelly, Skills PEI, Montague Office




  
Background;  I submitted a  paper, but not an actual proposal, to Skills PEI on December 11, 2017.  The idea being to assess continuing education needs especially for out of school young people.  I proposed surveys of current assets, employers, key informants and students. 
  


  
On Monday, I met with Ella Kelly, SkillsPEI in Montague to discuss the paper; there is an interest in such a project. Funding would come through the Labour Market Partnerships Program and, as far as I can see, cover all costs; I do not know if it is in the form of  contract or grant.





  
I have the application form to which we attach a proposal; we need to  sharpen objectives, traditional budget, deliverables, etc.
  
SkillsPEI interest is in adults transitioning to work but any study would have broader implications
  
We discussed a 3-4 month project but could be greater or longer depending on changes to the project
  
We couldn’t enter an agreement with Skills PEI and then contract out  to another agency 
  
Options:


  
Take contract ourselves – hire a director to direct and manage the work.  We would need admin support but that would/could be included in budget.
  
Another agency take the project and we provide technical advice.





  
On reflection:


  
Perhaps we should consider both “training and Technology Needs for Souris Youth”. I say this because “technology” arose during our first meeting in Souris and, second, There I some evidence that “upgrading is improved when linked to practical technology.


  
I also see the possibility of a “DACUM—like” analysis of skills being useful
  
In addition to a small committee to drive the project, perhaps we should think of a larger consultative council in Souris that could meet a couple of times.

title: Ken Gillis
summary: Substantive letter from Don to Ken Gillis (August 22, 2006) providing detailed feedback on IAHSP wind-up planning. Don emphasizes the importance of project timelines, requests greater detail on participant status and remaining completion requirements, and identifies needed wind-up activities including final reports and thank-you letters. He notes that John Robinson had been informed of the December 31, 2006 deadline and suggests this requires update if timeline changes. The letter demonstrates Don's systematic project management approach and accountability to stakeholders.
content_preview:
Date:		August 22, 2006




To:		Ken Gillis




From:		Don Glendenning




Subject:	IAHSP 




Sorry for the delay in responding; thanks for the draft paper on the windup of the IAHSP Program.  




Inclusion of the timelines is important because they point out some of the restrictions to finishing on time that were not of our making.  




Katy’s document mentions the likely status of each participant as of December 31.  I’d like to see more detail.  Specifically, what will remain for each participant to complete beyond the end of the contract?  The list should include their final reports.




As Katy points out, there are also project wind-up activities – the settlement of accounts, the preparation of a final report, thank you letters and a wind-up of files.  These also need to be identified in some detail.




Although Katy titles her draft “a report of possibilities”, in fact, the paper only offers one phase-out scenario and that deals only with project administration.  Assuming that this paper is for discussion purposes by the Board, I’d be inclined to deal first with wind-up activities of participants.  With that clear in our mind, we can then turn our attention to winding up the project.




You will recall that John Robinson met with the IAHSP Board some time ago to discuss our phase-out plans.  At that time, he was told that the project would be wound up by December 31, 2006.  If this is no longer the case, John should be alerted so that discussions can commence with DOCH.




I hope these comments will be helpful.




Regards




Don

title: Labour market
summary: Analysis of modern labour market composition from "The Conversation" (May 16, 2024), categorizing eight occupational classes: Doers (cashiers, cleaners, retail), Builders (construction trades), Supervisors (coaches, process supervisors), Knowledge workers (analysts, teachers), STEM professionals (technicians, engineers), Personal services (data entry, administrative), Technical trades (specialized skills), and Non-technical trades (stylists, photographers). Contextualizes education system design within contemporary employment realities and skill requirements.
content_preview:
About Education

Glendenning Notes

Modern Labour Market

The Conversation of May 16, 2024 reports  new way for thinking about the modern labour market:

  
Doers, which include jobs like cashiers, light-duty cleaners, nursery and greenhouse workers, pet groomers and store shelf stockers.
  
Builders, which include occupations like bricklayers, concrete finishers, longshore workers, and roofers and shinglers.
  
Supervisors, which include jobs like coaches, and supervisors of petroleum, gas and chemical processing and utilities.
  
Knowledge workers, which include occupations like investment analysts, economists, researchers and analysts, pharmacists and secondary school teachers.
  
STEM professionals, which include jobs like chemists, computer network technicians and numerous engineering roles.
  
Personal services, which include jobs like data entry clerks, legal administrative assistants and retail salespersons.
  
Technical trades, which include occupations like boilermakers, carpenters, industrial electricians and tool and die makers.
  
Non-technical trades, which include jobs like hair stylists and barbers, photographers, printing press operators and sports referees.

title: Learning 2
summary: This document is a blog post discussing the nature of learning and personal development. It emphasizes that learning is fundamentally a process of discovery, critique of traditional classroom lecture-based learning as inefficient, and the importance of curiosity as essential to effective learning. The author argues that learners need freedom to ask questions, time for reflection and exploration, sufficient leisure to think, open-mindedness to the unexpected, and a stress-free environment. References to two blogs: "Slow Leadership" and "The Coyote Within." The piece advocates for creating conditions where exploration and self-directed learning can flourish, particularly relevant for adult self-development and professional growth.
content_preview:
Ads by Google

Brain Exercises

Improve Memory and Attention with Brain Games by Scientists www.lumosity.com



Elementary School Teacher

Earn Your Teaching Degree Online Find the Right Colleges & Courses www.Online-Education-Degrees.org

One of the most heartening aspects of writing a blog is the continual evidence of how many people are actively striving to learn and develop themselves. It’s easy to become downhearted at the way the world seems. How the media constantly complain about schools and other educational institutions, as if spending on education were a waste of resources. If more reporters paid attention to blogs, they’d see just how much enthusiasm there is for all aspects of learning.

We all know learning is a process of discovery. Sitting in a classroom listening to a lecture is probably the most inefficient way for anyone to learn. I think that’s why some people leave the educational system with little or no sign of achievement, only to more than make up for that lack once they have the opportunity to pursue their own brand of self-development. I’m also sure most teachers don’t want to try to work in this way. It’s the pressure and lack of resources that force them into it — plus the crazy emphasis politicians have placed on standardized tests. 

When it comes to learning for yourself, the best friend you have is curiosity. Strong learners are always asking questions. They don’t accept glib or conventional answers. Nor do they assume others, even those in authority or people with a long string of credentials, automatically know better than they do. Experts are a great resource, but need to be used with care. Some of them got their degrees more by knowing how to work the system than by intellectual merit.

If you want learning to work for you, you must create the conditions in which exploration can take place and discoveries can be made. It’s very clear what these are:

regular time to reflect

enough leisure to think and explore

freedom to ask que...

title: learning diagram
summary: A visual flowchart organizing learning into three phases: planning, engaging, and documenting. The planning phase includes attempting tasks, gathering information, seeking advice, observing others, undertaking assessment, and developing learning plans. The engaging phase encompasses attempting tasks, receiving instruction, gathering information, seeking advice, receiving feedback, observing others, using resources, and applying new learning. The documenting phase involves transcripts, credentials, and qualifications. This diagram represents Don's effort to create a structured model showing learning as a dynamic, iterative process with clear entry/exit points and documentation procedures, reflecting his systems-design approach to educational reform.

title: Levels 1
summary: This document addresses the measurement and reporting of educational achievement levels, distinguishing between age-based grades and actual proficiency levels. Don critiques current PEI educational practices where learners at different starting points study the same material for fixed periods while learning at different rates—making grade-based achievement reporting confusing. He argues that assessment functions should be independent of those who teach, certify proficiency regardless of age, and establish levels rather than rankings. The document proposes elements including comprehensive competency analysis, evaluative criteria, benchmarks, criterion-referenced rating scales, and recognizable proficiency levels. He references examples like the Apprenticeship Red Seal program, Canadian Language Benchmarks, Red Cross Swim Program, and Royal Canadian Conservatory of Music as successful independent assessment models.

title: Levels 2
summary: This document focuses specifically on achievement levels in literacy and numeracy, chosen because they are foundational to modern society, unique in their educational roles, and critical budget priorities. Don cites European Commission research showing that increasing national average educational attainment by one year increases productivity by 6.2% immediately and 3.1% long-term. The paper outlines core beliefs: people differ in conditions of birth, prior learning, and aspirations; achievement levels involve range and level of demonstrated skills; sorting is not a school function; outcomes derive from subject examination rather than learner characteristics; and levels are non-competitive status indicators. Current issues include teacher-sorting conflicts, poorly measurable outcomes, absent benchmarks, complicated assessment systems, grade-level confusion, social promotion, and inadequate report cards.

title: Levels 3
summary: This occasional paper addresses educational standards and proficiency measurement. Don reiterates that while many education improvement suggestions focus on early childhood, teacher training, and engagement, standards revision is often overlooked. Key issues include: establishing levels based on subject examination rather than learner age, distinguishing between administrative grade levels and achievement levels, separating teaching from student ranking/sorting, establishing clear benchmarks, and developing published rating scales. He proposes characteristics for assessment: independent from teachers, certifying proficiency, open to all ages/backgrounds, non-competitive, confidential. Concrete examples include Red Seal apprenticeship, Canadian Language Benchmarks, Red Cross Swim Program, and Royal Canadian Conservatory of Music—all models where teaching and certification are separated.
content_preview:
.				About education	

Educational Standards




Occasional Paper No. 4		                        			              July 31, 2015







Life is a journey with education being what we’ve learned along the way.  is intended to help us cope with, enjoy and even smooth the way. One source of educational support is our school system  There are many calls for improvement or change in what, why, when and where we teach sucg S Suggestions for improvement are wide ranging and most focus on early childhood ears, on increasing engagement, better trained teachers; one that is seldom mentioned is that of revamping school standards. 




but one element that seldom gets mentioned is that of standards and, more specifically, what we measure, how we measure and how we report what has been learned. An educational standard is a widely recognized statement that describes what students know or can do  at a specific stage of their education.  

A 2003 multi-country study from the European Commission found that if the national average educational attainment level is increased by a single year, aggregate productivity increases by 6.2 per cent right away and by a further 3.1 per cent in the long run.1

Issues

  
Establishing  levels of difficulty


Levels of difficulty or achievement in a subject arises from an examination of the subject.  In fact, one of the reasons Spadey proposed OBE was to make it easier for learners to travel at their own pace. It is a long time since I read xxx by William Spadey but my recollection is that organizing outcomes, ant the curriculum arising therefrom, cannot nor should not, be linked to the age of the learner.  




  
Reporting achievementLinking achievementlevels to ages of learners  


The logic of using the same terminology to label both administrative and grading purposes escapes me; I’m sure that it must puzzle students and parents as well.  The two should be separate.  Have 12 levels of s subject if you must, although that seems excessive, but ref...

title: Levels-4
summary: This brief document challenges conventional education level measurement, arguing that years of formal study and credential accumulation are not meaningful measures of education. It proposes determining educational levels based on: what a person knows or can do, and the level of proficiency demonstrated in each competency area. Don references leadership, communication skills, and languages as examples and presents a DACUM-based model describing six discernible levels: exercising leadership in life roles; functioning well in roles with special abilities; functioning adequately with minimal support; functioning with assistance/direction; and inability to function without or with assistance. This represents a shift from traditional grading to competency-based proficiency descriptions.
content_preview:
Levels of education				22




Levels




.  The popular method is to measure one’s education by the number of years of formal study, but we all know that that is not a meaningful measure.  Some people add to that the list of ones credentials, high school graduation, Bachelors, Masters degree or Ph. D.  But the value of credentials is declining, perhaps because of the job market, the numbers of people with credentialsm and some would say because of declining standards (social promotion) on which they are granted.  Credentials, professional designations and other third party qualifications are also used as a measure of one’s education.  Readers, I am sure have their own criteria.




Determining  levels, I suggest, depends on a couple of things.  First  are the things a person knows or is able to do; the other is the level of each of ones skills




Leadership, communication skills, languages spoken




Here is an approach based on the DACUM model.  Discernable levels of education:

  
Exercise leadership in some aspects of one or more life roles
  
Functions well in most life roles with obvious special abilities in some
  
Functions adequately in life roles with minimum and occasional support from community
  
Able to function in most life roles with assistance and direction
  
Unable to function in life roles without assistance and direction
  
Unable to function in life roles

title: Levels A-4 Bloom Revised
summary: This document presents Bloom's Revised Taxonomy, a classification framework for learning objectives updated by Lorin Anderson from Benjamin Bloom's original 1956 work. The six levels, from lowest to highest order thinking, are: (1) Remembering - recall and recognition; (2) Understanding - comprehension and translation; (3) Applying - using concepts in new situations; (4) Analyzing - breaking down materials into components; (5) Evaluating - making judgments about value; (6) Creating - building new structures from elements. Each level includes specific action verbs and practical examples relevant to workplace and educational contexts. This framework is foundational to instructional design, assessment, and educational outcomes specification.

Key Words: comprehends, converts, defends, distinguishes, estimates, explains, extends, generalizes, gives an example, infers, interprets, paraphrases, predicts, rewrites, summarizes, translates.
      
    
    
      
        
Applying: Use a concept in a new situation or unprompted use of an abstraction. Applies what was learned in the classroom into novel situations in the work place.

title: Levels of education
summary:
Glendenning's critical analysis distinguishing between education and schooling - a recurring theme in his work. Defines education as "any experience that has a formative effect on the way a person thinks feels or acts" while schooling is "that part of one's education resulting from experiences planned and organized while in an educational institution." Critiques PEI Department of Education for focusing exclusively on children in school, suggesting this should be titled "Department of Public Instruction" instead. Advocates for provincial education systems that address all citizens' learning needs across the lifespan. Argues that distinguishing education from schooling clarifies communication, expands learning opportunities, and reinforces lifelong learning.
- **Key People**: None specifically named
- **Key Organizations**: PEI Department of Education; references New Brunswick and Nova Scotia education systems
- **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT
- **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Glendenning's fundamental critique and reconceptualization of education vs. schooling, a core theme throughout his consulting work.
content_preview:
About 

Education










Education and schooling







We often confuse schooling and education; we do not similarly confuse health and hospitalization, religion with church attendance or citizenship with court appearances.  Seldom do we conclude that a person is healthy because they spent time in a hospital or are religious because they attend church, mosque or synagogue regularly.  




Good’s Dictionary of Education defines education  as “the aggregate of all processes by means of which a person develops abilities, attitudes and other forms of behaviour of positive value in the society in which he lives.”  Mine is simpler than that; I define education as any experience that has a formative effect on the way a person thinks feels or acts.  A functional analysis would show schooling, or more likely “instruction”, as one of the functions of an education system




Schooling, on the other hand is described in Good’s dictionary as “individual training or education received in an educational institution, military or civilian.”;  again I define schooling that part of one’s education resulting from experiences planned and organized for a learner while in an educational institution.  This may be an appropriste time to pause and verbalize your own definition




The website of the PEI Department of Education, Early Learning and Culture includes a Philosophy of Education; a quick read tells us that the Department’s focus is on children but only those children who are in or preparing for; the structure of the Department reflects the same view.  Based on  their own documentation, a more accurate title would be Department of Public Instruction.  Department documents would leave the impression that the other 100,000 Islanders, those who are not children, don’t need or warrant an educational service.  







Although not as familiar with New Brunswick and Nova Scotia Education systems, web documents suggests that the focus of those Departments also to be youngsters in schoo...

title: Life roles-commentary
summary: A commentary on the learning framework incorporating Maslow's hierarchy of basic needs and the Oregon Educational model's concept of real and imagined life roles. The document identifies six life role categories (individual, family member, citizen, learner, consumer, producer) and explores how people develop imagined futures in areas such as family, career, lifestyle, community, and income. This framework positions learning as driven by both fundamental human needs and aspirational life goals, demonstrating Don's sophisticated understanding of motivation and human development as central to educational reform.

title: Life Roles
summary: Don presents his framework of six life roles (individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member, citizen) as the foundation for school outcomes. He argues schools should be "incubators" providing safe environments to experiment and fail. However, education lacks clear stakeholder alignment—student, provider, and investor interests don't clearly identify who the "customer" is. Don contrasts educator input measures (subjects taught, credentials, facilities) with community output measures (what graduates can actually do). He concludes that reconciling these views—aligning education content and measurement with community-based standards—is essential for raising educational quality.
content_preview:
BETTER EDUCATION FUND 










We fill many life roles in the course of a life time.  The Oregon Education Act of 1991 identified the following six: individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member and citizen.  The relative importance of each role varies from individual to individual and will change over time.    People  move into some roles without formal schooling but it is generally recognized that, at some point in our lives and for a varying length of time, all can benefit from help in the form of instruction, advice, coaching, information, counseling and practice.  The amount of help needed varies from individual to individual; that is one of the complications of teaching.  But the ability of each learner to function in society is the final test of the school system




Schools are incubators in that they prepare young people for life in the adult world; they help people in their most formative years to develop skills needed in their adult lives.  Schools offer a safe and controlled environment to experiment, to try new things, even to fail.  Society has placed few restrictions on what schools can or should do but neither has it described well its expectations.




Schools do not operate on the normal business model in which a person or a company invests in a product or service and a consumer or client purchases the product or service.  In the case of education, there are at least three sets of stakeholders and their interests overlap.  It is not always clear just who is the customer?  the learner?  the service provider? the investor?  Where does a prospective employer fit in?  Who is accountable to whom and for what?




The output of schools for each learner is the growth that occurs between entering and leaving the school system – that is, growth attributable to the efforts of teachers.  The clearer we specify the desired exit performance, the more likely learners are to achieve it.  The better we describe the difference schools make, the more like...
