title: MacKay Brochure-3
summary: Another iteration of the MacKay Endowment Fund brochure with similar content about David Arthur MacKay and his achievements. Emphasizes his characteristics: excellent judge of character, valued friendship, and his passion for building MacKay and Hughes Ltd. into a major potato distribution enterprise. This appears to be a working draft with minor variations from other versions.
content_preview:
What is The David A. MacKay Endowment?




The David A. Mackay Endowment Fund was established by Mr. MacKay’s family, colleagues and friends in recognition of his many accomplishments, his sterling character and his love for Prince Edward Island.  The Fund is a permanent endowment administered by the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island.  The purpose of the David A. Mackay Fund is to make grants to improve the cardiac emergency response system on Prince Edward Island.










Who was David Arthur MacKay?







David Arthur MacKay, (1932-2000?) a son of Prince Edward Island was a  successful  businessman, an excellent judge of character, a builder who valued friendship and was a loyal friend to all.  He loved his family, loved life, loved PEI and loved a good story.

 

David had a full and varied career including starting dozens of different companies.  His greatest success and main passion was the establishment of MacKay and Hughes Ltd.which was listed on the Toronto Stock exchange and became the largest fresh potato distributor in North America.
















 

What will the fund do?




The David A. MacKay Fund is one of a number of funds within the Community foundation of Prince Edward Island and is a non-profit, volunteer organization administered by a board of directors which oversees permanent endowments set up by members of the community.  The Foundation is a registered charity and all donations are tax deductible inn Canada and the USA




Grants may be made for  improving public awareness,  provide training (paramedics, nurses, doctors and the general public), purchasing equipment, etc. 













How can I help?




Individuals and organizations wishing to remember Mr. MacKay and support the David A. MacKay Endowment can make a direct donation to the Foundation.  Donations are tax deductible in both Canada and the USA.  A receipt to be used when filing your income tax returns will be issued for all donations.

summary: This brochure describes the Living Memorial Trust endowment established by the MacKay family in David's memory. Shows Don's role in developing multiple endowment programs honoring significant PEI citizens.
content_preview:
What is The Living Memorial Trust?




The Living Memorial Trust is a permanent endowment administered by the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island.  The purpose of the Living Memorial Trust is to make grants to enhance outdoor public spaces on Prince Edward Island.




Fund was established by Mr. MacKay’s family in recognition of his many accomplishments, his larger than life character, his love for his family, and his love for Prince Edward Island.  




Who was David A MacKay?










David Arthur MacKay, (1932-2002) was born and raised in Albany, Prince Edward Island. Dave was a successful businessman and an excellent judge of character who took great pride in being a “builder’ and not a “knocker”. He valued friendship and loyalty. He looked for the entrepreneurial spirit and encouraged and fostered it when  he encountered it, especially in young people. He was a sportsman who loved golf and the camaraderie of the game. His faith was solid and his support and assistance to many charities and organizations reflected the help he was always willing to give on a personal basis. Although known for his listening skills, he was especially loved for his story telling and joy of life.

 

Dave had a full and satisfying career which included numerous business partnerships and investments throughout Canada and the USA.  His greatest passion was building   MacKay and Hughes Ltd. of Toronto into the largest fresh potato distributor in North America.




What will the fund do?




The Living Memorial Trust is one of a number of funds within the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, a non-profit organization administered by a volunteer board of Directors, which oversees permanent endowments set up by members of the community.  The Foundation is a registered charity and all donations are tax deductible in Canada and the USA




Income from the Fund will be used to make grants for the enhancement and beautification of public spaces such as parks, Trails PEI .  E...

title: Map
summary: Comprehensive proposal and background document for creating a competency-based mathematics curriculum map for PEI. Begins with 2013 CFPEI youth survey findings regarding preparedness gaps, followed by Education 20/20's multi-year exploration of "basic skills." Document articulates major concerns: undefined content/levels, economic drag from low skill levels, duplication of remedial teaching, scattered institutional responsibility, and low priority given to basic skills instruction. Proposes using the 1978 "Practical Mathematics" analysis as a foundation and DACUM methodology (developed by Nova Scotia NewStart, pioneered by Holland College) for creating a shared competency framework. Outlines next steps: establish steering committee, review existing analysis, develop rating scales, identify profiles, and develop assessment processes.
content_preview:

In late 2013, The Community

provides a snapshot of the findings.  Bright

Although
PEI math scores on National and international tests have risen,

Islanders
need math; citizens may not need a high level but they need to be

Wolf and Leilo:

Great to see you last week but sorry my visit was so rushed.  Here are some further thought on our conversation:

  
Formal notification about pension - I did not see mention of any penalty for not returning the form to Germany other than they would suspend payment of the pension.





  
Volume One of your book – I checked three places about having your book printed.  All recommended that it be retyped first.  Should be able to find a typist at $15.00 an hour but am not sure of the number of hours required to type the volume.  Although you have already typed Volume One, there are quite a few additional hand written notes to be inserted.  





After the typing, the relevant photos need to be scanned and inserted in the appropriate place on the relevant pages, then a copy made for your review.  My thinking is that we set a limit of, say, $500 and see what we can do with it both in terms of typing and editing.  




At that point, we will have a better feel for the final document and the costs involved. 




I’ll send a copy of one of my reports so that you can see how I handled photographs.




  
Proposed Marold Fund – we had spoken during an earlier visit about an endowment fund at the Community Foundation that would provide grants on an annual basis to the PEI Humane Society.  I left a copy of our standard agreement which provides for a contribution now and allows for additional contributions later.  





If, as you indicated, you want the residue of your estate to pass to the Community Foundation you need to consult your lawyer about an appropriate clause in each of your wills.  The following is an example of such a clause:

I, Wolfgang Marold, transfer and convey to the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island ________ % of the residue (or a specific amount) as a contribution to the Dr. Wolfgang and Leilo Marold Endowment Fund for the purpose of making annual grants to the PEI Humane Society.

title: Math 4 -Releance 2 2019-5 (Repaired)
summary: Don's analytical essay on mathematics education and relevance in PEI, drawing on international research and education theory. Discusses definitions, educational impact on community productivity, and gaps between curriculum offerings and learner needs. Reflects Don's education reform thinking and policy analysis.
content_preview:
MATH: A PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED

4-1-Math/numeracy-

2019-2-25

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

DEFINITIONS: 

Education – any experience that has a formative effect on the way a person thinks, feels or acts

Mathematics – the study of science of number, quantity, and space.

Math education – the extent and nature of a person’s attitudes, skills an knowledge in and about the field of math.

Relevance – quality or state of being closely connected or appropriate




EDUCATION

Our futures and the future of our community will depend in large measure on the nature and level of education gained by our citizens; in addition to serving citizens, governments have a responsibility to ensure that our communities have the skilled people needed to care for the community in which we live.   A 2003 multi-country study by the European Commission found that, if the national average educational attainment level is increased by a single year, aggregate productivity increases by 6.2 per cent right away and by a further 3.1 per cent in the long run.




Education services are offered through a public-school system devoted to serving the needs of young people, relatively autonomous postsecondary institutions, the private sector and a variety  of services operated or administered through provincial ministries of learning, training and workforce development (much of the latter is paid for by federal dollars).  Public and media comment suggest a gap however, between services offered community expectations.  The Council of Ministers of Education Canada (CMEC) highlighted this concern in its statement of July 6. 2016 when it acknowledged that the need to improve transition is shared by many educators, employers, certification agencies and the community at large.




MATHEMATICS EDUCATION 

Mathematics is considered an essential part of every day life. One of the math issues is that of findin...

title: Math projects
summary:
(115 words):**
Don Glendenning outlines potential mathematics education projects designed to align curriculum with practical application and competency-based assessment. Projects include: correlating PISA test content with actual community mathematics use; analyzing course content relevance to community application; developing performance-based rating scales; identifying competencies across grade levels; providing competency lists to students; adopting New Brunswick's Grade 5 citizenship mathematics standards; questioning ranking systems; implementing self-rating practices; developing learning platforms; and establishing comprehensive learning competency frameworks. These projects reflect Don's commitment to making mathematics education relevant, practical, and competency-focused rather than grade-focused. They align with his systemic reform vision of education serving practical life and work needs.

title: MAXIMS f0r TEACHERS
summary: This document contains 58 instructional maxims written by Bronson Alcott (transcendentalist educator) in 1826-1827 to guide teaching practice. The maxims emphasize teaching as a moral and ethical calling ("with a sense of accountableness to the profession," "as an agent of the Great Instructor"), character formation, preparation of materials, respect for individual learning differences, inductive methods, and student-centered approaches. Key themes include: teaching through discovery and curiosity, learning from multiple sensory modalities, adapting to individual student needs, using encouragement rather than coercion, connecting learning to practical life applications, and fostering independent thinking. The maxims represent 19th-century progressive educational philosophy emphasizing pedagogy that respects students' dignity, intellectual capacity, and individual learning styles.
content_preview:
GENERAL MAXIMS f0r TEACHERS

By which to regulate the instructor's practice in instruction

Bronson Alcott [written 1826–7]




1. To teach, with a sense of accountableness to the profession

2. To teach, with reference to eternity

3. To teach, as an agent of the Great Instructor

4. To teach, depending on the Divine Blessings for success

5. To teach, as the former of Character, and the promoter of the collective happiness of Man

6. To teach, to subserve the great cause of philanthropy and benevolence

7. To teach, distinct from all sinister, sectarian and oppressive principles

8. To teach, with charitable feelings toward all rational and animal beings

9. To teach, distinct from prejudice, from veneration of antiquity and from excess of novelty

10. To teach, to improve the science of instruction and of mind

11. To teach, duty appreciating the importance of the profession

12. To teach, awed by the clamours of ignorance, yet governed by the dictates of wisdom

13. To teach, nothing from subservience to custom

14. To teach, with un-remitted solicitude and faithfulness

15. To teach, appreciating the value of the beings to whom instruction is given

16. To teach, regarding the matter as well as the manner of instruction

17. To teach, that alone, which is useful

18. To teach, in imitation of the Saviour

19. To teach, by exact uniform example

20. To teach, in the inductive method

21. To teach, gradually and understandingly, by the shortest steps, from the more easy and known, to the more difficult and unknown

23. To teach, illustrating by sensible and tangible objects

Memorial Service

Walter S. (Bud) McMurtry (1922-2001)

January 6, 2002




Gathered to remember and pay respects to Bud McMurtry




I first met Bud in Ottawa at a National meeting in 1962,  He was articulate, knowledgeable and represented the Island well around the Conference table.




PEI became a founding member of a regional teacher training program.




Some things are easy to visualize:

A young lad growing up in Nova Scotia

A student 

A husband

A father

A stint in the Navy

Arrival on Prince Edward Island to work with the Department of Agriculture




For a number of years Bud was Mr. Vocational Education in PEI

Bud was a jack of all trades

Director of Vocational Education

Larger Provinces had specialists in each area but Bud was responsible for everything - vocational High school education, training of technicians, apprenticeship, training of unemployed , vocational teacher training

The face of education on PEI changed under his leadership

Construction of PVI and PCVHS

A college of applied arts and technology was established







In 1969 he came to Holland college 

As Program Planning Coordinator he spearheaded the establishment of the Atlantic Police Academy.  He worked with Police Chiefs and others involved in law enforcement to keep the initiative moving.

Chief Dan Allen, then in Chatham, was promoting police training.  We thought that we should talk with him.  Bud arranged with Someone, bill Rix, I think, to bring him over for the day

title: Meals-Food
summary: Don's personal recollections of farm meals, family food traditions, and rural childhood memories including threshing crew meals, traditional desserts, mushroom foraging, and food preservation. Autobiographical reflections on domestic and family life on a PEI farm.
content_preview:
Meals




Although I often worked at the “thrasher’ at 







home, I never worked a “thrasher” elsewhere.  I spoke, therefore, with brothers, Norman and Kenneth about their recollections.  A Threshing crew consisted of 8 or more men.  At least one meal was provided and sometimes two meals if the crew worked late to finish up.




The crew started at 8:00 am. Dinner was about 11:30.  Meals might vary but usually included meat (roast beef or maybe pork), potatoes, carrots maybe turnip, bread, with tea (cannot remember ever having coffee) and dessert.  Jean says that apple pie was a favourite.  One of Mum’s regular desserts when there was a crowd at the house was gingerbread with whipped cream.  The second meal, if there were one, would be about 4:00 pm.  Many times the work was done by 4:00 pm or so and a second meal was not necessary. 







Washboard Pie




Washington pie was a regular dessert at home especially when entertaining.  It consisted of two layers of white cake with a filling between.  Seems to me that the filling was either raspberry or strawberry preserves but could have been a lemon filling as well.  Earl Taylor used tease Mum by calling it “washboard pie”




Mushrooms




While at the cottage earlier today, I picked a beautiful large mushroom.  Since then I’ve peeled it and fried it in lots of butter.  Was it ever delicious?  




I am reminded of picking mushrooms when I was a youngster.  For some reason, I recall picking them on the way home from taking the cows to the Finno” field – the one at Finno’s turn.  At that time the land on the back side of the road was an open, un-cultivated field.  It was a good place to find mushrooms.  Seems to me that Dad always checked to see that we had not brought toadstools – then Mum fried them.




I think that the one I just ate was a  mushroom. However, if you do not receive this letter, you will know otherwise.




Canning




As I was picking beans today, I thought about all the preserving of fruits and...

title: MEGS-1 Info. for Panel Members (003)
summary: Don's facilitation guide for DACUM (Developing a Curriculum) analysis panels, explaining the process and expectations for panel members. Reflects Don's role as a trained DACUM facilitator and his expertise in occupational skills analysis methodology used internationally.
content_preview:
DACUM Analysis - Information for Panel Members




What we will do:

We will follow a structured, proven process to analyse your occupation. This will then be produced as a chart. The chart is an organized, accurate, current description of your occupation as it is now and will be in the foreseeable future.




I will orient you thoroughly at the beginning of the session.  




What is DACUM?

We will use the DACUM process, invented in Canada in 1960 and now used around the world. 




A DACUM Analysis is a cost-effective, highly valid and dynamic process of identifying what practitioners do. It uses experts from the occupation to identify the competencies required to perform the job. Although DACUM stands for Developing a Curriculum, it has a wide variety of uses: training needs assessment; program development / review / revision; job description; job modification; occupational performance standards; employee recruitment; career planning; skill achievement record, etc.




What to bring:

Please bring a willingness to participate and a writing instrument. You will not need any documentation or electronic access. 




Roles:

You are the expert panel, and I am your facilitator. You know your work; I’m the process person. 




What to expect:

Being a member of a DACUM panel can be both really easy and really difficult! I’ll be asking you what you do, in detail. Your panel will reach consensus about the activities you do and will be doing in the foreseeable future.   




You do not need to know anything other than what you do and expect to do at work. It does not matter if you have been doing this work for 20 years or 1 year, your input is equally valid. 




You will be thinking and expressing your thoughts, not writing. I will input the group decisions. 




Most persons who participate find it to be a satisfying process. 




What helps:

It’s very helpful if you can participate fully – please say what you think! 




It takes quite a bit of effort and concentrati...

title: Minister Brown film
summary: Invitation letter to Hon. Richard Brown, Minister of Workforce and Advanced Learning, to attend a screening of the documentary film "Most Likely to Succeed" produced by education philanthropist Ted Dintersmith. Don notes positive reviews from the New York Times and Washington Post. The film showcases project-based learning at High Tech High in San Diego, California, emphasizing relational skills development and student autonomy over content-focused instruction. The screening is scheduled for Sunday, January 17, 2016 at The City Cinema in Charlottetown, with discussion to follow. Don extends a complimentary invitation as his guest.

title: Minister McIsaac
summary: Don's draft letter to Education Minister McIsaac advocating for systemic education reform in PEI. Discusses need for change beyond funding, emphasizing engagement, standards, professional freedom, accountability, and independent learning. Reflects Don's policy advocacy and reform agenda.
content_preview:
Minister McIssac




Education




During the last few months, I have engaged many Islander, educators and retired educators, business operators, parents, colleagues and friendsin conversations about education; some I sought out but others sought me out to share both information.  Overwhelmingly there is an interest and desire for change; no one expressed support for the status quo.  As part of my information gathering, I reviewed  a number of reports about education and  my own conclusions reflect many of the conclusions of those reports.  I am sure that you are aware of the public calls for change in education , not only in PEI, but around the world and at all levels – and I expect those calls to become more strident.




You may well argue that you, and your government has demonstrated your commitment to to education through new and upgraded facilities, increased number of teachers and improved salaries, an strengthened early childhood education program, increased postsecondary education, and the use of technology, and I would not be one to argue the contrary.  But the items that arise in my conversations are seldom, if ever, about more money; they are about doing business differently including engagement, standards, professional freedom and accountability independent learning, entrepreneurship to name bet a few.  We have built a system that is almost impervious to change, some external stimulus is needed.  While you may or may not agree, I believe that I am helping

title: Mission 1
summary: Don's strategic analysis of PEI education mission and scope. Critiques narrow departmental focus on youth-only education, argues for comprehensive lifelong learning framework, and discusses problems with current school system. Proposes broader definition centered on life roles and community outcomes.
content_preview:
What’s the education mission for PEI?

Education is complex.  Learners have different interests, experiences, learning styles, capabilities and needs. They also fill a variety of life roles, that of an individual, student, citizen, family member, consumer and producer. The system offers programs, courses, grades, credits, degrees, diplomas and certificates usually at locations and in formats established by providers. Education is confusing to say the least. A clear purpose is essential

In reading PEI documents, I am surprised to find, at least officially, that the department is only interested in the education of young people.  A paper on philosophy of education tells us that the Department helps “students find a meaningful place in society”.  The Department of Education website  gives the Department’s role as one of developing and delivering high quality programs and curriculum” to youth. Four things bother me about these statements (1) it under sells its Islanders (4I  fail to mention the range of services offered  and lacks  detail needed to develop programs and to measure progress.

Current school services not sufficient education for tomorrow’s world; it’s time for the Department to step up to the plate. 

























One could easily make the case that education is unexplored territory to the Department of education and not of great interest.great interest to those who run schools. in exploring it.

v

chooling has replaced education as the basis of communication. Silos are seldom breached and the task of informing the public is assigned to visiting experts.   

We understand the role of schools, neede for better ventilation and electric buses but citizens wonder why graduates still have problems with every day math, seem not to be able o managr personal finance, or be tuned to the expectations of employers.

Future of education is secure

Schools under pressure to change




The future of  our community and Isladers will depend to a large degree ...

title: MISSION 3
summary: An expanded exploration of education system missions globally, including statements from Maine, Bangor, Alberta, and other jurisdictions. Glendenning documents that PEI's education mission "captures neither the spirit, breadth, significance nor urgency of the education task." He identifies systemic problems: the department operates in "public instruction" mode rather than educational development, lacks engagement with 21st-century competencies, ignores soft skills, and shows no interest in broader Islander education. His conclusion: PEI's government is unclear about what it aims to accomplish through education. He proposes a new mission: "Help Islanders develop knowledge, skills and other attributes needed for life in 21st century" and recommends mission statement development as a valuable staff development activity.

title: Montague Press Release 2
summary: Post-workshop press release (February 19, 2014) reporting on Montague's February 18 workshop. Key issues identified: lack of basic skills (literacy, numeracy, citizenship) and disconnect between schooling and real life. The release critiques structural issues: government funding creates political short-termism over sound policy. This demonstrates how Don's workshops were catalyzing critical community analysis of systemic barriers.
content_preview:
February 19, 2014

Preparedness on the hotseat

The lack of basic skills, literacy, numeracy and citizenship, were the lead issue raised by participants in a workshop in Montague on Tuesday evening; the relevance of schooling to real life was a second.

The workshop, organized by Education 20/20 first heard a presentation on the findings of a recent survey of over 200 Island youth between the ages of 15 and 25.  The survey, Taking the Pulse of Island Youth, dealt with youth concerns about health, education, employment and social well-being.  The presentation, led by Steve McQuaid, VP of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island and Katherine MacDonald, Researcher, provided details about the methodology and findings.  

Among the other discussion points was the view that some of the desired changes are structural and not educational, a question as to whether or not it is the role of a school to teach life skills, the declining value of school diplomas, and the difficulty of developing a culture of learning. Since schools are entirely funded and more or less operated by Government, improvement initiatives often reflect short term political considerations over sound principles of public policy”. 

 Similar workshops are planned for other Island communities in the coming weeks.  People interested in future activities of Education 20/20, or to be placed on the mailing list for the monthly newsletter, should check the website, www.education2020.ca

title: Mrs Gallant
summary: Don's mentoring letter to Mrs. Mabel Gallant offering guidance on her grandson's reading development, recommending home-school partnership and suggesting the PEI Literacy Alliance. Shows Don's accessibility and commitment to individual educational advocacy beyond institutional roles.
content_preview:
62 Queen Elizabeth Drive

Charlottetown 

PEI  C1A 3A9

December 8, 2012




Mrs. Mabel Gallant

PO Box 243,

Charlottetown,  C1A 7K 4




Dear Mrs. Gallant:




First let me apologize for the delay in responding.  Although retired, I seemed to have been caught up in a whirlwind of activities lately and am just now responding to my mail.  Although reading is not my specialty, I believe good reading skills are required in all the things we do.  I know that schools are working to improve the levels of reading and I am told that levels are rising, but more needs to be done and done now.  




We know generally that students benefit from a close relationship between the home and the school and this is especially true, I believe with reading.  Students need encouragement and can benefit from conversations about what subjects of interest.  Perhaps picking up the occasional sports or hot rod magazine, depending on his interests, may also encourage him.




Since there is no one teacher of reading, I suggest that you start through a discussion with his teachers.  Some schools have special reading programs for students like your grandson; you should also have a discussion with the Principal.  You should feel as free to talk to a teacher or principal as you would with your doctor about a health problem.




I would also recommend that you talk with the PEI Literacy Alliance. They are located at 161 St. Peters road, the old Ellis Brothers Shopping Centre. (Tel: 902-368-3620).  They may have some ideas and be able to put you in touch with a volunteer tutor.




I commend you for your interest in your grandson’s school studies.  Our education system would benefit if more people like yourself took an active interest in what schools do.




Again, thanks for your letter.  I only wish that I could be more helpful.  Let me know how you make out.




Regards




Don Glendenning

Date:		March 4, 2007




To:		Elizabeth Noonan




From:		Don Glendenning




Subject:	Henry Purdy




Some thoughts on the nomination paper:




Played a leadership role in PEI in the field of Arts and Arts Education for 40 years

Founding member of the Arts Council and supporter of other arts related organizations in PEI

As Director of the School of Visual Arts, led a team of instructors.  Practically all active professional in the arts and crafts were provided instruction under Henry’s leadership.    Offerings were available in the School of Visual Arts but also through short courses and part time instruction in a variety of centres throughout PEI.  His visiting artists program and srt exhibitions strengthened the community of artists and art supporters

Was active nationally in the Canadian council of the arts, was awarded the RCA designation 30 years ago and was awarded the Order of Canada for his contribution to the arts.

Since retirement, Henry continues to paint, to teach mature students and teacher classes in Art at UPEI

title: Notes
summary: Extensive research notes synthesizing literature on performance-based assessment and competency analysis. Glendenning documents the shift from input-based to outcome-based education, noting that "certificates and diplomas should be awarded based on demonstrable skills rather than hours of instruction." He explores performance assessment's advantages over traditional testing: better validity, more useful feedback to unsuccessful candidates, improved knowledge assessment, and potential cost-effectiveness. He emphasizes that "informed professional judgment is essential" to reliable assessment and advocates for competency analysis as the foundation for certification standards. The notes reveal Don's deep engagement with educational research and his conviction that better assessment drives educational improvement.

title: Nova Scotia Glaze
summary: This document outlines recommendations for reform of Nova Scotia's education system, focusing on reorganizing from "nine silos" to an integrated system. It includes catalysts for change emphasizing student learning, resource allocation to classrooms, improved teacher support, and increased transparency. Key recommendations include establishing a College of Educators, removing principals from the teachers' union, and creating new administrative structures. The document includes comments reflecting critical thinking about whether improvements can focus only on public schools.

title: Numeracy -3
summary: Foundational paper distinguishing between math (abstract study of quantity and space) and numeracy (practical application of mathematical knowledge in daily life). Documents growing support for numeracy instruction based on Conference Board of Canada research showing 45% of Canadian adults have inadequate numeracy skills. Recommends that numeracy be recognized as an intrinsic part of every school subject, similar to literacy. References PEI Department of Education's Early Numeracy Intervention Program and the Scottish Education Department's eight categories of numeracy competencies.

title: Numeracy 4-1-N-1
summary: Paper examining numeracy as an essential skill distinct from formal mathematics education. Notes that 45% of Canadian adults lack adequate numeracy skills and no province grades above "C" for numeracy competency. Argues that numeracy should be offered as a separate subject based on skills citizens use in normal life. Recommends competency-based programs with levels established separately from grades, community-based advisory committees, and dynamic rating scales. Includes extensive references and pedagogical considerations about outcomes versus competencies.

is

title: Numeracy ask
summary: A persuasive fundraising letter dated February 20, 2019, from Don Glendenning to Robert Irving, President of Cavendish Farms, requesting financial support for the Numeracy Project. Don articulates the problem: while PEI math test scores have risen nationally, practical numeracy skills on the shop floor remain inadequate. He proposes a $15,300 project involving a two-day brainstorming session with external facilitators to identify numeracy skills needed for everyday Island living. The letter demonstrates Don's strategic thinking about applied mathematics education and his networking within the business community.

Mathematics
 on PEI






Although
PEI math scores on National and international tests have risen,
friends tell me that math has not improved on the shop floor; I’ve
been wondering why.






Islanders
need math; citizens may not need a  high level but they need to be
able to measure, sort, calculate, group and estimate numbers, space,
time  distance, etc.  and they need to do it quickly, easily,
accurately; and consistently.  This approach to math is called
numeracy and it involves the application of math to every-day lives.
Numeracy is being adopted elsewhere; usually in addition to
traditional math.  







But
we need more; to begin with we need to identify math skills used by
Islanders in their every- day lives. Making an analysis involves

 We’ll have to bring someone in at a cost $15,300.  The making of

title: NZQA
summary: Don's notes on New Zealand's National Qualifications Framework development, examining why NZQA emerged: gaps in recognized qualifications, unclear linkages between qualifications, unclear training access, non-recognition of prior learning, inconsistent terminology, and international mobility needs. Key principles include simplification, open learning pathways, lifelong learning emphasis, and performance-based assessment. The framework contains eight levels covering age six upward, using Units of Learning that may count toward multiple qualifications. Units include title, credit rating, performance criteria, and accreditation processes. Schools are accredited emphasizing teaching quality management, monitored by national staff. Learners receive records showing achieved units and earned certificates/diplomas.

Contains Spady's definition of OBE as "clearly focusing and organizing everything in an educational system around what is essential for all students to be able to do successfully." title: OBE paper
summary: A detailed analysis of Outcomes Based Education philosophy and implementation, contrasting traditional content-focused instruction with learner-centered, outcomes-driven approaches. The paper examines William Spady's OBE paradigm, including three premises (all students can learn, successful learning promotes more learning, schools control success conditions) and four power principles (clarity of focus, expanded support, high expectations, design-down approach). Don critically assesses both strengths (consistency, accountability, accessibility) and weaknesses (lack of standard models, grade-level confusion, teacher autonomy concerns) of OBE implementation. He reviews exit outcomes from Saranac Lake schools and Atlantic regional outcomes, ultimately recommending renewal of outcome identification processes and development of implementation handbooks—demonstrating his evidence-based, reform-minded approach.
content_preview:
200-1-3


Outcomes Based Education














Background














Traditionally
schools focused on content to be learned, whether it be on the arts,
science or business.  Fields are divided into subjects, courses and
units and lectures or lessons for the purpose of teaching and
learning. Assignments and assessment followed suit.  One’s
education, at least the part experienced in school, became the study
of a series of discrete experiences too seldom integrated into a
coherent life related whole.  Vocational educators, on the other
hand, based their planning and teaching on an analysis of skills of
an occupation , and more recently, skill programs focus on
competrencies.  Perhaps the best known approach, DACUM, was developed
in Nova Scotia and has since spread world wide








OBE
changes the focus of education from content to learners and organizes
teaching and learning around outcomes and measures change based on
performance regardless of when the learning took place.  According to
William Spady, a sociologist xxxat the University and one yime
professor at the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education in
Toronto, outcomes could be written with “traditional,
transitional, or transformational goals in mind”.   It appears that
the leadership in OBE dealt with broad principles only; as a result
there are no recognized standards for identifying out comes or
implementing OBE. As a result, there are many versions of OBE, most
focusing on outcomes only.

Schools control the conditions that affect directly affect successful

four “power principles” are:

2.
Expanded opportunity and support for learning success;


3.

title: Off to the Woods
summary: Personal memoir of childhood winter logging expedition in New Brunswick, describing travel by bobsled with brother Norman, equipment, clothing, and the landscape. Captures formative rural experience and family work, edited/typed June 19, 2016, offering autobiographical insight into Don's early life before his distinguished educational career.
content_preview:
Don

Off to the Woods

Undated manuscript

Typed and edited on June 19, 2016




Wearing a pair of mother-made woolen mitts, I sat at the right end of the bunk on the front bobsled, feet resting on the runner as the team of grey horses (Queen and Lady?)  trotted over the frosty, crunching snow.  Brother Norman sat at the other end of the bunk, urging and directing the team of horses towards the ridge.  The folded horse rug on the bunk protected our backsides from the cold bunk and provided a safety envelope to carry the sharpened double-bitted axes; we actually sat on the head of the axe.  A crosscut saw was fastened to the bunk of the rear sled.  A well-travelled track spread ahead, across the little Branch Road, in Uncle Jim’s lane, through the barnyard, across the fields and brook and into a thicket of spruce and balsam fir. further along we would pass the huge white pines and eventually reach our destination, a hardwood ridge.




At the time, I slept in the little room over the kitchen, the one where the pipe from the kitchen stove came up through the floor a. turned east and entered the chimney.  I’d wakened before 6:00 to the rattle of the stove as Norman was starting the kitchen fire.  That was my signal to get up and get dressed.  Woolen long-johns were the order of the day although I wore fleece lined underwear which was softer on the skin, woolen socks, Humphrey’s woolen pants, a redshirt, a cap with rear-muffs, and a heavy woolen Jacket was the typical dress for such an occasion.    Scuffed work boots completed the attire but they were more comfortable and less sweaty than the gumboots I wore as a kid.




Soon we reached the cover of the woods where the sleds twisted, bumped and slewed over the hummock and hollow. Because of the way bobsleds were constructed and linked it was a relatively smooth ride; flat sleds would have thumped along and forced is to hold on.  The huge white pones reached the sky from pristine forest floor marked only by the lone rab...

content_preview:
Back to school...back to basics?

Ontario

The new basics for public education: survival skills for

the 21st century

As the new school year begins, parents across Ontario can be condent

in the

knowledge that their children are entering one of the most successful education systems

in the world. Provincial, national, and international test results show that Ontario’s

schools are doing well in teaching students the subjects that we have come to think of as

“the basics”.

While the importance of literacy and numeracy skills is widely recognized, students need

a broader set of skills, not only to master the old ‘basics’, but to ensure that they can

thrive – now and into the future.

People for Education, working with experts from across Canada, has identied

ve

areas

that are foundational to all learning and that encompass the broad skills students need to

be productive, engaged, healthy citizens. Each category has a set of concrete

competencies and skills that are teachable, learnable, and have an impact on students’

long-term success.

What are the new basics?

Health, citizenship, creativity, and social-emotional competencies, and a learning

environment that supports their development: these are the new basics of public

education.

But aren’t these just ‘soft skills’? Why should we care

about them?

content_preview:
Ref

Ontario rubric


From Wikipedia, the free
encyclopedia

Jump
to: navigation,
search


	
	
	
		

			

		
		

			This article does not cite

			or sources.

Please
			help improve

			Unsourced material may be challenged
			and removed.
			(March 2008)
		
	



The Ontario rubric
is a rubric
system used to mark students in the Ontario
province's school system.


The Ontario rubric is typically a chart with five
columns. The first defines the category that is being evaluated, and
the other four show levels 1 through 4. Level 1 is 50%-60%, Level 2
is 60%-70%, Level 3 is 70%-80%, and Level 4 is 80%-100%. Some
teachers represent a perfect mark by suffixing a plus
sign to the 4 ("Level
4+"). The Ontario rubric system is used more or less throughout
high
schools and elementary
schools in Ontario.


The rows are typically broken into four strands:

	


	Knowledge/Understanding 
	
	


	Thinking/Inquiry 
	
	


	Application 
	
	


	Communication 
	



They can also be organized into sections for projects like this:

	


	Appearance/ Neatness 
	
	


	Organization 
	
	


	Information and Understanding 
	
	


	General Appeal 
	



Rubrics are usually only used if the school uses
these four strands for marking, as they can otherwise cause
unnecessary confusion. Rubrics provide a good breakdown of these four
strands, but the strands are not weighted evenly. While a student may
have received a low mark in only one of the rows, this can lead to a
dramatic decrease in their overall grade if that strand is weighted
heavier than the others. Similarly, if one receives a low mark in a
strand that is not weighed heavily, it can have little effect on
their mark. Rubrics are also often used for relatively hard-to-mark
items such as CASI
tests, and oral presentations.


The Ontario Rubric appears to be evolving into something known as a
"competency profile". Competency profiles are much more
user-friendly for te...

title: OP.Man.Amalgamating School Boards Not Answer
summary: Policy opinion piece examining school board amalgamation issues. Discusses effects of school board consolidation and challenges to effective educational administration.
content_preview:
(FB015) 
MARCH 2003 

AMALGAMATING SCHOOL DIVISIONS WON�T INCREASE EFFICIENCY 

Larger is not Cheaper 

Executive Summary 

� 
The Manitoba government recently reduced the total number of school divisions in the province from 54 to 37. Its main purpose so 
was to save costs on administration. 

� 
The Manitoba FRAME report provides a yearly accounting of school division spending. If larger school divisions are more efficient 
than smaller divisions, the difference would be expected to show up in the FRAME data. 

� 
Tiny school divisions (under 1000 students) do have higher per pupil expenditure rates and administration costs. However, the 
vast majority of divisions (those with more than 1000 students) show very little relationship between size and rates of spending. 

� 
The largest school division in the province, Winnipeg School Division #1, has very high per pupil costs while much smaller divisions 
within the city have much lower per pupil costs. 

� 
Some mid-sized school divisions like Hanover and Garden Valley have very low per-pupil expenditures and administrative costs. 
Emulating examples like these makes more sense than simply creating larger divisions. 

� 
The school board model itself, with its diffuse funding sources , lies at the heart of the problem. It is time to think about a more 
transparent and accountable model. 

Introduction 

The Manitoba government recently reduced the total number of school divisions from 54 to 37. Its stated purpose for doing so was to 
improve efficiency and save money on administrative costs. This backgrounder will compare the spending habits of school divisions 
and attempt to determine whether or not there is a relationship between larger size and higher efficiency. 

A number of school divisions and school districts are not included in this comparison. Due to their immense geographical sizes and 
other unique challenges, data from Frontier School Division #48 and D.S.F.M. are not applicable. For the same reasons t...

Opportunity Gap

NOTE:	Snippets of information as background to a discussion about an education award

Book: 	Carter and Weiner; Closing the Opportunity Gap: What America Must do to Give Every Child an Even Chance ( available on Kindle for $10.00)

The Washington Post, 2014/10/02

‘Schools of Opportunity’ – a new project to recognize schools that give all students a chance to succeed

By Valerie Strauss October 2 

We all know about the many efforts to rate and/or rank schools by student standardized test scores and other data points — but without any of the out-of-school factors that play an enormous role in how well young people fare academically. Now two veteran educators are spearheading a new pilot initiative to identify and recognize public high schools that seek to close opportunity gaps through practices “that build on students’ strengths” — not by inundating them with tests and not by evaluating them with scores.

The people behind the Schools of Opportunity project are Carol Burris, principal of South Side High School in the Rockville Centre School District in New York, and Kevin Welner, a professor at the University of Colorado Boulder’s School of Education who specializes in educational policy and law. Burris, a frequent contributor to The Answer Sheet on New York’s troubled school reform efforts, was named the 2010 Educator of the Year by the School Administrators Association of New York State, and in 2013, the same organization named her the New York State High School Principal of the Year. Welner is director of the National Education Policy Center at UC Boulder, which produces high-quality peer-reviewed research to inform education policy discussions.

The Schools of Opportunity project will start as a pilot this year in  Colorado and New York. In this post, Burris and Welner explain why they have launched their new effort and how it will work. This blog will exclusively publish the announcement of the schools selected to be recognized next spring.

title: Outcome framework vital to succeeding
summary: Identical to File 18—another version of Don's essay on outcome framework necessity. The piece emphasizes that while outcome-based education approaches have gained acceptance across Canada (except universities), the field lacks clear terminology and overall structure. Don's construction shed analogy effectively argues designers must establish framework before selecting details. He positions DACUM—which he associates with producer roles—within broader Oregon life roles context (individual, learner, producer, citizen, family member, consumer). Don proposes a clear outcome hierarchy moving from life roles downward to specific elaborations. He concludes that understanding outcome architecture enables practitioners and policymakers to work more effectively toward educational transformation.
content_preview:
Outcome framework vital to succeeding




During the past two weeks I have been party to a number of discussions about outcomes-based education and, more especially, about the nature of outcomes.




One discussion was in the context of the CRSP Project; another was with the chair of one of the national Sectoral Councils; other conversations involved colleagues, both long standing and new, who have a responsibility, experience and a major interest in outcome- or competency-based education, training, standards or performance assessment.




	The good news is the extent to which outcomes are viewed as the starting point for the design and development of both training programs and performance standards.  During our discussions, no one questioned outcomes as the place to start.




	It appears to me that, except for the university sector, the good ship education is trying to set a new course ― a course based on desired outcomes.  Although there are many views about how we get there or how we will know when we arrive, none surfaced about the ultimate objective.




Determine need for outcomes structure




	During our discussions, however, two things became quite clear.  The first is the need for some definitions of terms related to outcomes.




	Having said this, however, I am aware of the jurisdictional propensity to dream up unique terms.  I understand this and am also aware of how quickly terms lose their “freshness” and assume baggage that reduces their acceptability and even their effectiveness.  But work on common terminology, we must.




	The second observation concerns the need for an outcomes structure.  The importance of such a structure can be related to a construction project which I engaged in last year on my farm.




	I decided to build a small free-standing shed.  I took account of the lay of the land, selected a site and sketched out an appropriate building design.




	Only after my ultimate design was clearly established did I go to the woods, cut l...

title: Outcomes Based Education
summary: Don presents himself as a believer and practitioner in outcomes-based education, noting his direct experience with competency-based systems. He comments on browsing internet sources to update himself on OBE trends and expresses disappointment that educational emphasis has shifted from true outcomes to curriculum-based objectives. Don critiques the Atlantic Provinces Learning Outcomes as neither true competencies nor educational outcomes but rather curriculum outcomes. He references the Oregon Life Roles framework (individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member, citizen) as the proper foundation for identifying outcomes. Don argues that outcomes development should originate from community/occupational sources rather than textbooks, and he calls on the Department of Education to redesign outcomes to meet proper criteria of clarity, unambiguity, and relevance.
content_preview:
EDUCATION 							Issue No.

20/20  	       OUTCOMES BASED EDUCATION                                                                                         _______________________________________________________________________Let me say up front that I am a believer in outcomes or competency based education.  I am familiar with it, having both studied it and worked in a CBE system. Sound educational planning demands it.  Clear, unambiguous and measurable outcomes are the place to start.  




My experience was with competency based education; you can imagine my delight listened to William Spady.  We were talking the same language.  Granted competencies were more specific but I feel that the detail is needed. A tighter specification is needed to properly plan activities and interventions, hence my preference for the term competency.   







A competency is a statement of observable behaviour resulting from the application of knowledge to the solution of a problem or situation.  It follows then that competency based education is an approach to organizing educational programs and activities that clearly identifies what is to be learned and various levels of achievement. 




I browsed the internet recently to update myself on outcomes based education.  Imagine my disappointment to learn that, although many still confess to be using an OBE model, in fact the emphasis has switched to curriculum based objectives.  




My later browsing of the objectives as found in the PEI curriculum outlines confirms the general trend.  Atlantic Provinces Learning outcomes are, in my view, nneither competencies of educational outcomes.  They are, as the literature said, curriculum outcomes.




In issue No. 1, I mentioned the six Oregon Life Roles: individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member and citizen.  It is my view that program planners and curriculum developers should, therefore, look to those sources to identify in some detail the nature, range and depth of skills ex...

Appears to be working notes for developing a more comprehensive essay on education system structural problems.

title: PEI 3 Purpose
summary: Comparative analysis of education purpose statements across jurisdictions and philosophical frameworks. Don examines purposes from: Fielding (personal relationships priority), Alberta (economic competitiveness skills), New Brunswick (lifelong learning attributes), various anonymous sources emphasizing postsecondary entrance, life navigation, democratic citizenship, engaged participation, Home and School (general education level), OECD (multi-faceted world citizenship), Ontario (skilled caring citizens), Quebec (instruction, socialization, qualifications). PEI documents surveyed: School Administrative Handbook (children's meaningful societal place), Department Website (quality programs/curriculum delivery), philosophy documents (societal place preparation). Concerns noted: limitations to children only, insufficient specificity for planning/measurement. Advocates for purpose clarity enabling program design and progress assessment. Dated Nov 7, 2023. Demonstrates Don's comparative policy analysis approach across Canadian/international contexts.

title: PEI -4 Purpose
summary: Critical analysis of PEI education Department's naming, definitions, purpose, role, and organizational structure. Criticizes department name "Education and Early Years" (formerly "Lifelong Learning") as unnecessarily limiting when education encompasses all ages. Notes Department lacks formal education definition; School Act revision replaced "education" definition with "school" definition. Questions whether education should serve all Islanders versus only children. Reviews official purposes from multiple sources (School Administrative Handbook, Department Website, Philosophy documents) and notes inconsistencies and insufficient specificity for program planning/progress measurement. Lists comprehensive departmental goals (2015-16) spanning citizenship, critical thinking, knowledge acquisition, creativity, workplace skills, mental/physical health, bilingualism, gender equality, human rights. Dated June 13, 2024. Argues for clarity, transparency, and comprehensive documentation.

title: Personal Framework-2
summary: Personal evolving framework outlining Glendenning's comprehensive education philosophy. Defines key terms (learners, education, schooling, learning, teaching, education systems). States operating beliefs emphasizing individual uniqueness, home's role, personal responsibility for education, developmental nature of learning, and declining institutional importance. Identifies education system characteristics needed: accessible, affordable, flexible, relevant, accountable, transparent, focused on helping individuals change. Lists key intervention points and critical gaps. Concludes that fundamental education problems are organizational rather than educational, with recommended key interventions including clear mission, professional autonomy, learner-centered models, professionalized teaching, independent assessment, and counseling services. This represents Glendenning's mature synthesis of decades of educational thought.

title: Personal Investment 1
summary: Glendenning identifies systemic barriers to reform stemming from limited personal investment by education leaders. He catalogs problems: compensation based on university credentials rather than performance; dependence on outside experts; inadequate information in reporting systems; selective PISA result citation without implementing recommendations; reluctance to speak publicly about education; lack of conceptual clarity; frequent administrative turnover with government changes; political appointment of leadership; minimal educational research; and emphasis on delivery rather than development. The document suggests these structural incentives undermine leadership commitment to systemic reform and student learning outcomes. His underlying argument: systemic problems are not primarily pedagogical but rather structural, political, and cultural.

title: Personal Journey
summary:
Don's reflective narrative about his career journey. Describes "sandwich education" - 18 years of alternating work and study between high school and final degree across Canada, USA, and England. Career phases: student, teacher, principal, teacher trainer, federal training specialist, college administrator, consultant. Notes influences: Laycock on teaching and learning, A.S. Neal's "The Free Child," Programmed Instruction, DACUM, and recognition that there is a "school system not an education system." Guiding principle: 90% of students could achieve A grades with more time. Identifies as lateral thinker with diverse roles including curriculum developer and conference speaker. Explains motivation for writing: education is the most important issue, more important than oil reserves or climate change; system is impervious to change and needs external intervention.
- **Key People**: Donald E. M. Glendenning (author), Laycock, A.S. Neal
- **Key Organizations**: Multiple educational institutions throughout career
- **Tags**: BIOGRAPHICAL, PROFESSIONAL, MANUSCRIPT
- **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Comprehensive summary of Don's career trajectory, intellectual formation, and driving motivation for educational reform work; demonstrates breadth of experience and intellectual commitment.

title: POINTS OF VIEW@2015-02-03T16;44;10
content_preview:
POINTS OF VIEW




By the mid-1980's, DACUM, or at least the analysis component, had wide application throughout Canada and the United States of America.  Since then, its use has become international. Following are some comments by people who are familiar with the DACUM model.




1.	In 1986, Adrienne Burleigh from New Zealand visited the USA, Canada and a number of other countries and concluded:




"DACUM has widespread and growing use throughout both Canada and the United States of America. While the application of DACUM demonstrates small local variations, the concepts outlined by Adams have been adhered to and, in all cases, the tenets that underpin the DACUM process are instantly recognizable in all situations." 




2.	Macklin, in his Masters' thesis at Simon Fraser University, concluded that "... DACUM still stands, unchallenged, as the pioneer curriculum development system for competency-based  vocational training".




3.	Robert Norton of the National Centre for Research in Vocational Education, Ohio,  wrote: 




“DACUM or "Developing a Curriculum" is a relatively new and innovative approach to occupational analysis.  It has proven to be a very effective method of quickly determining, at relatively low cost, the tasks that must be performed by persons employed in a given job or occupational area." (p 1)




"DACUM is an occupational analysis procedure that has experienced remarkable success in a relatively short period of time in both Canada and the United States.  Because its structure and procedures allow occupational duty and task statements to be identified (1) effectively, (2) quickly, and (3) at a very low cost, DACUM has become closely associated with the movement toward competency-based education(CBE).  In addition, the DACUM process has a number of characteristics and qualities that are greatly needed in CBE if it is to become a practical alternative to traditional vocational education."  




4.	Donald Glendenning, the Founding President of Holl...

title: Post sec CSM-How higher education is leading us astray
summary: Bill Bonner's guest column critiquing higher education's value proposition, arguing that increased spending has not improved outcomes. The article compares educational spending across countries, noting the U.S. spends $8,000 per student annually versus Japan's $4,000, yet scores lower on achievement tests. Bonner argues that entrepreneurship and job creation come from dropouts like Steve Jobs and Bill Gates, and questions whether the emphasis on college education has harmed American economic dynamism. Contrasts real capitalism's "creative destruction" with government-backed education systems.
content_preview:
How
higher education is leading us astray


Despite
a skyrocketing price tag, higher education is not benefiting our
young people any more than when it was affordable


By
Bill
Bonner, Guest
blogger / October 31, 2011 


	


	
  





In
this file photo, Wichita State graduates walk to the graduation
ceremony for the college of liberal arts in Wichita, Kan. For most
Kansas college students, the road to a degree takes longer than four
years. Bonner argues that higher education is more cost than it's
worth in its current state.


When
the financial crisis of 2008 hit, we saw how state-managed capitalism
works. Favored companies are allowed to make as much money as they
can. But they are protected from going broke.


Certain
firms are deemed “too big to fail,” by virtue of the key role
they play in the economy, or at least by the role they play in a
politician’s plans for re-election or future employment. But
state-managed capitalism is very different from the real thing. It is
capitalism in a degenerate form.


Real
capitalism progresses in fits and starts, described by Josef
Schumpeter as “creative destruction.” It is like a jungle…not
like a zoo. It cannot be managed. You cannot take out the predators
or feed selected species without upsetting the balance of nature.
Take out the destruction, and you block the creative process too.


Since
the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, most real wealth has come
from real capitalism. Not from “playing the market.” Not from
getting a good job. Not by trying to cadge favors from the
government.


So,
what is real capitalism? It is what we’ve seen in the
computer/Internet industry over the last 20 years. This was a new
industry. It had not yet been tamed by the government. Regulations
were few. There were no large, entrenched companies to block
start-ups. There were no lobbyists to curry favor from the
politicians. There were no subsidies…and no barriers. It was young,
dynamic, chaotic…and very prone to blow-ups.


The
whol...

title: Post sec- Sports & Rec
summary: Sam Dillon reports on trends showing American colleges spending more on recreational facilities and administration while proportionally reducing expenditure on instruction. Study by Delta Cost Project analyzed spending 1998-2008, documenting a shift toward "country-clubization" of universities. Private research universities increased spending on instruction 22% over the decade, but 36% for student services and 36% for institutional support. Community colleges show similar patterns. The article criticizes this reallocation as inconsistent with educational mission and notes the economic crisis has made spending models unsustainable.

Colleges
Spend More on Recreation Than Class 


By
SAM
DILLON
Published:
July 8, 2010

	


	
Facebook

American
colleges are spending a smaller share of their budgets on

The
report, based on government data, documents a growing stratification
of wealth across America’s system of higher education. 



At

The

University
and Amherst
College
differed from sprawling public universities like Ohio
State
and community colleges like Alabama Southern. 



The
United States is reputed to have the world’s wealthiest
postsecondary education system, with average spending of around
$19,000 per student compared with $8,400 across other developed
countries, says the report, “Trends
in College Spending 1998-2008,”
by the Delta Cost Project, a nonprofit group in Washington that
advocates for controlling costs to keep college affordable. 



“Our
analysis shows that these comparisons are misleading,” said Jane
Wellman, the project’s executive director. “While the United
States has some of the wealthiest institutions in the world, it also
has a ‘system’ of postsecondary education with far more economic
stratification than is true of any other country.” 



Community
colleges, which enroll about a third of...

title: Post secondary Low cost degrees
summary: Tamar Lewin reports on Texas and Florida initiatives to create $10,000 bachelor's degrees as a response to escalating costs and student debt. Governor Rick Perry and Rick Scott launched programs to challenge universities to develop efficient degree programs using online learning and new pedagogies. Early results show limited uptake: Broward College offered low-cost degrees in only four specialized programs with 80-student target, while Miami Dade drew 62 students. Article notes most programs involve "re-pricing" rather than fundamental redesign, and federal/state aid means most students already pay under $10,000.
content_preview:
Low-Cost B.A. Starting Slowly in Two States

By TAMAR LEWIN

Published: October 18, 2013 

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — With tuition, student loan debt and default rates all spiraling higher, what’s not to love about a $10,000 bachelor’s degree? 

John Van Beekum for The New York Times

Maggie Biegelsen and Luis Santiago, at Broward College in Davie, Fla., want to teach math. 

In the last two years, two Republican governors — Rick Perry in Texas and Rick Scott in Florida — have challenged their states’ public colleges to develop bachelor’s degrees costing no more than $10,000, less than a third of the average sticker price for tuition and fees at a four-year public college. Governor Perry said he hoped 10 percent of the state’s degrees would meet that goal with online learning and new efficiencies. Governor Scott sought low-cost degrees in high-demand fields. 




Democrats were critical of both announcements, calling the idea a gimmick that would lead to a watered down “Walmartization” of higher education. Meanwhile, in California, a Republican legislator has called for a pilot program there. 




Now the $10,000 degrees are available in Florida and Texas — but not for many students, not for many majors and not on the flagship campuses. The original goal was that the degrees would use new teaching techniques and technologies to bring down costs; so far, many of the programs are unchanged. 




In Florida, the two dozen former community colleges that offer both associate and baccalaureate degrees all volunteered to meet the $10,000 challenge, but several programs are not yet under way. The state universities are not in the program. 




Broward College, which has 67,000 students, is offering the low-cost baccalaureate in its four smallest bachelor’s programs — middle-school math education, middle-school science education, information technology, and global trade and logistics — and seeking a total of 80 students. Even that may be a stretch. 




To qualify, students mus...

title: Poverty proposal
summary: January 2008 proposal exploring poverty alleviation initiatives in Eastern Prince Edward Island. Don's research identified multiple intervention opportunities: expanding Breakfast for Learning program (serving 5,500 students at $0.85/day), enhancing school poverty funds for clothing and field trip assistance, supporting isolated high school students living independently, and addressing gaps in Christmas basket distribution systems. Proposes three management approaches: direct grants to existing programs, call for proposals, or community committee implementation. Demonstrates Don's fieldwork approach to needs assessment and his interest in identifying gaps between existing services and vulnerable populations.
content_preview:
January 9, 2008	




COMMUNIITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND




Possible Project in Eastern Prince Edward Island










Background:




An anonymous donor has indicated an interest in a project in Eastern PEI for the purpose, loosely defined, as the alleviation of poverty.  In gathering information, I spoke directly with a number of people including teachers, the Breakfast for Learning Coordinator, a former Board member in Souris and several people in the field of social services.  There are many needs and many worthwhile options; the specific initiative depends upon the interests of the donor.  One can simply fund an upgrade or extension of work already being done or reach out to folk not now being served.  Multi-year funding is recommended especially if the reject is a new initiative..  




Ideas/options




My enquiries resulted in the following areas of need:




Breakfast for Learning, a national program operated locally by volunteers provides breakfast to about 5500 Islander students at an average cost of 85 cents per student per day; breakfasts usually includes a muffin, toast or bagel along with milk and a piece of fruit or vegetable..  Organizers would like to increase the number of times that fruit and carrots  can be included.  Some schools offer a mid-morning snack instead at an average cost of 55 cents per student per day.  While intended for those who need, in effect, it is open to any student at any grade level.  Most schools offer the service 5 days a week although a few offer it for  two or three days each week only.  A few schools offer a mid-morning snack instead.  

Core funding is available from the national organization and is supplemented by local donations of groceries and money.  The program has a half-time paid Provincial coordinator but the project does not receive any Provincial funding (although the Government has indicated an interest in this area).  




Additional funding would allow the program to be offered in additional ...

title: Press release-4
summary: Final press release dated April 3, 2014, announcing "Education award sparks interest." Updates timeline: nominations close April 26 (extended from earlier March 29 date); award late May. Reinforces core philosophy that engagement and student performance correlate. Lists five engagement dimensions. Describes engagement manifestations: Future Local Forums, Junior Achievement, translation services, cross-cultural events, technology use, and community-school collaboration. Notes schools can demonstrate engagement through single classes or multi-class/multi-age initiatives reflecting community interests and skills. Award made possible by Island family generosity. Directs to www.education2020.ca for details. Contact: Don Glendenning, 892-5859. Demonstrates sustained promotion of award as April deadline approached.
content_preview:
Press release

April 3, 2014

Education award sparks interest

 

Sometime in late May an Island school or learning centre will receive a cheque for $2,500, and the money can be spent for whatever the school decides; the award is given because engagement and student performance go hand in hand.   Education 20/20 has identified five kinds of engagement, student to student, student to teacher, student to learning material, student to community, and parent involvement; and there are likely others.  Anyone may nominate; nominations close on April 26 with the award being made in late May.




Engagement comes in many forms like the Future Local Forms for Grade 9 French students, the Junior Achievement in Kinkora; providing translation service for newcomers, communication between home and school, cross cultural events and the use of technology. 




Schools may demonstrate engagement in a number of ways, in a activities of a single class, students and teachers  in different classes and ages working together; students undertaking projects out in the community or members of the community working with students and teachers working together in a school; the range of activities reflects the interests and skills in the community.  




This award is made possible through the generosity of an Island family who also believes in the value of engagement.  Further information and nomination forms are available at www.education2020.ca. But act soon.  Nominations close on April 26 and the school or learning centre could have a $2,500 cheque by June 1.  




Contact:	Education 20/20 Inc.

Don Glendenning

		Res: 892-5859

title: Principal
summary: Occasional paper examining OECD PISA research establishing direct link between school autonomy and student performance. Notes that schools with greater autonomy over curricula and assessment show better results, particularly when combined with accountability for publicly posted achievement data. Details autonomy dimensions: resource allocation, teacher hiring/dismissal, budgeting, curriculum decisions, course offerings, and textbooks. Provides examples of schools using autonomy creatively (eliminating principal position, converting teacher positions to teaching assistants, alternative grouping approaches). Recommends autonomy extend to all learner-related decisions at teacher and school levels. Includes full text of PEI Schools Act defining principal responsibilities, highlighting tension between prescribed duties and teacher autonomy. Demonstrates Glendenning's evidence-based approach to educational reform grounded in international research.
content_preview:
About
Education


School
autonomy					



Occasional
paper No. 01							          June 19, 2014


	


	
	
School
	Autonomy	
	



	
	
An OECD report,
	Pisa in Focus, shows a direct link between PISA test results and
	school autonomy;   Citation 
	
	



	
	
Simply stated,
	there is a direct relationship between school performance and school
	autonomy.  In the words of the OECD Report:
	
		


		“In countries where schools have
		greater autonomy over what is taught and how students 
		
	
	

	are assessed, students tend to perform better. 
	
	
		


		In countries where schools account
		for their results by posting achievement data publicly, schools
		that enjoy greater autonomy in resource allocation tend to show
		better student performance than those with less autonomy. 
		
		


		In countries where there are no
		such accountability arrangements, schools with greater autonomy in
		resource allocation tend to perform worse.” 
		
	
	



	
	
Autonomy, or
	freedom to act, varies from country to country but may include such
	things as allocation of  resources, hiring and dismissing teachers,

title: Principles o education
summary: Don's comprehensive statement of educational principles emphasizing student self-evaluation, performance-based assessment, credit for prior learning, lifelong learning, shared responsibility with family and community, and individualized learning. Foundational philosophy document reflecting his educational reform vision.

About

Education

PRINCIPLES OF EDUCATION

About 4-11-Principles




PRINCIPLE: 	a statement of policy by which individual cases and decisions are judged in a consistent and critical manner.




  
Students will evaluate their own performance prior teacher confirmation
  
Ratings are based  on performance
  
Credit will be given for previously acquired kills
  
Assessment criteria shall reflect community criteria
  
Students are responsible for their own progress but teachers are accountable
  
Competencies taught will reflect competencies practiced in the relevant community
  
Programs will encourage lifelong learning
  
Learning activities centre on the development of each child
  
Respects the value of each individual
  
Education is a shared responsibility – school, family and community

2.	Students are responsible for their own progress

8.	Evaluation should be as realistic and meaningful as possible in keeping with evaluation in the work environment

9.	We should maximize student  staff interaction

10.	Students should be able to enter and exit from a program at any time

11.	Advanced credit should be given for proven performance

12.	Students should be able to continue their learning program in a systematic way even after leaving the college
