title: Principles of Adult Learning
summary: Canadian Literacy and Learning Network document outlining seven principles differentiating adult learning from child learning: adults must want to learn; learn only what they perceive as immediately relevant; learn by doing; focus on problems not sequential skills; bring prior experience; prefer informal settings; and want guidance rather than direction. Emphasizes adult learners' practical orientation, problem-centered approach, and desire for agency in learning decisions. Document positions itself as guide for educators working with adults in literacy and continuing education contexts.
content_preview:
Principles of Adult Learning 

Seven Principles of Adult Learning

These principles show the differences between how children and adults learn. Are you using adult teaching principles in your teaching?

  
Adults must want to learn They learn effectively only when they have a strong inner motivation to develop a new skill or acquire a particular type of knowledge.



Helping their children is a strong motivator for learners who are parents.

Getting a high school diploma or a good job is another strong motivator for adults.
  
Adults will learn only what they feel they need to learn Adults are practical in their approach to learning; they want to know, “How is this going to help me right now?”



Be practical, be direct.
  
Adults learn by doing Children learn by doing, but active participation is more important among adults.



Adults need to be able to use these skills immediately so that they see their relevance.
  
Adult learning focuses on problems and the problems must be realistic Children learn skills sequentially. Adults start with a problem and then work to find a solution.



Begin by identifying what the learner can do, what the learner wants to do and then address the gaps and develop practical activities to teach specific skills.
  
Experience affects adult learning Adults have more experience than children.  This can be an asset and a liability.



Use the learners’ experience (negative or positive) to build a positive future by making sure that negative experiences are not part of their experience in your program.
  
Adults learn best in an informal situation Children have to follow a curriculum.  Often, adults learn only what they feel they need to know.



Involve adults in the learning process. Let them discuss issues and decide on possible solutions. Make the environment relaxed, informal and inviting.
  
Adults want guidance Adults want information that will help them improve their situation or that of their children. They do not want to be told...

title: Pro-1 Math  employment-1
summary: This proposal outlines a plan to develop a "ready-reference map of math competencies needed by Islanders for entry into employment." Don argues that mathematics instruction is fragmented across PEI providers, and proposes a DACUM-style analysis to identify entry-level math competencies. The deliverables include a math map, rating scale, employment profile, and learning guides. This reflects Don's expertise in education systems analysis and his commitment to practical, competency-based learning approaches developed during his Holland College presidency.

For

Artist’s rendering of the

Orwell
corner Historic Village has been designated by the Province for its
major display of agricultural equipment and a new display and visitor
centre was constructed at that site in 200xx.  Some Island-made
agricultural equipment is included in the display, however, the
Museum has other Island made artifacts not on display and is aware of
many others either in the hands of private collectors or disappearing
from their current resting places – forests, hedgerows and rapidly
deteriorating barns.






The
Prince Edward Island Museum and Heritage Foundation continues to add
to its collection and, if space could be found, would mount a
permanent display of Island –made equipment in a prominent location
on the museum grounds.  The search for both additional Island-made
equipment and additional space has been facilitated by the Community
Foundation of Prince Edward Island.






More

	Designate an existing barn

	made farm equipment.  The barn is ideally located being the first

	starts a tour of the grounds.
	


	The barn is a typical small
	pitched-roof barn measuring 26 by 36 feet with both roof and walls
	clad in eastern cedar shingles.  In addition to fixing up the barn,
	the PEI Museum and Heritage foundation proposes to double the
	footprint by adding a shed measuring 18 x 26 feet at each end thus
	providing 1872 sq feet of ground level space.  A small amount of
	storage space will be available on the second floor of the original
	building.

	include new sills, new framing as required, cedar shingles on roof...

title: Proposal 3
summary: This proposal iteration refines the project goal and expands the objectives to six components: inventory development, needs assessment, gap identification, organizational capacity evaluation, strategy determination, and monitoring framework development. The methodology includes establishing a steering committee, environmental scanning of rural continuing education practices, and comprehensive stakeholder engagement across educators, employers, government, and community organizations. Deliverables include data collection instruments, materials, collected data, and a final project report, with a four-month implementation timeline. The document demonstrates evolving project scope and increasing sophistication.

development in Souris, PEI







Souris

Souris
is a year-round port in Eastern PEI with a population of 1,053
(Statistics Canada, 2016 Census), a decline of 10% from the 2011
Census. Compared to PEI as a whole, Souris has a smaller proportion
of residents under age 15 (13.8% vs. 15.9%) and age 15 to 64 (57.6%
vs. 64.7%) and a higher proportion of residents age 65 and older
(28.6% vs. 19.4%). Souris also had a much lower median total
household income ($42,368) compared to PEI as a whole ($61,163).
Wealth generating activities are focused around tourism, farming,
marine services, fishing and related food processing, and the normal
trades and services of any small community. Compared to the PEI
population generally, Souris had a higher percentage of residents
with high school education only and a higher percentage without any
postsecondary educational certification as of the 2011 Census. Note:
The education, labour, and mobility data from the 2016 Census will be
available on November 29, 2017.

title: Proposal  submitted draft
summary: This refined proposal draft establishes clear objectives for assessing continuing education and workforce development needs in Souris. It identifies gaps in local training provision and lack of comprehensive coordination between educational providers. The document articulates four main objectives: developing an inventory of continuing education assets, assessing adult education needs and interests, identifying capacity gaps, and determining optimal service delivery strategies. The proposed approach involves a steering committee, documentation review, key informant interviews with educators and employers, youth surveys, and data analysis leading to actionable recommendations.

title: Publications - professional
summary: Comprehensive bibliography of Don Glendenning's publications spanning 1966-2003, demonstrating a distinguished career in education, vocational training, and workforce development. Major works include "A Review of Federal Support for Technical and Vocational Education in Canada" (1991), DACUM methodology works (1997-1998), competency-based education materials for Mexico (1996), "Up To Standard" (2000), and "A Brief History of Presbyterians in Black River" (2003). Publications demonstrate expertise in vocational education, manpower development, secondary education policy, and educational systems. His output includes journal articles in Canadian Superintendent and other professional publications, conference papers, and books. The list reflects Don's influence across Canadian vocational and secondary education policy during the latter twentieth century.

title: Purdy Painting
summary: Draft letter from Norman Carruthers to Henry Purdy thanking him for donating an oil painting 'Gulls and Spring Ice' to the Community Foundation of PEI office. Reflects Don's involvement with the Foundation and his community leadership in supporting the arts.
content_preview:
Draft




Henry Purdy




Dear Henry:




This is a follow up to your conversation with Don Glendenning and your intention to gift an oil painting, Gulls and Spring Ice,  to the Foundation.  Needless to say, we are delighted.




As you may know, the office has been refurbished and upgraded, the Board table is back and Board and committee meetings are held in our own space – and your painting will continue to be prominently displayed.




On behalf of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward island, Henry, I want to thank you for your support over the years as a Director, donor and friend.




Thank you again for this gift




Warmest personal regards




Norman Carruthers

President

title: Ray Stiles
summary: Personal letter from Don recounting his 1955-56 study year at the Institute of Education, University of London on a Lord Beaverbrook Scholarship and his friendship with Ray Stiles, whom he shared accommodation with. Reflects Don's international education background and personal relationships from his formative professional years.
content_preview:
Dear Dominic:




Again, thanks for your note about your mother’s health and father’s death. Carol and I send our prayers and our sympathy.  It must have been a difficult year for your family; these times are never easy but I am sure that there are many happy memories from earlier times. 




The “golden years” are not always golden, and the past year for your family was a roller coaster year indeed.  When Christmas passed without the usual note, it raised concern so your note was not a complete surprise.  




In 1955-56, I studied at the Institute of Education, University of London, on a Lord Beaverbrook Scholarship and lived nearby just off Russell Square at, I believe, College Rooms, Woburn Square(?).  It was a fairly small residence and housed students from the UK and other Commonwealth countries.  I shared a room on the second floor with Ray Kilfoil, another Canadian, and your father shared an adjacent room with, I believe, Les Ingham from New Zealand (although I am not absolutely sure of the latter).  




Although your father and I did not take any classes together, because our rooms were beside each other, we met frequently when entering and leaving our rooms and usually shared a table at breakfast which was provided in a basement kitchen.  I also remember many cups of afternoon or evening tea and conversation.




Your Dad and I seemed to “hit it off” and found ourselves lingering in conversation, exploring the city together, and occasionally going to the theatre and sometimes to church.  That was before Ray and Molly were married and I know that Ray went home some weekends, (Would that be to Watford?).




In the spring or early summer of 1956, Ray suggested an outing to Hythe in the Dover area.  We spent a couple of nights and lucked out weatherwise.  The seafront there was beautiful and I remember exploring the area and walking along the bluff overlooking the English Channel.




While I do not remember your Dad’s exact age, I believe that he was slight...

title: Re-engineering
summary: Major policy proposal by Don advocating comprehensive education system re-engineering, replacing time-based schooling with student-centered learning via education advisors and competency-based certification. Demonstrates his innovative education reform philosophy and structural thinking about institutional transformation.
content_preview:
Re-engineering Education




Our education system is quite outdated; it emphasizes schooling rather than education, is inflexible,

accountability is scattered, there is too much emphasis on time spent in a class or on a subject,

allows little choice by learners and lacks clear and consistent standards.




Tinkering with the system won't do. We need to do more than strike a new committee, undertake a

new public survey, add or change courses, increase teacher pay, revise the curriculum, add more

professional development days or purchase a few new computers. The system could profit from

some re-engineering. But where do we start? The following structural changes would be high on

my list.




Provide each student with an "education advisor", a person with a role similar to that of a family

doctor, with whom the learner or parent could consult at any time on matters pertaining to the

education of their child. Most of us would not be very happy if we had a new family doctor each

year, especially if the new doctor was not of our choosing. An education advisor would, for the

most part, provide advice and direction during at least K through 12, however, it could be longer if

needed. Students could elect to change advisors but advisors would have no choice in selecting

students; advisors could refuse to take a student only if they were not accepting additional students.

The educational advisor would provide an access point to the education system, provide continuity

for each learner; the advisor would work closely with each learner providing advice, instruction and

referral to specialist teachers as needed. Student transcripts would be signed off by the educational

advisor.




Our current system of awarding degrees, diplomas and certificates interferes with getting an

education. Teaching and certifying are very different functions; they serve different purposes.

Pursuing an education is more than, perhaps even entirely different from, pursuing a diploma or...

title: Reading clinics
summary: An outline document addressing reading instruction as Don's lifelong concern (60 years of observation since first teaching). Don emphasizes reading as essential, learnable, and solvable through known approaches, requiring outside-the-box thinking. He identifies key elements: diagnosis, prescription, instruction, supervised practice, and unsupervised practice. Don advocates for reading as a separate educational subject and specialty, operated like dental or eye clinics with reading specialists and clinicians. The document notes reading instruction should operate within or outside the system, formatted as brief bullet points and topic headers suggesting work-in-progress thinking about reading clinic implementation and organization.
content_preview:
READING

Over my lifetime, including my recent discussions, no subject comes up more often than the subject of reading and especially the level of reading demonstrated by our graduates.  It has been a concern for years, I recall even during my first year of teaching, discussions with experienced teachers about approaches to teaching the subject.  Some 60 years later, it still sparks controversy.  Given the above, I believe it is worthy of at least one letter to the editor.

Let me hasten to add that reading is not a specialty of mine but I believe it to be an essential skill, that most people can learn to read at a reasonable level, and that we know how to solve the problem.  In so doing, we may have to think outside the box.




I know that there are other important skills but want to stick with reading not literacy

Should be an educational specialty and separate subject in school

Diagnosis, prescription, instruction, supervised practice, unsupervised practice

Cries out for change

Reading clinics – inside or outside the system

Set up like a dental clinic or an eye clinic: reading specialist, testing/assessmentreading clinicians,

title: Recognition
summary: Proposal by Don titled 'Education First: Celebrating success in Public Engagement' addressing family involvement in schools and implementation of National PTA standards for family-school partnerships. Reflects his commitment to community engagement in education and student achievement.
content_preview:
Proposal 2

April 24, 2012

EDUCATION FIRST




Celebrating success in Public Engagement




Objective:	to encourage and support public engagement in education at the school level




Background:




Research has repeatedly found that students do better in school when their families are engaged in the life of the school. Programs that involve parents in student achievement, such as family nights on math or literacy and family workshops on planning for college, are thought to be especially helpful.

Mantua Elementary School, with about 900 students from pre-kindergarten through sixth grade, was cited by the National PTA for its human relations committee, which provides translators for publications that keep families informed about the school, as well as for a mentorship program, service projects for the elderly and needy families, and extracurricular activities for students. Based on the National Standards for Family-School Partnerships of the Parent teachers Association in the USA:




The awards recognize schools  that have implemented the organization’s national standards for family-school partnerships.










Standard 1: 	Welcoming all families into the school community—Families are active participants in the life of the school, and feel welcomed, valued, and connected to each other, to school staff, and to what students are learning and doing in class.

Standard 2: 	Communicating effectively—Families and school staff engage in regular, two-way, meaningful communication about student learning.

Standard 3: 	Supporting student success—Families and school staff continuously collaborate to support students’ learning and healthy development both at home and at school, and have regular opportunities to strengthen their knowledge and skills to do so effectively.

Standard 4: 	Speaking up for every child—Families are empowered to be advocates for their own and other children, to ensure that students are treated fairly and have access to learning opportunities that wi...

title: Report on Mid Term Review (1)
summary: A June 2005 status report on the IAHSP mid-term review commissioned by Don in January. The report documents the review process: Don's January proposal, Board discussion (February postponed decision), April decision to conduct self-evaluation, and May 12 Board meeting devoted exclusively to review. Document includes framework for assessing administration, planning, PR/promotion, fundraising, technical assistance, and selection process. Notes that client survey would occur in September and October 1 review completion date was planned. Shows program governance and Don's strong advocacy for accountability mechanisms.
content_preview:
ISLAND ARTS AND HERITAGE STABILIZATION PROJECT




Status of Mid Term Review

June 9, 2005




Program Background

The Community Foundation of P.E.I. (incorporated in 1993) brought the Island Arts & Heritage Stabilization Program into being following four years of research and development. Executive Director (Katy Baker) began in September of 2003 and the process for the assessment and selection of participants was established. Six organizations were identified in the fall of 2004 and more will be finalized via the Outreach portion in June 2005. The sole purpose of the Program is to build stronger and more viable organizations for long term success in the non-profit arts and heritage community of PEI.  




Background to Mid-term Review




In January of 2005 Don Glendenning, Board Member of the IAHSP, raised the matter of a Mid-Term Review of the project. A preliminary contact was made with a number of individuals and organizations, through a series of email and direct conversations, in order to flesh out the idea and explore any interest in undertaking such a review.  .  




The matter of a ‘Mid Term Review’ was discussed at a Board meeting on February 25, 2005.  Minutes of the meeting state:




“The Mid-term report was considered a good step although premature at this date – maybe in a few months from now when organizations have had more work done while in the program, possibly in May”.




The matter was discussed again at a Board meeting on April 21, 2005 and the minutes record the discussion as follows:  




“Don talked about the mid-term report – after discussion on its needs and merits it was conclude such a review be a function of the Board in the manner of a self evaluation. Such a review would take place in a Board meeting designated exclusively for that topic. It was scheduled for May, 12, 9:00 am West Royalty.  Points to be discussed: the process, in general, of the Program; what other programs did to ‘self-evaluate’; the CH Stabilization Experience ...

title: Resume 1 2013@2016-01-19T19;06;49
summary: Curriculum vitae detailing Don Glendenning's professional background, including his early teaching career in New Brunswick, federal government positions, and founding presidency of Holland College.
content_preview:
ABOUT THE AUTHOR




Donald Glendenning was born in Little Branch and attended the Little Branch School.  He is a graduate of the Miramichi Rural High School, Teachers' College and the New Brunswick Institute of Technology (now the New Brunswick Community College) and studied at the University of London (England) on a Lord Beaverbrook Overseas Scholarship.  He holds a B.Sc. and MSc. from Bradley University and a Ph.D. from Indiana University.  He taught for a numer of years in  New Brunswick at the elementary, secondary and postsecondary levels.  Dr. Glendenning worked as a training specialist in Ottawa for a number of years with the Department of Labour and the Department of Manpower and Immigration.




In 1969 Dr. Glendenning moved to Prince Edward Island to become the first President of Holland College, a college of applied arts and technology.  In this capacity, he played a leadership role in the founding of the College and in implementing competency based education.  The College acquired an international reputation for its innovative approach.




In 1987 Dr. Glendenning retired from Holland College and operated a consulting firm with projects both in Canada and overseas.  He is an active volunteer with the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, is an amateur genealogist and enjoys genealogy and enjoys gardening, reading and puttering around.  He edits and publishes The Family Chronicle ( HYPERLINK "http://www.glendenning.net/don" www.glendenning.net/don) and the Community Foundation News aaaaaaaaaaa9www.cfpei.ca).  Dr. Glendenning is the recipient of a number of awards and honours including the Order of Canada, Atlantic Canada Innovator of the Year Award Finalist and holds an honourary degree from the University of Prince Edward Island.  




Publications include:




Glendenning, Donald, Thomas Hall and Bruce Clarke, A Review of Federal

Support for Technical and Vocational Education in Canada, Charlottetown: Information House, 1991

title: Rodd, Mark
summary: Solicitation to Mark Rodd (President of Rodd Hotels and Resorts) for the Math on PEI numeracy skills analysis. Follows standard June 2019 campaign template requesting $1-2,000 donations.
content_preview:
Mark
Rodd, President

Rodd

149
Kent St

Charlottetown
, PE


10,
2019F

Dear:

Math
on PEI






Although
PEI math scores on National and international tests have risen,
friends tell me that math has not improved on the shop floor; I’ve
been wondering why.






Islanders
need math; citizens may not need a high level but they need to be
able to measure, sort, calculate, group and estimate numbers, space,
time, distance, etc.  and they need to do it quickly, easily,
accurately; and consistently.  This approach to math is called
numeracy and it involves the application of math to every-day lives.
Numeracy is being adopted elsewhere; usually in addition to
traditional math.  







But
we need more, to begin with we need an analysis of math skills used
by Islanders. Making an analysis involves bringing together a small
group for a two- day of brainstorming session.   It’s a proven
technique, we used it regularly at Holland College but apparently
there is no one on PEI now with the expertise.  The cost of
undertaking the analyses is $15,000.  







I
am approaching a few people who might contribute $1-2,000 each to
help cover the cost. The Community Foundation, 121 Queen Street,
Charlottetown, PE, C1A 4B3 will accept donations on our behalf and
issue charitable receipts. 







I
appreciate your consideration and would be happy to explain further
and answer any questions.  Thanks in advance











Sincerely,











Don
Glendenning

title: Rotary Proposal - Draft 1 (1)
summary: 2010 proposal to Rotary Club of Charlottetown Royalty for three-year initiative establishing Community Funds in ten PEI communities (2010-2012). Outlines goals of providing community-owned vehicles for perpetual local charitable support, detailed activities, timelines, budgets ($11,200/year admin, matching fund options), and evaluation framework. Shows Don's strategic vision for decentralized, sustainable community philanthropy.
content_preview:
Rotary Proposal - Draft 1

'Building Island Communities'

1. 	Background and Assumptions 

The Community Foundation of PEI is committed to improving the quality of life in Prince Edward Island – in all its communities. Based on our activities to date, we  believes that there are many Islanders living (or have lived) in communities all across the Island who have the capacity and are interested in leaving  a legacy to their community to support a worthy cause or service. However, there is often not a broad-based 'community-owned' method or vehicle available to them to achieve their desire to do this. While it is acknowledged that there are opportunities to make donations or leave legacies to things like the regional hospital, these institutions are not really community-owned anymore as they are managed and funded by the government for the most part.   and the remaining local charitable organizations do not have or are not perceived to have  the capacity to handle endowments in perpetuity.




Over the past year, the Foundation has begun to develop a new approach to assisting Island communities through a fund called the Community Fund. The Community Fund is intended to provide a formal mechanism for Islanders to contribute to the well being of their community through a financial donation or a legacy fund. Having such a fund allows the community to support local services and initiatives (e.g. the high school band, local artists, health support services, etc).




Our Foundation has already helped the Eastern Kings area set up such a fund, and has begun similar discussions with interested parties in both the Charlottetown and Summerside areas. The Foundation has a vision of establishing a Community Fund in all areas across the Island. 




(insert a brief description of how the Eastern Kings/Souris Fund works - how it has already helped certain local causes - perhaps attach the Eastern Kings Fund 'handout' as part of appendix)

Direct quotation from the back cover of the book:




“Recent decades have shown the public’s support for government plummet alongside political leaders’ credibility.  This downward spiral calls for an exploration of what has gone wrong. The questions, “What is government good at”? and “What is government not good at?” are crucial one’s – and their answers should be the basis for good public policy and public administration.




In What government is good at? Donald Savoie argues that politiciens and public servants are good at generating and avoiding blame, playing to a segment of the population to win the next election, embracing and defending the status quo, adding management layers and staff, keeping ministers out of trouble, responding to demands from the prime minister and his office, send managing a complex, prime ministered-centered organization.  Conversely, they are not as good at defining the broader public interest, providing and recognizing evidence-based policy advice, managing human  and financial resources with efficiency and frugality, innovating and reforming itself, being accountable to Parliament and to citizens, dealing with non-performers, paying sufficient attention to service delivery, and implementing and evaluating the impact of policies and programs.




With wide implications for representative democracy, What is government good at? Is a persuasive analysis of an approach to government that has opened the door to those with resources to influence policy and decision- making while leaving average citizens outside looking in.”

title: Scale, DACUM
summary: DACUM (Develop A Curriculum) rating scale with performance levels from 0-6, emphasizing competency-based assessment aligned with workplace participation. Level 6 represents exceptional performance with initiative and leadership capability; descending levels show declining ability to work independently; Level 0 indicates inability to perform satisfactorily in work environments. This framework bridges education and employment, focusing on practical skill demonstration. DACUM methodology originated in vocational and technical education, aligning curriculum development with actual job requirements. The resource reflects Don Glendenning's interest in connecting educational outcomes to practical workforce needs and community employment.

title: Scale, Holistic
summary: Academic rating scale emphasizing holistic assessment of learner understanding from Levels 0-5. Level 5 indicates complete understanding with all task requirements met; Level 4 shows considerable understanding; Level 3 demonstrates partial understanding with most requirements included; Levels 2-1 represent diminishing levels of comprehension; Level 0 indicates no response or task not attempted. This holistic approach evaluates overall grasp of material rather than component-by-component analysis, reflecting progressive educational assessment philosophy. The scale acknowledges partial progress and incomplete attempts, supporting constructivist learning frameworks that value student effort and development trajectories.

title: Scale, math map-1 with notes
summary: Detailed working document from educational workshop on mathematics rating scales with extensive notes and collaborative refinement. Records discussion focused on assessing skill level rather than importance, identifying criteria: accuracy, speed, degree of assistance, plus emerging criteria like fluency, creativity, and strategy. Documents discussion of "math facts" concept as critical to addressing community concerns about mathematical competency. Proposes dropping zero level and includes substantial definitional framework (assessment, benchmark, criteria, evaluation, quality, rating, standard). Reflects iterative curriculum development process with multiple stakeholders, showing how Glendenning and colleagues engaged practitioners in creating assessment tools. Draft dated with working notes suggesting ongoing refinement.

title: Scale, Mathematics
summary: Specialized rating scale for mathematics education focusing on six higher-order cognitive dimensions: Evaluation (verify answers and select optimal results), Communication (represent information symbolically/graphically), Synthesis (generalize patterns to principles), Analysis (interpret mathematical models), Application (use multiple solution methods), and Criteria (apply mathematical reasoning). This framework elevates mathematics instruction beyond computation to encompass deeper conceptual understanding, verification skills, and problem-solving strategies. Drawing from Colorado higher education standards, it reflects sophisticated approaches to mathematics pedagogy emphasizing reasoning, communication, and metacognition central to 21st-century mathematics education.

title: scan0001
summary: A brief document on occupational standards focusing on the distinction between what someone can do versus how well they do it. Drawing on his federal labor department experience, Don notes that standards discussions historically focused on training inputs rather than performance outputs. He argues existing standards emphasize range of tasks but neglect performance levels, illustrated by the difference between apprentice and journeyperson performance on the same skill. Don advocates for identifying broad performance criteria (quality, speed, supervision required) and establishing employment-based levels that are recognized by practitioners, clearly stated, readily understood, and easily applied. He contends the challenge remains unmet of creating standards that balance comprehensiveness with practical applicability.

title: Schooling
summary: This document provides comprehensive analysis of schooling system weaknesses in PEI. It defines schooling as education occurring in schools under teacher direction, discusses components and state control characteristics (monopolies, limited participation, minimal choice). Lists system weaknesses (outdated delivery, inadequate accountability, silos between providers), service gaps (early childhood, specialist access), and identifies opportunities for external interventions including grants for innovation, teacher preparation, public information campaigns, and establishing a "Better Education Fund" for systemic improvement.

title: Schools-Full service
summary: This is Don's reflection on full-service schools, proposing that PEI communities could designate a local high school as an education centre with a Director of Educational Services, extending the school's offerings to serve community members beyond students. Don sees this model (operational in Quebec and the USA) as a solution for bringing comprehensive educational support to rural PEI communities like Souris and Wellington.
content_preview:
Ref/sch

Toronto

Schools, full Service 




Some time ago, I came across an article about a “full-service school” in or near Toronto; I hadn’t heard the term before.  In effect, they broadened the scope of an existing school and changed it into an education centre.  In addition to the usual public school services, the school day and year was extended and educational services for parents and other community members were added.




Full service schools may be a way to fill some of the education gaps at the community level in PEI. Take any community, Souris, Belfast or Wellington, for example, and it appears that the Premier is the only person with a responsibility to see that people in those communities receive the education services they need. Obviously, schools are there for young people but help for other community members is uncertain.




It would be easy to designate a local school, likely a high school, as a full-service education centre and appoint the principal as Director of Educational services.  Give a Director a bit of autonomy and accountability and, in one simple move, we provide a community with a person to work on their behalf.  While I have not researched the idea, a form of community based education centres appears to be in operation in Quebec, maybe in other Provinces, and certainly in the USA.




I’ve had a number of discussions about education with folks in the Souris area recently; when doing so, I ask where people get the information they need to make sound educational decisions. Although the people I talked with know where to get help in meeting their educational needs, I’m not convinced that Souris residents generally know where to turn. A full-service school may be the answer.

Dear:

Math
on PEI






Although
PEI math scores on National and international tests have risen,
friends tell me that math has not improved on the shop floor; I’ve
been wondering why.






Islanders
need math; citizens may not need a high level but they need to be
able to measure, sort, calculate, group and estimate numbers, space,
time, distance, etc.  and they need to do it quickly, easily,
accurately; and consistently.  This approach to math is called
numeracy and it involves the application of math to every-day lives.
Numeracy is being adopted elsewhere; usually in addition to
traditional math.  







But
we need more, to begin with we need an analysis of math skills used
by Islanders. Making an analysis involves bringing together a small
group for a two- day of brainstorming session.   It’s a proven

title: Schurman Trust MacCallum Letter
summary: Don Glendenning provides detailed legal commentary on a 1973 trust agreement for the Minor Hockey Council of Prince Edward Island and reviews proposed transfer to the Community Foundation. His analysis addresses compliance, permissibility, and recommendations for improving clarity in the new agreement.
content_preview:
12/06



Hi John,



Further to our exchange of messages yesterday, I confirm that I have

reviewed the original trust agreement which established the trust in

1973 ("the 1973 agreement"), and I have reviewed the draft document you

provided, which it proposed to transfer the entire trust to the

Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island.  You have requested that I

review and comment on same on your behalf alone as a trustee to this

trust fund.  My comments are as follows:



1.  It is permissible for the trustees to transfer the trust funds in

the manner proposed as section 4 of the 1973 agreement states, in part:



" ... the Trustees may in their absolute discretion, provided that all

Trustess agree, and with the consent of the

Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council, at any time or times, pay to or for the

use or benefit of the Minor Hockey Council of Prince Edward Island the

entire capital or such part or parts of the capital of the trust funds

as they deem advisable provided that such funds are used by the Minor

Hockey Council of Prince Edward Island for the purposes set out in

section 3 hereof......" 



Section 3 of the 1973 agreement states the purpose the said trust funds

are to be used for:



" ... and shall pay the net income derived therefrom to the Minor

Hockey Council of Prince Edward Island to be used by the Council in its

discretion for improvement of the Minor Hockey Program on Prince Edward

Island covering all classifications up to and inlcuding juvenile

classification and provided such expenditures are within the aims and

objectives of the Prince Edward Island Minor Hockey Council."



Accordingly, the transfer is appropriate if the purpose is complied

with and continued.  This should thus be clear in the new agreement, and

isn't really (see proposed section 3). I would suggest adding some type

of preamble, or declaratory provision added (perhaps add on to proposed

section 3?) to the new agreement confirming that the trustees are ...

title: Shillabeer
summary: Letter from Don Glendenning to Audrey Shillabeer supporting the Belfast Historical Society's summer lecture series. He endorses the initiative as valuable for summer visitors and island cultural connection, offering to participate.
content_preview:
Ms. Audrey Shillabeer, Secretary, 

Belfast Historical Society




Dear Ms. Shillabeer:




I am delighted to learn of your plans to offer a series of lectures for summer visitors.




I am aware of you custom of having guest speakers at your meetings and am impressed with the range and nature of the work of your Society over the years; the rich history of the Belfast area in the life of our Province, makes it  a further attraction and a natural setting for such a series.  I am pleased to note also that you plan to offer the lectures over an extended summer period.




Our summer visitors want more than simply  a warm summer holiday filled with fun; they want to know about their summer home,  its history, its traditions and its people.  The summer lecture series will not only help make that happen, it will also expand their linkages with other visitors and Islanders alike.

.

It is a great project; I commend you for the initiative, and look forward to participating in at least some of the events.




Let us know if we can help

Sincerely




Don Glendenning

title: Sitting by Nellie
summary: This deeply personal essay reveals Don's own educational formation through apprenticeship-style learning on his family's mixed farm along the Miramichi in New Brunswick. He connects his childhood experience of "sitting by Nellie" (a historical term from English cotton mills for learning through observation) with contemporary work-placement programs. While acknowledging the limitation of absorption-based learning lacking pedagogical intentionality, he expresses gratitude for those who mentored him and reflects on how work placements attempt to capture experiential learning's benefits. This piece provides crucial biographical context about Don's formative years.
content_preview:
Sitting by Nellie

Altered

Although we never used the term, it’s probably accurate to say that much of my early education was gained from “sitting by Nellie”.  No. I’m not talking about a classmate but rather about growing up on a mixed farm on the banks of the Miramichi in New Brunswick and absorbing farm skills, and others, by working beside my older brothers. Sitting by Nellie is not a Miramichi term; it actually arises from the days of child labour in the cotton mills in England where one learned by watching “Nellie” as she tended her loom.  The good part of the experience was the absorption of the plant culture; the downside was that Nellie often lacked the competencies that plant owners hoped would be emulated.

Today’s work placements for students, I suggest, are an attempt to capture some of the advantages gained from sitting by Nellie.  Too short mostly to absorb the employment culture, they do inject some reality into a student’s educational experience.  

My thanks to all the “Nellies” who helped me in my education career.

title: Skopeck letter--Rev Smith
summary: Don's October 4, 2012 letter to Lorraine Slopek requesting biographical information on Rev. Smith "who served as Minister at St. John the Evangelist Church in Bay du Vin, New Brunswick between 1937 and 1940." Don describes Smith's recognition of limited secondary education access, his rectory classes, hiring of teachers, and the resulting 1939 provincial approval for MRHS as "the first of a series of rural high schools throughout the Province." Don mentions the scholarship committee's ongoing efforts and requests additional biographical information. The letter exemplifies Don's role as institutional historian and his continued involvement with the scholarship fund decades after his own MRHS graduation.

title: Small Schools
summary: Don Glendenning compiles research on small schools benefits, documenting improved student achievement, attendance, graduation rates, teacher satisfaction, and school safety. Includes evidence that small school students accumulate more credits and are more likely to graduate.

About/

Small Schools

How big is small:

Varies; 500

Free standing schools not schools within schools

Benefits:

  
Raised student achievement 
  
Increased attendance 
  
Elevated teacher satisfaction, 
  
Improved school climate


Research shows that smaller schools:

􀂃 improve student achievement,

􀂃 increase attendance and graduation rates,

􀂃 elevate teacher satisfaction,

􀂃 improve school safety, and

  
􀂃 increase parent and community involvement.


Pros and cons/benefits may include:

  
Smaller schools may be especially important for disadvantaged students by more individualized attention and teachers being able to address different learning styles. 
  
Smaller schools may promote substantially improved achievement and higher grades
  
improved instructional quality and working conditions. 
  
greater job satisfaction for the small school faculty 
  
an environment in which students may be more visible. 
  
Student-teacher relationships improve, allowing teachers to more easily identify individual talents and unique needs of each student, which offers a more personalized educational experience. 
  
eachers are able to interact more with their faculty administrators. 
  
A small school staff size allows more opportunity for teachers to know each other well, more easily share information about their students, collaborate to solve problems, and generally support one another.
  
on a cost per-graduate basis, small schools have been shown to be more efficient. 
  
While small schools alone are not the solution, they can prove to be a useful platform for improved student achievement.
  
Five previous rigorous studies of this program and other small school initiatives have demonstrated significant benefits for students.  
  
Students randomly offered a seat at a small school accumulate 1.4 more credits per year, attend school for 4 more days each year, and are 9% more likely to receive a high school diploma.

Math
on PEI






Although
PEI math scores on National and international tests have risen,
friends tell me that math has not improved on the shop floor; I’ve
been wondering why.






Islanders
need math; citizens may not need a high level but they need to be
able to measure, sort, calculate, group and estimate numbers, space,
time, distance, etc.  and they need to do it quickly, easily,
accurately; and consistently.  This approach to math is called
numeracy and it involves the application of math to every-day lives.
Numeracy is being adopted elsewhere; usually in addition to
traditional math.  







But
we need more, to begin with we need an analysis of math skills used
by Islanders. Making an analysis involves bringing together a small

title: Sonny
summary: Complete lyrics to "Sonny's Dream," a narrative song about a rural boy with aspirations to leave his small farming community. Lyrics tell story of Sonny caught between his mother's need and his own dreams. No clear connection to Don's life, though themes of rural life and dreams resonate with Atlantic Canadian context.
content_preview:
Sonny’s Dream




Sonny lives on a farm, in a wide open space

You can take off your sneakers you can give up the race

You can lay down your head, By a soft river bed,

Sonny always remembers the words his mother said

And she said




Sonny don’t go away, I am here all alone,

Your Daddy’s a sailor who never comes home,

And the nights are so long, and the silence goes on,

And I’m feeling so tired, I’m not all that strong




Sonny carried a load, He is barely a man,

And there isn’t all that to do, Still he does the best he can

And he watches the sea, from a room by the stairs

The waves keep rolling and they’ve done that for years




Chorus




It’s a hundred miles to town, Sonny’s never been there And he goes to the highway, and stands there and stares

The mail comes at four, The mailman is old

He dreams his dreams of silver and gold




Chorus




His dreams are not real, They’re just stories he’s read

He has stars in his eyes and dreams in his head

And he’s hungry inside for the wide world outside

And I can’t hold on to him, though I’ve tried and I’ve tried 

And I’ve tried

title: sort
summary: Don examines the credentialing system in Canada and who should award credentials. He questions whether displayed diplomas and degrees actually indicate competence to serve, noting his experience as an employer revealed transcripts more useful than degrees. Don critiques how institutions award credentials after completing pre-set programs based on criteria that may not reflect occupational standards, limiting student choice and resulting in graduates following similar instruction regardless of individual interests. He contrasts academic credentials with more specific certificates and calls for reconsidering what credentials are needed, who should award them, and on what basis. Don emphasizes that teachers teach while schools sort learners, and this sorting function profoundly impacts future life choices. He questions current approaches to credentialing in addressing employer-valued competencies like communication, mathematics, history/geography knowledge, and work habits.
content_preview:
13 Who should sort? 







Canadians like credentials. Places of work, whether they be trade, technical or professional, often display credentials of people who work there. I am not sure if such displays are intended to impress or intimidate. Most credetiaals I enclounter are issued by universities although a few are issued by professional and technical associations.  Such displays tell about some life choices of the bearers have made such as where they went to school, the level of schooling they attained, and maybe some specialized courses they have taken.  . Presumably they are placed in a conspicuous location to support the notion that the bearer, and the person providing yhou service, is competent to provide the service you are waiting for.




As the user of services provided by an establishment, I put this information in the category of interesting but not very useful. That is not to downplay the sweat equity students put into the  acquisition of diplomas and degrees but seldom do the items on display tell me about the competence of the person about to serve me.




To qualify for a degree, diploma or certificate, from an educational institution, a person follows a pre-set program of studies  determined by the institution, or an instructor in the institution who may, or may not, have worked outside the institution, or of if he has, he did so many years earlier.  In addition, the criteria may or may not reflect the criteria in the field or occupation in which the learner is preparing.




orassessment is conducted by the institution, students are sorted by the institution, credentials are awarded based on which has a very limited opportunity for individual choice with the result that most students aiming for a diploma or degree having little opportunity to explore ideas of particular interest. Whild these credentials do not guiarantee anything, they do indicate that the holder followed a course of instruction much like that followed by a similar holder from a ...

title: Sorting-credentialing
summary: An expanded version of the credentialing distinction, providing detailed definitions of credentials as documents issued by officially designated bodies following assessment, indicating capability to perform specified actions. Certification is reframed as a sorting process separate from education, carried out by independent bodies, attesting to ability to perform services, potentially subject to renewal. Don emphasizes certification is not itself part of any learning model. This refined articulation demonstrates his conviction that fundamental system reform requires clarity about institutional roles and separation of educational delivery from credentialing and certification functions.
content_preview:
SORTING-CREDENTIALING




Credential - 

Credential 

  
Document
  
Usually issued by an educational institution
  
Attesting to participation


  
Of a person in a program of studies
  
A piece of paper
  
Provided by an institution or body officially designated for the purpose
  
Following an assessment
  
Indicating that the holder is capable of performing a specified range of actions
  



Certification:

  
A sorting process 
  
Not an educational function
  
Different from teaching
  
Carried out by an independent body
  
Based on assessment
  
Attest to the ability of a person to perform a service
  
May be valid for a stated period of time/may require renewable
  
Awarded by an independent body
  
Not in itself a le is a statement of what a person can do and how well.
  
Certification is not part of any learning model

title: Souris proposal- Wilmot note
summary: Letter from Don Glendenning to the Wilmots proposing alternative healthcare workforce initiatives for Souris Hospital. Outlines five options with pragmatic assessments: (1) active recruitment by hospital to high school students; (2) Nurse Practitioner upgrading (unlikely provincial funding); (3) relocation allowance triggered by vacancies; (4) scholarships for third/fourth-year nursing students with employment commitments (chosen path); (5) LPN-to-RN upgrading (requires government/union approval). Don's letter demonstrates strategic thinking and realistic assessment of implementation feasibility. Offers to discuss further with Terry Campbell (Souris Hospital) or himself.
content_preview:
Wilmot




Greetings from Prince Edward Island!




A beautiful crisp clear morning with temperature hovering at freezing as of noon.




Further to our discussions with the folks in Souris, I am delighted to convey a brief proposal showing some alternative initiatives in support of health care in the Souris Hospital.   While all are possible, we feel, some have a greater likelihood of coming to fruition in a reasonable time frame.  Some comments:




The Souris Hospital intends to take a more active role in recruitment generally and promotion to students still in high school.  

The Souris area certainly could benefit from an additional Nurse Practitioner and the cost of upgrading may well be manageable.  Once trained, however, the Province would have to create a new position and provide on-going funding.  In our view, it is highly unlikely that the Province would provide this measure of financial support.

A relocation allowance is a definite option but action can only be taken when a vacancy occurs.  When a vacancy occurs, the Hospital must first advertise on PEI,  if not successful recruitment can occur elsewhere in Canada.  To have the money available when a vacancy occurs would be ideal, but its actual expenditure must be triggered by an actual vacancy.

Scholarships for students in their third and/or fourth years could easily be added to students now in training on condition that they accept employment in Souris at the completion of their training.  This, in effect, would be a top-up to an existing scholarship arrangement and presents no hiring complications.

Upgrading of an LPN to an RN is possible, and I would say desirable, however, approval would be required from both the government and the appropriate union.




The attached proposal is for your consideration.  Either Terry (: 902-687-7150) or I (902-892-5859) would be delighted to provide further information or discuss the idea further.




Warmest regards




Don

title: Speed of change
summary: Personal essay on technological disruption and social change, attributed to Udo Gollub. Discusses exponential growth in technology (digital cameras, AI, autonomous vehicles, 3D printing) and their impact on industries and employment. Critiques overoptimistic predictions while addressing real changes in education, health, energy, agriculture, and work.
content_preview:
Subject: Speed of change

> Thanks to Gary - I can share a remarkable set of predictions. Having come 

> from a farming/fishing countryside with no electricity and minimal 

> machinery, these predictions are truly remarkable. However having spent my 

> working life in computing, I would challenge some of them as I know there 

> is no magic.

>

> No one has developed a machine that has intelligence even though they are 

> said to have artificial intelligence. This contradiction comes about 

> because much of what people do requires no intelligence even though we may 

> use some in doing them.

>

> Let’s look at what is probably most important to most of us – our quality 

> and length of life. Almost all records of better survival, health and 

> longevity are lies and misrepresentations. We are told that in the last 

> 150 years our life expectancy has doubled from 40 years to 80 years. That 

> is a gross misrepresentation. Almost all of this apparent gain is due to 

> the almost elimination of infant mortality. What was the motivation for 

> this? To have more sick people for doctors to work on? No body or a 

> healthy body is of any value to the medical system. A surviving sick body 

> is worth a fortune. What progress has really been achieved in medicine 

> over the past 150 years? Very little! In 1850, some people survived to 80 

> years without any medical help and if they did, on average they could 

> expect to survive another 6 years. Today, with hospitals everywhere, with 

> marvelous drugs and machinery, doctors everywhere, new drugs every day, 

> ambulances, 911 access, etc. an 80-year-old can expect to live another 9 

> years on average, mostly in drugged stupor and misery. That is a gain of 1 

> year in 50 years of questionable value at great expense. We really have 

> fewer years worth living now and the outlook is for still fewer because of 

> the deteriorating quality of our food supply and over-medication with 

> substances t...

title: Standards2000@2015-04-02T23;21;51
summary: Framework document authored by Don Glendenning for setting occupational standards. Intended for standard-setters and training program designers, providing practical guidance on occupational standard development.
content_preview:
2
	

	

	


	
	



	






















	

December 27, 1999





























































































A Framework For Setting
Occupational Standards




































































Donald Glendenning


Glendenning Educational
Resources


62 Queen Elizabeth Drive


Charlottetown, PE C1A 3A9















	


	
	

	


	
	

	FOREWARD
	

	


	
	

	This paper is intended for
	people who set occupational standards and for those who design
	training programs to meet them.  It should also be of interest to
	the harried administrator with a responsibility for standards
	although not an intimate knowledge of the subject.  It is a
	practical, non-academic presentation.
	

	


	
	

	This paper reflects a
	substantial but not an exhaustive literature review; 50 years of
	experience in education both as a teacher and an administrator,
	extensive experience working with industrial advisory committees, an
	examination of current standard-setting practices, experience gained
	in offering workshops on the subject and considerable reflection.  A
	brief description of the Canadian Scene, a handout at one of my
	workshops,  is included as Appendix 1
	

	


	
	

	The ideas are being presented
	at this time because of the belief that attention to standards is
	overdue.  The current model is not adequate; some re-thinking is
	necessary and timely.  Too often training standards and occupational
	standards are confused.  Standards involve a sorting process and
	deserve their own attention.  More of the same is not the answer; a
	different model is required.  The new millennium is a good place to
	start.
	

	


	
	

	I am grateful to many people
	for helping to shape and clarify my thoughts on this issue; a few
	had an opportunity to read an earlier version.  Their gracious
	response to my badgering for their time and comments is much
	appreciated.  The list is long and spans many years.  My thanks to
...

title: Staples-Senate
summary: Don Glendenning's letter supporting Garth Staples' nomination to the Canadian Senate. Highlights Staples' accomplishments including founding the Culinary Institute of Canada and organizing US citizen celebrations in PEI, emphasizing community leadership and ability to mobilize support.
content_preview:
Re: Garth Staples




This letter comes to support the nomination of Garth Staples, 62 Ambrose Street, Charlottetown, PE C1A 3P7  to the Senate of Canada, a man who I have known personally for nearly 40 years.  




Garth is a person of many accomplishments including private business, municipal and provincial government, running for public office, and community and service organizations.  He remains active in many local organizations and networks.  For purposes of this letter, I comment on only a couple of his accomplishments.




Garth played a leading role in the establishment of The Culinary Institute of Canada, an institution based in PEI that has become successful on the world stage.  Some 30 years ago, Garth as Deputy Minister of Tourism in PEI, initiated discussions about the need to improve food service for the tourism industry.  As the initiative developed, Garth marshaled support in the industry, community and within all levels of government.  The Culinary Institute of Canada has had a significant impact on the quality of food service in PEI, increased the level of competence of the food service workforce well beyond our borders, bought international recognition to Canada through the gold medals in many competitions, and opened new opportunities to hundreds of young people from PEI, Canada and elsewhere.




About four years ago, Garth assumed a leadership role in an initiative to thank and recognize the contributions of many citizens of the USA to the life of Prince Edward Island – especially those who return each year to their summer homes.  As a result, for each of the last three years, upwards of 200 US citizens have gathered in Charlottetown on July 4 to celebrate Independence Day with friends.  For each of the last two years, the US consul General from Halifax was in attendance.  The impact of that event can be seen in the flow of support for cultural and charitable activities in Prince Edward Island.




Garth knows how to harness the efforts of oth...

This concise synthesis establishes philosophical foundation for his education system advocacy.

title: summerside press release
summary: Draft press release dated December 5, 2006 covering the November 27 Summerside meeting. Highlights the co-chairmanship of Tom Hall and Don Glendenning in bringing together Prince County equipment collectors. Notes mention participants have restored equipment pieces and the group will create an inventory of PEI equipment. Additional meetings planned for Kings and Queens counties. Willy Dunbar (Elmsdale) coordinates information gathering, with follow-up meetings anticipated for January 2007.
content_preview:
Draft Press Release

Tuesday, December 5, 2006







Farm Machinery Collectors Meet




A meeting was held in the St. Eleanor’s’ Community Centre for residents of Prince County interested in old farm equipment - especially equipment manufactured in PEI.




Many of those present already have pieces of farm equipment that have been restored while others have equipment on which they are still working.  The gathering was co-chaired by Tom Hall and Don Glendenning, both of whom have an interest in the subject and want to see more done to identify and save this part of the Island’s heritage.  Meetings are also planned for Kings and Queens Counties.




Those present decided to start by making a list of pieces of old equipment in their possession and will also ask others in Prince County to do the same.  Willy Dunbar of Elmsdale agreed to coordinate the gathering of information.  The group plans to meet again early in the new year.




30 –




Information:  Willy Dunbar	(853-2055)

title: Summersiide meeting notes
summary: Early planning minutes from November 15, 2006 Agricultural Heritage Project meeting with Dr. Tom Hall, Willie Dunbar, and Weldon Rennie. Participants discussed preserving antique PEI farm equipment, especially pieces manufactured pre-WWII. Plans were made to convene interested residents in Prince County and eventually Kings and Queens counties. The initiative aimed to identify, catalog, and preserve this aspect of Island heritage through community-sourced equipment inventories and potential museum exhibitions.

	Agreed to convene a meeting soon in Summerside for interested people in Prince County.  Agenda to include brief presentations by representatives of Museums in Prince County, general discussion, future activities if any, and a list of equipment,  especially equipment manufactured on PEI prior to WW2.  Meetings in in other counties will be arranged later.

title: System 4 -B
summary: Refined version synthesizing key factors for education system creation: purpose, clarity, mission/vision, structure, service-based delivery, diagnosis, accountability, and assessment methods. Notably includes discussion of grading as a school function versus an educational function—a conceptual distinction central to Glendenning's critique. The document emphasizes the necessity of clear institutional design where organizational form follows functional requirements. Critical observation: despite widespread acknowledgment of delegation benefits, PEI teachers and principals lack meaningful operational freedom.
content_preview:
About
education

Structuring
Education-4-B

4-11

Our
future as individuals and as a community will be determined, in large
measure, by the nature and level of education demonstrated by our
citizens. Education is an umbrella concept and includes all
experiences that have had an impact on the way a person thinks, feels
and acts wherever those experiences occur and however they are
triggered. The key to a person’s education, the literature tells
us, are early experiences triggered in and through the home and
family followed by the influence of teachers. A good education is
described as one that prepares a person to handle events occurring in
their daily lives; task of educators is to help make that happen.






Frick
(Indiana University) tells us that an education system requires (a) a
student (b) a teacher, (c) content, (d) context, and (e) the
community/culture. The writer, on the other hand, considers an
education system to be best described by the services offered; the
Business Roundtable identifies the following education services:
Information, counselling, Instruction, quality assurance. products
and technology, funding and human resources.

Key
factors in creating an education system include:

	

Purpose
	-is about direction, what one hopes to achieve. It provides the
	fundamental reason for establishing an organization and is the key
	element from which everything else follows.  PEI literature
	describes our system as one of “developing and delivering”,
	“providing for the development of children” and” helping
	students secure a place.” None are sufficient, I suggest, on which
	to build an education system.
	

Clarity
	- The
	World Bank, the world’s largest funder of public education, has
	cautioned its members about confusing education with going to
	school; PEI also needs to be careful.
	 
	
	

Mission/Vision
	

Structure-Form

title: System 9 spedial summary
summary: Dated draft 24/06/22. Largely mirrors System 6 content with 30 foundational beliefs and detailed analysis of PEI's education structure. Key addition: examination of the "PEI Community" (160,000 people with wide interests, capabilities, and varied learning motivations). Document emphasizes that "schools are organizational arrangement[s]" for delivering services and reducing costs through specialization. Critiques observation that education philosophy merely references helping students find "a place" without clarity about meaning. Proposes several concrete actions including common definitions list, independent learner category, PEI Education Association, Education Council advisory body, role-reflective titles, and performance review mechanisms.

Education
in Canada is a provincial responsibility; the role of a Province is
to promote, support and regulate services; in the case of PEI, the

separately identified they appear to be mainly delivered through

title: Teacher-led Schools
summary: Don's analysis of emerging teacher-led school movement, featuring case study of Palmer Park Preparatory Academy (Detroit, K-8, principal-less, union-member teachers). Identifies significance: teachers as professionals willing to be accountable; union concerned with education quality not just working conditions; school boards confident in experimental models. Other examples: Boston Teachers Union School (K-8, 2005), Minnesota EdVisions charter network (1990s), Math and Science Leadership Academy Denver (union-designed, team coverage, peer evaluation, individual attention), Milwaukee teacher cooperatives running dozen schools. Notes two management models: MSLA model with one/two managing teachers as partners; Law Firm model with manager reporting to partners' committee. Cites Education Evolving finding that teacher-led schools show higher morale, less turnover, greater improvement motivation—analogous to business ownership versus employment. Sources education journalist Stacy Teicher Khadaroo (Christian Science Monitor), Walt Gardner (Education Week), and online resources. Demonstrates Don's continuing engagement with innovative governance and delivery models even in retirement years.

title: Teacher Pay
summary: (172 words):** Don advocates substantial teacher salary increases while critiquing current pay-grid systems based on training duration and tenure. Statistics Canada data show teacher salaries lag comparable professions. Don argues the grid system reflects what teachers know, not what they do, perpetuating low compensation. He proposes performance-based systems incorporating student numbers served, specialty complexity, responsibility, innovation, and market factors. Teachers should earn merit rewards for strong performance while facing market consequences for weak performance. However, Don notes teachers' limited autonomy—scripted curricula, prescribed timing, limited creativity—undermines professional status necessary for higher pay. He advocates professional control over working conditions as prerequisite for compensation growth. Denver's student-performance-based increment system and student-choice market pressure offer models. Don's perspective reveals frustration with education's industrial organization preventing teacher professionalization and corresponding compensation growth.
content_preview:
12-Teacher Pay




If education is as important as we say it is, teachers deserve higher pay, at least, good teachers do. Teachers’ pay should be comparable to that of lawyers, doctors and accountants - perhaps even higher. While job satisfaction, benefits and security are important, salary is a significant factor in attracting and holding top-notch professionals; a pendulum swing towards higher salaries is long over due.




I’ve looked at Statistics Canada data for both PEI and Canada, and find salaries of other professionals to be generally higher than that of teachers.  The exception may be school administrators whose salaries top those of teachers.  The higher salaries for administrators reflects industrial organizational model for schools as compared to the collegial model more prevalent in other professions.




Obviously, when comparing income, one must remember that salaries are impacted by the length of the training period, working conditions, risk, hours worked or people served.  One must also remember that many other professional groups provide their own working space and relevant support services.  Even taking all these factors into account, however, I believe that teachers’ pay and benefits should be much higher.




Teacher’s salaries are based on a grid that takes into account years of study and years of teaching experience; it is not a practice that I support.  The grid reflects what teachers know; if teachers are to earn what they deserve, their pay must be based on what they do. 




Remuneration should reflect the work done not the qualifications of the incumbent.  While there are a number of approaches to determining job size, any system should take into account the nature and level of preparation required, accountability, complexity of task, and impact of errors.  The teachers’ pay grid focuses on the preparation required for the job.  Freedom and accountability are not considered; maybe that is because teacher’s jobs have little of either. ear...

title: The Rating Scale
summary: Don Glendenning's professional writing on competency-based rating scales for vocational education. Explains the DACUM model and Holland College's adoption of a 0-4 rating system, with 4 subdivided into 4A, 4B, 4C levels. Demonstrates his innovative thinking in educational assessment and his leadership in establishing industry-standard benchmarks for performance evaluation across Atlantic Canada.
content_preview:
The Rating Scale












We
gave considerable thought to a rating scale and, again, examined
traditional marking schemes as well as innovative ones found in our
search.  We settled on the one developed by Adams as part of the
DACUM model as described earlier.  It is only in hindsight that I
realize the significance of that decision.  








The DACUM reflects the way we describe a person’s performance;
the DACUM rating scale weaves together a set of performance
statements based on such criteria as quality of work, quantity of
work, initiative, adaptability, amount of supervision and assistance.
 The scale was linear.   At the bottom was a “0” rating for a
person who did not have sufficient skill to function in the
workplace; the top rating was a “6” for a person who was able to
lead others in practising the skill.  It certainly is the most
realistic performance rating scale that I’ve encountered








As we began to use the scale, however, we concluded that a
completely linear scale did not reflect our understanding of
performance in the workplace; initial ratings are linear but higher
level ratings are not.  The college adopted levels “0” to “4”
as defined by Adams but  replaced levels “4 to 6” with a “4A,
4B  and 4C.  Under this format, a learner could obtain any or all of
the 4 levels.  Later, in an attempt to establish common performance
based rating system for Atlantic Canada, the “0” was dropped as
well.  I am not sure, in hindsight, that we should have done this.








The first three levels are linear, that is the person progresses
from level 1 through 2 to 3.  Performance at the 4 level is not
linear, that is a person may obtain a level 4a, 4b or 4c or any
combination thereof.








































































With any rating scale, a benchmark is necessary and the benchmark
should reflect the field in which the rating is practiced.  For a
plumber, for example, a rating of three would represent a plumber who
c...

title: TIME TO RESTRUCTURE
summary: Urgent call for structural reform. Lists references critiquing current state: unclear departmental literature, coordination focus rather than education focus, stakeholder discussions unlinked to citizen needs, unresponded media criticism, and insufficient research. Invokes three key references: World Bank (education vs. schooling distinction), OECD (school autonomy improves outcomes), Montreal Economic Council (autonomy-accountability combination increases quality). Identifies specific structural barriers: unclear purpose, inadequate service structure, unclear/uncalled accountabilities, school-focused organization, fear factors, insufficient in-service training, failure to identify services, and lack of comprehensive education system design.

title: Trends
summary: Essay on conceptual clarity as precondition for educational effectiveness. Glendenning argues that lack of clarity may arise from the idea itself, the person promoting it, or the recipient's understanding. He emphasizes that conceptual clarity is prerequisite for analysis and that term restriction may be necessary to prevent dilution and meaninglessness. Lack of clarity signals potential conflicting ideas or internal disagreement. Lists 12 specific comments/actions: prepare taxonomy, establish clear purpose, organize by functions, review accountabilities, check communication, monitor engagement, strike advisory bodies, establish individual profiles, distinguish education from schooling, keep community informed.
