title: UNICEF excerpt from report
summary: UNICEF working paper defining quality education across five dimensions: healthy, well-prepared learners; safe/supportive environments with adequate resources; relevant curricula addressing literacy, numeracy, and life skills; child-centered teaching with skilled assessment; outcomes linked to national goals and positive societal participation. Represents international consensus on educational quality standards, reflecting Glendenning's commitment to comprehensive, learner-centered education.
content_preview:
Defining Quality in Education

From A paper presented by UNICEF at the meeting of

The International Working Group on Education Florence, Italy

June 2000

Working Paper




Quality education includes:

  
Learners who are healthy, well-nourished and ready to participate and learn, and supported in learning by their families and communities;
  
Environments that are healthy, safe, protective and gender-sensitive, and provide


adequate resources and facilities; 

  
Content that is reflected in relevant curricula and materials for the acquisition of basic skills, especially in the areas of literacy, numeracy and skills for life, and knowledge in such areas as gender, health, nutrition, HIV/AIDS prevention and peace.
  
Processes through which trained teachers use child-centred teaching approaches in well-managed classrooms and schools and skilful assessment to facilitate learning and reduce disparities
  
Outcomes that encompass knowledge, skills and attitudes, and are linked to national goals for education and positive participation in society

title: US Day Anne Chocolates
summary: This letter to Natasha McCarthy at Anne of Green Gables Chocolates seeks $250 sponsorship of the same US Day Reception (July 4th). The letter uses identical language as File 13 regarding the event's purpose, format, and typical attendance. By targeting local businesses with connections to international visitors (Anne of Green Gables is a tourism-centered company), Don demonstrated strategic sponsor cultivation matching business interests with community investment opportunities.
content_preview:
2011 24 05




Natasha McCarthy

General Manager

Anne of Green Gables Chocolates

397 Capital Drive

Charlottetown, PE C1E 2E2




Dear ,




The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (CFPEI) is a volunteer driven, registered, non-profit, charitable organization.  Our mission is to improve the quality of life on PEI through the creation and building of endowment trust funds that will enhance life for all residents.  




The Foundation provides an established means for individuals, families, community groups, corporations, and private foundations to support philanthropic activities which invest in sustainable solutions to community needs.  We connect caring people and worthy causes through endowment building. 




For the past five years, CFPEI has organized a reception on July 4th for “Summer Islanders” who are US citizens.  The purpose is to give US citizens a venue to meet and celebrate their national day, to thank them for their contributions to our community and to keep them informed about the work of the Community Foundation.




The gathering is informal, with a cash bar, light food, a speaker, our national anthems, US flags and background music.  On three occasions, the US consul General from Halifax has joined us for the occasion.  Attendees are mostly US citizens with summer homes or who live here year round and contribute in so many ways to our Island life and Island economy.  Numbers usually range from 75 to 125 people.   




By means of this letter I am inviting Island Abby Foods  Limited  to become a sponsor at the $250 level.




The enclosed information will provide background on both the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island and the annual US citizen’s Day reception.  I’ll phone you next week to see if you have any questions about the Foundation or the Reception.




We thank you for your consideration.




Sincerely,







Don Glendenning, C.M.

Director




Enclosures

title: Vocational HS
summary: (179 words):** Don addresses vocational secondary education's decline, identifying both obvious factors (facility costs, image, program obsolescence) and deeper issues: academic-general education conflation inflating academic credit requirements. However, he notes research reveals no course-configuration superiority for further education or employment. While acknowledging high-technology economy needs educated workers, Don questions whether additional academic courses provide claimed breadth. He cites Senate report supporting core competencies: reading, writing, math, computer science, societal knowledge, learning-to-learn, teamwork, adaptability, information synthesis. Critically, Don argues these skills aren't content-driven but approach-dependent. Vocational welding courses often better develop core competencies than traditional history classrooms: real projects, responsibility assumption, authentic work habits, freedom of movement—practices schools often discourage. Don proposes secondary programs group subjects under clusters (science, social studies, communications, business, technology), allowing individual courses to serve general or vocational purposes depending on instructor approach and learner intent. He advocates eliminating academic-vocational distinctions, allowing student choice to guide educational decisions.
content_preview:
42 Secondary Education:







Is there a place for Vocational Courses?




vocational education in secondary schools is at a crossroads.

Some of the reasons are obvious: cost of facilities, lower student teacher ratio, image, programs becoming out of date, failure to develop programs in emerging occupations, delay by students in making career choices, and the list goes on.




But there is a more major reason for the decline and that is the view that general education and academic education are one and the same. The result of this view, widely held by those who make speeches and make or influence decisions, is an increase in the number of academic credits required for High School graduation. Understandable and commendable, but is it based on fact? Our reading railed to reveal one pattern of courses at the secondary school level to be better than another as preparation for further education or for life (Perhaps our readers can enlighten us).




The argument goes something like this. We are moving into an era of high technology, information as a resource, rapid change, and the global economy. A better educated work force is a key component. Better educated means more years of schooling - a minimum of high school graduation and preferable some postsecondary education.




Education must also be more transferable so that one can adjust to changing times. Vocational courses are too narrow and limiting. Additional academic courses are the answer so that the worker will have a broader base and have more options open to him/her.




In support of the need for more transferable or generic education, one reads on page 3 of the recent Senate report entitled, In Training, Only Work Works:




"To transform information into knowledge in our information society, our people need basic, core skills: the ability to read, write and understand complex material; to comunicate in one's mother tongue; to know a certain level of mathematics and computer science; to know how society and...

346 Bedford Road

It is my pleasure to welcome you to the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island for a work placement.  We are delighted to have you as a volunteer and know that you will make a contribution to our work.

Sincerely




Don Glendenning

title: W-1 Life Road 4 commentary

Framework discusses learner differences, types of educational support (instruction, feedback, mentoring, etc.), and documentation needs. Notably references his son Brian and daughter Janet as learners with different interests, capacities, and needs—personal application of educational philosophy to family.

Notes about Webinar




  
General


  
This is the framework for those who plan  education programs

content_preview:
Translated by Rachelle




Thank you for setting the stage for the collective engagement of key stakeholders as we move forward with this societal agenda of contributing to a better future for Island youth.

 

As we read the following 41-point summary of our very rich roundtable discussion, it appears as if these three important messages should be taken into consideration:

1) The French education system is parallel to the English education system; however, there are significant differences.  

2) As with the saying 'necessity is the mother of invention', the Island's Acadian and francophone community has been very innovative and creative over the years in addressing demographic and other challenges identified in the Vital Signs study (i.e. the school community centre model, the PERCÉ program, etc.) : the community is willing to share these success stories. 

3) Workshop participants were very engaged in the discussion and look forward to the next steps.

  

Merci d'avoir pris le temps de contribuer à cette importante réflexion au sujet de ce que nous pouvons faire pour mieux soutenir nos jeunes qui se préparent à prendre leur place dans nos communautés. 

 

Voici les grandes lignes de ce que j'ai retenu de notre échange d'hier soir : 

 

A) Prendre le pouls des jeunes de l'Île (Katherine MacDonald et Steve MacQuaid)

La Fondation communautaire de l'Î.-P.-É. a effectué un projet de recherche qui lui a permis de dresser un portrait de la situation des jeunes de l'Île-du-Prince-Édouard. Dans le cadre de cette recherche, la Fondation a examiné dans quelle mesure les jeunes de l'Île se sentent bien préparés à s'engager et à s'intégrer dans les réalités du monde moderne (travail, qualité de l'emploi ainsi qu'engagement social, communautaire et civique).

 

Les trouvailles principales de cette étude incluent:

1) le nombre de jeunes dans la province est en décroissance

2) les taux en matière de littératie et de numératie sont peu élevés malgré que l'Île a le plus ha...

title: Why
summary: Introductory piece for "About Education" newsletter explaining Don's rationale for writing about education. Articulates his philosophy that education shapes individual lives and community development. Distinguishes education broadly from schooling specifically, drawing on World Bank research cautioning against conflating school attendance with education. Emphasizes that education encompasses life experiences beyond formal schooling and includes development of attitudes, knowledge, and coping abilities. Demonstrates Don's conviction that education systems should be understood comprehensively and that current definitions narrowly focus on curriculum delivery.
content_preview:
About

Education




Why?

Welcome to About Education!




No doubt you are wondering why I’m writing this newsletter; the answer is simple. I  believe education to be important. It was important to me; I believe it is important to other readers and to the community at large. What we are allowed to do and what we are encouraged to  learn as pat of our education, is and will continue to be influenced to a significant degree by the nature and extent of our individual and collective education. 

I’ve spent my life in formal education, first as a student, later  as a teacher and always as an independent learner.  Education has much to offer; it has been good to me and good for me. But I think the view as to what constitutes education has narrowed.  So, what is education anyway? There are a number of ways to respond; here are three:

•            A person’s education consists of experiences that have had a measurable effect on the way a person thinks, feels and acts.

•            A person’s level of education reflects the extent to which they are able to cope with circumstances that confront them in their daily lives 

•            A good education, presumably, is one that prepares one to cope and thrive at a reasonable level in ones various life roles.

•            An education system is a system of services put in place by a community to support the education of its citizens.  




Another reason for writing is the belief that the meaning of education is not well understood. Te World Bank, for example, cautioned  member countries about confusing education with going to  school. (World Bank, Report on Education 2019). The PEI Department of Education seems to have fallen into the same trap when it continues to refer to its role as serving young people through “developing and delivering  programs and curriculum”. Our experiences in school are important but in no wy should we consider successful shool studies as the measure of our education.




4-15-1Newsletter

title: Wilmot apology
summary: An apology letter from Don Glendenning to a donor (recipient name Wilmot, February 2007). Similar to the Upson letter, Don apologizes for failing to enclose a handwritten note with Foundation information following a visit. The letter shows Don's high personal standards for donor relations and his characteristic transparency about administrative lapses. References Norman and planning for a July 4, 2007 reception.
content_preview:
Wilmot




Greetings from Prince Edward Island.  We have had a marvelous fall and winter so far.  Here it is almost the first of February and we are still without snow.  I trust that you and James are well.




I write to offer an apology and an explanation.




Following our visit with you and James at your summer home in Fairfield, I prepared a hand written note to enclose with information about the Foundation.  Just yesterday, I realized that it had been placed in your file instead.  I am deeply embarrassed.




For your information I am enclosing my original note and a package of information about the Foundation.  




I have also made Norman aware of what happened; he sends his regards.  




I am pleased to report that the Committee has already begun planning for the reception on July 4, 2007 – this time at a different venue.  We look forward to seeing you at that time if not before.




Warmest regards to both.




Sincerely










Don Glendenning

title: Worth A Look
summary: An analysis of three major educational models: DACUM (Design A Curriculum, a Canadian competency identification methodology from 1968), CRSP (Canadian Restructured School Plan developed during Don's consulting work), and NZQA (New Zealand's national qualifications framework). Don credits DACUM's strength to its practitioner-based approach and escape from academic semantics in favor of life-based, occupation-specific competencies. He describes CRSP as providing personalized, competency-based, and computer-assisted learning within flexible structures. NZQA's framework demonstrates how to recognize learning through multiple pathways while maintaining consistent standards. Don advocates for adopting these models despite barriers like terminology confusion and educators' preference for current systems, as they represent significant advances in learner-centered, performance-based education.
content_preview:
DACUM







	DACUM has come a long way since the first analysis was undertaken in Ottawa in January of 1968.  For people not familiar with the term, DACUM is an acronym for Design A Curriculum and is a widely accepted approach to identifying competencies being practiced or to be learned – and it is no longer limited to an analysis of traditional occupations. And it is a Canadian idea at that.

 

DACUM is most widely used  as a rigorous, relevant, inexpensive and internally consistent approach  to identifying competencies in a field or occupation.  A major strength is the reliance on practitioners as the major source of information and a presentation of the competencies of a field on a single sheet..  As a result, DACUM escapes the semantics of the academic.  It is life based rather than research based and, therefore, is readily understood by people in the field since it reflects what they do and is stated in a language that the field understands.




The performance-based rating scale proposed by Adams is unique.  It includes all the required elements of a good rating scale ─ competencies, performance criteria, a scale, and benchmarks.  While it does not have rubrics or exemplars, they can easily be prepared.  On the other hand, it has benchmarks (industry-based ones) which are missing in most other assessment systems I’ve seen.  In my reading and discussion, I have not found an assessment system as complete.




A DACUM analysis is a tremendous tool for identifying and planning learning resources.  For each competency, one can identify the kind of human resource expertise required; facilities, equipment and supplies; appropriate learning activities; assessment techniques and strategies; and the best location for learning whether it be a classroom, laboratory, shop or actually in a real work situation.  




The model provides recognition for prior learning, self assessment, instructor confirmatiob of achievements,  a tool for career planning, a basis for learning...

title: Z A-1 -Introduction -
summary: Don's introduction to comprehensive learning framework developed by Education 20/20 Inc., presenting webinar series on learners and learning. Establishes foundational definitions (learner, education, learning) and organizing principle of 'road of life' metaphor with multiple life roles.
content_preview:
1

A LEARNING FRAMEWORK

Introduction




Given that learners and learning are at the heart of education, we start our conversation about what we know and believe about learners and learning. 

Understanding the learning process will help with our own learning, but it will also help us become more effective in supporting the learning of others, including our children.  




To provide a framework for making decisions about learning, Education 20/20 Inc. has developed a series of webinars, short clips on a variety of subjects available at the touch of your fingers.  Each presentation is in outline form and of 3-4 minutes duration. Each may be viewed alone or with others, and we’ve included questions for you to mull over at the end of each unit.




Some time ago, each of us was dumped unceremoniously on life’s road, and we’ve been travelling  that road ever since; the road itself has many twists and turns, hills and hollows, and smooth and  rough patches as well.  While on the road, we fill many roles, that of an individual, family member, citizen, learner, consumer and producer.  Our education helps us in our travels; it helps us understand, prepare for, adjust to, extricate from and manage situations we encounter along the way. 




Our education is the outcome of experiences that change us. What we can do today, as compared to what we were able to do yesterday or twenty years ago, constitutes our education – that is, any and all experiences that have changed us, all the experiences that have had a formative effect on what we think, feel and do.  













Consider the presentations as providing a framework, a framework that will:

  
help our understanding. 
  
improve the consistency of our decisions, and  
  
insure that elements are left out by design not by accident.





There are many ways to build a framework, we’ve adopted one that revolves around the learner and the learning process; this series includes presentations and discussions on:

  
Learners ...

title: Z Bio notes-2
summary: A formal biographical statement ("About the Proposer") suitable for professional submissions or proposals. Covers education credentials (Miramichi Rural High School through Indiana University Ph.D.), teaching experience across elementary-to-postsecondary levels and high school principalship, and federal government training specialist role. Emphasizes Holland College founding presidency achievements: recognized leader in outcomes-based education, performance-based assessment, flexibility and learner/community responsiveness. Details establishment of Atlantic Police Academy, Culinary Institute of Canada, and School of Visual Arts. Notes post-Holland consulting firm work domestizing secondary education competency models and overseas projects in Kenya, Swaziland, India, Pakistan, and ASEAN region. Highlights Community Foundation founding leadership and extensive publications/speaking record. Likely original composition by Don.
content_preview:
ABOUT THE PROPOSER




Donald E. M. Glendenning







Donald Glendenning was born in New Brunswick, graduated from Miramichi Rural High School, Teachers College, New Brunswick Technical Institute, completed a year of study at London University (England), holds a Bachelor’s and Master’s Degree from Bradley University  and a PhD. from Indiana University.




His experience includes teaching at the elementary, secondary and post secondary levels, a high school principalship, a technical training specialist with the Government of Canada, 




Dr Glendenning was the Founding President of Holland College and, under his direction for 18 years, Holland College was a recognized leader in outcomes based education, performance based assessment, flexibility and responsiveness to both learner and community needs.  In addition to the usual college level programs, Dr. Glendenning brought into being the Atlantic Police Academy, Culinary Institute of Canada and a School of visual Arts. 




Upon leaving Holland College, he established his own consulting firm and carried on projects both at home and overseas.  Canadian projects were many and varied the largest being the development of a competency based model for secondary education.  His overseas work included projects in Kenya, Swaziland, India, Pakistan and the ASEAN Region.




Dr. Glendenning was an active player on the national and local scene, has written  and spoken extensively.  Most recently, he played leadership role in the establishment of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island and still serves as a Director.  In the latter case, he led a partnership with the Federal and Provincial Governments and the private sector to implement a stabilization initiative in the arts.

title: Z Learner-B-commentary
summary: Educational commentary by Don on learner diversity covering three key differences: prior conditions (physical, mental, emotional, social wellness), prior learning from experience (recreational activities, cultural background), and imagined future (ambitions, career aspirations, values).
content_preview:
4

COMMENTARY

ABOUT LEARNERS




Learner – a person engaged in learning 




We are all learners, you’re a learner, I’m a learner, your family members are learners, as are parents and grandparents, your neighbours and your colleagues at work. 




So, we are all learners – but no two learners are exactly alike. Learners differ in a number of ways.







First, we differ because of what we call prior conditions




Prior Conditions:

  
Physical
  
Mental
  
Emotional
  
Social wellness





We carry some mixture of these conditions into our new learning situation. They likely impact on our new learning; in fact, or prior conditions may have to be dealt with before new learning can take place.

Prior learning:

  
Reacreational activities
  
Team  or alone
  
Camping
  
Drive a car
  
Play music
  






But we also carry the results of our previous experiences, experiences arising from our yesterday, and previous years – our prior learning.  In one sense it results from the culture or circumstances in which we grew up: siblings or no siblings, country or city, warm or cold climate, a western or eastern country  - and the list goes on.

Imagined future:

  
Ambition
  
Career choice
  
Interests
  
Choices
  
Values





A third difference, but one we seldom think of, is our imagined future, our daydreams, our ambitions, our interests – where we imagine ourselves to be, to be like or to be doing at some future time – whether it be a nurse, a poet, an astronaut or the Prime Minister.

title: Z Resume 2 2016
summary: A 2016 resume-style biographical summary beginning with Don's 1969 move to PEI as Holland College founding president. Reviews previous teaching experience in New Brunswick (elementary/secondary levels), teacher training program leadership for vocational teachers, and federal government training specialist role. Notes Little Branch farming community origins and education trajectory (Little Branch School through Indiana University Ph.D.). Emphasizes 1987 retirement and establishment of consulting firm with domestic and international projects. Highlights Community Foundation founding presidency and contemporary board service, amateur genealogy, and hobbies. Lists honors: Order of Canada, Queen's Jubilee Medal, Atlantic Canada Innovator finalist, UPEI honorary degree, plus executive roles in local/national organizations and publications. Notably mentions 2012 leadership role establishing Education 20/20 Inc., a national educational organization. Notes marriage to Carol and two children with two grandchildren. Original composition by Don.
content_preview:
Some notes about




Donald Glendenning







Don Glendenning moved to Prince Edward Island in 1969 to become the founding President of Holland College.  For a number of years he had taught in the elementary and secondary schools of New Brunswick, been head of a teacher training program for vocational teachers also in New Brunswick, and worked as a training specialist with the Federal Government in Ottawa. 




He was born in Little Branch, a farming community near Chatham on the Miramichi in New Brunswick. He attended the Little Branch School, the Miramichi Rural High School, Teachers' College and the New Brunswick Institute of Technology (now the New Brunswick Community College); he also studied a at the University of London (England) and Bradley University and Indiana University in the USA




In 1987 Dr. Glendenning retired from Holland College and operated a consulting firm undertaking with projects both in Canada and overseas.  He is a founding member and Past President of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, is an amateur genealogist and enjoys gardening, reading and puttering around.  He has edited and published a number of newsletters, is the recipient of a number of awards and honours including the Order of Canada, Queen’s Jubilee Medal, Atlantic Canada Innovator of the Year Award Finalist and holds an honourary degree from the University of Prince Edward Island.  He served on the executive of a number of local and national organizations and has also has a number of publications to his credit




Since 2012 Dr. Glendenning has taken a leadership role in education reform through the establishment of Education 20/20 Inc., a national, independent educational organization committed to ensuring a quality education for every Canadian.  He and his wife, Carol, live in Charlottetown and have two children and two grandchildren.

title: ZDACUM-HC Chronology
summary: Historical chronology documenting Holland College's pioneering implementation of the DACUM (Developing a CUrriculum) methodology from 1970-1976. Key milestones include the first DACUM analysis in March 1970 (Electronics, with Bob Adams as facilitator), first student enrollment under DACUM model in July 1970 (Secretarial Arts), institution-wide adoption by September 1970, 1971 publication in Canadian Vocational Journal and staff presentations at provincial and out-of-province workshops, 1973 visit from Ohio Centre for Research in Vocational Education, 1974 introduction of DACUM to Ohio Centre staff by Lawrence Coffin, 1976 institutional assumption of all trade and occupational education responsibility and conversion to DACUM model, and 1976 development of staff training program. This document provides crucial evidence of Holland College's leadership under Glendenning in educational innovation and the DACUM model's development.
content_preview:
March, 1970	First DACUM analysis (Electronics) prepared at Holland College with Bob Adams as facilitator.  Analyses quickly followed for Secretarial Arts and Commercial Design.  




July 2, 1970	Students in Secretarial Arts became the first to enrol under the DACUM model.  This included the use of the occupational analysis, modular approach to curriculum development, and student assessment and management.




Sept. 2, 1970	All new and returning students enrolled under DACUM model.  




1971		Article appeared in CV Journal about Holland College including its commitment to DACUM model.




1971		Holland College staff acted as resource people and presenters at meetings, workshops and conferences in other provinces. 




1973		Visit by staff from the Ohio Centre for Research in Vocational Education.




1974		DACUM introduced to staff of the Ohio Centre for Research in Vocational Education by Lawrence Coffin from Holland College.




1976		Holland College assumed responsibility for all trade, occupational, apprenticeship and adult education on PEI and began converting trade and occupational programs to DACUM model.




1976		Holland College instituted a DACUM based training program for its instructional staff.
